fields.headline: Goal-happy Gunners in striking trouble
fields.trailText: Arsenal are beginning to restate their case for consideration as the only serious alternatives to Manchester United as Premiership champions. Behind the claim is the growing strength of Arsène Wenger's options at Highbury, although he is still in the market for another striker.
fields.body:
Arsenal are beginning to restate their case for consideration as the only serious alternatives to Manchester United as Premiership champions. Behind the claim is the growing strength of Arsène Wenger's options at Highbury, although he is still in the market for another striker.

In their last two home league matches Arsenal have defeated Leeds United, the Premiership leaders, 2-0 and Sunderland, starting Saturday in fourth place, 4-1. They have done so, moreover, while lacking the services of Dennis Bergkamp, their principal creative influence, and this win was achieved in the absence of not only Bergkamp but Tony Adams, Marc Overmars and Nwankwo Kanu.

Arsenal meet Manchester United at Old Trafford a week today. Wenger doubts whether Bergkamp will be fit but at least he knows that his team will not need Dutch courage for their most important domestic fixture of the season so far.

Before the United game Arsenal face an FA Cup replay against Leicester at Filbert Street. "I believe that if we do well at Leicester we will feel confident for Manchester United," said Wenger. "We do have the quality and potential to do well at Old Trafford."

With Bergkamp injured, Davor Suker suspended and Kanu away on African Nations Cup duty with Nigeria, Arsenal look like having to play only one recognised striker, Thierry Henry, against United. Henry may be partnered up front by Graham Barrett, an 18-year-old Dubliner who before he came off the bench for the last seven minutes against Sunderland had had precisely 60 seconds experience of first-team football.

"Barrett has a good chance of playing if we don't buy anybody in the meantime," said Wenger. "But I can't exclude a new signing at the moment and if there is an opportunity I will take it. To go into such a big game you really need two main strikers."

George Weah was an obvious possibility before he joined Chelsea on loan from Milan last week. But whether or not Wenger buys another forward this week, he will go to Old Trafford knowing his squad is starting to acquire sufficient depth to challenge United on their own terms.

This victory was distinguished by two slickly taken goals from Henry and a wonderful piece of opportunism from Suker, who also scored with a tap-in. Equally significant was the way Arsenal's defence managed, in Adams's absence, to cope with the prolific partnership of Kevin Phillips and Niall Quinn.

Oleg Luzhny, normally a right-back, played on the left side of Martin Keown with no hope of beating Quinn in the air. Yet the Ukrainian still managed to reduce Quinn's effectiveness through persistent hustling which cut off an essential source of opportunities for Phillips.

Overall, the main reason why Sunderland were overrun before half-time and kept at arm's length thereafter lay in the continuing excellence of Patrick Vieira and Emmanuel Petit in midfield. One crossfield pass from Petit to Suker midway through the first half, beautifully timed to reach the Croatian through a closing gap, was football's equivalent of the perfect cover drive.

The speed of Henry might have brought him a goal after just 20 seconds but for Thomas Sorensen's save. As it was, Henry put Arsenal ahead on three minutes when a ball from Fredrik Ljungberg enabled him to turn inside Steve Bould and drive in a shot off Sorensen's knee.

Bould, Quinn and Stefan Schwarz are Highbury old boys; by half-time they must have felt even older. In the 27th minute Suker gathered a square pass from Henry to the left of goal, spotted Sorensen a fraction off his line and proceeded to loop a gloriously impudent shot over the 6ft 4in Dane and into the net via the far post.

"A Suker goal," was how Wenger described it. Certainly the Croatian has a penchant for lobbing Danes, witness his towering shot against Peter Schmeichel in Euro 96.

Henry set up Suker's second after twisting past Paul Butler on the byline and turned Bould once more to add Arsenal's fourth nine minutes from the end, Quinn having toe-poked Sunderland's goal immediately after half-time.

Sunderland, who lost 5-0 at Everton on Boxing Day, have now taken one point from four matches and meet the Premiership leaders Leeds next Sunday with Newcastle United to follow. "You can't give fours and fives away at this level," Peter Reid sighed. This match, for all Reid's sterling efforts as manager, put his team into better perspective.

fields.headline: Washout costs NCU dearly
fields.standfirst: Northern Cricket Board "will cut back development programmes"
fields.trailText: The third day of the final Test was washed out. Not a ball has been bowled since play finished early on Fri day and there have been only 45 overs in all. Rain has fallen almost incessantly, quagmiring the playing area, and although it stopped long enough for the captains Nasser Hussain and Hansie Cronje to go to the ground and squelch around, it was apparent that neither wanted a start. A downpour arrived on cue and spared them a decision.
fields.body:
The third day of the final Test was washed out. Not a ball has been bowled since play finished early on Fri day and there have been only 45 overs in all. Rain has fallen almost incessantly, quagmiring the playing area, and although it stopped long enough for the captains Nasser Hussain and Hansie Cronje to go to the ground and squelch around, it was apparent that neither wanted a start. A downpour arrived on cue and spared them a decision.

The washout has cost the Northern Cricket Union dearly, just as it did four years ago when the inaugural Test at Centurion was abandoned after two days. "We will be losing £80,000 on the bottom line against a projected profit of £160,000," said the NCU president David Harrison yesterday. "It is a catastrophe and it will mean that some of our development programmes will have to be cut back."

fields.headline: Donald dumped from one-dayers
fields.standfirst: Paceman pays price for county commitment as South Africans give youth its head
fields.trailText: Allan Donald's international one-day career has been terminated by the desire of South Africa's selectors to drive through their youth policy leading up to the 2003 World Cup. The fast bowler had hoped to play in the forthcoming triangular series against England and Zimbabwe but he was told yesterday by the convener of selectors Rushdi Magiet: "You are no longer part of our thoughts."
fields.body:
Allan Donald's international one-day career has been terminated by the desire of South Africa's selectors to drive through their youth policy leading up to the 2003 World Cup. The fast bowler had hoped to play in the forthcoming triangular series against England and Zimbabwe but he was told yesterday by the convener of selectors Rushdi Magiet: "You are no longer part of our thoughts."

His omission follows his decision over the weekend to fulfil his contract with Warwickshire rather than make himself available for the home and away series of revenge matches between South Africa and Australia, which are scheduled for April and August. The selectors have decided that anyone not available for the matches against Australia will not be considered for the triangular series.

So after 121 matches and 206 wickets, the last sight of Donald wearing the myrtle-green uniforms of his country will have been of him as a batsman standing in the middle of the Edgbaston wicket, without his bat, as the Australians celebrated the run-out that took them through to the World Cup final last June.

The move by the selectors may yet have a bearing on whether he recants his decision, also announced over the weekend, not to tour India next month. He had intended taking a sabbatical and picking up his Test career against New Zealand and Sri Lanka in the next South African season. But with his tally of Test wickets only 10 away from the landmark 300 he craves, he may now take the view that he cannot afford to leave the door open for young pretenders such as Nantie Hayward and David Terbrugge.

webTitle: Boon lays down the law to young guns

fields.headline: Boon lays down the law to young guns
fields.trailText: England's under-19 coach Tim Boon has told his players to pull their fingers out for tomorrow's World Youth Cup second-phase match against the home side Sri Lanka.
fields.body:
England's under-19 coach Tim Boon has told his players to pull their fingers out for tomorrow's World Youth Cup second-phase match against the home side Sri Lanka.

England only qualified for this Super League stage of the tournament after a fortunate win by three runs over Zimbabwe in Colombo on Saturday.

Having been bowled out by West Indies for 98, England's only other win so far came against the lowly Americas. The reigning one-day world youth champions face a stiff challenge against Sri Lanka who topped their group after thrashing Australia by eight wickets.

But there was some good news for England with the rank outsiders Nepal - rather than South Africa - qualifying for their pool, which also features India. South Africa's matches were all rained off.

"This is no time for a big celebration because we were expected to get this far," said Boon. "I'm just very relieved. I read the players their rights after the game and told them they have to get out of the comfort zone. We've got through by the skin of our teeth and it will be damned hard work from now on. The performance from our top order was simply unacceptable."

An unbeaten 68 by Durham's Gary Pratt helped England to 187 for eight, before Zimbabwe's batsmen failed to score the eight runs needed for victory from the last two overs. The seamers Nick Warren and Tim Murtagh, who bowled at the death, were singled out for praise by Boon.

"It was a phenomenal bit of bowling by Warren," he said. "Both he and Murtagh were exceptional under great pressure - they were both consistently bowling blockhole deliveries."

 An unbeaten 81 from 92 balls by Australia's captain Steve Waugh led his side to a six-wicket win over Pakistan in Melbourne, taking them to the top of the triangular one-day series.

webTitle: Two-goal Ferguson leads humbling of the Saints

fields.headline: Two-goal Ferguson leads humbling of the Saints
fields.trailText: Newcastle 5 - 0 Southampton
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at St James' Park
fields.body:
Ruud Gullit may still own the copyright, but Bobby Robson could be excused for indulging in a touch of plagiarism yesterday. With an arrogance belying their league position his Newcastle side provided compelling evidence of their renaissance by contemptuously dismissing Southampton with an exhilarating display loaded with the sexy football frequently promised but seldom delivered by his predecessor.

Five goals, including a brace from Duncan Ferguson inside the opening four minutes, emphasised their superiority, al though it would not have flattered the hosts unduly to have doubled their goal count after bullying their opponents into submission during an afternoon of complete dominance.

Was this really the same Newcastle side that had shipped four goals at the Dell a few months ago? "I reminded them about that hammering and they responded magnificently," Robson said afterwards.

"I wanted them to take the initiative and we couldn't have done more in the first half. We scored four goals, hit the woodwork four times and missed a penalty, which isn't a bad return."

Newcastle were in for the kill straightaway against a side which hoisted the white flag before most of their players had even muddied their knees. After two minutes Nolberto Solano surged down the right and crossed for Alan Shearer to head against the crossbar. The rebound fell kindly for Ferguson and from six yards the rest was a formality.

Within another 90 seconds Newcastle's accountants were already writing out the cheques for the players' win bonuses. This time a rejuvenated Ferguson displayed his prowess on the ground with the sweetest of right-foot drives to ram a loose ball low and hard beyond Paul Jones.

Only three minutes gone and Southampton, those notoriously bad travellers, were already facing a damage-limitation exercise. But Newcastle had no intention of extending any form of hospitality.

Robson did not need reminding his team had surrendered a two-goal advantage in their previous Premiership game against West Ham. Solano ensured there would be no repeatwith the third goal following a 17th-minute move that epitomised Newcastle's approach play.

Ferguson was the instigator with an exquisite flick that sent Kieron Dyer scampering clear. His one-two with Shearer was simplicity itself and the Peruvian was clinical in his execution.

When Richard Dryden inadvertently diverted Dyer's low delivery beyond his own goalkeeper, thoughts were turning to the 8-0 rout of Sheffield Wednesday in September.

Newcastle even had the luxury of a wasted penalty after Neale Barry spotted a sly tug by Dean Richards on Ferguson that even the recipient did not appear to have noticed. Shearer's spot-kick crashed off the underside of the bar and was scrambled to safety, although TV as revealed it had landed marginally over the line.

With victory a foregone conclusion, Newcastle were entitled to ease off slightly in the second half and Southampton avoided further punishment until seven minutes before the final whistle when Nikos Dabizas's shot took a fortuitous deflection off Gary Monk.

By then the travelling fans had turned on Southampton's manager Dave Jones. Their escapology over two decades has gained near-legendary status, and another wade through quicksand beckons.

webTitle: Ashton stokes the fires at Wednesday

fields.headline: Ashton stokes the fires at Wednesday
fields.standfirst: MP insists his gang of four will 'set the agenda'
fields.trailText: Joe Ashton, the leader of the gang of Labour MPs who have been widely disparaged for demanding the sacking of Sheffield Wednesday's manager Danny Wilson, responded yesterday in the manner of the team. Recognising that nobody believed he had much of a defence, he opted for all-out attack and hoped for the best. All he lacked to make the vision complete was a blue-and-white striped shirt.
fields.body:
Joe Ashton, the leader of the gang of Labour MPs who have been widely disparaged for demanding the sacking of Sheffield Wednesday's manager Danny Wilson, responded yesterday in the manner of the team. Recognising that nobody believed he had much of a defence, he opted for all-out attack and hoped for the best. All he lacked to make the vision complete was a blue-and-white striped shirt.

Far from being embarrassed by revelations that four Sheffield MPs had secretly met a major shareholder - the investment group Charterhouse - to discuss Wednesday's future, Ashton promised further revelations about how a club known for financial stability had run up debts of nearly £18m during a free fall to the foot of the Premiership.

"This is not just about Danny Wilson," he said. "It is about debts of between £16-18m when nobody knows where they have come from. It is about the position of the chairman. It is about whether the two clubs in Sheffield should merge. We are going to set the agenda in our own time and our own way."

The MPs, among them the education and employment minister David Blunkett, whose constituency includes the Hillsborough stadium, have been depicted as publicity-seeking politicians meddling indefensibly in Wednesday's affairs at a critical juncture of the season. Even Kate Hoey, the sports minister, reminded them yesterday that "MPs do not run football clubs" and chided them as "rather silly".

Rubbish, exploded Ashton, MP for Bassetlaw. He was a club vice-president until his resignation last week, he had been a director for nine years, he was a shareholder, a season-ticket holder, a lifetime fan. He had every right to get involved. Many Wednesday supporters grudgingly take the point. At least they know he cares.

"All that Sheffield has talked about for months is football," he said. "If there is a pit closure or a factory goes down the pan the MP has to get involved, so why can't we use our influence to try to save this football club? We know the club intimately. This is the fourth biggest city in the country. It deserves a Premiership team."

The Hillsborough crowd chanted Wilson's name as they revelled in their third Premiership win of the season on Saturday, 2-0 against Bradford City, but there was no evidence that Ashton or his colleagues had become the hate figures portrayed by much of the media. Ashton even claimed supporters had given him a "tremendous welcome".

"We put some gunpowder behind them; the fans were telling me we should have done it months ago," he said. November 5, preferably, since Ashton's plotting has left him sitting atop a media bonfire.

Spectators outside Hillsborough before kick-off revived old jokes about the last time Ashton captured the headlines, when he had to explain to police his presence in a Northampton massage parlour. He was massaging a few figures yesterday. As chairman of the 150-strong football group of MPs, he expanded upon his football credentials by claiming to have had a key influence on every football issue in the past few years.

There was the little matter of blocking BSkyB's takeover of Manchester United; then the preserving of Wembley for football; and, if England win the bidding for the 2006 World Cup, expect him to put the word around that he wouldn't object to the title Lord Ashton of Bassetlaw.

Outside Sheffield such bombast will only swell the ridicule. On the right wing the MPs have been attacked by the Keep Politics Out Of Sport brigade. From the left comes the denunciation that there are more important things to think about: the NHS, books in schools, a clogged-up transport system. There are times when New Labour's fondness for football looks awfully tacky.

Blunkett in particular may wish his constituency were elsewhere. The city of Sheffield does not regard him as a football man and the spectacle of a minister for employment calling for someone's sacking was unfortunate. If he hankers after a sporting role, he might like to consider how much damage his idea of schools staying open for some pupils until 10pm might do to sports clubs nationwide.

Football habitually resents outside interference, but most Wednesday supporters welcome the MPs' attempt to quiz the club's major shareholder about the financial strictures they believe may result in loss of Premiership status. What they resent was that the MPs personalised it by pressing for Wilson's sacking. "Bullying," one supporter said.

"We had a one-hour discussion and spent about 30 seconds talking about Danny Wilson," said Ashton. As watching Wednesday should have made only too clear, 30 seconds is ample time for a cock-up.

Wilson remains popular in Sheffield in spite of the club's decline during his 18 months as manager, largely because he is seen as a nice guy, a Wednesdayite through and through, and the problems are not entirely of his own making. Wednesday have also gone 10 matches unbeaten at Hillsborough, although politicians will be the first to tell you that statistics can prove anything.

Whatever misjudgment Ashton may have made, he has not succumbed to the celebrity-football posturing seen from Tony Banks and David Mellor. Kate Hoey, though, is finding Labour's populist befriending of Premiership football frustratingly counterproductive. Her efforts to improve facilities in schools are largely overlooked and it is the fan-speak of Ashton and his colleagues which has grabbed the headlines.

Football habitually resents outside interference, but most Wednesday supporters welcome the MPs' attempt to quiz the club's major shareholder about the financial strictures they believe may result in loss of Premiership status. What they resent was that the MPs personalised it by pressing for Wilson's sacking. "Bullying," one supporter said. "We had a one-hour discussion and spent about 30 seconds talking about Danny Wilson," said Ashton. As watching Wednesday should have made only too clear, 30 seconds is ample time for a cock-up. Wilson remains popular in Sheffield in spite of the club's decline during his 18 months as manager, largely because he is seen as a nice guy, a Wednesdayite through and through, and the problems are not entirely of his own making. Wednesday have also gone 10 matches unbeaten at Hillsborough, although politicians will be the first to tell you that statistics can prove anything. Whatever misjudgment Ashton may have made, he has not succumbed to the celebrity-football posturing seen from Tony Banks and David Mellor. Kate Hoey, though, is finding Labour's populist befriending of Premiership football frustratingly counterproductive. Her efforts to improve facilities in schools are largely overlooked and it is the fan-speak of Ashton and his colleagues which has grabbed the headlines.

fields.headline: Scottish review
fields.trailText: The Scottish Football Association has defended the decision of the referee Craig McKay to call off Dalbeattie Star's Tennents Cup second-round replay with Albion Rovers only 30 minutes before kick-off.
fields.body:
The Scottish Football Association has defended the decision of the referee Craig McKay to call off Dalbeattie Star's Tennents Cup second-round replay with Albion Rovers only 30 minutes before kick-off.

There were angry scenes at the Islecroft Stadium after the pitch was declared unplayable because of overnight frost. Earlier in the morning the pitch had been passed fit, and several Albion fans had made the 90-mile trip. The game is now scheduled to go ahead at 1pm today.

The SFA's spokesman Andy Mitchell said: "The referee takes all the conditions into account when deciding if the pitch is playable. The problem with games like yesterday's is that at many grounds the weather deteriorated throughout the day and the pitches got harder."

Alloa's match at home to Whitehill Welfare was also postponed because of the weather, but Brechin and Arbroath progressed to the third round with victories over Annan Athletic and Fraserburgh respectively.

 Dunfermline narrowed the gap to St Mirren at the top of the First Division to six points after a 2-2 draw with Falkirk, who remain in fourth place. Falkirk's Ivo den Bieman scored in the final minute to earn his side a share of the points. Raith beat Airdrie 2-0 to move into third.

 At the bottom of the Second Division Queen of the South and Hamilton earned much-needed wins.

fields.headline: Pay-per-goal-replay is a turn-off
fields.trailText: David Lacey Professional footballers' hunger for ever-increasing incomes should not be understimated.
fields.body:
The ingenuity which prompts professional footballers to dream up ways in which they can earn even more money should never be underestimated.

In fact, were they all to display similar imagination on the field Kevin Keegan could look forward to a knighthood once England had won the European Championship and the next World Cup, and the Labour MPs of Sheffield might feel moved to declare that Danny was the greatest Wilson they had known since Harold.

The latest wheeze takes the cake, the icing on which has long been a staple diet of the footballer. It is proposed that players should copyright their outstanding goals and receive royalties each time they are replayed on television.

This idea was put forward at a recent one-day seminar on the commercialisation of football and has been given substance by a lawyer whose firm represents two dozen players. The argument: since the best goals are frequently shown on TV and used to sell satellite coverage of matches, the players who score them should get their cut.

A comparison has been drawn with American sport where those who perform have some control over the marketing of action replays. The legal theory has been advanced that since the scoring of a goal is a highly personal thing the scorer should, under the copyright law, be entitled to a fee each time it is shown again.

The Premier League has rubbished the notion, insisting that the ownership of rights for games rests with the league itself and the clubs. But if there is a test case in the High Court it may not be so easy for those who run the game to dismiss out of hand this latest attempt by those who play it to wring even more money out of the football boom.

The idea, of course, is preposterous. First, football is a team game and behind most goals, however well taken, is a crucial tackle, run, pass, free-kick or corner. Second, the best goals are not necessarily the most important.

All right, Ryan Giggs's bewitching dash through the Arsenal defence in last season's FA Cup semi-finals may be a good example of what the supporters of the pay-per- replay proposal are getting at. It enthralled the nation, set up Manchester United for what proved to be the middle part of their treble and is part of televised football history.

So why should Giggs not be able to charge royalties each time the moment is re-shown? Or Michael Owen for his outstanding solo goal against Argentina in the 1998 World Cup ? Or Davor Suker for the inspired lob that brought Arsenal a second goal against Sunderland on Saturday?

The reason why not is that football is already in danger of reaching a situation where everything has a price and that allowing leading players to receive even more money for doing a job which already brings them huge rewards will simply harden the game's grasping image.

F ootballers of the past were not above grabbing the extra bob or two where they could find it, and had TV technology reached its present stage 50 years ago there would have been no shortage of players eager to exploit the situation. Yet the £10- and £20-a-weekers who enthralled those vast crowds belonged to an age when the glory was enough.

What is being suggested now are nobbins on a grand scale. Why should it stop with goals? Goalkeepers could market their saves, wingers their crosses, defenders their last-ditch tackles. And what about video collections of blunders and fouls? Even spectacular own-goals might command a useful fee.

The game should nip this in the bud before the locusts descend in earnest, give TV accountants headaches every time the football credits roll and reduce BBC's Match of the Day to a Throw of the Month competition.

webTitle: Nursery clubs would be 'saviour of game'

fields.headline: Nursery clubs would be 'saviour of game'
fields.trailText: Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson believes the transformation of some lower league sides into nursery clubs for Premiership teams would be "the saviour the game is looking for".
fields.body:
Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson believes the transformation of some lower league sides into nursery clubs for Premiership teams would be "the saviour the game is looking for".

Hutchinson says top-flight teams should develop close links with smaller domestic clubs rather than looking abroad for similar tie-ups.

He insists that not only would young players' development be improved but that lower clubs could also benefit financially as well as tap into the technical, coaching and medical expertise of rich clubs.

Hutchinson, writing in Chelsea's match programme on Saturday, declared the Football Association's "blueprint for the 21st century... has one major flaw."

He went on: "Academies, Premier League under-17 and under-19 leagues and a Premier League reserves competition are all part of the development process, but the system is crying out for nursery clubs to 'fast-track' bright youngsters. Nothing helps a young professional more than playing in front of crowds."

Hutchinson cited how David Beckham was helped by a loan to Preston and Michael Duberry by a brief spell at Bournemouth. He added: "Playing for a league club is far better experience than reserve games."

Liverpool have rejected a loan move to Rosenborg of Norway for Brad Friedel, their out-of-favour goalkeeper.

fields.headline: Nationwide Third Division
fields.trailText: Merry Millers
fields.body:
Merry Millers

Rotherham moved into a three-way tie at the top but ahead on goal difference after beating the bottom club Chester with goals from Paul Warne and Leo Fortune-West. But the Millers had to be grateful to managerless Exeter, who held Barnet 0-0, and the weather, which prevented Swansea from playing on Carlisle's sodden pitch.

 Jon Cullen's 86th-minute penalty in his last game for Halifax after a productive loan spell from Sheffield United denied 10-man Hartlepool victory at the Shay. The visitors took a first-half lead through Gary Jones but later had Ian Clark sent off for a rash tackle, his second bookable offence.

 Fourth-placed Darlington took the lead at Macclesfield through the Dane Jesper Hjorth but the Silkmen, in their first game under Peter Davenport, quickly hit back with goals from Neil Moore and John Askey to move up to seventh place.

 Northampton, in sixth place, also went down on their travels, a 72nd-minute goal from Jason Lee, his first for the club, giving Peterborough a 1-0 win.

 Rochdale scored three goals in seven first-half minutes at Southend only for the hosts to respond with three of their own. Scott Houghton started the comeback after 55 minutes, Martin Carruthers then converted a penalty and Leo Roget made it 3-3 five minutes from time. Gary Jones and Graham Lancashire, twice, were on target for the Spotland club.

fields.headline: Nationwide Second Division
fields.trailText: Rovers return
fields.body:
Rovers return

Bristol Rovers moved into second place as goals from Jamie Cureton and Jason Roberts secured victory against Gillingham. Iffy Onuora made the final score 2-1 two minutes from time.

 Burnley slipped off the pace with a 1-1 draw against lowly Chesterfield at Saltergate. The visitors took an early lead through Andy Payton but Ryan Williams levelled on 73 minutes.

 Blackpool conceded two goals in the last 10 minutes to spoil Steve McMahon's first match in charge. Phil Gray and Matt Taylor gave Luton a share of the points in a 3-3 draw. Gary Ablett had earlier scored his first goal for three years to give Blackpool the lead.

 Wrexham completed their first win in 17 games, an unenviable club record, when they beat Bury 2-0 at Gigg Lane with Neil Roberts scoring both goals.

 Oldham gained their biggest league success of the season with a 3-0 win against Brentford, who had their goalkeeper Andy Woodman sent off after bringing down Mark Allott. The striker got up to score the final goal, having also scored Oldham's second. Andrew Holt opened the scoring.

 Colchester sealed a much-needed victory, 2-1 away to Notts County, thanks to two goals from Steve McGavin. Kevin Rapley pulled one back after 65 minutes for the home side.

 Reading's slide continued with a 0-0 draw against Cambridge at the Madejski Stadium.

fields.trailText: Pulis deflated
fields.body:
Pulis deflated

Portsmouth's manager Tony Pulis suffered a disappointing start to his career at Fratton Park when his side led Wolves 2-0 only to lose 3-2.

Sammy Igoe and Steve Claridge put the home side ahead before Steve Sedgley began the Wolves revival with a goal in the 73rd minute. Michael Branch equalised 12 minutes later and Ade Akinbiyi sealed the victory with seconds to go.

 Nottingham Forest had Jon Olav Hjelde and Dave Beasant sent off as they were beaten 4-3 by Grimsby at Blundell Park. Jack Lester, Kevin Donovan and Lee Ashcroft, twice, scored for the home side. Two goals from Alan Rogers and a Mark Lever own-goal gave the visitors hope.

 QPR's first home defeat of the season came when Bolton's Claus Jensen scored the only goal at Loftus Road.

webTitle: Molby a Harrier in a hurry as promotion beckons

fields.headline: Molby a Harrier in a hurry as promotion beckons
fields.standfirst: Former Anfield hero plots his way back with the pride of Worcestershire
fields.trailText: Jan Molby has taken Kidderminster to the top of the Nationwide Conference. He talks to Grahame Lloyd.
fields.body:
The timing could hardly have been better. When Jan Molby's former employers Swansea City took the lead in the Third Division, his present club Kidderminster Harriers moved above the favourites Rushden & Diamonds to the top of the Nationwide Conference. Anything you can do...

The former Liverpool and Denmark playmaker took the Swans - currently second - to the verge of promotion in 1997 before being sacked after a disappointing start the following season. It was a journey from Anfield to Vetch Field and then into football punditry.

Nearly three years later, Molby - and Kidderminster - have moved on. The Harriers won the Conference by three points in 1994 but the state of their Aggborough Stadium meant they were refused entry to the Third Division. A team to match one of the best non-league grounds has been astutely assembled by Molby, backed by the club's multimillionaire chairman Lionel Newton. Both want to make history: Worcestershire is one of the few English counties never to have had a Football League club.

"I'm not trying to prove anything to the people who sacked me," said Molby. "I think I can make it as a manager and that's why I'm back. I'm sure if you asked the majority of people at Swansea they'd all agree that I did OK. But what other people think of you is not that important; it's what you think of yourself. I sleep well at night."

Molby's team lost four of their first five Conference games in August but Newton's faith never wavered. The retired furniture businessman said: "Jan came across as very sincere, honest and hard-working, someone who wanted, with a passion, to get back into league football.

"I wasn't worried that he'd been sacked by Swansea, I felt he could do a job for us and I think I've been proved right."

Molby's contacts have brought in two Danish forwards, Rene Petersen and Thomas Skovbjerg, the defenders Andy Brownrigg (Rotherham) and Phil King (Aston Villa, Sheffield Wednesday and Brighton) and the goalkeeper Tim Clarke (Scunthorpe). Molby's former Anfield team-mate Mike Marsh has arrived from Southport and the former Liverpool striker Ian Foster, who scored both goals in Saturday's 2-1 win over Hayes, was recruited after spells with Hereford and Barrow.

Petersen, the only new player to have cost Kidderminster a fee, has settled down well in a Molbyesque role in the heart of midfield. "Everyone has taken good care of me since I've been here. Jan is a hard manager and he shouts at us all; the two Danes don't get any special treatment."

By embracing the passing game, the Harriers are on a nine-match unbeaten run which has taken them three points clear of big-spending Rushden.

"I'm surprised we have reached the top so quickly," said Molby, who travels to training twice a week from his Merseyside home. "After our poor start we were 15 points behind the leaders at one stage. The squad have shown a great attitude but the real work starts now."

Molby has committed himself until May 2001. Though Newton maintains he will be content with a top-eight position this year and a serious title challenge next season, the manager appears to be a Harrier in a hurry.

"Off the pitch everything is ready... we've now got to ensure that we are ready on the pitch," said Molby.

webTitle: Turmoil as fans round on Robson

fields.headline: Turmoil as fans round on Robson
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 1 - 4 Derby
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
For someone whose psychological make-up has seldom revealed the slightest hint of vulnerability, Bryan Robson is rapidly discovering that his armour is not impregnable after all. It has been a cruel learning process, but further trauma could be round the corner as the Middlesbrough manager confronts the most examining test of his credentials to date.

Robson made little attempt to conceal his turmoil as he conducted his inquest into a capitulation which ended with supporters demanding his removal from office.

Never has the criticism been so vitriolic and patience is a commodity in notoriously short supply at a club still craving its first major trophy.

"Robson Out" reverberated around the Riverside but it is surely improbable that the dissenters will get their way. The bond between Robson and his chairman Steve Gibson is close and the man who has financed Middlesbrough's image overhaul did not make his millions by succumbing to the demands of others.

That said, it is not beyond the realms of possibility that Robson's pride will intervene should the downward spiral that has incorporated cup defeats against Wrexham and Tranmere Rovers continue.

"If you are underachieving you have to expect criticism in this job. It hurts but the way I see it is: where were Middlesbrough when I arrived here? We are still going forward and there is time to put it right," Robson said.

"We finished ninth last season and the aim is to improve on that. If we don't, the supporters can judge me then."

That the humiliation was inspired by an unknown 20-year-old merely deepened Robson's blushes.

Malcolm Christie was plucked from Nuneaton Borough for £75,000, but two goals in an impressive debut suggests he possesses qualities lacking in several of his Derby predecessors. Not least, in the case of Esteban Fuertes, a valid passport.

From the moment Christie headed Jim Smith's team into an eighth-minute lead, the home fans' anger and resentment rained down on Robson from every corner of the stadium before half-time's breathing space arrived.

Within two minutes of the restart, though, Deon Burton scored to crank up the decibel levels. The crescendo arrived on the hour when Schwarzer blasted an attempted clearance straight at Christie, presenting the debutant with his second goal and prompting a stampede for the exit gates.

Those who abandoned ship missed Hamilton Ricard squandering a penalty and a fine strike from the substitute Andy Campbell, but this was rendered meaningless when Craig Burley provided Derby's fourth in stoppage time.

"I can understand the fans' frustration," said Boro's captain Paul Ince. "Sometimes there can be a fear factor in times like this and people tend to hide. The team performance was diabolical as well and the fans are entitled to voice their opinions. But I feel for Robbo. He is one of the reasons I came here and it hurts me, probably more than anyone, when I hear the supporters saying he should go."

Christie is from Cambridgeshire and so inevitably he is a Manchester United supporter. He even admitted to having a poster of Captain Marvel on his bedroom wall. But that was the old, invincible Robson.

Those who abandoned ship missed Hamilton Ricard squandering a penalty and a fine strike from the substitute Andy Campbell, but this was rendered meaningless when Craig Burley provided Derby's fourth in stoppage time. "I can understand the fans' frustration," said Boro's captain Paul Ince. "Sometimes there can be a fear factor in times like this and people tend to hide. The team performance was diabolical as well and the fans are entitled to voice their opinions. But I feel for Robbo. He is one of the reasons I came here and it hurts me, probably more than anyone, when I hear the supporters saying he should go." Christie is from Cambridgeshire and so inevitably he is a Manchester United supporter. He even admitted to having a poster of Captain Marvel on his bedroom wall. But that was the old, invincible Robson.

webTitle: Pushy Paolo adds oomph to soap opera

fields.headline: Pushy Paolo adds oomph to soap opera
fields.trailText: West Ham 1 - 1 Aston Villa
fields.body:
If there is one group of people who find the frequency with which misfortune visits television soap operas perfectly true to life, it is West Ham fans.

Each week the club seems to be in a scrape juicy enough to rival the script of EastEnders. Saturday's latest episode featured their resident rogue Paolo di Canio appearing to push David James in the face when the Aston Villa goalkeeper refused to shake hands after the final whistle.

On the scale of past dramas, this was a minor scene. But it added to the feeling that no West Ham week can pass without some sort of controversy.

Last season's highlights included John Hartson kicking Eyal Berkovic in the head, the board upsetting Harry Redknapp by ordering Andy Impey be dropped from the team, cup exits to Northampton and Swansea, Ian Wright trashing the referee's room after three West Ham players were sent off against Leeds, and the disappearance of Javier Margas.

West Ham wasted no time finding new plot lines this season when they discovered that Igor Stimac had played in the InterToto Cup while banned.

Highlights also include: Di Canio being accused of diving to get Patrick Vieira sent off, Neil Ruddock accused of inflaming the situation before Vieira exits with a spit; Trevor Sinclair accused of diving to win a penalty against Sheffield Wednesday; Samassi Abou fined for not turning up at the club.

Di Canio then accused West Ham of playing like a Conference team while Berkovic called them a pub side; eliminated from the FA Cup by the First Division's Tranmere, they were ordered to replay the Worthington Cup quarter-final win over Aston Villa after fielding a cup-tied player; the secretary and his assistant resigned; they lost the replay; and on Friday the captain Steve Lomas was fined £6,000 by the FA for post-match comments at Chelsea.

It may all be a bit short on love interest but as for the other soap opera ingredients - agony, anger, frustration, intrigue and misunderstanding - it is all there.

Even the circumstances which fuelled Saturday's dust-up came straight from the Albert Square book of emotions. Having equalised late in Tuesday's enforced Worthington Cup replay, Villa took the lead three minutes into extra-time and the result hinged on a penalty awarded to West Ham eight minutes later when Di Canio went sprawling again.

Villa players loudly accused him of diving, and James said something extra before administering his own justice by saving the Italian's spot-kick.

After Saturday's Premiership rematch Di Canio, best remembered for pushing over the referee Paul Alcock while at Sheffield Wednesday, said of his apparent push on James: "I wanted to be a sportsman but he shoved me away. When someone does that to me I think he is a stupid man. He is not a sportsman. I put my hand up just as a reaction but not to fight."

James, presumably still feeling slighted by Tuesday's shenanigans and also upset at having just gifted Di Canio West Ham's equaliser, said: "He came to shake my hand but I didn't want to shake his and I pushed him away."

It is understood the referee Graham Poll will not include the altercation in his report, so any FA action would have to be based on video evidence.

As for the game, West Ham and Villa must feel like long-lost twins: impossible to separate. Not content with both playing in claret and blue, meeting twice in five days and sitting next to each other in mid-table obscurity, they have drawn their last four league meetings - and they twice needed extra-time to separate them in the Worthington Cup.

On Saturday Villa took the lead through Ian Taylor, twice a scorer in Tuesday's game. West Ham's Paulo Wanchope then somehow contrived to miss from three yards before James inexplicably dropped Sinclair's cross and Di Canio eagerly slotted home the equaliser. West Ham continued to press for the winner but could do no better than hit the bar.

So Villa's mini-resurgence continues, while West Ham's failure to win a league game since November has badly dented their chances of securing a European place. On recent evidence they have more chance of being handed a slot in BBC1's evening schedules.

webTitle: Flighty Owls find the only way is up

fields.headline: Flighty Owls find the only way is up
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 2 - 0 Bradford
fields.body:
New Labour, new Wednesday. It is amazing what this government can do. All it took was four Labour MPs to delve into the problems at Hillsborough and call for the sacking of Danny Wilson, and the campaign to save the club's Premiership life began in earnest.

If only all politics was so easy. Joe Ashton, the Bassetlaw MP and former Wednesday director, suggested that the terraces were awash with cries of "Well done, Joe lad" and "Yougerronwi'it, Joe" even before Wednesday produced one of their few scintillating performances of the season.

Three Premiership wins to their name and only a point behind the second-bottom club Watford: any politician worth his salt would claim that improvement as a triumph. Best not mention that Bradford were next to useless.

For once Wilson's side defended acceptably enough, although if Dean Saunders had stolen between Peter Atherton and Pavel Srnicek to give Bradford a second-minute lead, or if Andy Hinchcliffe hadn't later headed off the line from Jamie Lawrence, Ashton might have been tempted into a sit-down protest on the pitch.

Instead a host of Wednesday near misses in the first half became irrelevent as Niclas Alexandersson and an own-goal from Andrew O'Brien provided a victory that really was fundamental to their survival.

The home side's first-half wastage had left their fans fraught, with the much-maligned Gerald Sibon - who had one of his better games - Atherton and Gilles de Bilde all denied by the woodwork.

"I'm not interested in what the MPs think," Wilson said. "If they want to embarrass themselves, let them continue." However, there are still questions that need to be asked, such as just who was at fault for refusing to sell Emerson Thome to Chelsea for £4.5m at the start of the season and then selling him to the same club last month for £2.7m?

Wilson has had limited money to spend, and the final verdict on his major Low Country signings, such as De Bilde and Sibon, will largely rest upon whether Wednesday survive. They should not be written off just yet.

fields.headline: Taggart exposes Vialli false dawn
fields.trailText: Chelsea 1 - 1 Leicester
fields.body:
Chelsea last week basked in the wonderful world of Weah, prompting a new optimism captured in the match-programme message from Gianluca Vialli: "I would like to think this is just the beginning." Then Leicester, ever more defiant in adversity, left their calling-card.

By the end of the match Vialli, barely concealing his frustration, had toned down his message to the point of warning darkly: "Hopefully, this is going to be the last time we play in this way."

Remarkably - given his worldly collection of players - the Chelsea manager effectively accused his side of performing without intelligence and patience against a Leicester side which sprung no real surprises, even if their spirit seemed even more willing in the absence of six first-team regulars at the start.

George Weah was given little scope to collect the reported £15,000 bonus he is on for any goal he scores. As Gianfranco Zola, recalled after his midweek humiliation, put it: "They didn't offer any opportunity, any space."

Even if an improbable Dennis Wise header produced the late equaliser, this was largely a Chelsea case of banging their heads against a high brick wall, an exercise useful only as further familiarisation with Leicester before a possible rematch in the FA Cup on January 30.

That trophy may well be Chelsea's most realistic ambition and not surprisingly, Vialli did not talk of pursuing a Champions League place as he offered a curious diagnosis of his side's malaise on the day. "We kept playing in the middle and this is what they wanted us to do. We needed more width."

Yet his side delivered any number of crosses, especially in the first half, that were gratefully received by Matt Elliott and the outstanding Gerry Tag gart. This tactic would have been understandable if Chris Sutton had been the target; but it was the tall striker's turn to be removed from the squad, a thigh injury being the official reason.

It appears Sutton is surplus to requirements at Chelsea, even if there will be few takers at the £10m that Leeds claim they were quoted after recent inquiries, which ended with the Premiership leaders ruling out a deal at that price. As for Zola, distraught at his axing from the squad for last Wednesday's league match, he says he is "committed to the club".

When Chelsea did create clear-cut chances, Gabriele Ambrosetti and Gustavo Poyet shot poorly; Weah was restricted to an unconvincing effort with his thigh that Darren Eadie cleared off the line. Even the introduction of a third striker, Tore Andre Flo, midway through the second half, scarcely ruffled Leicester.

More puzzling was Leicester's inability to deliver a second, killing goal after Taggart's scrambled opener four minutes before half-time and inflict on Chelsea damage comparable to their last visit to Stamford Bridge in April, when a late comeback in a 2-2 draw prompted Vialli to call it the day "when we lost the Premiership title".

Even without four of their first-choice midfield, Leicester produced three chances for Emile Heskey - all wasted - to build on the advantage Taggart had given them. That durable Northern Ireland defender later summed up the Leicester spirit and credo: "We like to get amongst skilful players and battle. We are mentally strong. Everyone pulls together and anything is possible."

fields.headline: Stockwell finds winning route
fields.trailText: Ipswich 3 - 0 Swindon
fields.body:
As befits a team with names such as Clapham, Stockwell, Holland and even Venus in their line-up, Ipswich Town are a club intent on going places.

After four seasons in this division, the worst of which saw them finish seventh, their destination remains the Premiership and, though they did what they had to in this mismatch, they may yet regret failing to increase their goal difference significantly against a club who are seven points below the third-bottom side.

Micky Stockwell opened the scoring with a low drive from 12 yards and when Richard Naylor beat Frank Talia with a deft lob in the 37th minute it was game over. Naylor wrapped it up with a late header from Jamie Clapham's cross, but David Johnson alone should have scored four after the interval.

"You could see the difference between the two teams; they haven't got a weakness," said Jimmy Quinn, the Swindon player-manager, who has not been helped by the apathy that set in among the fans during Steve McMahon's tenure. This season he has been forced to sell four regular first-team players and sack 15 backroom staff.

Gates are at a 13-year low, the club are a reported £4m in debt and struggling to attract match-ball sponsors, but Quinn is hoping for the go-ahead to rebuild; nine of the expensive 28-man squad he inherited are out of contract in the summer.

For Ipswich, things could not be more different. They have "significant funds" to help "go the extra mile", according to the chairman David Sheepshanks, and even had the chance to give Gary Croft a run-out five days after his release from prison, where he watched the previous Saturday's results on television.

The defender was given a standing ovation when he came on with an electronic tag strapped above his left ankle. "It's the sports version: waterproof and shockproof," he said.

"I've missed the big-game atmosphere. It's something you love as a footballer and it was great to be part of it again," he added before heading for home smartly, before the 7pm curfew which is a condition of his parole.

webTitle: Poacher Goater keeps City in hunt

fields.headline: Poacher Goater keeps City in hunt
fields.trailText: Manchester City 4 - 0 Fulham
fields.body:
Shaun Goater continued a rehabilitation as startling as Manchester City's, scoring a hat-trick to take his season's tally to 18 and his team into second place in the First Division.

The scoreline flattered Joe Royle's team absurdly, three goals coming inside the final quarter-hour after Fulham had Chris Coleman sent off for deliberate handball. But to the many striking qualities that the City manager has brought to the club in his near two-year reign can be added arguably the most important of all - good fortune.

All successful teams have it - none more, City fans would argue, than their rivals from across town - and this was a game that, on the balance of play, could quite easily have been settled by a solitary goal, either way.

But Goater ensured otherwise. A year ago, the Bermudan striker was finding the net in the Second Division - ending the season with 20 goals - but also squandering numerous chances that hardly endeared him to the loyal but demanding home support.

Popular consensus had it that promotion would see Goater, bought for £400,000 from Bristol City two years ago, eased out. Royle, however, is a supremely loyal manager and Goater was offered the opportunity to stake a claim for the position. Eighteen goals later, that decision looks like a stroke of genius.

"His all-round game has improved," said Royle of his striker. "He has always got goals but the quality of his finishing and bringing people into play has improved. That comes from confidence and knowing the crowd are behind you.

"People doubted whether he could step up to this level. I hope he gets the chance to step up another level again because he has scored against Premiership opposition as well."

There was a suspicion of offside about Goater's first, on 29 minutes, as he and Richard Edghill stole ahead of the Fulham backline to chase Robert Taylor's long ball. The City left-back reached it ahead of the defender Rufus Brevett who twisted awkwardly, sustaining an injury that saw him take no further part in the game. Edghill's cross found the unmarked Goater who swept the ball home.

The lead arrived largely against the run of play. City, with Michael Kennedy effectively as a third striker, had surrendered control in midfield where Lee Clark sprayed passes around with abandon.

Paul Peschisolido and Wayne Collins went close before Fulham's fate was sealed by Coleman's 68th minute handball and red card, after Goater had broken away from him.

Fulham's manager Paul Bracewell felt aggrieved about a number of decisions, includ ing an unsuccessful Peschisolido penalty appeal after an Edghill challenge.

"The linesman was 10 yards away from the sending off and never gave the handball," said Bracewell. "The lads thought the first goal was offside and we should have had a penalty. Those decisions turned the game."

In the 77th minute Goater scored with an overhead kick after Maik Taylor had failed to deal with a Kevin Horlock free-kick and five minutes from time he headed into another open goal after Taylor had saved a Richard Jobson header.

Two minutes later, another rewarding result in this increasingly rewarding City season was complete, the full-back Steve Finnan tripping Danny Tiatto in the area and Horlock converting the penalty.

fields.headline: Parkes sets right tone
fields.trailText: Blackburn 2 - 0 Huddersfield
fields.body:
Tony Parkes attributes much of his success to the lack of formality he applies in the workplace. "Just call me Tone" was among his first instructions on becoming manager of Blackburn Rovers.

After serving his apprenticeship in five spells as caretaker-manager, Parkes agreed to take the top job after some arm-twisting. Since then Blackburn have lost only once in 15 games. Are these really the same players who performed so meekly in 11 months under Brian Kidd?

Parkes insists automatic promotion is beyond them and, bearing in mind the consistency of the top three, he may be right. Their best route appears to be the play-offs and, if they pull it off, Parkes will surely have his contract renewed in the summer.

Those who had predicted a fierce Roses clash between two of the First Division's stronger sides will have been disappointed. Huddersfield, themselves on a roll until Christmas, were meek whereas Blackburn were mighty. Well crafted first-half goals from Damien Duff and Damien Johnson did not reflect the extent of the Lancashire side's dominance.

Asked for the secret of his success, Parkes shrugged and said: "I don't have a magic wand and I would never criticise what Brian did in his time in charge. I changed one or two things training-wise but that's all really."

Duff, a player transformed under Parkes, said: "Tone just tells us to go out and express ourselves. He's also probably a bit easier to get on with than Brian Kidd was. He asks us to call him Tone, whereas Brian was the Gaffer."

Victory came at a cost - the goalkeeper John Filan will now have surgery on a shoulder problem which has bothered him for months - but Blackburn, unlike their opponents, have the strength in depth to deal with such setbacks.

With Jason McAteer and Matt Jansen substitutes, and Keith Gillespie among those approaching full fitness, Rovers are looking ominous.

He's also probably a bit easier to get on with than Brian Kidd was. He asks us to call him Tone, whereas Brian was the Gaffer." Victory came at a cost - the goalkeeper John Filan will now have surgery on a shoulder problem which has bothered him for months - but Blackburn, unlike their opponents, have the strength in depth to deal with such setbacks. With Jason McAteer and Matt Jansen substitutes, and Keith Gillespie among those approaching full fitness, Rovers are looking ominous.

webTitle: Owen's solo act steals the show

fields.headline: Owen's solo act steals the show
fields.trailText: Watford 2 - 3 Liverpool
fields.body:
It was asking a lot of Watford's new record signing to snatch the headlines away from that hamstring and that ankle. In the circumstances Heidar Helguson did rather well and at one stage he ignited hopes of an unlikely victory, though that deservedly went to Liverpool along with some welcome relief from injury gloom.

Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler are an alliance of championship-winning potency but, according to Gérard Houllier, the pair have shared the same patch of grass for only 60 minutes in the past 10 months. When Fowler learned on Thursday that he must undergo another ankle operation it might have seemed that the Liverpool manager was risking a second savage twist by announcing Owen's return so soon after his latest hamstring troubles.

Yet a week that had begun with Liverpool's surprise exit from the FA Cup ended sweetly as Owen helped lift his team into fourth place. His withdrawal 16 minutes from time was purely precautionary and Kevin Keegan can pencil him in for next month's friendly with Argentina.

"Michael didn't want to come off but he understood," Houllier said afterwards. "He did not feel the injury at all, he was always lively and his movement on and off the ball was back to its best. Like that, he is a tremendous asset for us and the national team."

However, Owen must plough on without his preferred running mate. Fowler, booked in for more surgery tomorrow, will be out of first-team action for at least eight weeks, leaving Houllier to muse on where Liverpool might be had Owen and Fowler been blessed with a problem-free year.

"We have lost six games in the league, five by the odd goal," Houllier said. "With Robbie and Michael together we would probably have at least three draws from those games and would still be in the FA Cup, because in the one-off games the ability to seize your chances is crucial."

On Saturday Houllier was grateful to his midfield players, who scored all three goals and prevented a victory turning into a draw. Owen's handiwork was equally vital. He set up Patrik Berger for the first through an accurate pass across a crowded area, the third for Vladimir Smicer - who was on target for the first time since moving to Anfield - and also rapped a shot against the bar himself.

Having gone two goals up when David Thompson touched home Dietmar Hamann's free-kick, Liverpool should never have needed a third. But they switched off before the interval and granted Watford a lifeline through Richard Johnson. Then, within 30 seconds of the restart, Sander Westerveld ventured too far and invited Helguson to dispatch a scoring header on his debut.

The Icelander's impressive performance gives Graham Taylor several forward options when everyone is available, though none possesses the calibre of Owen or Fowler. And with defenders who lack concentration at key moments it is no wonder Watford are heading back to the First Division.

webTitle: Moore gives Keegan less to ponder

fields.headline: Moore gives Keegan less to ponder
fields.trailText: Everton 2 - 2 Tottenham
fields.body:
At least Kevin Keegan found a fruitful afternoon's employment here, though the contest featured a telling contribution from an American in the Everton substitute Joe-Max Moore who came on late to claim an injury-time equaliser.

Everton began with six players eligible for consideration by the watching England coach while George Graham started with only two of his overseas contingent, David Ginola and Steffan Iversen, as he has reportedly begun to question the over-reliance of some teams on foreign players.

The Spurs manager can only have had such an opinion reinforced as Ginola was virtually anonymous, save for the second goal which deflected freakishly off Dave Watson, and Iversen missed three excellent chances to put the game beyond Everton's reach.

Keegan, on his first visit to Goodison as national coach, was given food for thought in his ongoing process of selecting an initial 35-man squad for next summer's European Championship.

He will have noted that the Everton striker Francis Jeffers, still more than a week away from his 19th birthday, started nervously but impressed as the game wore on, that Sol Campbell was his usual dominant self in the Spurs defence and that Darren Anderton, sans sicknote, did enough to suggest he is worth keeping tabs on.

"Darren is a quality player," Graham said. "He did okay and he linked well with Tim Sherwood at times, but he is still short of match fitness."

But the best of the British on display was, by some distance, Sherwood. Solid while Everton threatened to sweep the visitors aside in a committed opening burst, the midfielder began to assert his influence in attack and had a hand in both Spurs' goals, which came within six minutes of Kevin Cambell's 22nd minute opener.

First his excellent free-kick found Sol Campbell whose header against the post was turned in by Chris Armstrong. Then his pass towards the right-hand corner flag found Ginola whose cross was deflected into the Everton net.

That cancelled out an impressive opening effort: neat sleight-of-feet by Jeffers in midfield, passing wide to Don Hutchison, pinpoint cross and superbly converted header by Kevin Campbell.

Sherwood clearly has some work to do to convince Keegan that he is worthy of a place in the Low Countries in the summer but, at the very least, he is proving a testimony to the emerging view that British can still live with the best at the top level of the domestic game.

Or, if not British, then at least English-speaking. Moore, who arrived from the New England Revolution last November, had the final say two minutes into what he would call "over-time". Mark Pembridge's long throw was not cleared, Watson saw his shot blocked and Moore scrambled in his first goal for Everton.

Ironically, he should have inflicted the curse of the foreign footballer - enforced absence - upon the Everton manager Walter Smith this weekend. Instead the United States manager Bruce Arena gave his striker permission to miss yesterday's international with Iran and the forthcoming Gold Cup.

"I told Bruce I was feeling better here after struggling to start with," said Moore. "I felt it was important to stay and establish myself and he agreed."

fields.headline: Marshall law needs widening
fields.trailText: Birmingham 2 - 0 Norwich
fields.body:
A second successive league win suggests Birmingham are not only emerging from their mid-season trough but have also put their controversial FA Cup exit at Everton behind them.

The manager Trevor Francis was still chuntering in Saturday's match programme about the theatricals of Nicky Barmby that earned the match-turning penalty at Goodison Park.

As is often the case with one of the game's more perceptive observers, however, Francis did offer a cogent solution to the question of "cheating". He reasoned: "If we can use video evidence to hand out bans to players whose fouls have been missed by the referee, then why not use it to punish players who have obviously cheated? It could help eradicate an increasing problem in the English game."

At St Andrew's the referee Robert Lewis, who showed admirable common sense throughout, needed no assistance from the cameras to deal with the afternoon's two miscreants. Both came from Norwich and Mr Lewis dispensed justice to the pair for the same offence: deliberate handball.

There, though, the similarities ended. In the first half the central defender Malky Mackay was shown the yellow card for trying to punch the ball into the Birmingham goal; in the second the keeper Andy Marshall was given first use of the Wash and Go for punching the ball clear of the Norwich net. That the hapless Marshall was out of his penalty area when he intercepted Steve Robinson's goalbound shot accounted for the difference between yellow and red.

The services of Rumpole of the Bailey, however, are surely not needed to argue that trying to score a goal illegally is pretty much the same offence as trying to prevent one illegally. All of which suggests that this particular law is not so much an ass but a dog's breakfast.

Which, at the time of Marshall's exit in the 55th minute, is what an off-colour Norwich had made of the match.

By then Birmingham's midfielder Martin Grainger had scored the game's two goals, his double coming courtesy of a sweetly struck left-foot volley after 16 minutes followed by a header from Gary Rowett's corner 14 minutes later.

Birmingham, badly depleted for so long, are now only three points off the play-off zone. "No other club would have coped with the injuries and illnesses we've had," said Grainger.

Especially Norwich. "In our circumstances you cannot afford to give any team a two-goal start, especially one as strong as Birmingham," said their manager Bruce Rioch.

Being reduced to 10 men didn't help much either.

fields.headline: Leaders breatheeasily as racetightens
fields.trailText: Charlton 1 - 0 Crewe
fields.body:
Charlton Athletic consolidated their lead in the table without undue effort against lowly Crewe Alexandra but the jury is still out on whether they are, as their position indicates, the best team in the First Division.

"I think there are a fair number of sides who are about the same standard," said Dario Gradi, who as the country's longest-serving manager, with 18 years at Crewe, should be as good a judge as anybody.

"I would think if Birmingham had all their players fit they would be the best," he added, "but Huddersfield have good strikers, Manchester City are decent, Fulham can be good and I don't think there's much to choose between any of those sides."

It was a view broadly endorsed by the Charlton striker Martin Pringle. "There are so many good sides in the division, it shows in how tight it is at the top," he said. "You've got Barnsley, Ipswich, Man City and us and I think those are the four best teams and we'll just have to see in May who are the best two."

Evaluating Charlton's promotion prospects was not an easy job on Saturday. Coming off a draining 3-2 victory at Wolves four days earlier the Addicks were unwilling to exert themselves unduly and did the bare minimum needed to quell Crewe.

Nevertheless this was their sixth win in a row and they should make it seven when they visit Norwich City next weekend and maybe eight when they play Coventry City in the fifth round of the FA Cup.

Forced forward by their tireless and combative captain Mark Kinsella, Charlton wrapped a ligature around Crewe's neck and expertly tightened it. Kinsella is reputedly the subject of a £5m bid from Newcastle United but he said last week: "I'm happy where I am."

Graham Stuart made the breakthrough from close range in the 13th minute and after that the game was done and dusted. Charlton continued to fashion openings on a whim and must show a greater ruthlessness should they go up this time around.

But the side have a more battle-hardened look than when they came down from the Premiership last summer and the experience of playing in the top flight seems to have stood them in good stead.

"I think we're a bit more mature," Pringle said. "We are able to do enough to win games like this and I think that's what makes us a better team.

"We used to be up and down but now we're a bit more consistent, and we can do really well if we just keep on doing what we are doing, which is grinding out results. You cannot play nice football all the time; sometimes it's just three points in the bag."

"We should have won it by a street," admitted Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley. "The expectation levels at this club are great and if we don't beat teams 3-0 at the Valley then people think there's something wrong. Obviously that's not the case: we had to follow up Tuesday's win against Wolves and that's what we did and we thoroughly deserved the three points."

The club, he emphasised, could handle the pressures of leadership. "It's unrelenting at the top," he said. "But I'm not too fussed about where we are because if you're up there you're up there and that's it; I don't see it as a problem.

"The expectation level at this club would be the same if we were first, second, third or fourth. The fans and the pundits expect us to win and it's something we've got to live with."

Pringle put it in perspective, stating: "At the end of the day we're top of the league, we got three points and that's what counts."

fields.headline: Century up for McAllister
fields.trailText: Coventry City 2 - 0 Wimbledon
fields.body:
Coventry have turned entertainers of late, all flicks, tricks and glorious goals, but this new-found flair has not come about simply because Gordon Strachan has invested in a couple of Moroccans and an audacious young Irishman.

While Moustapha Hadji, Youssef Chippo and Robbie Keane have increased the attraction of watching Coventry, the transformation has been underpinned by two of the club's old guard, Gary McAllister and Carlton Palmer.

McAllister, 35 on Christmas Day, scored one - his 100th league goal - and created the other as Coventry saw off Wimbledon's tepid challenge with a display that made light of the absence of nine first-team players on Saturday, including Chippo and Hadji who have remained with their national side at the African Nations Cup.

Palmer, a driving force in the midfield at 34, and McAllister allow their more skilful team-mates to express themselves. McAllister, though, will have his own freedom of movement should Coventry decide that the midfielder does not warrant a new contract when his current deal expires at the end of the season. The Scot is free to talk to other clubs but is keen to open a dialogue with his present employers.

"The club have not yet spoken to me about a contract and I would have expected them to," McAllister said. "Maybe they thought I was going to America to see out my career because that had been mentioned. But that's not happening. I feel I can play on in the Premiership for a bit longer."

Despite McAllister's concerns about his future, Strachan does not doubt his captain's commitment and expects to discuss a new deal with him over a pint or a coffee in the coming weeks.

"We talk as mates and that's all there is to it," said the Coventry manager. "At the moment our discussions are agent-free and chairman-free. We talk as players about what's the best for his football.

"In any case, have you seen the size of the house he owns in Leicester? He owns half of Leicester and he's not going to leave that behind."

Egil Olsen was equally positive last week when asked if he wished to stay on as Wimbledon's manager when his contract expires at the end of next season. The Norwegian may change his mind, however, unless his side overcome their current striker crisis.

The Dons are not in a position to splash out for a short-term solution à la Chelsea, but with John Hartson out after an ankle operation and Marcus Gayle Jamaica-bound for the Concacaf Gold Cup they are desperately short up front.

Carl Cort played as an emergency striker on Saturday but Coventry's goalkeeper Magnus Hedman enjoyed a quiet afternoon. Cedric Roussel and Keane, by contrast, were a constant threat for the home side.

Yet it took some eagle-eyed refereeing for Coventry to be rewarded. In the 56th minute Roussel played the ball through to Keane and Hermann Hreidarsson pushed out an arm, which the ball flicked en route. As the crowd turned to watch whether Keane would finish, Steve Bennett was indicating a penalty - which McAllister duly converted. It was a fine decision by the referee, who did not produce a card all afternoon.

Eighteen minutes later Keane clinched the win by latching on to McAllister's through ball and firing home at the second attempt.

webTitle: Benson finds it hard to please

fields.headline: Benson finds it hard to please
fields.trailText: Wigan 1 - 1 Athletic
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the JJB Stadium
fields.body:
It is hard to see what more Wigan can do. Their manager, John Benson, recently masterminded a 24-game unbeaten start to the season and his side topped the division, the highest position in their history.

The chairman has ploughed money into the club and built a magnificent stadium which can hold 25,000. The Latics have never had it so good.

But on Saturday only 6,304 fans witnessed this match between two of the division's more accomplished sides. Attendances have increased by 223 per cent in six years, but there was a depressingly hollow feeling at the ground, adding weight to the theory that the town remains a rugby league stronghold.

Not that the lack of fans particularly bothered Benson. It was the reaction to his substitution of Roberto Martinez which irked him. "I don't like it," he said. "It's not his fault but if I take Roberto off, the crowd boo. I can't win. They have this thing about him, but it affects the other lad I'm putting on. It happens every time I do it."

This time it paid off, though. Down to 10 men when Stuart Balmer was sent off after 17 minutes for accidental handball on the line - though Roy Carroll saved the penalty - and trailing to David Livermore's goal, Benson pushed Arjan de Zeeuw up and Millwall wilted.

With three minutes to go Pat McGibbon flicked on Scott Green's long throw and Michael O'Neill bundled the ball in. "The crowd don't like O'Neill either," added Benson. "He won them over today but if he has a bad game next week, they'll be at him again. That's how they are."

Down to 10 men when Stuart Balmer was sent off after 17 minutes for accidental handball on the line - though Roy Carroll saved the penalty - and trailing to David Livermore's goal, Benson pushed Arjan de Zeeuw up and Millwall wilted. With three minutes to go Pat McGibbon flicked on Scott Green's long throw and Michael O'Neill bundled the ball in. "The crowd don't like O'Neill either," added Benson.
