fields.headline: Spielberg potty over Potter
fields.standfirst: Today, Spielberg gets animated over Harry Potter | Leonardo DiCaprio demanded steamy sex on The Beach | Star Wars fan goes sky walking | Romance is banned in Australia | Ten-hour wait for Toy Story 2 | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Today, Spielberg gets animated over Harry Potter | Leonardo DiCaprio demanded steamy sex on The Beach | Star Wars fan goes sky walking | Romance is banned in Australia | Ten-hour wait for Toy Story 2 | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg is to direct a film version of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, JK Rowling's first story about schoolboy wizard. The American director spent Christmas debating whether to adapt the literary phenomenon or work on his other long-planned film, AI, based on a storyline by the late Stanley Kubrick, or on Minority Report, a film with Tom Cruise.

But despite the fact that AI and Minority Report would be produced by his own studio, Dreamworks, Spielberg has opted to produce and direct Harry Potter for rival company Warner Bros, after seeing the first draft of the screenplay by Steve 'The Fabulous Baker Boys' Kloves.

Hollywood's finest, including Jonathan Demme, Chris Columbus, Mike Newell and Robert Zemeckis, had been queuing up to make the film. Warner Bros - who bought the rights to the book last summer - was therefore able to dictate terms to Spielberg, stating that the phenomenally successful children's story must be the director's next project, in order to capitalise on the popularity of the book.

But before any bespectacled 12-year-old with black magic inclinations gets any casting ideas, it should be noted that Hollywood's most feted director is said to favour a computer-animated version of the adaptation

DiCaprio demanded steamy sex on The Beach

Fans of Alex Garland's best-selling novel The Beach might be surprised on seeing the movie to find that the film contains Leonardo DiCaprio's most steamy on-screen sex scenes to date.

Apparently, the Hollywood heart-throb was unhappy with the lack of sex scenes in the original script, and demanded his character enjoy more "sexual contact" with leading lady Virginie Ledoyen.

"It truly bothered me about the book that he never had any kind of sexual contact with Francoise," he complained. "I really wanted something, whether it be complete and utter rejection or some sort of wild sexual encounter - it had to happen."

Sky walking fails to impress George Lucas

A Star Wars fan caused havoc in Sydney yesterday when he climbed onto the roof of the city's Fox Studios in a bid to win a role in the next prequel. The man, a scaffolder called Brett, was talked down from the cinema roof after almost five hours 40 metres above the street.

Brett handed a Fox employee a note saying he wanted to meet Star Wars director George Lucas, before scaling the front of the Hoyts cinema. An ambulance waited below and a section of the street was closed.

A friend of Brett's assured security staff that the scaffolder meant no harm, but was just a huge fan of Star Wars and wanted a role in the second prequel, which is to be filmed at the Australian studios. "He just wants to be in the movies," the friend said.

A studio spokeswoman, labelled the climb a harmless, if disruptive, stunt. A police spokesman said the starstruck Brett would probably be charged.

Romance is over for Australian film censors

Australian film censors have banned controversial French film Romance. In what the acting chief film censor, Simon Webb, described as a "line-ball" decision, the 17-member office of film and literature classification opted to ban, by nine votes to eight, Catherine Breillat's explicit study of a woman on a sexual odyssey. Potential Films, the Australian distributors of the film, described the ban as "disappointing", and said they would contest the decision.

The office said the ban was based on sexually explicit scenes including a depiction of implied sexual violence. Echoing the opinion of many Australian film critics, Paul Byrne of the Sydney Morning Herald said: "The Australian censor's decision means, in effect, that adults here are allowed to watch films which don't take sex seriously - millions of pornographic tapes sold from mail-order houses - but not one which treats the subject with gravity and intelligence."

Australia is the first country to have banned the film which has been shown uncut in every country which it has played so far.

Ten-hour wait for Toy Story 2

The makers of Toy Story 2 recently broke with cinema tradition when the trailer for the computer-animated film was released exclusively online. Now they're to make cinema history again by holding the first ever digital screening of a full-length feature film in Britain.

At the Odeon in Leicester Square, not a single reel of film will be in sight when Woody the Cowboy and Buzz Lightyear get their second airing from the toy box on February 4: the film will be projected straight from a computer.

But while the London arm of Buena Vista shows that it is light years ahead of the rest of the industry, the practicalities of the project are proving to be quite difficult. A spokesman explained: "We're having to fly over vast amounts of digital equipment at huge expense because it just doesn't exist in Britain yet. It's worth it because it's an important milestone. In 20 years' time there will be no film in cinemas - they will just download the film from the studio."

But Buena Vista technical staff aren't quite so enamoured of the process - the film takes over 10 hours to download

In brief

 A release date for Guy Ritchie's new film, Snatch, has been announced. The diamond heist flick which features Brad Pitt will open on September 1, almost two years to the day that Ritchie's phenomenally successful debut Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels was released.

 Sharon Stone missed out on starring in Angela's Ashes. The star offered her services for free to play the woman Frank McCourt has an affair with on his arrival in the US. But director Alan Parker chopped the scene at the editing stage. Explaining his decision, the director, who has taken some flack for his bleak depiction of Limerick, said: "Poor Sharon, that's the one thing we left out. The film actually ends with Frank's arrival in America. The book goes on for one more chapter where he has this affair in upstate New York. I don't know why. I think probably because Frank was easing into his next book 'Tis." 'Tis seems set to repeat the success of Angela's Ashes, but Parker has said that it is unlikely that he will film the sequel.

 Eyes Wide Shut will be released in the US on DVD and video on March 14, but those hoping to see the orgy scene in its pre-digital remastering state will be disappointed. Warner Home Video has announced that Stanley Kubrick's swansong will still contain the same digital alterations which the director made to forestall accusations of excessive nudity on the film's cinematic release.

 Blink and you'll miss him, but apparently the star of the latest Guinness advert is none other than Al Pacino. Look closely at the bearded man who drinks a celebrationary pint after winning a snail race... An insider on the set said that Pacino was in Cuba at the same time that the ad was being filmed, and - as a great fan of the commercials - agreed to appear in this one for free. However neither Guinness nor Pacino will confirm the story. You'll just have to decide for yourself.

 Robert Carlyle, currently playing a useless feck of a father in Angela's Ashes, has his own real-life family problems to contend with. Today's Express newspaper carries an 'emotional plea' from the star's mother, who walked out on the actor when he was six and has not seen him since. Carlyle regards her as dead, but his mother is very much alive, and wants to see her son. "I am not after his wealth... I just want us to make our peace" she says.

Casting couch

 Roman Polanski is to return to his native Poland to make his next movie. The director has acquired the rights to The Pianist, a chronicle of a Jewish musician's fight for survival in Warsaw during the second world war. Shooting is scheduled to begin at the end of the year.

 Rebecca Miller, the wife of Irish Oscar winner Daniel Day-Lewis and the daughter of American playwright Arthur Miller, is to direct an adaptation of Mary Webb's novel Gone to Earth. Samantha Morton and Jeremy Irons are possible leads.

webTitle: Young lose out in housing boom

fields.headline: Young lose out in housing boom
fields.trailText: Long-term confidence in the south-east's booming housing market has left most people fearing that home ownership will be beyond the reach of a younger generation, according to a poll published today.
fields.body:
Long-term confidence in the south-east's booming housing market has left most people fearing that home ownership will be beyond the reach of a younger generation, according to a poll published today.

The poll reinforces concerns that rapid house price inflation in the past year, which saw property prices in greater London rise by almost 30%, means young professionals are increasingly unable to afford a mortgage.

The Mori survey for the National Housing Federation and the Chartered Institute of Housing marks the launch of a national campaign - Our Homes, Our Future - to warn the government that Britain faces a housing crisis.

The poll of 2,000 people found that in the south-east 55% of people doubted that the next generation could afford a home. Even in three northern regions, where house prices rose by just over 5% last year, a large minority (45%) have the same view.

"The housing market is creating winners but also losers," said Jim Coulter, chief executive of the Housing Federation, which mainly represents publicly funded housing associations - the only agencies that are currently building lower-cost homes for rent.

"The winners are the ones lucky enough to own a home soaring in value, while the unlucky ones cannot afford a home - forcing employers to increase wages to cover housing costs. It is not surprising people are losing confidence."

The latest survey follows research by the federation which shows that people on average incomes working in London are finding it increasingly difficult to afford rented accommodation, let alone qualify for a mortgage.

The average weekly rent for a two-bedroom flat in London is £274 - more than four times the £65 a week average rent for a similar property in a city such as Leeds.

Calculating that the average price paid for a property by first time buyers is about £100,000, the federation says key workers are being frozen out of the market.

A nurse with five years experience, and earning £18,500 a year, would only qualify for a maximum mortgage of around £53,000, says the federation, while a teacher with the same length of service would earn almost £23,000. This would put a mortgage of £65,000 within reach.

Londoners earned, on average, 12% more than people in the rest of the UK, but housing costs - rents and mortgages - are "several times higher", says the federation.

Away from the region, the federation says rural areas are facing acute shortages of low-cost homes - partly because more than 100,000 council houses have been sold off under the "right to buy" scheme.

The government's countryside agency calculates that more than 62,000 new homes are needed to meet demand.

David Butler, chief executive of the Chartered Institute of Housing, which represents council housing managers, said: "Clearly the market cannot provide enough decent homes at prices people can afford. We need a strategy that provides a strong social housing sector to ensure everyone can enjoy a decent home."

fields.headline: Crisis - what crisis?
fields.trailText: I am an intensive care doctor. I have just finished a 28-hour shift with four hours sleep. In our unit we have nine physical bed spaces and just about enough equipment for eight of them (although much of it is old or falling apart).
fields.body:
I am an intensive care doctor. I have just finished a 28-hour shift with four hours sleep. In our unit we have nine physical bed spaces and just about enough equipment for eight of them (although much of it is old or falling apart). On a good day we have enough nurses to staff seven beds safely.

When I left the unit today, like every day for the past few weeks, we had nine critically ill patients - but there's no crisis. Instead of caring for her patients or running the shift, the sister in charge was ringing off-duty colleagues begging them to do extra and longer shifts - but there's no crisis. In the last few weeks we have been forced to refuse admission to numerous patients who have had to be transferred to other units. Such transfers introduce delay and the possibility of further complications for people who are already fighting for their lives - but we are told there is no crisis. There are two patients at our hospital who have been awaiting major and potentially life-saving elective surgery for oesophageal cancer for weeks. They have not had their operations because we have not had a bed to admit them to following surgery - but this is not a crisis.

Perhaps Mr Milburn would like to tell us whose ventilator we should switch off so that we can do these operations. Perhaps he could tell us what his definition of a crisis is. Lord Winston is merely articulating what everyone working in the health service has known for years and what Clarke, Bottomley, Dobson, Milburn and whoever we get next will never have the courage to admit. Sleep deprivation comes with this job, but I'm glad I'm not secretary of state for health - I'd never sleep a wink.
Name and address supplied

 The Conservative internal market in the NHS has not been removed. It has been modified to be less commercial, but the fragmentation remains, contributing to current funding being inadequate for clinical services.

Lord Winston's analysis of the funding situation is also right. However much modernisation and increased efficiency is achieved, this country will still be faced with three options - an underfunded NHS increasingly unable to meet its commitments, increased taxation (maybe hypothecated), or an insurance system.

Alan Milburn rightly does not favour the third option. He will need a lot of help in persuading his cabinet colleagues to find the political courage to adopt the second.
Peter Fisher
President, NHS Consultants' Association

 The much needed modernisation is being increasingly dictated by theoretians and academics whose sole aim is to make every element of the service "viable" and thus are recommending fewer and larger centralised units.

This argument has some credence in speciality units such as renal, vascular, cancer etc and even in general medicine/elective surgery disciplines so long as they don't view increased patient turnover as an excuse to cut bed numbers (which they do). But in acute/emergency and maternity services it is simply not applicable.

In east Kent, our three major hospitals in Margate, Canterbury and Ashford have been running at 95% bed occupancy for months and for the last couple of weeks at 100%-plus. But we are to lose almost a third of our beds (2,088 down to 1,414), lose A&E and intensive care at Canterbury, and lose acute maternity at Canterbury and Dover.

The health service must decide whether it is a business or a service (albeit a cost-effective one). By its very nature it can not be both. By the reaction of the public, I know which they want - and they appear prepared to pay for it.
David Shortt
Concern for Health in East Kent

fields.headline: Blair's £12bn pledge to NHS
fields.trailText: Tony Blair promised yesterday to inject at least £12bn of extra money into the national health service over the next six years to prevent a repeat of the winter flu crisis that has precipitated the government's worst period in office.
fields.body:
Tony Blair promised yesterday to inject at least £12bn of extra money into the national health service over the next six years to prevent a repeat of the winter flu crisis that has precipitated the government's worst period in office.

In an unprecedented move to regain the initiative over the NHS, the prime minister pledged to bring spending up to the European average by 2006 through annual cash injections increases of around 5% in real terms each year. This compares with an average increase of 3% over the past two decades.

"Spending is too low at the moment so we'll bring it up [to the average of the European Union]," Mr Blair told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost.

The prime minister's dramatic commitment to such a specific spending target underlines the fear among ministers that Labour has appeared vulnerable in the past two weeks on one of its key areas.

One senior government source last night underlined the anxiety at the highest levels in Whitehall. "We have a real problem because we have had static funding for the past two years, the source said. "New money has only just kicked in."

Under the prime minister's pledge, an extra £12bn will be injected into the health service by 2006 by increasing spending by 5% in real terms each year, which works out at about £2bn each year. This will mean that spending on health care in Britain will increase, as a proportion of GDP, from 6.7% to 8%.

Mr Blair, who lacked his usual confidence in his first television interview of the year, underlined the government's fightback over the NHS by promising to speed up reforms of the NHS. As a first step, middle-ranking nurses will receive a £1,000 pay rise today when the prime minister accepts the recommendations of the pay review.

Ministers will also accelerate the development of NHS Direct, the new service which allows patients to consult doctors over the phone. The service, which currently covers two-thirds of Britain, will cover the whole country from October.

Mr Blair, who warned during the election campaign that only Labour could save the NHS, admitted during his interview that the government had been able to do little during its initial period in office because of his election commitment to stick to Tory spending plans for the first two years.

"We've had two years in the health service of pretty tight funding, we've put in slightly more money than the Conservatives but only slightly more because we had to sort out the borrowing we inherited," the prime minister said.

However, Mr Blair said the government was now able to make a difference. "Having sorted out the public finances we are now halfway through the first year in which there are substantially extra resources going into the health service. We've brought back 2,500 nurses already."

Mr Blair's intervention will massively strengthen the hand of the health secretary, Alan Milburn, who is about to embark on an intensive round of negotiations with the treasury over his next three-year budget. "The prime minister has talked numbers and established the benchmark," one government source said. "That is what counts."

The ultra-Blairite Mr Milburn, who was made health secretary because Mr Blair sees him as one of the government's most effective modernisers, knows that Labour's election campaign will be severely disrupted if he allows a repeat of the flu crisis.

Health department sources said Mr Milburn would concentrate on increasing the number of intensive care beds, which will only be achieved when the influx of trainee nurses start to enter full-time service.

Ministers, who have been horrified by the plight of high- profile flu victims, believe that the intense press coverage has blown the problem out of proportion. Mr Blair underlined this when he expressed his concern about the "dreadful case" of Mavis Skeet, whose operation for throat cancer was cancelled four times in five weeks because of bed shortages, adding that people should "retain some sense of balance".

Health pressure groups and doctors gave a cautious welcome to Mr Blair's spending plans. Dave Prentis, Unison's deputy general secretary, said: "What we have seen this winter is just the start - it won't go away just by ordering extra critical care beds. The only way in which we can overcome the problems of the NHS is if the government recognises it has to have a fundamental review of how it funds the NHS."

fields.headline: Green thumbs up
fields.standfirst: The farming crisis is forcing a radical rethink on cultivation practices. Environmentally friendly ideas are becoming money spinners
fields.trailText: As the worst rural crisis since the 1930s has deepened, some farmers are starting radically to rethink what they should grow. For years British agriculture has seemed devoted to increasing food mountains or, encouraged by European Union farm funding regimes, to set land aside to do nothing. Now there are new approaches to the problem of over-production. Some of those who till the ground are looking back to the future.
fields.body:
As the worst rural crisis since the 1930s has deepened, some farmers are starting radically to rethink what they should grow. For years British agriculture has seemed devoted to increasing food mountains or, encouraged by European Union farm funding regimes, to set land aside to do nothing. Now there are new approaches to the problem of over-production. Some of those who till the ground are looking back to the future.

In Yorkshire farmers are growing willow trees for a new generation of green power stations. In fields elsewhere they are growing hemp, once a common sight in the English countryside, for the German motor industry. In the Conwy valley, north Wales, three farmers have set up a co-operative to make money from farming the wind as well as livestock - they have won permission to install three 75-metre turbines on their land.

Government-sponsored trials are examining whether historic sources of dye such as madder, weld and woad might be grown commercially once more to supply bubble jet printers with ink. Studies are under way to see whether sheep wool might be used for insulation.

Over the past decade, there have been calls from ministers for the industry to diversify. At first, attention turned to converting unwanted barns into small factory or business units. Then the emphasis was on bed and breakfast for tourists. Now there are green initiatives such as planting woodlands, saving of moorlands, redeveloping old country skills such as dry stone walling. Belatedly, some would say, farmers are meeting growing demands for organic or at least closer-to-nature produce.

Another acorn has been planted by ministers eager to find positive routes out of the crisis. They want farmers to help create new markets for industrial crops. This has meant juggling EU payments to ensure that no one loses if they move away from a system that simply props up prices and creates wasteful surpluses.

Ultimately entrepreneurs may find a fruitful commercial future supplying fuel and raw materials for pharmaceuticals and heavy industry. The government has put just £1m a year into such developments but soon that will increase six-fold - still small beer compared to the £5bn plus annually devoted to shoring up the existing system or to the rest of the phased £1.6bn switch in funds from agriculture to wider rural development initiatives by 2007.

Yet it is a start. Farmers are being invited to be virtuous, to take part in the switch to green power generation as the government seeks to meet a target of generating 10% of electricity from renewable sources and cut greenhouse gas emissions. The first of the new power stations open soon. At Sutton, near Ely, a plant will provide power for 80,000 homes using straw from local cereal farms. Trials are under way to grow commercially miscanthus, or elephant grass, a bamboo-like plant which grow to around four metres.

In Eggborough, Yorkshire, Arbre Energy is to open a £30m plant to supply 33,500 local customers, first of all using woodchips from forestry clearing, but soon willows from coppices on local farms. The company is planning up to 10 more power stations, up to three times the size, if the experiment is a success. Between 50 and 60 suppliers have signed up to supply the first Arbre plant with willow which takes about four years to develop for a first crop, but delivers every three years after.

Elsewhere, 80 farmers are now supplying hemp, a staple that provided ropes for the navy as far back as Elizabethan times. Hemcore, based near Bishops Stortford, buys it in: its factory is seek ing to double its production this year of products ranging from cheap horse-bedding to panels for the car industry. "We have invested hundreds of thousands of pounds in all this," says director Ian Low. "It is a real goer and a terrific alternative environmentally friendly crop. You are not simply growing for a grain mountain and the more growers there are, the better it is for Great Britain plc."

There is a drawback. Farmers have to pay Jack Straw (that is to say the home office) £320 for an annual licence and allow inspectors to check the narcotic content of what is the member of the cannabis family. But hemp, say enthusiasts, is not going to get anyone high or offer any black market opportunities in that sort of drug industry.

Such initiatives are not by themselves going to immediately lift farming out of depression. But there are signs of irritation among politicians and within the wider food industry at farmers' continuing demands for taxpayers' support. Danish pig producers have bluntly told their British counterparts to quit whingeing - they risked deepening an already severe crisis by talking down everyone's products.

In response, agricultural interests are accentuating the positive. Witness the talking-up of farmers' markets, undergoing phenomenal growth (but accounting for a minuscule percentage of production). History does offer some comfort, says Joan Thirsk, a distinguished historian of British agriculture. Farming non-food crops has been the solution before. This is the fourth time that since the Black Death in the 14th century, she says, that overproduction has forced farmers to find alternative sources of income. Agricultural prosperity has been cyclical - depression lasted 150 years from the 1300s, and there were further dips for a century after the mid-17th century and for about 70 years from 1870 to 1940. The present crisis could last another 40 years.

"People only look at (non-food crops) in times of trouble. It is much more straightforward to grow mainstream crops when farming is prosperous. But these things have to be taken seriously if we are not to lose a whole generation of farmers."

webTitle: Young lose out in housing boom

fields.headline: Young lose out in housing boom
fields.standfirst: More about house prices
fields.trailText: Long-term confidence in the south-east's booming housing market has left most people fearing that home ownership will be beyond the reach of a younger generation, according to a poll published today.
fields.body:
Long-term confidence in the south-east's booming housing market has left most people fearing that home ownership will be beyond the reach of a younger generation, according to a poll published today.

The poll reinforces concerns that rapid house price inflation in the past year, which saw property prices in greater London rise by almost 30%, means young professionals are increasingly unable to afford a mortgage.

The Mori survey for the National Housing Federation and the Chartered Institute of Housing marks the launch of a national campaign - Our Homes, Our Future - to warn the government that Britain faces a housing crisis.

The poll of 2,000 people found that in the south-east 55% of people doubted that the next generation could afford a home. Even in three northern regions, where house prices rose by just over 5% last year, a large minority (45%) have the same view.

"The housing market is creating winners but also losers," said Jim Coulter, chief executive of the Housing Federation, which mainly represents publicly funded housing associations - the only agencies that are currently building lower-cost homes for rent.

"The winners are the ones lucky enough to own a home soaring in value, while the unlucky ones cannot afford a home - forcing employers to increase wages to cover housing costs. It is not surprising people are losing confidence."

The latest survey follows research by the federation which shows that people on average incomes working in London are finding it increasingly difficult to afford rented accommodation, let alone qualify for a mortgage.

The average weekly rent for a two-bedroom flat in London is £274 - more than four times the £65 a week average rent for a similar property in a city such as Leeds.

Calculating that the average price paid for a property by first time buyers is about £100,000, the federation says key workers are being frozen out of the market.

A nurse with five years experience, and earning £18,500 a year, would only qualify for a maximum mortgage of around £53,000, says the federation, while a teacher with the same length of service would earn almost £23,000. This would put a mortgage of £65,000 within reach.

Londoners earned, on average, 12% more than people in the rest of the UK, but housing costs - rents and mortgages - are "several times higher", says the federation.

Away from the region, the federation says rural areas are facing acute shortages of low-cost homes - partly because more than 100,000 council houses have been sold off under the "right to buy" scheme.

The government's countryside agency calculates that more than 62,000 new homes are needed to meet demand.

David Butler, chief executive of the Chartered Institute of Housing, which represents council housing managers, said: "Clearly the market cannot provide enough decent homes at prices people can afford. We need a strategy that provides a strong social housing sector to ensure everyone can enjoy a decent home."

webTitle: How we fell in love with the web

fields.headline: How we fell in love with the web
fields.standfirst: It's not a religion, but one in five people in Britain is a recent convert. Nobody owns it, but it's the basis of hundreds of new businesses. And it's changing the way we work, play, communicate and think. In the first of a week-long series of reports on how to make the most of the internet,  Simon Waldman  charts five years in which Britain took the leap into cyberspace
fields.trailText: It's not a religion, but one in five people in Britain is a recent convert. Nobody owns it, but it's the basis of hundreds of new businesses. And it's changing the way we work, play, communicate and think. In the first of a week-long series of reports on how to make the most of the internet,  Simon Waldman  charts five years in which Britain took the leap into cyberspace
fields.body:
There is no real road to Thong Nai Pan. The 15-mile journey to the tiny Thai resort is an hour-long roller coaster ride along a succession of dirt tracks that jars your back and leaves you praying for tarmac. When you arrive the facilities are pleasantly basic. There is no hot water and the electricity supply is somewhat unreliable. There are some beach huts, a shop and a couple of bars and basic restaurants. It would be the ideal place to get away from it all were it not for one building - a small, spartan office set 100 yards back from the beach with the sign "Internet, E-mail" outside it.

Thong Nai Pan might not have much, but it has a cybercafe. We were there earlier this month at around 8pm on a Wednesday night, sending a birthday email to my girlfriend's mother in Surrey. Next to us, Dave, from north London, was printing out some Arsenal match reports and sending a message to some friends who were travelling on another island. A German sat at another desk, checking his share portfolio.

Had someone predicted this little scene 10 years ago, it would have sounded like science fiction. Now we pretty much take it for granted. In the five years since the UK really became aware of the internet, we have witnessed change which is more radical and more mind-boggling than even the most enthusiastic of net zealots might have predicted.

The way we communicate, the way we do business, and the most fundamental issues of who gets to say what are all being transformed before our eyes. Numbers alone chart the net's remarkable growth in the UK. According to the latest survey, at the end of last year, 24% of the UK's population now regularly uses the internet; there are 11.2m users over the age of 15. That figure increased by 1.2m - the equivalent of the entire population of Birmingham - between May and November.

In 1995, when the net in the UK was the property of a small number of academics and geeks, there were only 19m users in the world. Now that global audience is over 200m. Research group IDC believes there will soon be more internet users than there are US citizens. E-commerce (the term only started to appear in 1997) was worth £2bn in the UK last year, according to Continental Research - a multi-billion-pound business that has appeared from nowhere in three years.

But these bald facts tell only part of the story of the net's impact on the UK. Statistics alone cannot convey, for example, how the simple concept of email has changed the way we communicate. Five years ago, telling someone your email address was about as easy and useful as dictating your life story in Sanskrit. Now it is more convenient and simple than swapping phone numbers.

The @ sign, which languished unloved on the keyboard for decades, has become an icon of our times. Email has dissolved the barriers of time and space that traditionally restricted communication. It works whether we are communicating with someone on the other side of the office or the other side of the planet. My emails from a Thailand cybercafe show one side of this: the phone, the fax and airmail are clumsy and expensive in comparison. It is little wonder that Hotmail has become as much a part of a traveller's life as Lonely Planet guidebooks and friendship bracelets.

Back in the office, email has created an entirely new culture of communication. It combines the permanence of a memo with the immediacy of a phone call and some of the intimacy of a face-to-face meeting. We use it to confront people we daren't confront in person. We use it to bitch about colleagues at the same time as talking or sitting opposite them. Entire business school dissertations could be written on the politics of using the "cc" and "bcc" functions (bcc allows you to send a copy of a mail to someone without revealing so to the principal recipient - a particularly devious tool). And where on earth did jokes come from before they arrived magically at our desks via email?

But email is only one way that our workplaces are changing thanks to the net. Every corner of commerce is feeling the change. Some industries, such as stockbrokers, travel agents, car dealers, music and book retailers and newspapers, find themselves facing elimination as the net threatens more and more. Boardrooms that were once full of certainty and arrogance have found themselves dithering as the internet has grown. I recently met with an old family friend, the head of a major retail chain with 30 years' experience and an impressive track record. He confessed that the net had him baffled. He was doing everything right - all the research, all the analysis, all the usual steps that had got him where he was, yet still he couldn't find a way to make it work. He eventually admitted that his sole consolation was that he would soon be retiring and be able to pass the problem on to his successor.

Even those who have long been rulers of their domain now find themselves treading uncertainly. When, last year, the Halifax had a security lapse on its site, it immediately sent out an apology email to all its online subscribers. Can anyone remember when any bank last apologised to 10,000 people about anything? E-commerce is set to change all scales of transactions, from the way a car manufacturer buys components to the way we buy our groceries. While many of the companies currently hoping to be the next Amazon will ultimately disappear - as might Amazon itself - the simple premise that we can now shop online (whether through the PC, TV or mobile phone) is with us to stay. Online transactions simply make too much economic sense to be ignored. They eliminate middlemen and cost less, which is great for those at either end, but miserable for those in the middle, which is why the likes of travel agents and stockbrokers have so much to fear.

The internet economy has also brought with it changes in working culture. While the government has introduced a working time directive and a maximum 48-hour working week, internet start-ups are desperate for a 48-hour working day in order to fulfill their ambitions. Anyone with the right ideas and abilities can start up their own company - not simply middle managers who have served their time. Share options too are now deemed a right, not a privilege.

We have also learned to network - in London, there are networking events for the internet industry pretty much every night of the week where wannabe cyber-millionaires swap business cards, quaff white wine and lager and ooze unbearable confidence. It is a most un-British way of doing things. And in our most important lesson from the US, we have seen the rise of the internet stock - Freeserve, QXL and the 365 Corporation have proved that we are just as capable as our American cousins of valuing a company that has never made a profit at hundreds of millions of pounds. Despite all this, it is not true that anyone can be a millionaire through the net. But anyone can put up a website, and this has been the third great change caused by the net. We have created a medium where anyone can be a publisher, where people can get their message across without having to rely on the scraps of space and airtime offered by traditional media.

The results are not always attractive. Violent anti-abortionists, racists and pornographers have found it as effective a medium as environmental activists and oppressed minorities. It has resulted in fraught debates about freedom of speech and censorship, but never before in history have so many different shades of belief and argument had the opportunity to promote themselves on a global scale.

At a time when the coverage of serious issues in mainstream media is increasingly glib and driven by sound bites, where the agenda is dictated by proprietors and mega-media corporations, the net is playing a vital role in democracy. It is the only place where all the voices on an issue can be examined in their undiluted form. You want to make your mind up on GM foods right now? On the net you will find the views of Monsanto, Friends of the Earth, the government and the controversial scientist Arpad Pusztai unedited.

But there are sceptics. Particularly over the past year, when we have seen the frenzied activity with internet share prices and an apparently endless stream of net millionaires being created, it has become common practice to ask: "When will the bubble burst?" The simple answer is that it won't, because this is not a bubble - a phenomenon that has popped up from nowhere for its brief moment in the spotlight before fading away as quickly as it appeared. The net has caused seismic change. It is true that much of the mayhem we currently see will eventually die down, but even when it does, the landscape will never be the same again.

We use it to bitch about colleagues at the same time as talking or sitting opposite them. Entire business school dissertations could be written on the politics of using the "cc" and "bcc" functions (bcc allows you to send a copy of a mail to someone without revealing so to the principal recipient - a particularly devious tool). And where on earth did jokes come from before they arrived magically at our desks via email? But email is only one way that our workplaces are changing thanks to the net. Every corner of commerce is feeling the change. Some industries, such as stockbrokers, travel agents, car dealers, music and book retailers and newspapers, find themselves facing elimination as the net threatens more and more. Boardrooms that were once full of certainty and arrogance have found themselves dithering as the internet has grown. I recently met with an old family friend, the head of a major retail chain with 30 years' experience and an impressive track record. He confessed that the net had him baffled. He was doing everything right - all the research, all the analysis, all the usual steps that had got him where he was, yet still he couldn't find a way to make it work. He eventually admitted that his sole consolation was that he would soon be retiring and be able to pass the problem on to his successor. Even those who have long been rulers of their domain now find themselves treading uncertainly. When, last year, the Halifax had a security lapse on its site, it immediately sent out an apology email to all its online subscribers. Can anyone remember when any bank last apologised to 10,000 people about anything? E-commerce is set to change all scales of transactions, from the way a car manufacturer buys components to the way we buy our groceries. While many of the companies currently hoping to be the next Amazon will ultimately disappear - as might Amazon itself - the simple premise that we can now shop online (whether through the PC, TV or mobile phone) is with us to stay. Online transactions simply make too much economic sense to be ignored. They eliminate middlemen and cost less, which is great for those at either end, but miserable for those in the middle, which is why the likes of travel agents and stockbrokers have so much to fear. The internet economy has also brought with it changes in working culture. While the government has introduced a working time directive and a maximum 48-hour working week, internet start-ups are desperate for a 48-hour working day in order to fulfill their ambitions. Anyone with the right ideas and abilities can start up their own company - not simply middle managers who have served their time. Share options too are now deemed a right, not a privilege. We have also learned to network - in London, there are networking events for the internet industry pretty much every night of the week where wannabe cyber-millionaires swap business cards, quaff white wine and lager and ooze unbearable confidence. It is a most un-British way of doing things. And in our most important lesson from the US, we have seen the rise of the internet stock - Freeserve, QXL and the 365 Corporation have proved that we are just as capable as our American cousins of valuing a company that has never made a profit at hundreds of millions of pounds. Despite all this, it is not true that anyone can be a millionaire through the net. But anyone can put up a website, and this has been the third great change caused by the net. We have created a medium where anyone can be a publisher, where people can get their message across without having to rely on the scraps of space and airtime offered by traditional media. The results are not always attractive. Violent anti-abortionists, racists and pornographers have found it as effective a medium as environmental activists and oppressed minorities. It has resulted in fraught debates about freedom of speech and censorship, but never before in history have so many different shades of belief and argument had the opportunity to promote themselves on a global scale. At a time when the coverage of serious issues in mainstream media is increasingly glib and driven by sound bites, where the agenda is dictated by proprietors and mega-media corporations, the net is playing a vital role in democracy. It is the only place where all the voices on an issue can be examined in their undiluted form. You want to make your mind up on GM foods right now? On the net you will find the views of Monsanto, Friends of the Earth, the government and the controversial scientist Arpad Pusztai unedited. But there are sceptics. Particularly over the past year, when we have seen the frenzied activity with internet share prices and an apparently endless stream of net millionaires being created, it has become common practice to ask: "When will the bubble burst?" The simple answer is that it won't, because this is not a bubble - a phenomenon that has popped up from nowhere for its brief moment in the spotlight before fading away as quickly as it appeared. The net has caused seismic change. It is true that much of the mayhem we currently see will eventually die down, but even when it does, the landscape will never be the same again.

fields.headline: The time of your life
fields.standfirst: Too much to do and not enough time to do it? Time-famine has become one   of the greatest stresses of modern life, with serious implications for our health,   realtionships and wellbeing. Here's how to beat it.
fields.trailText:
Too much to do and not enough time to do it? Time-famine has become one 
of the greatest stresses of modern life, with serious implications for our health, 
realtionships and wellbeing. Here's how to beat it.
fields.body:
Remember when the usual answer to 'How are you?' was 'Fine'? Now, the reply most often given, by everybody, is 'Frantic'. If there is one experience we all share at the beginning of the 21st century, it's the desperate feeling that there's never enough time. We schedule time in ever smaller chunks - 10-minute slots for meetings, five-minute slots for cooking an evening meal (just check out the number of Meals In Minutes cookbooks on any bookshelf), one-minute slots for reading a child a bedtime story Multi-tasking, originally a way to make more efficient use of time, has become another pressure. Doing just one thing at a time is a positive indulgence, so we work on the train, feed the baby while we talk on the phone, have a sandwich at our desks, and do sit-ups in front of the TV.

Dr Donald Wetmore is a time-management guru at Connecticut's Productivity Institute. It's a single decade, he says, that has taken us from 'fine' to 'frantic'. 'Between 1982 and 1989 I taught 600 people time-management courses at the Institute. From 1989 to now, that number rose to 30,000.' And it's no good hoping the next 10 years will be easier as technology finally frees us all from our frenzied existence. 'Innovations don't eradicate previous methods. They simply add other layers of responsibility to our lives.'

How much more can we take? Is it possible to keep up in a speeded-up world without giving up our private lives and personal passions? Actually, yes. Most time-management advice tends to be mechanistic - little tips to help you save half an hour here or there. They can be useful, but they won't do any good if you don't start by examining your own attitude to time, and your own core values. In his book Faster: The Acceleration of Just About Everything, James Gleick coins the term 'hurry sickness' to describe this modern malaise. He points out that although we may be desperate to step off the treadmill, it's also true that we thrive on the speed and adrenaline of modern life. Conditioned to expect it as given, we crave more, but at a price. 'A minute!', barks stressed-out Everyman Homer Simpson at his tub of popcorn. 'Isn't there anything faster than a microwave?!' If you're really ready to begin taking your time back, the strategies below can help. Many of the principles governing effective life balancing and time management are commonsense. Yet how many of these simple axioms do you currently apply to your own time? The answers lie in being honest and proactive, rather than reactive, to the way we see and spend our time. And underpinning them all is the message that your time, like your life, is what you make it.

General
Dr Wetmore recommends that you start with the basics. 'Take a few minutes to plan your day in advance. Very few people actually do this, although they may make long lists of all the things they want to get done, it's not the same as a realistic plan of what you will do, and how and when you will do it. This can dramatically improve your effectiveness and cut down on wasted effort.' Look at your position at work as just that - a position, not a 'job'. A position from which you can attend to your needs on three levels - social, financial and professional. Keep interruptions to a minimum. 'My phones don't take calls, they take messages,' says John Naisbitt, author of High Tech/High Touch. 'How can I find time for my own agenda when everyone's trying to make me a part of theirs?' One of the best and most powerful ways to take back time and reduce your stress levels, according to Dr Wetmore, is to maintain good relationships with others: 'an often overlooked but uniquely effective method of minimising stress, staying happy and reducing the amount of time wasted on counter-productivity'.

Balance/Technology
Technology was supposed to free us from time-famine, cutting our workloads, making our lives more flexible, and giving us back time and space to spend on ourselves. Often, it's had the opposite effect. According to Dr Wetmore, 'Five years ago it was assumed that e-mail would make postal communication redundant. Last year, the highest number of e-mails ever were sent, and the highest number of letters too.' Learning to balance the pros and cons of the digital age is vital for achieving control over our own time. John Naisbitt, Nana Naisbitt and Douglas Philips, authors of High Tech/High Touch, offer their advice.

Don't dismiss technology - or take it for granted. It's important to recognise that technology isn't just simply there for good or ill - technology, in this particular instance, meaning consumer technology. It's in no way neutral. You have to appreciate and address the fact that you have a relationship with it. Examine that relationship thoroughly and ask yourself what you really need from technology and what you can do without. Very few people do this. Technophobes pass over its many potential benefits and the rest are seduced on to the endless slope of one upgrade to another without ever really thinking why.

Identify the consequences of technology. What you are being sold when you buy into technology is a promise that things will be easier, faster and better. We often look at technology as a toy, but behind its promise lie unspoken consequences. Not least of these is the way technology shapes our sense of time. The speed of response it now requires from us has contributed to the desire for instant gratification.

We need to lose both our awe and our fear of technology, and see it with clear eyes. With a conscious approach, its true benefits and deficits become apparent. It's possible to estimate how we might apply it constructively in the future. And if you can see where it's going, it gives you much less to feel anxious about in the present.

Time at Work
Recognise your personal energy levels. According to Jaqueline Atkinson, author of Better Time Management, time management and energy management are essentially the same thing. If you are tired and stressed, stop. 'Identify your personal energy levels. Be realistic about how much you can do. Resolve to work only as long as that permits. You may have to ask yourself, do I want this job, or my health and family?'

Be realistic in defining yourself. Atkinson likes to tell what she calls 'a true, cautionary tale. A small business owner's marriage and health were dissolving. His bank manager suggested he pay himself less and hire an employee. He refused, because he defined himself by what he earned. If you realise work is most important to you, acknowledge it, at least to yourself, if not necessarily to your family or partner.'

Be realistic in your expectations. Most psychological pressures in the workplace come from unmet expectations, says Dr Wetmore. 'Many small disappointments grow into one big one. Lowering your expectations - to real rather than low levels - allows you to focus much better on the reality of what you can achieve.'

Aim for an appreciation of working processes, not just results. '"You are what you achieve" isn't necessarily true but still hangs over from the 1980s when it was paramount,' says Atkinson. 'Don't ask yourself relentlessly "what have I achieved?", but "did I enjoy the process of doing it? Did I learn from it?" This alleviates guilt and anxiety over work. A positive approach to processes produces a higher standard of work, more quickly than focusing only on the end result.'

Tailor the quality of your work to the time available. 'Perfectionists balk when told, "make it good enough,"' admits Jaqueline Atkinson. 'Yet PC printers offer "fast", "good" and "best" options. Why? Because excellence is not a prerequisite for all tasks. Realise that good enough is still good, increasing productivity and free time for other tasks.'

Time at home
Soporific pursuits can bring you down still further. Slumping in front of the TV (or doing similar pursuits that aren't really satisfying) creates lots of 'dead time' and usually ends up making you feel more tired - and just as time-pressured - as before. Is it such a good idea for a stressed, tired person to subject themselves to the evening news? Many time-management experts identify 'vegging out' with the TV as a major cause of lost time, fatigue and dissatisfaction. Atkinson recommends that you simply use a VCR and set aside specific time to watch what you really want in a block. Or put the TV away in a cupboard, so you have to make a conscious effort to get it out.

Satisfy your inner needs It's easy to let the thoughts and effects of work overbalance into home time. At the end of the day take an opportunity to buy back time for yourself, says Atkinson. 'It's a shame that the term "hobby" has such nerdy connotations. It's extremely unlikely that work gives you what you need to satisfy your innermost requirements, so having an occupation that does is a prerequisite for achieving that balance. When people ask me why I enjoy patchwork I tell them simply, "because of the juxtaposition of colours".'

Sorry, you still have to vacuum the carpet. Wilfully managing your time allows you to do a great deal more with your life. Sadly, this doesn't translate into no longer having to do the housework. 'We all have routine tasks and responsibilities to attend to,' says Atkinson. 'But if you've accepted that pre-planning is essential, it's easier for you to recognise the optimum time for attending to the nuts and bolts of home life. Understand that it's the accumulation of small daily victories that enhance our sense of self-worth. Be self-disciplined, do the work at a pre- governed time, and you'll find that beating the housework counts among them.'

Time alone/relaxation
For so many of us, time alone is either a luxury we can't afford or something we fear and try to avoid at all costs. Either way, we almost never get time completely to ourselves. And yet it can be an enormously powerful way to get back a feeling of owning your own time, destressing and balancing the pace of your life.

'There's no set requirement or method for spending rewarding time alone,' Atkinson says. 'A person's basic need for time alone is based on the individual's need for stimulation. The trick is to relax properly, not necessarily just do nothing.'

You can do so at any time with meditative and relaxation techniques that can be put to good use in just a few moments, even if you don't have the time or inclination to keep your own company. Psychotherapist Sue Vaughan includes this Yogic breathing exercise for 'when your head feels muzzy and your nerves are jangled' in her book Finding the Stillness Within in a Busy World. Try it at your desk. Ignore any sideways glances.

Alternate Nostril Breathing Exercise. Sit with your back straight, with your neck and head in a straight line. Shoulders slightly back but relaxed. Breathe steadily and easily. Try to get the incoming and outgoing breaths the same length. Observe the natural rhythm of your breathing. Now press the left nostril closed with your thumb and inhale through your right nostril. Remove your thumb and close your right nostril with your forefinger and exhale through your left nostril. Without changing fingers, inhale through your left nostril. Change fingers, exhale through the right. Inhale through the right and exhale through the left, and so on.

Feel the fear and do it anyway
What if you recognise the need for personal space and to relax but are uncomfortable with the idea of being alone? The fear of loneliness manifests itself in many ways. According to Vaughan, 'There is a constructive and destructive side to the fear of loneliness. Unexpressed, it can flow into behaviours designed to avoid rather than release it. The constructive side to loneliness can be that it serves as the impetus and motivation to look within for your inner resources; to find the stillness in the whirlpool.' It can be overcome, she says, by making friends with yourself. Stop criticising and belittling yourself. Treat yourself kindly and politely as you would another, and recognise that flaws of character and making mistakes are normal. 'The lesson that loneliness can teach us is that when it occurs in our lives, we have the opportunity of looking within. It is then that we can discover all the resources we need. We can become our own person, aware of the strength as well as the peace and serenity we hold within ourselves.'

webTitle: Rivalry that dare not speak its name

fields.headline: Rivalry that dare not speak its name
fields.standfirst: Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland try to face each other down
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland try to face each other down
fields.body:
In a traditional battle, Bank of Scotland would have the clear advantage. The 300-year-old institution sits proud above Edinburgh, looking down on its Royal Bank of Scotland rival.

But this is no ordinary war and BoS's location, perched uphill aside Edinburgh's imposing castle, counts for little.

The war has already entered corporate folklore. By launching bids for NatWest, BoS and the Royal Bank have shaken the staid banking world, broken unspoken rules about hostile bids and, more crucially, rocked their own tight-knit community to the core.

They have shattered a common perception that the Scottish banks were protected from unwanted takeovers on political, nationalistic grounds and the two have, for the first time, turned on each other.

"It cannot be in Scotland's interest for two major public institutions to fight in public," one Royal Bank shareholder told last week's extraordinary general meeting to back its bid for NatWest.

It is from its headquarters in that splendid pile up on the Mound that the BoS plotted its audacious attack on NatWest, an English opponent twice its size.

Peter Burt, the shy yet ambitious chief executive of the BoS, had the advantage in firing the first shot in the battle. But he and his righthand man, Gavin Masterton - the life-long banker whom BoS believes should run NatWest - are now on dangerous ground, locked in battle on a second front, where the Royal Bank of Scotland is fighting hard and fast.

While the two Scottish banks have long pitched for business against each other, their battles have, until now, been in private and they maintained a public image of healthy yet friendly rivalry.

Their furious fight for NatWest has changed that; Mr Burt is engaged in almost daily shots against Sir George Mathewson, his counterpart at the Royal Bank, and Fred Goodwin, the Royal Bank's youthful deputy chief executive, rather than NatWest, the original target of his venom.

All the talk in Edinburgh's financial community, now that the initial euphoria about the brave and audacious Scottish banks has died down, is how they will restore their relationship after the Valentine's Day deadline in the battle.

Such is the level of sensitivity that senior financiers in the Scottish capital are reluctant to speak publicly.

For instance, one senior fund manager whispered last week that his top management had warned him to keep his opinions on the battle to himself.

Privately, though, the gloves are off.

"People find it (the personal attacks) distasteful," one senior figure in the Edinburgh financial scene said last week. "This sort of thing has never happened before. Their position had always been never to fight in public," another Scot said.

The men at the top of the Scottish banks insist that this is a myth. Royal Bank's Sir George laughed off the notion that he and his rivals at BoS hung around, all friends together, in Edinburgh's stylish New Club, avoiding competition with another. He insisted that the two banks have cooperated on major projects in the past and have continued to do so while the battle for NatWest has raged.

Try as they might, though, many in Edinburgh find it hard to believe their protestations that life will return to normal on February 15.

For a start, the personal stakes are high for the men who have fought the battle. One of them could be running one of Europe's biggest banks in four weeks' time - if NatWest does not escape their clutches altogether. One of them will be deflated, defeated and dogged by speculation that his bank is vulnerable to a similar hostile bid.

"There has to be a big question mark about them remaining independent," one senior banker said.

"During the battle, both have revealed so much of their hands," another said, wondering whether this would make life easier for a predator.

But both insist they will not be vulnerable to attack after Valentine's Day if they prove to be on the losing side. If both lose, they will feel safe in the belief that the market is not ready for such a major takeover to take place. If only one fails - the smart money is currently backing Royal Bank over BoS - the rise in the losers' share price on takeover speculation could make it difficult for any predator to strike.

Yet the concerns, in private, that the Scottish banks could themselves become prey were so great that this fuelled rumours earlier in the battle that Sir George at the Royal Bank was being pressured by the "financial community" not to launch a counter bid for NatWest, to prevent such a scenario.

Others also dispute the idea the fight is bad for Scotland and the banking sector.

webTitle: Scots set to backtrack on student fees

fields.headline: Scots set to backtrack on student fees
fields.standfirst: Labour and Lib Dems prepare to dilute plan to abolish charges
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive is preparing to water down plans to abolish university tuition fees. The move comes amid fears that the package of student-friendly measures proposed last month by a committee of inquiry under Andrew Cubie would produce huge political difficulties in Westminster and Brussels.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive is preparing to water down plans to abolish university tuition fees. The move comes amid fears that the package of student-friendly measures proposed last month by a committee of inquiry under Andrew Cubie would produce huge political difficulties in Westminster and Brussels.

The Cubie committee said tuition fees were discredited and called for them to be replaced by a Scottish graduate endowment scheme, whereby the fees would be publicly funded and students would not be required to pay them back until they were earning at least £25,000 a year.

It also recommended bursaries of up to £4,100 for students from poor families living away from home - similar to the maintenance grant abolished by the government when fees were introduced in 1998.

The package would have cost £71m a year, but it is understood that Labour executive members are negotiating with their Liberal Democrat coalition partners to cut that by half.

Although English ministers insist they are not meddling in devolved Scottish business, they are extremely nervous about political and legal pressures that could force them to offer a similar deal to students from England, Wales and Northern Ireland at an annual cost of more than £700m.

"To find resources on that scale, we would have to take money from other parts of the education service. That would be political dynamite," one minister said last night.

It is understood that David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, would be glad to get treasury approval for better maintenance for mature students and incentives for those from poor families and schools with a low take-up of university places. But he would be reluctant to follow Scotland's lead on fees, even if the cost were half what the Cubie committee envisaged.

Government lawyers have not resolved whether it would be legal under EU law for Scottish and EU students to get a better deal than those from England, Wales and Northern Ireland, as the Cubie committee recommended.

Mr Blunkett asked for legal advice, but his lawyers said they could not give a definitive ruling until they knew which of the many possible reform permutations would be chosen by the Scottish executive.

Two years ago the government exempted Scottish and EU students from tuition fees in the fourth year of an undergraduate course.

Ministers said this did not discriminate under EU law against English, Welsh and Northern Irish students who did not get the exemption because most Scottish students left school a year earlier and deserved an extra 12 months of public funding.

But even if a different Scottish funding regime were legally watertight, there were signs yesterday from normally loyal Labour MPs that it might be politically unsustainable.

Jim Cousins, the Labour MP for Newcastle upon Tyne Central and member of the treasury select committee, said students and their families throughout the UK would find the Cubie proposals attractive.

"What will worry people is why we aren't having them across the UK as a whole. Of course it's a big political problem - it's a big political problem for English, Welsh and Irish MPs, who will have the difficulty of explaining why students from their areas don't have the same funding system that Scottish students have.

"It's a double problem because most of us think the Scottish proposals are really good and take the whole discussion about student finance forward in a very sensible and creative way," he told the BBC's On the Record.

The treasury would face pressure to come up with the cash to fund similar reforms in the rest of the UK. "It's a bit hard for Gordon Brown, as a Scots MP himself, whose constituents are going to benefit from these excellent proposals, to say to the rest of us that we can't have them because there's no money," Mr Cousins said.

On the same programme, Mr Cubie said he hoped the Westminster government would examine some of his committee's proposals.

"I would hope, given that the wider community in Scotland has welcomed our report, that some of that may echo across the border," he said.

fields.headline: The best briefing scene
fields.standfirst: Sleepy Hollow
fields.trailText: Constable Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) has been seconded to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a spate of particularly bloody murders.
fields.body:
Constable Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) has been seconded to Sleepy Hollow to investigate a spate of particularly bloody murders.

The local elders sip tea in the drawing room of town leader Baltus Van Tassel (Michael Gambon), while Crane paces the floor, firing off questions.

"Three persons murdered", he asserts. "First Peter Van Garrett, then his son Dirk Van Garrett. Both of them strong, capable men found together..."

He pauses for dramatic effect. Then, enunciating every syllable, turns to Van Tassel before completing his sentence, "...de-cap-i-tated."

After a beat, he continues:

"One week later the Widow Winship, also decapitated."

He faces the room: "Now I will need to ask you many questions. But first let me ask - is anyone suspected?"

At this point, one of the men chokes on his tea. With a scornful laugh, Van Tassel catches Crane's eye.

"How much have your superiors explained to you, constable?"

"Only that the three were slain in open ground, their heads found severed from their bodies."

At this point the Reverend Steenwyck (Jeffrey Jones) stares directly at Crane.

"Their heads were not found severed. Their heads were not found at all."

See also: Seven, In The Heat Of The Night

Don't see also: Money Talks

Pointless trivia: Having co-starred with him in John Waters' Cry Baby, onetime porn star Traci Lords said of Johnny Depp that he was "the kind of guy that would be really sweet to a girl and bring her flowers, but still take a pee in the alley".

webTitle: Trains to the camps were 'well provisioned', says Irving

fields.headline: Trains to the camps were 'well provisioned', says Irving
fields.trailText: The image of the Holocaust is dented by the fact that trains carrying Jews to concentration camps were "well provisioned", the alleged Nazi apologist David Irving said today.
fields.body:
The image of the Holocaust is dented by the fact that trains carrying Jews to concentration camps were "well provisioned", the alleged Nazi apologist David Irving said today.

A telegram message about a transportation of 944 Jews from Berlin to Lithuania on November 17 1941, decoded by British intelligence at Bletchley Park, Bucks, showed that there was 24 days' worth of food on board for the three-day journey, said the historian.

His remarks came as part of the high court case he initiated against American academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books for libel over claims that he is a "Holocaust denier".

"It's a bit of a dent, a tiny dent in the image we have of the Holocaust today," the 62-year-old author of Hitler's War told the London court.

It went against the accepted image of victims being stuffed into cattle trucks and shipped across Europe with no food or water, to arrive half dead at the other end, he said.

In fact, intercepted messages indicated that the trains were equipped with a "very substantial amount of food" to keep the Jews going for three weeks after their arrival, he added.

Mr Irving says that Ms Lipstadt's 1994 book Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory alleges he has distorted statistics and documents to serve his own ideological purposes and reach historically untenable conclusions. He says it has generated "waves of hatred against him".

Cross-examining Mr Irving, Richard Rampton, QC for Prof Lipstadt and Penguin, said he was concerned with the historian's "readiness to leap to conclusions in favour of the SS and the Nazis". Mr Irving told Mr Justice Gray, who is hearing the case without a jury, that he "strongly objected" to the suggestion.

"Here's a British intercept of a SS telegram which has not been quoted by any of your (Rampton's) experts because it doesn't fit into the picture that they are trying to create."

It was, he said, a "subtly different picture of how this deportation programme was carried out - brutal and cruel though it was".

Mr Rampton said that far from it being a "dent in Holocaust perception", it was quite possible that the food had been paid for by the Jews on the shipment.

Mr Irving agreed that it was quite probable because the Jews kicked out of Berlin were "robbed blind".

He said that he did not doubt that there was a "lot of hardship and cruelty and barbarism", but he questioned the impartiality of experts for the defence who he said had paid no attention to these documents which "go against the notion that it was a systematic programme to exterminate Jews".

Mr Rampton showed the court a report which said that 2,934 Jewish evacuees from Berlin and other cities, including women and children, were shot in the east on November 25 1941.

Mr Irving said "it was not impossible" that the trainload of Jews in the message ended up "in that atrocity".

He agreed that up to 1.5m Jews were shot in the east, but denied that they were "part of the system".

"The system ended when the train arrived. The system put the victims on the trains and sent them to the east with food and equipment to start a new life.

"Once they arrived on the spot, the system broke down and the murderers stepped in," he said.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Right-back, Right-on and Write-off
fields.trailText: BABBELING ON
fields.body:
BABBELING ON

The Fiver loves nothing more than a tiresome transfer saga which starts out tediously and doesn't really improve with age. So imagine how upset we were when Markus Babbel, whom Liverpool have been chasing since the Shankly era, signed for the Reds today on the Bosman ruling. The Bayern Munich defender, who can play at centre or right-back, will move to Anfield in the summer on a free transfer, where he will earn £23,000 per week for four years.

"It is a dream for me to sign for Liverpool," said the charming 27-year-old German international, who then spoiled the effect by adding, "because I have wanted to play in the Premiership for many years. I have nearly joined Manchester United and Newcastle in the past. But I have followed the fortunes of Liverpool for many years."

Gerard Houllier sounded a bit happier. "He is a full international with plenty of experience who will add strength to our defence!" he exclaimed, his bulbous eyes nearly falling out of their sockets. "He can play right-back or in the centre of defence!" continued the Liverpool boss in the style of an advertising copywriter.

With the Babbel deal done, the Fiver has one less dull tale to trot out whenever things get a bit quiet. What are we to do now? How about Houllier's efforts to find a club prepared to part with cash for Phil Babb? That one should run for a while.

THE BIRD AND THE BEAK

You can't get away with anything nowadays. Ben Thatcher thought that by running right next to Nicky Summerbee and waggling about a bit he would disguise his magnificent flying elbow. But to no avail: the Wimbledon defender got a two match ban. On Saturday, Paulo Di Canio thought a sneaky one-fingered salute to travelling Aston Villa fans would never be spotted if he did it behind his back. After seeing his digit plastered all over this morning's papers, he may have changed his mind.

Di Canio could simply have been signalling how many certified sitters Paolo Wanchope had missed at Upton Park that day (in which case he should have flicked a V). But the FA are likely to accuse the Italian of an infringement of rule 26, a10 (that's 'bringing the game into disrepute' to you and me) if his roving hands make it into referee Graham Poll's match report. The report should arrive at Lancaster Gate on Wednesday, so get there before 9am, Paulo, and there's a chance of nicking off with the postie's bag.

The likelihood of action against Di Canio raises concern over wider disciplinary issues. If the 31-year-old is punished for his indiscretion, what kind of an example does it set for kids around the country? Will the bird, cunningly disguised as a rub of the eye, become a thing of the past? Will practitioners of 'camouflage' (sticking up your three middle fingers and waggling them about) become social pariahs? A nation holds its breath.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I think we have done enough pioneering for the time being." - So that's what it's called. Money Martin Edwards rejecting claims that Manchester United are ready to join a European Super League.

ROBSON IS GOOD MANAGER - ROBSON

Beleaguered Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson received public support today, when Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson told Boro fans not to worry about Robson's increasingly inept performances. "It's really important we don't panic," Robson said after fans had turned on Robson during Boro's 4-1 home defeat by relegation-threatened Derby.

Robson defended the widely-ridiculed Robson in front of an audience of Teessiders who were screaming, tearing their hair out and running around like something out of Dante's Peak starring Pierce Brosnan. "The expectations were high at the club at the start of the season," said Robson as the soap box on which he was standing collapsed, "but we've brought that to the club and that's what I want around the club."

As army and navy rescue teams arrived at the scene, Robson fully backed Robson's plan for Premiership success. "The way we've been playing there's a realistic chance of us getting dragged into the relegation zone if we don't do something about it," said Robson, adding, "Let's see where we finish at the end of the season and then people can judge me." At this point Robson's three-quarter length leather overcoat caught fire and the meeting was adjourned.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Wimbledon goalkeeper Neil Sullivan looks likely to sign for Arsenal on a free transfer this summer. Meanwhile occasional Gunners defender Nelson Vivas could join Spanish side Celta Vigo on loan until the end of the season.

Both West Ham and Sunderland have been linked with a move for Torino's French defender Djibril Diawara, who is out of favour with the Serie A side.

Dundee United want Aberdeen striker Jim Hamilton. Hamilton is interested in the move.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Arsenal have been labelled 'irresponsible' by the Nigerian FA after the Gunners requested that Kanu return to London in between African Nations Cup matches. "There's just no way we are going to release Kanu for any Arsenal game until after the championship," said NFA chairman Anthony Williams "Once Kanu is in the Eagles' camp, he stays in camp."

Fifa vice-president David Will has conceded that a European league featuring several Scottish clubs is likely to be up and running in three years' time. But he warned that any would-be participants risk being ejected from Uefa and Fifa. "Nobody can stop them going their own way and forming their own league," said Will. "I'm not saying there will not be an Atlantic League. But it must be done through the proper channels, and Uefa must be approached first and then Fifa."

Leeds have completed the signing of Australia's Under-23 international goalkeeper Danny Milosevic.

Leicester striker Ian Marshall will be out for up to a month with a torn hamstring.

Shaun Teale wants to quit Motherwell after discovering he will not be offered a new contract.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (12.35am)
This is on so late that only students are still awake to watch it. And they're too Mo Mowlam-ed to know what's going on.

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 3.45am)
Religious programming from Sky Television which graphically explains where you'll end up if you murder someone or covet your neighbour's ox.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 7pm, 11pm SS1)
Steve Sedgley can't get his copy of Finnegan's Wake back off Andy Sinton. This, he argues, is testament to the power of James Joyce's final statement.

Eurosport: Eurogoals (10pm)
Goals from the home of Archie MacPherson, Angus Loughran and other improbably-monickered bad commentators.

talkSPORT: It's Just Like Watching Brazil (7pm)
What is? Listening to Alan Brazil on the radio? And that's just like watching Brazil, the international football team, is it? Don't be so bloody stupid.
