Will practitioners of 'camouflage' (sticking up your three middle fingers and waggling them about) become social pariahs? A nation holds its breath. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I think we have done enough pioneering for the time being." - So that's what it's called. Money Martin Edwards rejecting claims that Manchester United are ready to join a European Super League. ROBSON IS GOOD MANAGER - ROBSON Beleaguered Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson received public support today, when Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson told Boro fans not to worry about Robson's increasingly inept performances. "It's really important we don't panic," Robson said after fans had turned on Robson during Boro's 4-1 home defeat by relegation-threatened Derby. Robson defended the widely-ridiculed Robson in front of an audience of Teessiders who were screaming, tearing their hair out and running around like something out of Dante's Peak starring Pierce Brosnan. "The expectations were high at the club at the start of the season," said Robson as the soap box on which he was standing collapsed, "but we've brought that to the club and that's what I want around the club." As army and navy rescue teams arrived at the scene, Robson fully backed Robson's plan for Premiership success. "The way we've been playing there's a realistic chance of us getting dragged into the relegation zone if we don't do something about it," said Robson, adding, "Let's see where we finish at the end of the season and then people can judge me." Hamilton is interested in the move. Shaun Teale wants to quit Motherwell after discovering he will not be offered a new contract. Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 3.45am) Religious programming from Sky Television which graphically explains where you'll end up if you murder someone or covet your neighbour's ox. Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 7pm, 11pm SS1) Steve Sedgley can't get his copy of Finnegan's Wake back off Andy Sinton. This, he argues, is testament to the power of James Joyce's final statement. Eurosport: Eurogoals (10pm) Goals from the home of Archie MacPherson, Angus Loughran and other improbably-monickered bad commentators. talkSPORT: It's Just Like Watching Brazil (7pm) What is? Listening to Alan Brazil on the radio? And that's just like watching Brazil, the international football team, is it? Don't be so bloody stupid.

fields.headline: The low down
fields.standfirst: Job turnover
fields.trailText: Job turnover
fields.body:
One of the signs of a healthy job market is a high turnover. Secretarial job turnover has been steadily rising since 1996. And in 1998 (the latest year for which figures are available) more than a fifth of secretaries voted with their feet.

This is an expensive problem for employers: replacing a secretary can cost £1,400-£3,000. It is also frustrating because it is never easy to discover exactly why people leave. Obvious factors such as job satisfaction do not necessarily influence behaviour as clearly as we might expect. Some employees spend years drafting resignation letters but never quit; others are all smiles one day and gone the next.

It does not help that turnover is an elusive subject. Compiling raw data takes a long time, and any picture is broad brush. Mass movement is a useful indicator of wider trends, but it can be more relevant to know how the economy affects individual behaviour.

Help in understanding turnover has come from, of all places, Taiwan. The country has a traditional surge in job turnover around the Chinese new year, which made it a good case study for Eamonn Ferguson, a senior lecturer in psychology at Nottingham university. He conducted a study of people on the point of resignation and concluded that the best way to find out if someone is going to leave is to ask them. This may sound obvious, but with so many influences in play - job satisfaction, wages, market insecurity - it is useful to have some meaty qualitative research.

He found that the awkward squad who threaten to leave but don't, and those who bolt out of the blue, have a lot in common. They tend to be young (or not long into their careers). But the threateners tend to be in big companies, the bolters in small firms. Sometimes even perverse behaviour is predictable.

fields.headline: Don't upset the rabbit
fields.standfirst: How can journalists maintain their integrity when they are managed by companies that own everything from news magazines to cartoon characters? Julian Borger  reports on the darker side of the AOL/Time Warner merger
fields.trailText: Synergy has been the buzzword of the week. The marriage between Time Warner and America Online was said to be full of it - synergy between the old media of solid newspaper journalism and glamorous celluloid films combined with the new media of the world wide web.
fields.body:
Synergy has been the buzzword of the week. The marriage between Time Warner and America Online was said to be full of it - synergy between the old media of solid newspaper journalism and glamorous celluloid films combined with the new media of the world wide web.

The breathless coverage of the merger marvelled at its enormity - the biggest of all time, worth up to $180bn, "bigger than Mexico" [its economy, that is]. Its very mind-boggling vastness, most reports suggested, would open doors to a new world in which everyone would benefit.

Consumers would have a vast array of choice at their fingertips, cyber-surfing effortlessly between their favourite Warner movies and the latest news on CNN.com, picking up their AOL messages (You've Got Mail!) along the way, before browsing through online articles from Time, Fortune or Sports Illustrated, or watching Bugs Bunny cartoons.

The upbeat visionary mood was stoked by the frequent television appearances by the two leading protagonists, AOL's youthful Steve Case and Time Warner's casually dressed Gerald Levin, hugging and dancing and joking together.

But as the sheer surprise of the news begins to wear off, darker questions have arisen about what the corporate mega-merger means, not just for consumers, but also for readers and citizens. For example, is the new synergy really just old-fashioned cross-promotion? Will it amount to anything more than Time magazine and CNN pumping out worshipful reportage on AOL, with AOL returning the favour by playing Peter Pan to tens of millions of internet users, leading them down a familiar path to Time magazine, CNN and Warner movies?

In this world of relentless mutual reinforcement, what will happen to the anarchic explosion of diverse opinions and choice that the internet was supposed to make possible? What will be the future of journalistic integrity in a world where newspapers, magazines, television news channels and cartoon characters are all part of the same sprawling corporate monolith?

That was a question that revealed itself in the starkest terms last Monday morning when Marc Gunther, the media correspondent of Fortune (owned by Time Warner), was due to interview the AOL chairman and his colleagues for a story provisionally entitled: "Steve Case Wants to Take Over the World". At 6am, an AOL executive rang to tell Gunther that the interview was off. "We're buying your company," she said. Gunther still plans to write the story, only now, he jokes, it will be retitled: "Steve Case has Taken Over the World".

For US media watchers it's no joke. Robert McChesney, a communications professor at the university of Illinois, warned that "the traditional autonomy of journalism that existed arguably from the 1940s and 1950s to the 1980s has come under sustained attack".

It is hard to argue that there has ever been a "golden age" for journalistic independence. Newspaper advertisers have always tried to wield their economic muscle. According to Mark Crispin Miller, the director of the Project on Media Ownership at New York university, medical evidence unearthed in 1935 about the dangers of smoking was suppressed for decades in the mainstream press because the tobacco companies were the biggest advertisers in the newspaper business.

"It's the same old problem now, only it's infinitely worse," says Miller. "Reporters have to be careful not merely about offending some group of local advertisers, they have to be aware of a whole range of corporations, including the one that owns the newspaper or network or television station they work for.

"As these media corporations have grown they have got much closer to the government, and their political influence is decisive. There really isn't anything like the same amount of relative independence that the big media had 20 years ago."

There is no doubt about the increasing concentration of ownership in the media world, with a series of increasingly gargantuan mergers. Four years ago, Warner swallowed Time, then last year the US broadcaster CBS was bought by Viacom (which in turn owns MTV and the publishers Simon & Schuster). Now AOL's acquisition of Time Warner dwarfs them all. More media mergers are rumoured to be on the way, as the other big players seek some old-new media synergy of their own.

George Vradenburg, AOL's vice-president for global and strategic policy, insisted that Time and CNN "will have the same degree of independence that they have today. They're permitted to report as they see fit."

Time's managing editor, Walter Isaacson, offered a gruff assurance: "We have a long history of covering these things and we do it with journalistic integrity and we damn well plan to keep doing it that way. We have a lot of practice."

In Britain, long accustomed to Rupert Murdoch's dominant media role and the constant plugging of BSkyB in his newspapers, such avowals of media independence would be greeted with snorts of cynicism. But in the US they are treated more seriously.

"The brazen way Murdoch meddles with journalism in Britain wouldn't happen here," says Gunther of Fortune. He insists that although he writes constantly about Time Warner and its competitors, his corporate masters have not tried to interfere. He also says he has written bullishly about AOL in the past but would, if anything, be more cautious now for fear of appearing a sell-out to his new masters.

Miller, at the Project on Media Ownership, agrees that in the US journalistic ethics are probably more robust than in Europe, but he believes the rot is as inevitable as the corporate pursuit of profit. In a recent incident, it was claimed that the ABC television network spiked a story from one of its reporters that Disney Corporation (which owns ABC) had hired convicted child molesters at its theme parks. ABC came back with a statement that the story didn't meet editorial standards. But Miller says such incidents are rare. Self-censorship, he argues, is far more dangerous.

"Usually it isn't necessary for the boss to interfere. The culture of the newsroom in this corporate system tacitly requires you to learn the ropes. You learn what to do and what not to do. You've got to make a living," Miller says.

The other insidious process that is eroding journalism on both sides of the Atlantic is the increasing emphasis on celebrity and "lifestyle". That trend is clearly visible in the US news magazine market, but at Time it has become particularly questioned because of the magazine's role as part of a mega-corporation.

Thus, when Time published a cover story about tornadoes a few years ago, the critics were quick to point out the resemblance between the picture on the front and the advertising poster for a newly released Warner Bros film, Twister. Late last year, the toy phenomenon Pokemon appeared on Time's cover - reasonably enough perhaps in view of its grip on children around the world, except that the cover appeared just as Warner launched Pokemon, the movie.

Meanwhile, the merger's impact on pluralism on the web has raised as many concerns as its potentially stifling effect on the traditional media of newspapers and television. The world wide web no longer looks like the wide open frontier of free thought it once appeared. Log on these days, and the online options for news and journalism look pretty familiar.

"The internet is being brought fully into the circle of commercial media," Professor McChesney of Illinois university points out. "It is going to have a billion websites from every possible point of view, but it is not going to spawn a new generation of commercially viable media companies. The few that are left are destined to be bought."

In other words, it does not matter how many quirky online magazines are out there. Only those with the big business backing to advertise intensively are likely to thrive.

As Mark Crispin Miller puts it: "Let's imagine a shopping mall in which the management allows people to come in to sell old jewellery at stalls and so on. But most people are going to go to Starbucks."

Miller does not believe the corporate annexation of journalism and the internet is inevitable. He says US journalists he talks to "feel shame and disappointment about having to do work they see as trash." In the backlash against Microsoft's overweening power, he sees the outline of a popular revolt of the kind that paved the way for the trust-busting Progressive Era a century ago. "We could have another popular groundswell against the power of wealth. But in order for that to happen you have to have some sort of independent media."

fields.headline: Gielgud award for Branagh
fields.trailText: The West End and Hollywood united in London last night to honour Kenneth Branagh as the "greatest Shakespearean of our day".
fields.body:
The West End and Hollywood united in London last night to honour Kenneth Branagh as the "greatest Shakespearean of our day". Even Bill Clinton sent his ambassador to pay homage at the court of King Ken.

His most recent ex, the actress, Helena Bonham Carter, was also there, though his former wife, Emma Thompson - from whom he had a "frightfully civilised divorce" - stayed away.

She was the only notable absentee in a star-studded gathering at the Middle Temple Hall. Bob Hoskins, Stephen Fry, Ben Elton, John Sessions and Richard Briers took part in a revel dedicated to the Branagh and the Bard before Dame Judi Dench, last year's winner of the Gielgud award, handed on the "Golden Quill".

Belfast-born Branagh, who has yet to reach 40, is the youngest ever recipient of the award presented by the US-based Shakespeare Guild. "Through his remarkable films, Kenneth Branagh has introduced the works of Shakespeare to a new generation of audiences," the guild's founder, John F Andrews, said.

Branagh has been credited with bringing Shakespeare to Hollywood, if not quite to the masses, with his films of Henry V, Hamlet and Much Ado About Nothing. His success in persuading the likes of Keanu Reeves and Denzel Washington to don doublets paved the way for Buz Luhrman's cult Romeo + Juliet and the box office smash, Shakespeare In Love. His Renaissance company was at the forefront of the Shakespeare revival in the 1980s.

webTitle: Controller who shook up Radio 4 quits BBC

fields.headline: Controller who shook up Radio 4 quits BBC
fields.standfirst:
After a stormy three years at the station, James Boyle is tipped to take over the British Library
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: James Boyle, the controller of Radio 4, who notoriously staked his job against the success of the sweeping changes he made to the network, is to take early retirement from the BBC, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
James Boyle, the controller of Radio 4, who notoriously staked his job against the success of the sweeping changes he made to the network, is to take early retirement from the BBC, it was announced yesterday.

Mr Boyle will leave the corporation, where he has worked for 25 years, in April. He has been tipped to take up the post of running the British Library which becomes vacant in May.

His retirement comes after a stormy three years running the BBC's flagship radio station. During his tenure Radio 4 registered its lowest ever audience figures after his controversial new schedule was introduced.

However, a BBC spokeswoman dismissed reports that Mr Boyle was leaving following clashes with his boss, BBC director of radio Jenny Abramsky, and said the 53-year-old Glaswegian was leaving having achieved his goals for the station.

Mr Boyle said in a statement that Radio 4 was now enjoying great success which would sus tain it into the future. "When I became controller, I said that I had a clear idea of what had to be done and that I would complete that task and go".

His changes to Radio 4, which hit the airwaves last April, proved too seismic for its conservative middle England audience, which complained in droves. High-profile moves, such as moving The Archers, extending the Today programme, axing Kaleidoscope, and moving Yesterday in Parliament, met with outrage and with open dissent from presenters and BBC staff.

Critics, too, had a field day with the sudden introduction of more than 50 new programmes of varying quality and success.

After a set of audience figures from the radio ratings authority, Rajar, in which Radio 4 was revealed to have lost 600,000 listeners to fall under 8m listeners for the first time in its 31-year history in October, Mr Boyle admitted that some of the changes had not worked.

He has since enjoyed a turnaround in Radio 4's fortunes. With the appointment of Ms Abramsky to the post of direc tor of radio, the tortuous commissioning structure of Radio 4 has been overhauled and problems in the schedule - including lunchtime quiz shows and early evening comedy programmes - have been addressed. Listening has since improved and stabilised at around 8.5m as audiences have adapted to the new schedule. Rajar figures due to be published next month are expected to show the station's reach has increased and audiences are staying with Radio 4 for longer.

Mr Boyle was said by insiders to have been disappointed not to have been appointed director of radio.

The job, previously held by Matthew Bannister, became vacant at the peak of Radio 4's problems and he was said to be seen as too controversial a candidate.

Radio 4 is seen as an intellectual challenge for its controller and, as there is no commercial equivalent, the field for potential candidates is small. Candidates tipped from inside the BBC include Helen Boaden, head of current affairs, Graham Ellis, controller of radio production, and Ann Morrison, head of features.

The corporation is also without a controller of Radio 5 Live, since Roger Mosey moved to a new job in BBC news. But eight executive editors within BBC news whose jobs have been consolidated in a shake-up may be possibilities for the radio controllerships.

Boyle's hits

Home Truths

John Peel's anecdotal Saturday morning show about the minutiae of life and family got off to a stormy start but has proved a resounding hit.

Front Row

Replaced Kaleidoscope and initially suffered in comparison. It has since grown in stature and authority.

Jeremy Paxman

Newsnight's rottweiler, hired to replace Melvyn Bragg as the host of Start The Week, has proved unstoppable. Henry Kissinger will not forget his appearance - he left the studio in mid-show.

Drama

Strong classic adaptations such as Bleak House and Nicholas Nickleby have been joined by well received children's dramas and innovative works from new writers.

And misses

Yesterday in Parliament

Boyle's plan to revolutionise Radio 4's Westminster coverage backfired in the face of protests from MPs.

Lunchtime quiz shows

One of the first casualties of the new schedule, the lunchtime quizzes were regarded as "moronic". Similarly some of the early evening comedy was dismissed as poor.

Listening figures for summer 1998

The first full set of figures after the schedule revamp are the worst in Radio 4's history - a 600,000 drop taking the station below its crucial 8m listeners barrier for the first time.

Feedback

Chris Dunkley was dropped from right to reply show Feedback - seen as a move to rid the network of a presenter critical of the changes.

fields.headline: Oi! Mind your own business
fields.trailText: There has never been a Financial Times party quite like last Wednesday's. Called to bid farewell to a journalist joining an internet enterprise, most of the chatter should have been about the media's electronic future. Instead, it centred on the FT's present.
fields.body:
There has never been a Financial Times party quite like last Wednesday's. Called to bid farewell to a journalist joining an internet enterprise, most of the chatter should have been about the media's electronic future. Instead, it centred on the FT's present.

A reporter fished from his pocket a cutting from the previous day's Sun and several FT staff, along with their City contacts, were soon poring over the implications of the 85-word final leader.

It was a full-frontal attack on the FT, comparing it unfavourably to its global rival, the Wall Street Journal, which it said had broken the story about America Online's merger with Time Warner. The FT had never obtained a similar scoop claimed the Sun, because "most British financial journalists are a lazy bunch privileged, business-hating no-hopers who wouldn't know a story if it hit them in the face".

It concluded: "Isn't it about time the FT was taken over too?" In one of the more hyperbolic responses, a journalist at the party was even moved to ask: "Do you think it means Murdoch will buy us?"

The FT's editor, Richard Lambert, also treated the criticism seriously, telephoning to remonstrate with the Sun's editor, David Yelland. What really irked him was the fact that the leader was based on a somewhat false premise.

It was Dow Jones Newswires, rather than the WSJ which is a separate entity also owned by Dow Jones, which beat the world to the AOL story. Why, though, should Lambert and his staff be so touchy about the censure of a red-top tabloid? Regardless of its mistake about the scoop, is there any truth to the Sun's substantive point that the FT doesn't break big stories?

Lambert, who swiftly faxed a list of his paper's claimed scoops to Yelland, is adamant that the FT is often first with the news. He points to two stories on successive days last week: Scottish Media's takeover of Chris Evans's Ginger group and the revelation of a mooted merger between Glaxo and SmithKline.

"What sells newspapers is news," he says, "and our paper is good at getting news, big news. We've had plenty of major corporate scoops, like the Exxon-Mobil merger." Lambert notes that in the US, where the FT has gradually been winning sales in the past two years, its promotional advertising campaign is based around its list of scoops.

"Our expansion in New York has been a key element in our breaking of more stories in recent years," says Lambert. "We've been building circulation there despite being up against the Wall Street Journal." To get this in perspective, the WSJ sells 1.7m copies in the US while the FT has only just achieved a sale of 100,000.

Yelland sees the gap as very significant: "The FT is regarded as a joke in America. It has no political nous or clout. The Journal is far better in every way."

Yelland is also scathing about British business journalists in general and the FT staff in particular. "I've been at press conferences where an entrepreneur, some decent, self-made, hard-working guy, has been making a statement about some success or another. But most of the journalists there were a bunch of old Etonians who clearly find the whole thing distasteful. That's the opposite of the way journalists feel about businessmen in the States."

He does believe there are "honourable exceptions", such as Jeff Randall, the editor of Sunday Business. But Randall doesn't share Yelland's views on the WSJ or the FT. "The figures speak for themselves," he says. "If the WSJ was essential reading for the British business community, it wouldn't sell as few copies as it does."

The WSJ has a circulation of about 16,000 in the UK - against the FT's 180,000 - and some 54,000 in continental Europe against the FT's 125,000. Both papers are also running head to head in Asia. Randall, whose paper is just two years old next month and has just recorded a sale of 68,050, is convinced that if the WSJ's journalism was "irresistible" the hard-headed leaders of Britain's business world would buy it.

"They choose the FT on week days and our paper on Sundays because we do offer them what they want," says Randall. He argues that the approach adopted by the WSJ runs counter to the British culture. "It's full of thumb-sucking articles exploring the interaction between economics and politics. In Britain, we concentrate on the relationship between business and finance. Personally, I find that more sexy than politics. Let's face it, price-sensitive news and analysis is a must-read. The political stuff is tedious."

Randall isn't without criticisms of the FT. He thought the Glaxo story was terrific but was amazed that it was placed below a piece on Microsoft's Bill Gates giving up his chief executive role. "I'd give them 10 out of 10 for the scoop but nil for news values."

The rumbustious Randall and the intellectual Lambert may be very different characters but they agree that, despite the speed with which stories are now transmitted by electronic media, news remains of paramount importance to them.

The Sun is far from the FT's only critic. In a recent article in France's Le Monde, questions were raised about the FT's failure to land really big stories, especially if they involve investigative reporting.

The writer, Marc Roche, Le Monde's London-based City correspondent who has worked in Britain for 15 years, says: "All the time, the FT is after the event. With BCCI, Barings and Maxwell they did well, but only afterwards. I can't remember one big story they've got, except when they get a call before a press conference."

Some senior executives within Pearson, the owners of the FT, believe that investigative reporting is over-rated. Business people haven't time to read it. Their readers want reliable, straightforward news conveyed with precision.

In other words the paper is not meant to be read for pleasure: it is a tool in their professional lives. They do not wish to be provoked, merely informed. Perhaps that's why the Saturday FT is so very different. It is a much more features-oriented package with its lively new magazine. It is also the most popular edition, with last month's Saturday sale up 20% on a year ago.

Perhaps the most surprising part of this episode is the fact that what the Sun says should cause such ripples. Lambert has invited Yelland for a drink. It could prove a fascinating conversation.

webTitle: Norris finally gets the Tory mayoral nod

fields.headline: Norris finally gets the Tory mayoral nod
fields.standfirst: Steven Norris's website
fields.trailText: Steven Norris has finally become the Conservative candidate for London mayor, after resoundingly beating rival Andrew Boff in a postal ballot of Tory members.
fields.body:
Steven Norris has finally become the Conservative candidate for London mayor, after resoundingly beating rival Andrew Boff in a postal ballot of Tory members.

Mr Norris, a former transport minister, polled 12,903 votes to Mr Boff's 4,712. The turnout was just 46.9%, significantly less than the Tories' first election, in which Jeffrey Archer beat Mr Norris by 9,366 votes.

Mr Norris said he was delighted to have won the "overwhelming" support of London party members in a fair and secret ballot. "I have had losing and I have had winning, and believe me, winning is better," he said.

He paid tribute to Mr Boff, who he described as "a fair opponent, a straight opponent and a tough opponent", who had a great future in the Conservative party.

Mr Norris said he had "the strong endorsement of party members, indeed the overwhelming support of party members, in London in a secret ballot who, having heard all the arguments and watched all the twists and turns, nonetheless voted for me to represent their party."

The former minister contrasted the Tories' one-member one-vote selection process with the electoral college set up by Labour to choose their candidate.

"Labour was offering its membership a choice of 'any candidate you like provided it's Dobson'," he said, adding "New Labour has ditched all it's democratic credentials and retreated to a shameful process where it takes the votes of about one thousand Labour members to equal the vote of one MP.

"The contempt that shows for their ordinary members in the capital ought to show the voter how much contempt the Labour party have for this process."

The Conservative leadership hope Mr Norris's belated election marks the conclusion of a turbulent campaign, in which first-choice candidate Lord Archer was forced to resign after it was revealed that he had asked a friend to lie ahead of his libel battle with the Daily Star in 1986.

Mr Norris, who initially opposed a re-run of the ballot, said he was now pleased that party leader William Hague had insisted on it. "I am absolutely clear that William Hague was absolutely right to insist on the whole of our selection process being re-run."

Mr Norris was controversially omitted from the new nomination shortlist by members of the party executive, until pressure from William Hague forced the party high command to reinstate him. Party members were concerned about Mr Norris's womanising past and opposition to William Hague's support for clause 28, which bans the "promotion" of homosexuality by local governments.

One of Labour's potential candidates, Frank Dobson, said Mr Norris could not be trusted to run the affairs of London. "It beggars belief that the Tories are resorting to another ex-MP who fails to take politics seriously and who has failed as transport minister in London," Mr Dobson said.

"His greatest claim to fame as transport minister, according to his autobiography, was the Jubilee line extension, but in reality this line opened two years late and was £2bn over budget.

"Throughout his career, Norris has consistently shown more cheek than competence or commitment. He went as far as admitting in his book that he never read a manifesto."

This time round, Mr Norris said he has a programme of policies for the London mayor and pledged to press the government to improve the financial settlement to London.

"I'm going to leave others to play political games, I did not come back into active politics to do games, but to do what I believe is a very serious job in this capital city," he said.

"The mayor has to be the voice for this city to speak up on behalf of every one of the seven million people who live here," he added.

 Yesterday, Conservative leader William Hague accepted that he had been wrong to back Lord Archer's candidacy.

Asked whether the party made a mistake over allowing the best-selling author to stand, Mr Hague replied: "With hindsight, yes, we did, and I take entirely the responsibility for that."

He said the party's anti-sleaze watchdog, the ethics and integrity committee, would prepare a report on Lord Archer in the "next few weeks".

fields.headline: And now, on 4 . . .
fields.standfirst:
The Birt legacy - radio: The outgoing DG's trusted lieutenant, James Boyle, is leaving Radio 4. Who will replace him and will radio be the richer? By Maggie Brown and Kamal Ahmed
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The Birt legacy - radio: The outgoing DG's trusted lieutenant, James Boyle, is leaving Radio 4. Who will replace him and will radio be the richer? By Maggie Brown and Kamal Ahmed
fields.body:
James Boyle always said he was a revolutionary. Once he had completely challenged, overhauled and changed Radio Scotland in the mid-90s he immediately started looking for his next challenge. He was rewarded with the controller's job at Radio 4.

Now, three years on, he has challenged, overhauled and changed that station as well. Last year, with the appointment of Jenny Abramsky as director of radio (a job he wanted) already in place, Boyle started talking privately about the need to move on.

Maybe Boyle had reached his ceiling at the corporation. What other big jobs were there for him to do? The man of revolution was left looking at a job at Radio 4 that was now about refining his own changes. And Boyle has never been a tweaker.

He admitted yesterday that the rumours of a desire to become chief executive of the British Library were true. He has written to the library board expressing an interest in becoming Brian Lang's replacement when the present chief executive retires in May.

Thoughts immediately turn to the huge changes in radio that now face the BBC and Abramsky. Roger Mosey's move to become the head of television news means there is a gap at Radio 5 Live. That, along with Boyle's departure and the fact that Jim Moir, the head of Radio 2, is likely to move on in the near future, mean that Abramsky, and Greg Dyke, have a chance to make a BBC radio after their own image.

Boyle was often known as McBirt - a man who put in place formalised processes to make Radio 4 run more efficiently. He was liked and highly rated by the outgoing director general, who appreciated his adherence to the twin tenets of "necessary change" and "strategic management".

Throughout the battering Boyle took over the changes to Radio 4, much couched in the same language as the attacks on Birt, he stuck steadfastly to his cause, citing copious audience research to show that his Radio 4 was the Radio 4 the listeners wanted. He was finally rewarded with higher listening figures and the radio holy grail - people listening for longer.

Now that Boyle-Birt legacy will be tested by Abramsky and Dyke. The new appointment at Radio 4 will certainly be the most high-profile of the changes to come, and the one that will be most scrutinised and commented on by the British establishment. The person who gets the job is charged with tending one of the commanding heights of middle-class existence.

Although the news that Boyle was stepping down took no one by surprise, it is immediately clear that there is no obvious successor in the wings - no one standing head and shoulders above other wannabes. For much of the previous two years, the BBC has been distracted by the prolonged handover to Dyke.

"There are four or five possible names that have been drawn up. But the post is certain to be advertised," says one key insider. "It may well be genuinely open to an outsider."

Of course, the name that springs to everyone's lips when talking of a big cultural figure who would send out all the right signals about the intellectual future of Radio 4 is a certain Lord Bragg. But given the difficulties of his peerage (look what happened to Birt) such a move would surely be impossible.

What is certain is that the appointee to the £100,000-plus post will be someone in the mould of Abramsky, who is highly rated by Dyke and key governors, including the vice-chairwoman of the BBC, Baroness Young.

A highly creative if mercurial character, driven by a passion for BBC Radio, above all Radio 4, Abramsky surprised herself by landing the prestigious post of director of radio. Never a strong Birtist, she remains touchingly thrilled with her lot and her desire to put creativity at the heart of her tenure has been welcomed by often demoralised staff.

On her appointment, rumours spread about the relationship with Boyle, a touchy but brave man. Such factors can tell us much about who Boyle's successor may be. "Things were never warm and loving [between the two], but the crockery didn't fly," said a senior source. "You could just tell from the body language that they were not close." Crucially, Boyle was seen as driving out a generation of experienced, older radio hands.

At the time of Abramsky's appointment, Boyle's controversial revamp of Radio 4, introduced in April 1998, was under question. "The level of corporate support was not as strong as he might have hoped," said an insider. There was a sense that by annoying everyone from politicians (who forced the restoration of Yesterday in Parliament) to the disability lobby (with the axing of Does He Take Sugar?), Boyle had cooked his goose and with it hopes for further promotion. Very quickly Abramsky, former editor of the Today programme, ex-controller of Radio 5 Live and the driving force behind the launch of BBC Online, set up a special study of radio commissioning, under a former trusted deputy, Martin Cox.

It was an implicit criticism of the way Boyle had reordered Radio 4. He had chosen an inner group of five thirtysomethings as "day-part" editors (commissioning for sectors of the day rather than by genre), some without relevant radio experience, and had skipped a whole generation of older experienced hands, such as Sally Feldman, former editor of Woman's Hour.

Abramsky's aim, as radio's champion, was to restore, in part, Radio 4's structure of commissioning by genre and to hand back as much responsibility as possible to experienced people. Boyle's successor will continue those changes.

The moves were cemented late last year with the appointment of a trusted radio production figure, Graham Ellis - the man who sorted out the Vanessa Feltz crisis for the BBC - as head of radio production.

Ellis is certain to be a front-runner for Boyle's job. So are several women: Helen Boaden, the head of BBC current affairs and a former editor of Radio 4's File on Four; Anne Morrison, head of features and events within BBC Production and a well-qualified administrator; and Anna Carragher, head of broadcasting at BBC Northern Ireland, who also has plenty of experience. Crucially, Carragher remains very close to Abramsky.

Importantly, Abramsky praises the way Moir, the former head of BBC television comedy, has run Radio 2. Although Moir's name is not in the frame - his health has been poor - Abramsky's praise tells us that the trawl will be wide and will certainly include executives with a television background.

Boyle's departure does allow for a new, post-Birtist, era. Birt was often attacked for giving television the whip hand over radio. Whoever gets Boyle's job, and the one running Radio 5 Live, will be scrutinised closely.

"The level of corporate support was not as strong as he might have hoped," said an insider. There was a sense that by annoying everyone from politicians (who forced the restoration of Yesterday in Parliament) to the disability lobby (with the axing of Does He Take Sugar?), Boyle had cooked his goose and with it hopes for further promotion. Very quickly Abramsky, former editor of the Today programme, ex-controller of Radio 5 Live and the driving force behind the launch of BBC Online, set up a special study of radio commissioning, under a former trusted deputy, Martin Cox. It was an implicit criticism of the way Boyle had reordered Radio 4. He had chosen an inner group of five thirtysomethings as "day-part" editors (commissioning for sectors of the day rather than by genre), some without relevant radio experience, and had skipped a whole generation of older experienced hands, such as Sally Feldman, former editor of Woman's Hour. Abramsky's aim, as radio's champion, was to restore, in part, Radio 4's structure of commissioning by genre and to hand back as much responsibility as possible to experienced people. Boyle's successor will continue those changes. The moves were cemented late last year with the appointment of a trusted radio production figure, Graham Ellis - the man who sorted out the Vanessa Feltz crisis for the BBC - as head of radio production. Ellis is certain to be a front-runner for Boyle's job. So are several women: Helen Boaden, the head of BBC current affairs and a former editor of Radio 4's File on Four; Anne Morrison, head of features and events within BBC Production and a well-qualified administrator; and Anna Carragher, head of broadcasting at BBC Northern Ireland, who also has plenty of experience. Crucially, Carragher remains very close to Abramsky. Importantly, Abramsky praises the way Moir, the former head of BBC television comedy, has run Radio 2. Although Moir's name is not in the frame - his health has been poor - Abramsky's praise tells us that the trawl will be wide and will certainly include executives with a television background. Boyle's departure does allow for a new, post-Birtist, era. Birt was often attacked for giving television the whip hand over radio. Whoever gets Boyle's job, and the one running Radio 5 Live, will be scrutinised closely.

webTitle: 'All hell is set to break loose'

fields.headline: 'All hell is set to break loose'
fields.standfirst:
The Birt legacy - fallout: Is the BBC tripping over itself to get rid of its Birtist past? Maggie Brown reveals the latest newsroom u-turn
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The Birt legacy - fallout: Is the BBC tripping over itself to get rid of its Birtist past? Maggie Brown reveals the latest newsroom u-turn
fields.body:
Last Monday, eight senior BBC News executives arrived at work to find their posts axed. Their jobs, on salaries of £60,000 upwards, involved overseeing everything from Newsnight to editing News 24 and BBC World.

Like snowdrops in January, the cuts - which a surly BBC News PR department tried to hush up - were the first sign to the outside world of a Dykeist BBC spring. "Delayering", with the immense savings it implies, has arrived. "All hell is about to break loose," reports a senior figure who expects Greg Dyke's reorganisation, when unveiled in March or April, to be very radical.

But there is a real piquancy to this U-turn. When shown the new "organisation chart" for BBC News, this was the reaction of one of the redundant managers. "It was curiously familiar. With the exception of News 24 and BBC World, which weren't invented then, it was precisely back to the way things were run in the 1980s, before John Birt was recruited to head up BBC journalism."

Even those made redundant see the logic of what is taking place. "My personal view is that this is excellent news," said another person affected."This is precisely what we fought for in 1997." This refers to one of the most explosive rows to rock BBC News in the 90s. In September '97, BBC News chief executive Tony Hall and Richard Clemmow, then head of TV news sprang a plan to downgrade programme editors in charge of programmes and dedicated teams, adding new "super editors".

The result was fury. Public resistance from presenters, including Jeremy Paxman, John Humphrys, James Naughtie and Anna Ford, combined with editors including the then Today editor Jon Barton, Kevin Marsh (The World at One) and Peter Horrocks (Newsnight), propelled it on to the front pages. After two days the chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, intervened and had a meeting with Birt and Hall. Programme editors remained intact, but in the resulting fudge, the extra tier of executives was installed as well.

As buffers between programme editors and the top echelon, it was unclear what taxing administrative duties some of the new executives would do all day. "Play computer games. Fill in forms, help out in staffing crises," one insider suggests. Now that the BBC has decided to get rid of the extra tier, there is a sadness among many at the corporation that the people who took the new jobs are staring at an uncertain future. Eight of them will have to apply for the three posts that remain.

"These are people with typically 15 to 20 years' experience under their belt," said the editor of a high-profile news programme. "Some are highly respected. My relief that this is right is combined with wondering what sort of system it is which has promoted creative, experienced people, often despite their protests, to such 'non-jobs' - only so that they can be dispensed with like this?"

All of which poses an obvious question: how often can Hall - a civilised, clever man but one seen as a Birtist reformist who has failed to defend his staff against cuts - perform such reversals in policy without losing his credibility? A very senior BBC figure says bluntly: "The problem has been that Tony is more Birtist than Birt. There will be no celebration about Birt's departure here while he remains."

Hall's critics say the latest flip-flop completes his hat-trick. "Bi-medialism" has been junked with the recent creation of radio and TV heads. Attempts to impose an internal market between a monopoly supplier, BBC News, and News 24 and BBC World are also thrown out. Sources say that there is also a marked hostility towards BBC News management in almost every radio and TV news programme, for the insensitive way budgets have been cut by annual slices.

A senior figure on Newsnight says: "We certainly can't do the foreign features we used to. Newsnight has become a lesser programme. You can't keep taking money out of programmes. It has become drastic, serious." The decision to create a flatter structure at a stroke actually stems from the promotion of Roger Mosey, the ex-controller of Radio 5 Live, to head of TV news. He spearheaded the recognition that news programmes are best produced by small groups.

Too personable to be feared as the ruthless operator he is, Mosey - identified by some insiders as director-general material - waded into battle this week by stressing his belief in that classic mix: editors with control and strong presenters. "I want people to take imaginative decisions, enforced by BBC values," he said. Not, then, imposed deci sions, sullenly resented. "We've got some great editors here," Mosey said. "I don't want to suffocate editors under a bureaucratic structure where they feel unable to take decisions. Editors edit. That's the whole point of it. I want editors to feel free to innovate. What makes great programmes? The answer is great editors and great presenters."

Hall, the runner-up to succeed Birt, has been applauded by many for his efforts launching News 24 and overseeing news online. He denies that any of the changes amount to a U-turn. He explains that the cut in managers will be "simplifying the structure, so it's easier to understand and brings it closer to the people doing the programmes day by day. Less management, but, I hope, management that is visible."

The bi-media structure, he now says, was "a way of creating one organisation", by bringing radio news staff then based in Broadcasting House together with news teams in TV Centre. "We had split sites at the time, one structure eased people across. Once on the new site, we then asked how to organise ourselves. We asked the staff." When the staff gave the answers, Hall says, he responded.

Both Hall and Richard Sambrook stress that BBC News is not turning the clock back. The basic news-gathering machine, along with current affairs, business and political programmes, remain bi-media, with correspondents increasingly operating in a multi-media world, including servicing the successful online sites.

And the despised annual savings targets? Hall is hoping this coming year to set "differential targets". Newsnight is thought to be a Mosey priority. Asked if he realises that many of his staff simply wonder whether he's leaving, Hall appears deeply wounded. "Absolutely not. I've now got a fantastic team around me. No one has said that to me. It's utter rubbish."

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: The bizarre tale of Alan Davies and The News of the World | Dyke's people
fields.body:
* The bizarre tale of the Alan Davies non-interview with the News of the World takes another twist. Phil Hall's breathtakingly truthful paper ran a Q&A on December 19 with the Jonathan Creek star which Davies says must have been made up as no one spoke to him about it. Davies has now gone to the Arsenal website, areseweb, to set the record straight.

The News of the World said Davies attended his first match at the age of seven. No, Davies says, he was five. The NoW said that his "most memorable match" was the recent 3-2 win by Arsenal at Stamford Bridge. No, Davies says, it was a match against Spurs in 1987.

What will Hall do now it seems clear that his millions of loyal readers have been duped? We await his apology with bated breath.

*Unnoticed, Greg Dyke has been joined by one of his own people. Professor Gareth Jones of the Henley Management College and now BBC director of personnel first advised Dyke at LWT 10 years ago. Then, at Pearson Television, the ex-BT professor of managerial development was summoned to help. A touchy-feely alumnus of the University of Kent, Jones has a very different approach from the short-term commercial-contracts culture and daft internal market that pervaded the BBC at the height of Birtism. Could the creative juices really start to flow again?

*Much disgruntlement at the Telegraph, where hacks are mightily unimpressed with a 2% pay rise. "The money must be going to Conrad's Canadian ventures," moans my contact in the tweeds.

*As the lobbying over an increase in BBC funding reaches the final stage, key cabinet ministers are being asked to give their views this week to culture secretary Chris Smith. David Blunkett is to urge that any extra spending for the BBC's expansion into education should be spent on proper educative material, not "pet shows" like Walking with Dinosaurs or programmes with a convenient "education" tag slapped on them. Behind the scenes the BBC says the likeable vice chairman Baroness Young will monitor educational commitment.

*I can reveal that the scheme to give pensioners aged 75 and over a free licence fee, a benefit for 3m households, was dreamt up by Labour MP Michael Wills, the minister for information technology. Not only is he a close friend of Chancellor Gordon Brown but an ex-producer of LWT's Weekend World, founded by Birt, and worked on by Dyke. In a further twist, before becoming an MP in 1997, he handed over his independent TV company, Juniper, to ex-BBC News executive and arch-Birtist, Samir Shah. Oddly, the BBC remains deeply suspicious of the free licence fee.

*In tonight's first episode of Gormenghast clock the albino rook, who plays Master Chalk. Producer Estelle David scoured the country before finding the bird on a Welsh bird sanctuary. But there was a heart-stopping moment when this essentially wild creature had to be freed, to fly over a lake in a ceremony. "Fortunately, it had taken such a liking to Celia Imrie [playing Countess Gertrude], it flew straight back to her shoulder," says David. "We felt our prayers had been answered".

*If Coronation Street's stoned-barmaid storyline was being aired on American television, media watchers would suspect government payola. Salon.com last week revealed that US networks have received $25m over 18 months from Bill Clinton's drugs czar for incorporating anti-drugs messages into such shows as ER and Beverly Hills 90210. "The White House did view scripts," one network executive confirmed.

You can email Maggie Brown at maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

webTitle: My life on the net: Piers Morgan

fields.headline: My life on the net: Piers Morgan
fields.trailText: Piers Morgan
fields.body:
My favourite site is arseweb. It's the original Arsenal website, before you get too excited. I would rather not think what my IT department makes of there being so many hits on a site of that name. Arseweb is the first and the best Arsenal website.

I use it for its accurate, up-to-date calendar of fixtures - it's become a hugely important part of my life. It has also got the best chat forums of any football site, which is a good way to keep on top of current Arsenal controversies. I read the chat forums often, although I've not quite been tempted to take part - not yet.

I admire its editorial line. It's harsh but fair, and jealous of its independence. I've seen the official Arsenal site, and I look at other sites sometimes and they can be a bit serious and straight. It's the same difference as that between official club programmes and fanzines - this is a fanzine website. A lot of football websites are springing up on the web these days, and that can only be a good thing.

Arseweb often gives the Mirror a kicking for what we may have said about Arsenal, which I find hard to take. But I would never dream of going down to our sports editor and suggesting he make changes according to what arseweb has said.

I do occasionally find news stories on the site that we haven't featured in the paper, too. The people who write the site are exposed to different sources, and what they hear on the terraces or in their own circles often crops up on the site. I also like it for the several anti-Tottenham Hotspur chants and jokes that appear. But I can't talk about them here - you can find them yourself if you go and have a look.

I use the net almost every day, but there are no other specific sites I use as regularly as arseweb. The exception is the Mirror's own site, www.mirror.co.uk/, which doesn't really count. And besides, I don't use that from the same standpoint as a consumer at all.

 Piers Morgan is editor of the Mirror.

fields.headline: 'I wasn't born to be content'
fields.standfirst:
The Birt legacy - the interview: Next week Sir John Birt leaves the BBC. How will we judge the man described as everything from a Dalek to saviour of the corporation? Opening a special edition, he speaks to Ian Hargreaves
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The Birt legacy - the interview: Next week Sir John Birt leaves the BBC. How will we judge the man described as everything from a Dalek to saviour of the corporation? Opening a special edition, he speaks to Ian Hargreaves
fields.body:
John Birt is about to meet the man who tells new members of the House of Lords what they can re-name themselves. It's a bit like choosing a domain name on the internet. You start off fancying yourself as Lord Birt of Liverpool, but end up with narrower options because all the other names have been used: Lord Birt of Bootle, say, or Lord Birt of Formby.

The lad from Liverpool, who once looked like a walking Afghan coat, says he had no hesitation about accepting the honour which has finally cut short, by just two months, his epic, 13-year-long run at the BBC.

Even the new edition of Who's Who puts the closing date of his director- generalship at March 2000, but in fact he's leaving at the end of this month, drawing to a conclusion what some consider the most damaging cultural episode of the post-war years and others the most significant period of leadership in the BBC since the cantankerous retirement of John Reith. Like Reith, Birt is a director- general who has given birth to an adjective: Birtist. Exactly what this word means will be a subject for historians.

On the peerage, as on most things, Sir John is clear. "The only reason we have a new plan is because there is a new circumstance," he says. Knowing the itchiness of Birt's colleagues to terminate the prolonged handover to Greg Dyke, I express incredulity. No, he insists, it's clear that "you can't head an important national institution and be a member of the Upper House". But a peer could still chair the board of governors? No problem - that's a non-executive job. What about Lord Hollick at United News and Media? He pauses. "You'll have to ask Clive."

Was he asked to take the Labour whip in the Lords? "I can't talk about any of the details," he says, which I think means yes. He will, he says, be an active member of the Upper House, contributing to debates on the communications industry and other policy issues. "But I shall have to learn how to be opinionated." So, what's his opinion on the muddled state of government thinking about the way the Upper House is to be constituted? "Whilst remaining DG I should keep my opinions on such controversial matters to myself."

As ever, Sir John doesn't give ground easily. When I ask him whether he ever felt tempted to change course at the BBC as a result of the blistering attacks upon him from the likes of Dennis Potter ("croak-voiced Dalek") he replies: "I don't think so." Yes, he was hurt. Yes, he thought the attacks unfair, but it's what you expect "when creative institutions face adverse circumstances".

And there is the nub. "Adverse circumstances" is the phrase which can be used to defend, in Sir John's mind, so much of what happened during his tenure at the BBC. All those internal markets, and the split between "broadcast and production" - bureaucracy on a Leninist, even Stalinist, scale according to critics like Michael Grade and even Lord (Marmaduke) Hussey, chairman of the BBC for Birt's first decade at the corporation. "I'm absolutely certain that we got it right and that all these changes have made our programmes better," he says.

There is, of course, another side to John Birt. The funny, loyal, self-deprecating man who likes nothing better than to clear off with a gang of friends to Barcelona, or for an organised discussion of the case for and against DH Lawrence (yes, he does like a plan, even for a country weekend).

Professionally, there was a hint of this other John Birt in his correspondence with Michael Grade when the two fell out in 1987 and which was published recently when Media Guardian serialised Grade's autobiography. The row says an awful lot about Sir John's tenure at the BBC.

Grade and Birt had been longtime colleagues in ITV when the latter arrived at Broadcasting House in 1987 to find Grade colourfully ensconced as director of programmes for BBC TV. Grade was the staff's darling, much as Greg Dyke has set out to be. Birt was quickly seen as the cold administrator with the menacing plan, the remote managerial figure who communicated even with senior executives in terse, handwritten notes.

Grade, smarting from a couple of Birtian tickings off, dug in to resist Birt's right to intervene on his patch. He appealed to Birt to back off, but got a very different response. "I ought to have realised that John's grand plan made no provision for the claims of friendship. There was an utter single mindedness which enabled him to press on with his reforms in the teeth of unprecedented hostility. He was so sure that he was right that anyone who challenged his ideas became not just a sceptic but an enemy. The place for enemies was outer darkness, into which some of the most talented and experienced BBC staff were cast. Whatever John put into the organisation, he sure as hell took the fun out of working there."

When I raise the subject of these letters, Sir John's body language shifts to something more complex. "Extracts from letters," he jabs. OK, but what's his reply? Surely, I suggest, the key is in one of his own letters to Grade where he closes: "I needed help and a welcome and not what I got."

"Yes," he murmurs, pointing out that he has never discussed these matters in public before. "When I arrived at the BBC I felt very unwelcome. This was an organisation which had truly been in crisis. The board of governors had fallen out with the board of management. The organisation had had something close to a nervous breakdown. A director-general had been dismissed. I was the first person to join the BBC from the outside world at such a level since the war - and I wasn't welcome."

How did that hostility show itself? "The tiniest remark you made to a close colleague, you would read the next day in the Daily Express. This was a wholly new experience for me."

The breakdown of the relationship with Grade was, he says, part of that. "It didn't happen casually. Michael didn't set out all the circumstances, but it's not something I feel angry about, it's something I feel regretful about. I don't want to say more."

This part of him I recognise, having worked closely with Birt as a fellow outsider in the BBC from 1987 to 1990. It was a time of civil war, when Birt's enemies within believed they could reject and so eject him, as they very nearly did - in 1992 he got the nod from the governors to become DG by a single vote.

Among the many extraordinary incidents of my own time, and something that reveals what Sir John was faced with, was the occasion when the controller of BBC 1 (Jonathan Powell) flew at the director of news and current affairs (Ron Neil) with his fists. The view of established barons in radio and television was that Birt and anyone associated with him had no place.

So, in response, did Sir John harden up? "You have to learn," he says.

There is no doubt that he became capable of great toughness, though these qualities were not unfamiliar to those who worked with him when he was a senior manager at LWT. Grade describes a moment when he found himself "looking into the eyes of a stranger". This only happened to me once - in a clash with both Birt and the then director-general, Michael Checkland, over an edition of Panorama which Birt wanted to hold back.

For the most part, though, I shared Birt's analysis of the BBC's situation. The corporation, unaccustomed to any circumstance other than plenty, found itself under political attack from the Thatcher government and its income frozen in real terms. It simply lacked the managerial expertise to adapt.

How close did the BBC come to privatisation? "I don't think there was ever a plan," says Sir John. "That's not how political parties work. Nor were opinions in the Conservative party uniform - all parties are coalitions." The privatisers - Norman Tebbit, for example - were balanced by the resisters, notably, Douglas Hurd, who was home secretary from 1985 to 1989, and David Mellor, heritage secretary in 1992 at a crucial stage of one broadcasting bill.

"Mellor was a bold and brave politician, a doughty fighter, as determined as I was to see the BBC emerge as a powerful public sector organisation as a result of the charter review process. We were staunch allies," says Sir John. Among Mellor's crucial moves was the insertion of a programme quality clause for the ITV companies into the broadcasting bill, thus protecting the BBC's flank.

From Birt's account, Margaret Thatcher was not quite such a dragon about the BBC as is often suggested. "She always spoke with restraint when you were with her. She was very conscious of her role as prime minister and she never spoke to me as a party leader about the BBC."

But the crucial point, Sir John says, was that he arrived at the BBC with his own clear agenda for reform. "I had seen how ITV had resisted reform and so found itself reformed from the outside - that had quite an impact on me and I resolved that the BBC should not find itself in that position."

He had also, prior to arriving at Broadcasting House, checked out BBC politics on the other side of the House. This, he believes, was vital, prompting him to warn today's broadcasting executives of the dan ger of the industry getting too close to New Labour. "It would be a huge risk if the industry lost touch with the Conservative party," he says. "You must always work for consensus about the value of an institution and the legitimacy of its strategic goals."

Rupert Murdoch slots into this narrative cleanly. Having launched a ferocious assault on the BBC through his newspapers and in the interests of establishing Sky Television, Murdoch became, in BBC mythology, Public Enemy Number One. But Sir John didn't see it that way: the fact that Murdoch pushed a reform agenda, albeit one based on commercialising the BBC, was something he found helpful on the grounds that "any reform agenda was better than none". In his own eyes, Birt's real enemies were those who argued for no change - including the left of centre press - which backed Birt's most significant internal foes.

Birt certainly suffered heavy criticism for doing deals with Murdoch on televising football and for insisting that BBC programmes should be available on all digital platforms - including Sky. "Others argued we should treat Sky like lepers, but that wouldn't have been in the BBC's interest," he maintains. There is no doubt that Sir John's openness to American influence has shaped his reading of global trends in broadcasting, and prompted his boldest decisions - to invest early and heavily in the digital world of multi-channel TV and internet services.

How does he now see the future of television? Can he imagine the end of linear television channels, designed for couch potatoes, and their replacement by on-demand programme selection?

"In ten years, a majority of homes in Britain will enjoy the total digital experience, but it may take 20 or 25 years for a world where almost everybody does," he says. "My sense is that linear channels will become less important but they will still be important - the older part of the audience will accept these changes more slowly."

The role of such channels will, however, change. "They will become rather like the Empire Leicester Square, where important programmes are shown first. The latterday Walking with Dinosaurs will need a premiere and it will get it on BBC1.

"The future is a multiplicity of services which delivers to individuals something which aligns closely with their own passions and needs. They will go to a place where they can find programmes on demand, and where they will have all the benefits online of being able to join communities of like-minded people. The future will be owned by those organisations which can create the most compelling services. The whole drive of the BBC is to be one of those organisations and we are well ahead of the game."

It follows, surely, from this "total digital future" that the BBC faces change in the next decade even more radical than during the Birt years. "We have long understood that organisations like Yahoo are fantastically perceptive and agile and we hold them in great admiration. A huge issue for the BBC is getting people inside to understand who the future belongs to and not to see the immediate competitive environment as being the one that most matters. If organisations like the BBC don't understand that, they will diminish and die."

This is another way of saying that Sir John simply does not rate his British competitors. "I begin to see some slight signs that they are appreciating the implications," he says. "Most other media organisations in the UK in the last five years have had no idea whatsoever of what was truly at stake - they're a long way behind in the race."

The implication of this judgment, in terms of the management and organisation of the BBC, is stark. His own managerial structures, however bloodily imposed, should be seen as "staging posts", designed to reduce costs and raise efficiency. "If the BBC doesn't understand that it has to be involved in perpetual revolution, then it won't be as strong in the digital age in ten years' time as it is now," he says, noting that BBC managers "now understand this".

There is, of course, another view. That the BBC should be sticking to its knitting, concentrating its resources on BBC1, Radio 4 and its other core services - paying more attention to the digital underclass than the digerati. Lord Hussey, who as chairman of the BBC governors brought Birt to the BBC, took this line in a House of Lords debate last year. Birt chuckles and comments: "I can only say that I'm surprised - that's not what he said in the ten years we worked together."

Quite what Dyke will make of this inheritance, we shall swiftly see. The rumour is that he will raze Birt's managerial structures, including the broadcast/production divide. "The structure has served its purpose but it has to change," says Sir John. "If I were still DG, I'd be changing it myself."

Another place where large structural change is in the offing is in the area of broadcasting regulation, a subject on which Sir John expects to make a large contribution from the red benches of the Lords.

The challenge for Sir John in his post-BBC years will be to step aside from merely continuing to lobby for the organisation with which he is now so closely identified - a transition many distinguished public figures find difficult when they enter the House of Lords. If he proves to be different, perhaps it will be because he was never quite a BBC man in the first place, although he constantly points out that almost his entire career has been spent in the public service end of broadcasting.

Halfway through our conversation, I ask him about the famous row in 1993, when it transpired that he had joined the BBC as deputy director general without even becoming a member of the staff - rather, he was contracting his services through a personal company, in the way that entertainers do.

It was, he admits, a serious error. In explaining the decision, however, he says something more interesting. "It goes way back to the ethos of the 1960s. I worked at Granada, where a large number of people were independently minded, rather maverick. I positively didn't like the idea of employee status - it was the culture of the time. At LWT that continued. I joined the BBC with the same attitude. I didn't relish the idea of staff status."

It was, he says, a cultural, not a financial decision. "I didn't have this status for commercial reasons, I did it for cultural reasons, without any detailed knowledge of whether it was in my interest and it turned out it was barely in my interest at all."

Does he feel now that after 13 years at the BBC he is a different person, or a person with a different culture? Or will he quickly revert to maverick status, culturally and fiscally? "I don't know the answer to that question," he says. His plan is to write an autobiography, the first of several book projects, and to join a select array of public and private sector boards in a non-executive capacity.

Does he leave the BBC content? "I wasn't born to be content," he says, not even with the progress of BBC News, whose "mission to explain" lay at the heart of his first flush of evangelism. "I am very proud about what BBC news has become - we are the most powerful news organisation in the world. But do I think that we perfectly explain the key policy areas of the day? No. We do it better than anyone else, but I always feel restless."

So what does this restless re-engineer of the Reithian heritage see as his legacy in terms of programmes? What three programmes represent the epitome of the John Birt BBC? Three is too few, he complains, and proposes: Cops, The Human Body, League of Gentlemen, Radio 4's Home Truths, Radio 3's Sounding the Century and . . . Teletubbies.

fields.standfirst:
The Birt legacy - programmes: His era began with a 'massive attack' on the BBC and a radical manifesto. But, says John Dugdale, the revolution has not been televised
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The Birt legacy - programmes: His era began with a 'massive attack' on the BBC and a radical manifesto. But, says John Dugdale, the revolution has not been televised
fields.body:
Seven years ago, on Monday, January 18, 1993 - halfway through John Birt's first month as director-general - BBC1's evening menu offered national and regional news (6-7pm), a soap (the soon-to-be-axed Eldorado), two sitcoms from 8-9 (including "a new comedy series set in Glasgow's boxing world"), news (9pm), Panorama (9.30pm), Film '93 (10.10pm) and Cagney and Lacey (10.40pm).

On BBC2, Janet Street-Porter's Def II yoof zone ran from 6.30-7.30pm, followed by an arts documentary, Horizon (8pm), a movie, Newsnight (10.30pm) and The Late Show (11.15pm). Apart from the news and current affairs output, which he had overhauled as deputy DG, Birt was not responsible for these schedules - in radio, where one DJ can replace another overnight, his impact was sometimes swifter, but in television, his era only really begins when programmes commissioned by the new controllers installed at the same time, Alan Yentob (BBC1) and Michael Jackson (BBC2), came on stream in 1994.

This, then, is still the Beeb before Birt - the product of what he called "the bloated, inefficient BBC that history bequeathed us" (MacTaggart Lecture, 1996), so debased that only the merciful cruelty of a "massive attack" could save it. But what strikes you, comparing the line-ups with those of January 17, 2000, is an impression of plus ça change, plus c'est la meme chose.

So tonight's early-evening offerings on BBC1 are A Question of Sport, EastEnders and a spin-off from Watchdog, all three pre-1993 launches. Flanking the second news bulletin are ex-ITV perennial, This Is Your Life, and Soldiers To Be, revisiting any number of 1980s army-training documentaries. After Panorama comes It's Only TV But I Like It, Telly Addicts revamped with celebs.

The few discernible changes reduce risk to keep the two channels competitive. Panorama has moved from 9.30pm to 10pm, Horizon from 8pm to 9.30pm. The Late Show has gone. No BBC1 controller nowadays would risk a new sitcom about Glaswegian boxers. True, Gormen- ghast, starting tonight on BBC2, is strikingly adventurous; but back in January 1993 the same channel was premiering Clarissa.

This is the opposite of what one might expect, because two months before Birt acceded to power the manifesto of the incoming regime, Extending Choice, committed the corporation to a strategy of anti-populist risk-taking. To justify the continuation of licence-fee funding and the renewal of its charter, the BBC would progressively move away from programming that could be replicated by a commercial broadcaster. "Distinctive" output became compulsory. "Imitative, derivative or formulaic" programmes were outlawed.

If the strategy set out in Extending Choice had been implemented for seven years, the BBC would have axed Neighbours, Hollywood movies, and US dramas or comedies. Most dramas involving detectives and medics, and/or starring former soap stars, would have gone too.

Jim Davidson and Hale & Pace could not be poached from ITV. Live football would have vanished, as would the Lottery Show. Successful factual series (eg Airport, Changing Rooms) would have to be abandoned as soon as the opposition came up with a copy (eg Airline, Better Homes). Kids' shows would eschew cartoons. No hits would be played on Radios 1 and 2.

Clearly, none of this has happened: in television, controllers recognised the prescriptions of Extending Choice, Birtism's Old Testament, as suicidal, with their minds concentrated by a ratings slump in 1993. Atavistic populist practices continued, and were eventually ratified by People and Programmes, the more pragmatic New Testament, in 1995. When Yentob's head of popular drama, Nick Elliott, was asked by the Guardian how he squared his plethora of detective series with Extending Choice, he replied that he'd never read it.

The one marked change of the Birt era has been the ascendancy of trusty reality over chronically unreliable fiction and fun, with BBC1 slots that would have gone to drama or entertainment going to factual output, and BBC2 cutting its commitment to drama serials and single films. And with this shift came a recognition that a diluted version of Reithian and Birtist ideology could be reconciled with ratings rivalry - could even inform hit shows such as Animal Hospital, Antiques Roadshow and Ground Force.

Factual series have cheekily borrowed tricks from the genres they supplanted, most obviously in the transformation of the observational documentary into the docu-soap and the emergence of the lifestyle gameshow. Programmes with a wide range of subject-matter - cookery, gardening, DIY, antiques, pets - can be loosely defined as educational, and enlivened by vivid presenters and/or the injection of challenge or competitive features.

On Monday, January 18, 1993, a transitional Radio 1 had Simon Mayo hosting the breakfast show, Simon Bates at 9am, Jakki Brambles the lone female DJ at 12.30, Steve Wright at 3pm, Mark Goodier at 6pm, Mark Radcliffe at 9pm and Nicky Campbell at 10pm. Radio 2 fielded exactly the same morning line-up as now, but its afternoon slots were filled by Gloria Hunniford, Ed Stewart and John Dunn. Radios 3 and 4 had much the same mix as today, although on 4, controller James Boyle has reshuffled running orders. Radio 5 had not yet been relaunched as 5 Live.

BBC radio in the Birt era has seen the same shift as television from batty purism to realism, with Radio 1 under Matthew Bannister - the man credited with writing Extending Choice - inevitably the most volatile station. Taking over in summer 1993, and bidding sayonara to Smashy and Nicey types such as Bates and Dave Lee Travis, Bannister set about implementing the manifesto, introducing intelligent, quirky DJs - Radcliffe, Danny Baker, Emma Freud - and running speech strands, including comedy, in mid-evening. Certainly "distinctive", but the results were catastrophic: in his first seven months, the station lost four and a half million listeners.

Over at Radio 2, controller Frances Line was repositioning her network as an oldies' station. Thus the corporation's music channels abandoned on principle the 25-45s, with Radio 1 concentrating on the young, Radio 2 on the over-45s.

When the inevitable pragmatic backlash occurred, Radio 1 remained a youth station, but it slashed speech output and reverted - first with Chris Evans, and currently with Zoë Ball and Chris Moyles - to the highly un-Birtist notion of the personality DJ.

Kudos and ratings stability have been regained, but - in contrast to television, where Birtism was never rigorously applied to non-news programming - the Bannister years saw a step-fall in audience figures, not gradual slippage: the station will never come close again to the 19.23m listeners he inherited.

Showing all the strategic consistency of the Grand Old Duke of York, Radio 2 meanwhile wooed back the 25-45s under new controller Jim Moir, adding performers jettisoned by Radio 1 (eg the Corrs, Simply Red) to the playlist and even giving breaks to DJs under 50. With similar belated realism, the original plan for a "rolling news" 5 Live was abandoned in favour of a hybrid network inheriting the old Radio 5's hefty following of sports fans.

In shaking up first BBC News and Current Affairs, then the structures of the entire organisation, there can be no doubting Sir John's impact as a radical reformer.
