fields.bodyText: Seven years ago, on Monday, January 18, 1993 - halfway through John Birt's first month as director-general - BBC1's evening menu offered national and regional news (6-7pm), a soap (the soon-to-be-axed Eldorado), two sitcoms from 8-9 (including "a new comedy series set in Glasgow's boxing world"), news (9pm), Panorama (9.30pm), Film '93 (10.10pm) and Cagney and Lacey (10.40pm). On BBC2, Janet Street-Porter's Def II yoof zone ran from 6.30-7.30pm, followed by an arts documentary, Horizon (8pm), a movie, Newsnight (10.30pm) and The Late Show (11.15pm). Apart from the news and current affairs output, which he had overhauled as deputy DG, Birt was not responsible for these schedules - in radio, where one DJ can replace another overnight, his impact was sometimes swifter, but in television, his era only really begins when programmes commissioned by the new controllers installed at the same time, Alan Yentob (BBC1) and Michael Jackson (BBC2), came on stream in 1994. This, then, is still the Beeb before Birt - the product of what he called "the bloated, inefficient BBC that history bequeathed us" (MacTaggart Lecture, 1996), so debased that only the merciful cruelty of a "massive attack" could save it. But what strikes you, comparing the line-ups with those of January 17, 2000, is an impression of plus ça change, plus c'est la meme chose. So tonight's early-evening offerings on BBC1 are A Question of Sport, EastEnders and a spin-off from Watchdog, all three pre-1993 launches. Flanking the second news bulletin are ex-ITV perennial, This Is Your Life, and Soldiers To Be, revisiting any number of 1980s army-training documentaries. After Panorama comes It's Only TV But I Like It, Telly Addicts revamped with celebs. The few discernible changes reduce risk to keep the two channels competitive. Panorama has moved from 9.30pm to 10pm, Horizon from 8pm to 9.30pm. The Late Show has gone. No BBC1 controller nowadays would risk a new sitcom about Glaswegian boxers. True, Gormen- ghast, starting tonight on BBC2, is strikingly adventurous; but back in January 1993 the same channel was premiering Clarissa. This is the opposite of what one might expect, because two months before Birt acceded to power the manifesto of the incoming regime, Extending Choice, committed the corporation to a strategy of anti-populist risk-taking. To justify the continuation of licence-fee funding and the renewal of its charter, the BBC would progressively move away from programming that could be replicated by a commercial broadcaster. "Distinctive" output became compulsory. "Imitative, derivative or formulaic" programmes were outlawed. If the strategy set out in Extending Choice had been implemented for seven years, the BBC would have axed Neighbours, Hollywood movies, and US dramas or comedies. Most dramas involving detectives and medics, and/or starring former soap stars, would have gone too. Jim Davidson and Hale & Pace could not be poached from ITV. Live football would have vanished, as would the Lottery Show. Successful factual series (eg Airport, Changing Rooms) would have to be abandoned as soon as the opposition came up with a copy (eg Airline, Better Homes). Kids' shows would eschew cartoons. No hits would be played on Radios 1 and 2. Clearly, none of this has happened: in television, controllers recognised the prescriptions of Extending Choice, Birtism's Old Testament, as suicidal, with their minds concentrated by a ratings slump in 1993. Atavistic populist practices continued, and were eventually ratified by People and Programmes, the more pragmatic New Testament, in 1995. fields.headline: Quality control
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade on a broadsheet revival
fields.trailText: The change is coming slowly, but it's happening all the same. As the latest ABC figures reveal, while the tabloids are gradually losing sales, the broadsheets are holding on to theirs. In December 1998, the six tabloids together sold an average of 10,421,405 copies a day. Last month they managed 10,121,919, a 2.87% drop. But the six broadsheets, which sold 2,835,054 in December 1998, managed a rise of 0.67%. This increase must be put in context, of course. Only one title, the Financial Times, increased sales substantially, and most of those came from outside Britain.
fields.body:
The change is coming slowly, but it's happening all the same. As the latest ABC figures reveal, while the tabloids are gradually losing sales, the broadsheets are holding on to theirs. In December 1998, the six tabloids together sold an average of 10,421,405 copies a day. Last month they managed 10,121,919, a 2.87% drop. But the six broadsheets, which sold 2,835,054 in December 1998, managed a rise of 0.67%. This increase must be put in context, of course. Only one title, the Financial Times, increased sales substantially, and most of those came from outside Britain.

After a downward sales trend that has lasted 30 years, we cannot blind ourselves to what is happening. Fewer people are prepared to buy a paper every morning. They feel they can get their news - if they want it at all - from other sources.

Broadsheets are suffering less, partly because they are more credible than their red-top cousins and partly because they have incorporated tabloid concepts. But there is a long way to go; more than 10m buyers, which means about 30m readers, still prefer tabloids. This dwarfs the broadsheet's 2.8m buyers (8.5m readers). The figures also show that, despite the drop in sales and anecdotal evidence about fewer people wanting papers, the vast majority of Britons still read the press. The game isn't up yet.

fields.headline: Easy as ABC?
fields.standfirst: American TV was left reeling when it was accused of racism. Now two networks are trying to put it right.  Edward Helmore  reports
fields.trailText: In the media, as in most areas of American public life, the issues of race and discrimination are never far beneath the surface. So it was with some fanfare last week that two of the major broadcast networks, NBC and ABC, reached an agreement with racial equality organisations to try to correct what has long been perceived as a colour bar within the US television industry.
fields.body:
In the media, as in most areas of American public life, the issues of race and discrimination are never far beneath the surface. So it was with some fanfare last week that two of the major broadcast networks, NBC and ABC, reached an agreement with racial equality organisations to try to correct what has long been perceived as a colour bar within the US television industry.

Since last summer, when black leaders seized on the fact that none of the 26 new comedy or drama series set to premiere in the autumn of 1999 featured a single figure from the ethnic minorities in a leading role, the networks have been under sustained attack for their apparent failure to embrace racial diversity on camera and, just as importantly, on the studio floors, in the corporate offices and in the boardroom.

The networks, nervous of attacks from such a powerful part of the American population, were originally brought up short by Kweisi Mfume, leader of the NAACP (National Association of the Advancement of Colored People, the nation's oldest and largest civil rights group). He accused the networks of a "virtual whitewash in programming" and threatened them with a boycott that would wreak havoc with ratings just at the time when advertising rates were being calculated.

The new agreements include initiatives to place more black faces on TV screens.
There are also plans to ensure minorities are given the same opportunities as white people as writers, directors, producers, engineers and executives.

"The networks are very white worlds and that's what they're trying to get at," says Sig Gissler, professor of journalism at Columbia university. "To put a few actors into shows only deals with one element of the television universe but what they're trying to do here is get at the superstructure of TV itself and make it more diversified.

"This struggle mirrors what's going on elsewhere in society. How do you get diversity embraced in the mass media, in newspapers and magazines? Nobody feels that we have achieved the full measure of progress."

Under the NBC deal, the network agreed to provide internships and scholarships to minorities, guaranteed it would increase purchases from minority-owned suppliers and promised that a minority writer would be added to the staff of every new show that wins a second year on the air. The network also pledged to hold a one-day seminar next month with its producers to emphasise its interest in casting more minority parts.

ABC's deal similarly concentrates on changing the behind-the-scenes operations in the hope that it eventually makes a difference to what goes on the air. The Disney-owned network said it would assign high-level mentors to minority employees, set up a diversity training programme, consider a producer's diversity record when hiring and tie executive bonuses to success in employing minorities. Similar agreements with CBS and Fox are expected to follow.

So far, the initiatives are on a good-faith basis and the NAACP
has not yet pressed the networks to introduce a quota system similar to affirmative-action legislation that ensures minority quotas are reached at universities. Many suspect that may come if the networks fail to implement the agreements.

But the difficulties in enforcing the ideal of racial diversity are as legion in television as they are in society at large. As soon as the agreements were announced, there was an outcry from Hispanic, Asian and native American groups, who felt they had been excluded. Moreover, the idea of fostering racial diversity under the terms of the agreements carries inherent suspicions.

One chief executive of a production studio noted that such an approach, while conceived with the best of intentions, "might get to be like having the boss's son on your staff" and NAACP leaders stressed it would not interfere with the creative process and stand in the way of freedom of expression.

"At certain times, the creative process must be allowed to be creative," stressed Mfume. "I don't see the NAACP sitting down and nit-picking every character."

"The tricky part comes in implementing diversity," says Gissler. "It's not just about getting the numbers up but making the most of the diversity. One of the problems with the plan is that it comes with a certain suspicion about whether minority hires are qualified or whether they are just bringing them in to meet a number. It's very important for management to get the staff to be supportive and hire
good, qualified candidates that can succeed."

Yet, while the agreements have been broadly welcomed by network executives and black leaders alike, it's uncertain whether they will have much impact on the lack of racial diversity in front of the camera.

A sprinkling of black characters have already been added to new shows that had all-white casts before the controversy erupted and though there are strong roles for black actors in some hits like ER, the US TV industry as a whole seems light-years away from the time when Benson, Diff'rent Strokes and The Cosby Show were high-rated, prime-time programming for black and white audiences alike.

Twenty years ago, when sitcoms like Benson were at their peak, there were only three networks and the need to cater to minority audiences was self-evident. With the proliferation of cable channels, audiences have fragmented, with minority viewers drawn to stations specifically tailored to meet their concerns - like the black-owned, black-watched BET [Black Entertainment Television] or Hispanic stations like Televisa.

It's a well-worn rule that series dealing with race, starring a high proportion of minority actors or dwelling on the black experience, will not find a white audience. High-rated white shows like Friends neither concern themselves with black characters nor find an audience in minority viewers.

In fact the only common ground is in NFL football coverage and CBS's 60 Minutes. The only drama series con sidered to have any cross-racial appeal is ER and its audience is still 90% white. The top show among black viewers, Warner Brothers' Steve Harvey Show, ranks just 127th among white viewers.

"Black and white audiences have moved down separate paths. We seem to have less integration in mainstream television but more shows with black casts on cable television," says Gissler. But while the dream of racial integration lives on, so too does the corresponding impulse of "separate but equal".

'O n one hand there's still an effort to have an integrated society, but there's a parallel impulse to have your own cultural identity," says Gissler. "There's a kind of sundown segregation now. We work together during the day but at night we go back to our separate racial caves and that's reflected in television. Some people would call it self- segregation; black people would call it self-affirmation."

Many in the industry believe that the black-white divide on network TV is exacerbated by advertisers who are primarily interested in young, white, affluent viewers and provide the networks with little financial incentive to attract minority viewers. BET and other minority channels have some of the lowest ad rates in the industry and receive significantly less ad revenue per viewer even when the audiences
are of a similar size and demographic to their white-targeting counterparts.

A congressional report into advertising practices on radio last year unearthed a training memo from one company that represented broadcasters selling airtime. It stated that the "the non-ethnic customer is more attractive" and that clients should be steered to broad-based [ie white] radio stations because advertisers want "prospects not suspects". One manager of a company owning three stations in New York reported that companies like Volvo and BMW refused to buy time on the company's black-targeted station even after they were shown that the black audience was more interested in buying cars.

Yet the established difficulties of the black and white of US television broadcasting are being challenged. Last night, CBS broadcast the first episode of City of Angels, a new series by Steven Bochco, creator of Hill Street Blues and NYPD Blue. The series centres on a struggling county hospital in Los Angeles and was not only made by a crew 70% of which was drawn from ethnic minorities, but features a cast made up overwhelmingly of black and Hispanic actors.

Its creators hope that by focusing on the drama of life-and-death issues
and not tackling racial themes directly, the show will avoid the perceived problem that white viewers feel uncomfortable watching black characters in positions of power or sensing that they are being taught a racial lesson. To get white viewers to watch a black drama, Bochco says, "You don't make it about the experience of being black. You make it a really compelling drama, whether it's about cops, doctors or lawyers." In the case of City of Angels, he adds: "The fact of one's ethnicity is secondary to the necessity of treating the sick."

The show's success depends on attracting a substantial white audience. If it succeeds, other networks will undoubtedly open the doors to more minorities; if it fails, it will set back the cause of the networks producing more television with a non-white emphasis. "There are consequences if the show doesn't fly," says Vivica Fox, one of the series' leading characters. "They'll say, 'I told you, no one wants to watch those people.'" And if no one watches, there's very little the NAACP and network goodwill will be able to do about it.

fields.headline: The gene machine
fields.standfirst:
Martin Wainwright on the debate surrounding the patent of two genes in the US and the implications for the NHS
Plus: All Mo-ists now
fields.trailText: When you were born, you were registered and given a national insurance number, but for all its obsession with statistics and filing, The System didn't go as far as patenting you.
fields.body:
When you were born, you were registered and given a national insurance number, but for all its obsession with statistics and filing, The System didn't go as far as patenting you.

That may change before the 21st century goes much further. There are huge implications in the news from Utah that the company which claims to have patents on two genes at the centre of cancer research is to test its legal claims in Europe.

The immediate reaction is one of pounds and pence, with Myriad Genetics of Salt Lake City charging twice as much as its British counterparts for screening BRCA1 and BRCA2, as these scraps of human DNA are romantically known.

Given that British scientists did much of the graft behind BRCA2, there is the making of an international spat of the sort genetically suited only to lawyers' pockets. But the longer-term costs, and the urgent need to plan for them, go much further and deeper.

One of the roots of the present NHS crisis is the basically healthy one - that we have become so stunningly successful at prolonging life and dealing with its medical flaws.

Pills and skills now offer treatment which would have been unthinkable less than a generation ago. And, for all the queues and cancelled ops, they offer it democratically in Britain to everyone - very properly, but with obvious effects on the health budget.

The tragedy of Mavis Skeet, who had four cancer operations cancelled this winter at the age of 74, is an example - somewhat hidden because her main media role has inevitably been that of a victim of underfunding and muddle.

Without in any way sidelining the mistakes in her case, it should be noted that Mrs Skeet had already received a radiotherapy course, high-dose drug treatment and two operations to try to stretch her throat, all within ten months of diagnosis.

That sort of treatment would have been pay-bed stuff or reserved for royalty within a lot of our lifetimes, had it indeed been available at all. This is the really substantial implication of the Myriad Genetics initiative. How many beds - or possibly greenhouses and growmore - will the NHS need when doctors can pluck out a scrap of our BRCA2 and grow us a replacement finger or breast?

The government does not deal in science fiction, but Tony Blair's talk on Sunday of "turning round a supertanker", when trying to re-finance the NHS effectively, is a metaphor which extends itself appropriately in this context. The masts of the good ship Health Service need to be swarming with lookouts, with plenty of high-quality staff in the engine room to put their warnings into action.

This is easy to say and extremely hard to organise in detail. But there is one layman's nostrum which everyone concerned should take on board. Doctors, nurses and NHS managers often talk wistfully of too much change and "letting things settle down".

Impossible now. The gene which governs willingness - no, enthusiasm - to change ought to be patented by the NHS as soon as practicable.

US firm may double cost of UK cancer checks
More about the NHS

All Mo-ists now

In the 60s, we were all Maoists at university, applying the distant wisdom of the old dictator to the unlikely setting of lawned quadrangles or campuses of concrete and red brick. The Little Red Book instructed us to "let 1,000 flowers bloom" and in many bedsitters this understandably became cannabis ferns - the pot-in-a-pot which gave many long-haired students a lifelong interest in gardening.

Mo Mowlam wasn't a grower, but the fact that she puffed a spliff makes her nothing more than wholly representative of her generation, just as Cherie Blair represents millions who have failed to attract the attention of railway booking clerks busy doing other things. She gives hope, too, to countless modern parents whose kids may be clubbing or online chatting at university: they could grow up to be cabinet ministers too.

In her role as overall head of the government's anti-drugs blitz, Mowlam's realistic CV is equally helpful - not that anyone doubted her candid credentials in a world where so many players hide, dodge or claim that they didn't inhale. Hooray for her (and for everyone from Tsar Hellawell to the Conservatives who have properly downplayed this "revelation"). We are all Mo-ists now.

Related documentary
Drugs in Britain: special report

fields.headline: The vast show
fields.standfirst: Gormenghast, the epic tale of byzantine skulduggery, marks an attempt by the BBC to step off the period drama treadmill. It's just a pity, says  Mark Lawson, they didn't pick something with more substance
fields.trailText: Gormenghast, the epic tale of byzantine skulduggery, marks an attempt by the BBC to step off the period drama treadmill. It's just a pity, says Mark Lawson, they didn't pick something with more substance
fields.body:
For some time in the 80s, Sting owned the rights to Mervyn Peake's Gormenghast trilogy. The pop star spoke of a possible movie, although what everyone really dreaded was a concept album. Neither materialised, although he did appear in a radio version. The books have finally been screened as a four-part drama (Gormenghast, BBC2, tonight, 9pm), and though the cast includes almost every senior British character actor - Ian Richardson, Warren Mitchell, Christopher Lee, Richard Griffiths - those who know the history of the attempts to film the book will inevitably think: where is thy Sting?

And, indeed, sting. In theory, this should be the perfect time to televise Gormenghast. Fantasy literature - in its various forms, from Terry Pratchett to David Eddings - is as busy a genre as the strange scuttling little creatures who tend to inhabit such imagined worlds. And digital technology allows for off-the-map gothic locations - such as Peake's mythical aristocratic kingdom of Gormenghast - to be visualised more vividly than ever before. Certainly the BBC seems unusually confident in the project. It is hard to recall another drama advertised and trailed so enthusiastically.

And what do you get? Admittedly, Peake has always seemed to me to be a writer who attended a lecture on Dickens and fell asleep after a few lines about grotesques. Each character is allotted a silly name and a single mannerism. The chef is fat and called Swelter (if you can't stand the heat). The 76th Earl of Groan is Lord Sepulchrave and is, indeed, not famously cheerful. Ian Richardson is a television actor of orchestral range, but can do little with this single note of whimsy. Only John Sessions - experienced as an impressionist in fattening out one characteristic - gives a full twitching and scheming inner life to his character, Dr Prunesquallor.

Waking up at the end of the Dickens lecture with his worryingly sparse notes, Peake seems to have supplemented his material with some general borrowings from myth and fairytale. There are ugly sisters and various gargoyle employees, but only one legendary borrowing - a grotesque Nativity sequence involving the birth of the Groan heir Titus - interestingly renovates the details.

Schoolboy name jokes - the nursemaid is called Nanny Slagg and the name of the hero Titus contains both a breast pun and a beer one - combine with student politics. Whereas Tolkien at least ensured that those who could be bothered might agonise over what the characters and symbols meant, Gormenghast - conceived while Peake was doing national service - is an obvious but wobbly metaphor for the English class system. The crazy and collapsing aristocrats - the Groans - are challenged by the cowering underlings who staff their castle.

But, while the ideology may be picture-book, the pictures are at least impressive. In giving the book a look, director Andy Wilson has intriguingly drawn on the discovery that Peake spent his childhood in China. So the sets - which you feared would be rather too Great Elf - are more Last Emperor. Yet, even here, it seems to me that digital and computer technology is more impressive when it recreates reality - for example, the extinct natural history of Walking With Dinosaurs - rather than visualising fiction. The great limitation of fantasy fiction - that the writer is not bound by either the rules of physics or the reality of history - affects Gormenghast at every level.

The best aspect of the series is to remind us - as did the recent BBC David Copperfield - that casting is an art in drama. At a time when the budgeting and eventual success of a project is often assumed to depend on the presence of one star (usually David Jason or Robson Green), Copperfield and Gormenghast have subtly drawn from different fields of performance. The Christmas Dickens employed both Maggie Smith and Pauline Quirke, from very different sides of the theatrical sheets, while this Peake piece intriguingly teams Ian Richardson the theatrical grandee with June Brown (Dot Cotton in EastEnders) as Nanny Slagg and Hammer film veteran Christopher Lee as the manservant Flay.

Andy Wilson has made the interesting point that television adaptations have concentrated too much on the 19th century and that there should be more versions of works published in viewers' lifetimes. He's right, but Gormenghast - which is, anyway, a pastiche of earlier literature - is not the text to make that case.

It's appropriate that the screen version of the Peake should finally emerge at the same time as Raul Ruiz's movie adaptation of Proust. If bringing A La Recherche Du Temps Perdu to the screen has been the fantasy project of highbrow film-makers for several decades, turning Gormenghast into pictures has long been the dream of middlebrow television. In both cases, the books were left on the shelf for so long because they were, in different ways, such literary experiences, achieving their best screening in the heads of readers. With Dickens, television has been able to ground the stories in historical and social realism. Gormenghast is panto Dickens taking place in limbo, just funny names and dusty jokes.

After only three weeks it seems right to use for the first time the insult all critics have been storing up. Gormenghast just feels very 20th century.

fields.headline: Don't Maddy the waters
fields.trailText: Today's rain at Centurion didn't just extinguish the last faint hope of a result to this Test match. It also washed away any chance of redemption for England's supporting cast.
fields.body:
Today's rain at Centurion didn't just extinguish the last faint hope of a result to this Test match. It also washed away any chance of redemption for England's supporting cast.

It's still possible that there will be some play tomorrow, that Alan Mullally will take a hat-trick, and Mark Butcher will make a century, and Chris Adams, defending immaculately, will help steady the ship following an early collapse. But even if that happens, there will be no pressure, and therefore no relevance.

To be brutally honest, this is a good thing. If the fringe players had done well in this match - and the law of averages says one of them would have - the effect would only have been to muddy the waters. Or Maddy them.

As it is, the series stats now tell the selectors what wisden.com has been telling them all winter: that you cannot throw a handful of beginners in at the deep end together, and expect them to swim. Adams, Maddy, Michael Vaughan and Andrew Flintoff have had 21 Test innings between them in South Africa, and failed to reach 50 once. Butcher hasn't managed it either. England went in to every game, against the second-best side in the world, with half a batting order.

And the bowling was only marginally better. Andy Caddick continued his progress and became the only real addition to the nucleus of the team. Darren Gough went the other way, perhaps because, as Bob Woolmer argues, he was never fully fit. Chris Silverwood was over-praised, as English seamers tend to be if they are making a visible effort and come from north of Watford. He bowled very well for a day in Cape Town, and for two balls in Port Elizabeth (when he rattled Jacques Kallis). Otherwise, he has been Dean Headley without the reverse swing.

Alan Mullally has been worse still: not so much Silverwood as dead wood. The only thing he has going for him as a Test cricketer is his economy rate, and even the captain now recognises that that is a sleight of hand, a function of Mullally's amazing ability to bowl wide on both sides of the wicket at once.

If Mullally was Glenn McGrath, then his space-cadet fielding and school-clown batting would be a price worth paying. But he is not even Angus Fraser.

For the immediate future - the two home Tests against Zimbabwe and the first two against West Indies - Mullally's role should be merged with that of Phil Tufnell, and handed to someone who can bat, field, keep it tight, swing the ball and take the odd wicket. Come back, Mark Ealham, all is forgiven.

Butcher and Adams must go, to work on their hopelessly ropey techniques. Mark Ramprakash and Graham Thorpe must return, with Graeme Hick and Nick Knight just behind them in the pecking order. In fact, just having a pecking order would be a start.

Hussain, who is an intelligent man and a promising captain, needs to sharpen up his thinking as a selector. He keeps talking in terms of the balance between planning ahead and picking the best team for now. But there isn't a real conflict here. The way to plan for the future is to pick the best team for now, beat Zimbabwe and West Indies - the world's worst two teams on this winter's form - and aim to bed in, at most, one batsman, one bowler, and a wicketkeeper. Vaughan, Alex Tudor and Chris Read (if he can keep out Rob Turner) should expect to be in England's next Test squad; for the rest of the supporting cast, it's back to provincial rep.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

webTitle: Relatives of 'disappeared' urge police to charge Pinochet

fields.headline: Relatives of 'disappeared' urge police to charge Pinochet
fields.trailText: Relatives of the "disappeared" in Chile today urged the Metropolitan police to bring criminal charges against General Augusto Pinochet if the extradition case against him was dropped.
fields.body:
Relatives of the "disappeared" in Chile today urged the Metropolitan police to bring criminal charges against General Augusto Pinochet if the extradition case against him was dropped.

A delegation met assistant commissioner David Veness to lobby for an investigation into the former Chilean dictator under UK law.

Campaigners hope a case brought by Scotland Yard would stop Gen Pinochet fleeing the country if, as expected, home secretary Jack Straw rules he is unfit to be sent to Spain to face charges of human rights abuses.

The delegation was led by Labour MP Jeremy Corbyn, who confirmed that Scotland Yard had a file on Gen Pinochet and was considering whether to take any action. He added there was a clear case for an investigation under legislation making torture committed anywhere in the world a UK offence and because the torment of the relatives of the disappeared was still continuing.

"This is not just a gesture. The only thing that's prevented police here acting legally has been the priority given to the extradition case," Mr Corbyn said. "If that falls down, we believe he's liable to prosecution."

Today's bid was prompted by Mr Straw's decision that he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against Gen Pinochet on torture charges after a medical examination indicated he was unfit to stand trial.

He has given opponents until 5pm tomorrow to present their submissions and several groups have said they will attempt to influence the decision.

Four campaign groups, Amnesty International, the Medical Foundation for the Care of the Victims of Torture, the Association of the Relatives of the Disappeared in Chile and the Redress Trust asked Mr Straw to make public Gen Pinochet's health report.

Amnesty International said possible action included seeking an immediate judicial review of the way the medical examination on Gen Pinochet was carried out.

They have criticised the fact that the tests were carried out in secret, without either medical experts or observers appointed by the other parties involved, and without any details from the medical report being released.

The Spanish government also demanded new medical tests on Gen Pinochet.

Spanish ministers said they were passing on a request from Judge Baltasar Garzon, who is leading the legal bid to put Gen Pinochet on trial, for further tests to determine whether the 84-year-old is fit to stand trial.

The judge has protested at the absence of anyone representing the Spanish court at the medical examination of Gen Pinochet, and the refusal of the former dictator to allow anyone else to read the report.

A spokesman for the Crown Prosecution Service, which is acting on behalf of Spain in the case, confirmed that instructions had been received but refused to give any information on the contents.

webTitle: US space missile test angers Moscow

fields.headline: US space missile test angers Moscow
fields.standfirst: Related story: US 'kill vehicle' put to the test
fields.trailText: The United States will attempt again this week to shoot down a missile in space in a key test of whether it could soon begin building a national missile defence system, despite bitter objections from Russia.
fields.body:
The United States will attempt again this week to shoot down a missile in space in a key test of whether it could soon begin building a national missile defence system, despite bitter objections from Russia.

A missile with a dummy warhead will be fired from California late on Tuesday and a revolutionary US "hit-to-kill" weapon will be launched from Kwajalein Atoll, 4,300 miles away, shortly afterward to try and hit the warhead 140 miles above the Pacific Ocean.

If the weapon pulverises the warhead into space dust at a speed of 15,000 miles per hour, it would be the second successful US hit in three months. Its success or failure would likely affect US President Bill Clinton's decision this summer on whether to begin building a limited US missile defence.

The test has international implications and will be watched closely by contractors including Boeing Co., integrator of the proposed national missile defence system, and Raytheon Corp., which builds the 121-pound weapon.

Russia has warned that a national missile defence, likely to be based initially in Alaska, would violate the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty.

Moscow has refused a US request to modify the treaty to allow the system.

The United States has stressed repeatedly that a modest successor to former President Ronald Reagan's "Star Wars" missile defence plan would only protect US cities from limited attack and would not neutralise Russia's massive nuclear arsenal.

Meanwhile, Washington's European allies are worried that a singular US defence against long-range missiles might isolate the world's only remaining superpower from its long-standing friends and cool America's military commitment to Europe.

The four-hour time frame for Tuesday's test will begin at 9pm EST (0200 GMT Wednesday), which is mid-afternoon Wednesday in the western Pacific.

This test will be more complicated and difficult than one on October 2 because it will include and integrate the use of space- and ground-based radars in Hawaii and Kwajalein. Those radars, along with pinpoint global positioning systems, will become more and more important as the system evolves.

Defence Department spokesman Ken Bacon told reporters on Friday that the integrated battle management system for the missile defence, which is being developed by TRW Corp., is a key to its success.

"I think that one thing that should be clear is that the most difficult and sophisticated part of this entire programme is really the battle management system," he said. webTitle: Women's group launches court action against Tyson

fields.headline: Women's group launches court action against Tyson
fields.trailText: Women's rights groups today vowed to take Mike Tyson to court following the former world heavyweight champion's arrival on British soil yesterday.
fields.body:
Women's rights groups today vowed to take Mike Tyson to court following the former world heavyweight champion's arrival on British soil yesterday.

Justice for Women is bringing a court action to get Tyson sent back to the US. "It's a smack in the face for rape victims," said Julie Bindel a Justice for Women official. "It isn't just a gesture. We are taking it very seriously."

Tyson flew into Britain on Sunday amid tight security and controversy over his fight against British champion Julius Francis on January 29. About 100 security personnel, including police, security officials and Tyson aides, were at Heathrow to keep back 400 reporters and fans who had gathered to greet the former world champion as he arrived on a Concorde flight from New York.

In a U-turn, home secretary Jack Straw decided late Thursday to allow Tyson into the country despite a rape conviction. For days, government officials had said Tyson was purely a matter for immigration officials, but Mr Straw intervened at the last moment.

Ms Bindel accused Mr Straw of inconsistency: "It's sending out the wrong message to men and boys who may see Tyson as a role model," she said. "Rapists are not stigmatised the way rape victims are."

Under British law, anyone convicted of a crime which carries a sentence of 12 months or more in Britain should not be allowed into the country unless they can demonstrate "strong compassionate reasons" for the trip.

But Mr Straw granted Tyson leave to be in Britain until January 30 - the day after his bout against Francis in Manchester. Mr Straw said he had to balance his "abhorrence" at Tyson's criminal record with the "inconvenience" it would have caused to the public if the fight had been called off.

Women's rights groups want to force a judicial review in the high court of Mr Straw's right to make the decision.

"This is to challenge the decision of the home secretary... This (review) is to look at the extent of his powers and whether or not he has abused them," Ms Bindel said. "It is not a witch-hunt against Tyson... It is actually looking at how the home secretary has acted inappropriately so I do think we have a good chance. We have the top lawyers in the country working on this."

Tyson was convicted of rape in the United States in 1992 and sentenced to six years in jail. He then served another term for a "road rage" attack on two elderly motorists and was freed eight months ago.

webTitle: Money and the meaning of life

fields.headline: Money and the meaning of life
fields.standfirst: Business and science in race to crack genetic code
fields.trailText: The accelerating international effort to decode the blueprint of human life - the billions of building instructions locked inside each cell of the human body, is often likened to a race.
fields.body:
The accelerating international effort to decode the blueprint of human life - the billions of building instructions locked inside each cell of the human body, is often likened to a race.

The reality, as the gene patenting row now building in Europe shows, is that there are three sets of racers - capital investors, racing to make money out of genetics; scientists, racing to decode human DNA and explain the results; and ordinary people with health problems, rushing to every new hope of medical breakthrough.

Myriad Inc, one of the US biotechnology tigers riding high on Wall Street, was among the first firms to exploit the commercial potential of genetic screening in the mid-1990s when it patented a method to identify mutations in two human genes which, if present in women, give about an 80% chance that the person will develop breast cancer.

Myriad's system, which involves crunching through the entire length of the suspect gene to find its mutations, is widely admired as effective.

What has caused concern, in the US and now in Europe, is that as well as patenting the means of screening the genes, Myriad decided it would patent the genes themselves.

The genes, known as BRCA1 and BRCA2, occur naturally in the body. To many, taking out a patent on something which was simply discovered, rather than designed, seems bizarre, if not offensive. In copyright terms, it sounds like claiming rights to notes and letters instead of music and books.

Like the many other firms which have taken out patents on human genes, Myriad likes to point out that gene patenting isn't new. This is true, although the history is hardly comforting.

According to one version, the first patent on human genes was in 1976, when a US citizen, John Moore, had his spleen removed. Finding that Moore's cell line was unique, his doctor patented it and later sold it to a Swiss pharmaceuticals firm, which turned it into a million-dollar drug.

When Moore went to law, he was the Californian supreme court judged that citizens do not have rights to their cells once they have left their body.

"We've invested an enormous amount of man-years in making this discovery and making it applicable. It's only right that we should be protected," said Myriad spokesman Bill Hockett.

"It doesn't seem strange to us that we should find something of incredible value to individuals and have some commercial exploitation of our discovery."

He said Myriad had invested $10m (£6.25m) in its "invention". But how much went into finding the genes?

According to Mike Stratton, professor of cancer genetics at the Institute of Cancer Research, in London, it was the ICR which discovered BRCA2, with the help of the Sanger Centre, the non-profit Cambridge lab which is a partner in the global project to decode all human genes.

Prof Stratton said Myriad benefited from Sanger data and from a leak of information from the ICR.

The ICR is still in dispute with Myriad. "They are using their patent to restrict the use of the BRCA1 and BRCA2 sequences by publicly-funded diagnostic labs in Europe," Prof Stratton said.

The effect of Myriad's drive to monopolise BRCA screening in the US has been to stop research labs doing commercial screening. Now the tests are only done at a dozen labs licensed by Myriad, at a price set by Myriad.

The company's current move into Europe - enabled by a new European directive apparently making it possible to patent genes here, too - has provoked mixed reactions.

The Dutch government says it will not accept Myriad's approach. The British government appears to be caught between the promise of the exciting new world of reliable disease prediction and the dangers of endorsing an expensive, legally contentious monopoly.

At the 15 UK centres now screening BRCA genes in the small minority of women likely to be at risk, there is concern that they may be forced to stop their own simpler, cheaper tests. The best, in the form of Myriad, could be the enemy of the good.

"In theory, it could completely cripple a lot of labs. We're not as effective as Myriad, because we don't sequence the gene in quite the same way, but we do it in a more intellectual fashion," said Shirley Hodgson of the department of medical genetics at Guy's hospital, London, which screened 230 women last year.

"If we came to a mutation, we'd stop, whereas they sequence the whole gene."

Neva Haites, chairman elect of the British Society of Human Genetics, said: "It's not really the cost, it's more the lack of freedom to decide what kind of service you will offer.

"In a way I'd rather offer a 70% service to the whole of the UK rather than a 100% service to a tenth of the country."

The issue could soon hit the courts. The Wellcome Trust, the charitable foundation which provides a large slice of the funding for the Sanger Centre, has warned that it will use its financial muscle to confront zealous gene patenters.

"If faced with opportunistic and inappropriately broad patents being filed on sequence data, the Wellcome Trust confirms that it will challenge these as necessary," the foundation stated recently.

"The trust is committed to ensuring that data remains in the public domain."

The new European directive is open to interpretation. Some argue that it allows gene patenting, but Britain's patent office says it means "patents are not obtainable for genes or other body parts in their natural state".

Some cynics argue that the aggressive biotechnology corporations do not expect their patents to survive in court, but are simply using them to talk up their stocks and gain market share for the technology they use to exploit the genes.

Disturbed as he is by the gene patenters, the head of the Sanger Centre, John Sulston, says his real concern is companies like Celera, the private corporation competing with the non-profit Human Genome Project to decode the sequence of all the genes in human DNA.

Celera, headed by Craig Venter, plans to put his data on a commercial database, available only to subscribers.

The Human Genome Project makes its data public as soon as it gets it. Venter, said Mr Sulston recently, wanted his firm to be another all-encompassing giant of the information age - the Microsoft of Biology.

webTitle: US firm may double cost of UK cancer checks

fields.headline: US firm may double cost of UK cancer checks
fields.trailText: An American company which has "patented" two human genes for breast cancer screening is threatening the work of 15 publicly funded British laboratories that perform a genetic test at half the cost.
fields.body:
An American company which has "patented" two human genes for breast cancer screening is threatening the work of 15 publicly funded British laboratories that perform a genetic test at half the cost.

The attempt by the Salt Lake City firm, Myriad Genetics, to move into the European market signals the beginning of what is likely to be a bitter struggle over the "patenting of life" - whether private companies should be given exclusive rights to exploit the codes printed by nature in the cells of every human being.

Despite Myriad's patent claims, much of the work on at least one of the genes, BRCA2, was originally done in Britain, at the Sanger centre in Cambridge and the Institute of Cancer Research. Myriad filed its patent application literally hours before the ICR published its discovery of BRCA2 in the journal Nature, and the ICR still insists it discovered the gene first.

Myriad's move infuriated John Sulston, head of the Sanger Centre. "On both genes, for valid reasons, there's a very strong feeling that the way the patent system operates is neither ethical nor advantageous," he said.

"We can't quite believe it," said Dr Shirley Hodgson of the department of medical genetics at Guy's hospital, London.

"Basically, what they think they've got is the patent on both genes, which really has us by the short and curlies."

In a statement to the Guardian, the department of health said it had held "general discussions" with Myriad as part of consultations with "the whole of the genetics industry".

However, Myriad and genetics professionals in the UK said that talks about specifics were under way.

Speaking from Myriad's headquarters in Utah, a company spokesman, Bill Hockett, claimed that the existing laboratories were providing a poor service. He said that Myriad was seeking "standardisation of high quality testing" - effectively a monopoly over screening the "patented" genes - in Europe.

He said he did not know what would happen to the British laboratories which were providing the service. "It really depends on discussions with the NHS and other labs we're talking to in the UK. We don't intend to reduce the access to testing in any way.

"We're in the business to make this broadly available and to allow people high quality testing, and not just what ever home brew is whipped up in a laboratory."

British gene screeners argue that while they are not as sophisticated as Myriad, they can do the job and are more cost-effective. While Myriad's system churns through the entire gene, listing all mutations, the British method begins with known "hot-spots" where mutations are likely to occur, and only sequences the whole gene if this turns up nothing.

British laboratories charge £750 per test, half of Myriad's fee. British genetic screeners say they have never used technology or data from Myriad.

The genes involved, BRCA1 and BRCA2, occur naturally in human cells as one tiny part of the immense sequence of DNA, whose coded instructions build and maintain our bodies from the first union of human egg and seed.

Researchers discovered that certain mutations in these genes made women who had them much more likely to develop breast and ovarian cancer - an 80% chance in the case of breast cancer.

In the mid-1990s, Myriad began filing patents worldwide relating to BRCA 1 and 2. Most of the claims incorporated in the patents covered technology to discover and, one day, perhaps, treat the mutations. But the headline claims were patents on the genes themselves, scandalising many scientists, bioethicists, religious leaders and the emergent genetic rights movements in the United States.

Myriad's patent applications, like that of a series of other gene patents by private and public bodies worldwide, have yet to be seriously tested in the courts.

But a European directive on patents, to be incorporated into UK law this summer, appears to accept the principle that genes can be patented.

Neva Haites, professor of genetics at Aberdeen university and chairman-elect of the British Society of Human Ge netics, said: "This is a precedent. In the US, Myriad has managed to convince all the labs that used to test for this gene to shut down. If companies see this is a successful ploy for these two genes, they will start to exploit other patents for themselves.

"Some countries in Europe are coming out with very strong statements about the patenting of genes, and specifically saying they will not let their countries have their patient care inhibited. We'd like to see the department of health working on that."

fields.headline: Pharmaceutical giants announce merger
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's financial editor on what the deal means
fields.trailText: Drugs giants Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham today announced they had agreed terms for a merger to form Glaxo SmithKline.
fields.body:
Drugs giants Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham today announced they had agreed terms for a merger to form Glaxo SmithKline.

The groups said the "merger of equals" would create the world's leading research-based pharmaceutical company.

The combined group will have a value of around £114bn and will be one of Europe's largest companies by stock market value.

Glaxo shareholders will hold 58.75% of the new group, with SmithKline Beecham shareholders owning 41.25%.

The new company will have its corporate headquarters in London. Its new operational base will be in the US.

Glaxo SmithKline will have combined sales of £15bn and an annual research and development budget of £2.4bn. It will have an estimated 7.3% share of the global pharmaceutical market.

Sir Richard Sykes, chairman of Glaxo Wellcome, will become non-executive chairman of the new group. Jean-Pierre Garnier, chief executive elect of SmithKline Beecham, will become chief executive.

In a statement to the Stock Exchange, the companies said: "It is inevitable that redundancies will arise as a result of bringing the two companies together."

But they added that it was too early to comment on where job losses would occur and how many there would be.

The companies said the merger would generate annual cost savings of £1bn before tax - slightly lower than many analysts predicted. The integration process would take several years and the impact of job losses would be reduced by early retirement schemes and other plans.

The groups said there was no plan to close any major research and development site of either company worldwide.

Unions, which feared up to 15,000 job losses could follow the merger, were worried the tie-up would lead to the closure of either Glaxo's main research unit at Stevenage, Herts, or SmithKline's equivalent operation at Harlow, Essex. The merger comes two years after the companies first announced they were in talks. Negotiations then broke down as the boards failed to agree on management positions.

The merger comes two years after the companies first announced they were in talks. Negotiations then broke down as the boards failed to agree on management positions.

fields.headline: No rejoicing for 'defensive' merger
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's financial editor examines the implications of the Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham merger
fields.trailText: It has a been a long wait, almost two years in fact. But today Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, two of the country's premier pharmaceutical companies, have finally agreed to merge.
fields.body:
It has a been a long wait, almost two years in fact. But today Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, two of the country's premier pharmaceutical companies, have finally agreed to merge.

What we get is a drugs powerhouse worth more than £100bn, currently ranking as Britain's second biggest company and controlling just over 7% of the British drugs market. Its remedies will range from asthma and diabetes, through to the one proven drugs cocktail treatment for AIDs and then a long line of consumer products, such as Aquafresh toothpaste.

As the two companies merge to create what will be known as Glaxo SmithKline jobs will be lost and while the new firm will be headquartered in the UK its culture will be predominantly American, with a new operational base being established in the US.

The stock market might have been expected to rejoice at the creation of a new corporate world player with the clout to out-do rivals such as Pfizer, Warner-Lambert, Bristol-Myers Squidd and Johnson & Johnson. But there was little sign of any celebration yesterday as shares in both companies were marked sharply lower.

The City, in short, sees this as a defensive merger, forced on the two companies by the pace of change already happening around them.

Two years ago, when the deal was first mooted, the markets were ecstatic, adding £13bn to the value of the two companies in just one day. But the premium disappeared just as quickly as it emerged that the two men running Glaxo and SmithKline, Sir Richard Sykes and Jan Leschley, could not agree on who would run the newly merged entity. Executive ego, it seemed, matter rather more than shareholder value.

It was only when Mr Leschley set a retirement date and Sir Richard began to dabble with the idea of spending the rest of his working days back in the world of academia (Imperial College has been mentioned) that talks between the two companies resumed with any real vigour. Mr Leschley's successor at SmithKline, Jean-Pierre Garnier, will now take on the key chief executive role at Glaxo SmithKline.

It should be noted that this is not one of those slash-and-burn mergers so prevalent in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The mega-deals of the Hanson/BTR era were about consolidating businesses and then squeezing out as much cash as necessary, cold shouldering the resultant misery in terms of job losses and general upheaval. In fact the Glaxo SmithKline deal is forecast to produce annual cost savings of just £1bn from a combined business turning over £16bn a year, while a quarter of the savings will be reinvested in research.

Jobs will be shed in management (as one head office disappears) and in some areas of manufacturing. But the impact on research and development is likely to limited, because throwing money at developing and marketing new drugs is crucial to the new company maintaining its forward momentum.

Rivals will respond in predictable fashion. Pfizer of Switzerland is already trying to take over America's Warner-Lambert which, in turn, would rather merge with its domestic rival American Home Products. Other heavyweights such as Roche and Novartis, two other Swiss drug combines, are already engulfed by speculation.

The development of top quality drugs requires top dollar investment and then exceptional speed in marketing and distributing a new product around the world's markets. For this industry, like so many others, constant change is inevitable.

fields.headline: Fourth day washed out
fields.trailText: Play has been officially abandoned on the fourth day of the fifth Test between South Africa and England after heavy rain. But ground officials are optimistic of clearing up the saturated pitch so the final day's play can go ahead tomorrow.
fields.body:
Play has been officially abandoned on the fourth day of the fifth Test between South Africa and England after heavy rain. But ground officials are optimistic of clearing up the saturated pitch so the final day's play can go ahead tomorrow.

The United Cricket Board of South Africa had earlier rejected England's offer to play a one-day international tomorrow in a desperate attempt to make up for the rain-affected final Test.

Captain Nasser Hussain suggested the unscheduled day-night fixture against South Africa after the saturated run-ups once again delayed the start of the fourth day at Centurion Park, where the match has been restricted to just 45 overs play so far.

But Dr Ali Bacher, managing director of the UCB, and match referee Barry Jarman have rejected the offer because of contractual difficulties with both television companies and sponsors. "To the credit of the England captain, he volunteered to play a day-night game tomorrow," confirmed Bacher.

"There are practical problems involved with that. We have contractual obligations we would have to sort out. Both groundsmen say they think it is fit to play, but we have gone back to the umpires and conveyed to them what they have said."

South African captain Hansie Cronje is believed to have put Hussain's suggestion to his team, who were in favour of trying to continue the Test match rather than getting useful practice in for the forthcoming triangular one-day tournament against England and Zimbabwe.

Match referee Jarman said: "It's not my position to call the game off. The game is in the umpire's hands, and whatever they say goes. "From what we have seen out there, it is not going to be possible to play unless you play spinners from both ends. It is very soft underneath, and with the water table coming up so far I couldn't see it getting any better."

webTitle: Kosheh clashes Egypt in shock after sectarian violence

fields.headline: Kosheh clashes Egypt in shock after sectarian violence
fields.trailText: Police in Egypt found two burned bodies yesterday in a town where more than 20 people were killed over the New Year in the country's worst sectarian violence in decades.
fields.body:
Police in Egypt found two burned bodies yesterday in a town where more than 20 people were killed over the New Year in the country's worst sectarian violence in decades.

Muslim-Christian clashes in Kosheh, triggered by an argument between a Christian merchant and Muslim shopper, have shocked a country recovering from years of Muslim militant violence, often aimed at Egypt's Coptic Christians.

Members of Egypt's parliament had even proposed changing the name of the town from Kosheh to Peace in a bid to wipe out its troubled history.

Up to 59 Muslims and Christians including Coptic priest, Father Gabriel Abdel-Maseeh, are wanted for provoking violence, murder and arson. There have been 21 arrests. Father Maseeh has denied reports that some witnesses said they had seen him randomly open fire at neighbours during the clashes.

"That is not our style as Christian men of religion. We are not men of weapons," he declared, saying his aunt was among 19 Christians killed in fighting which erupted two days after a December 31 quarrel.

The Egyptian government has allocated £350,000 to rebuild gutted shops and houses in the town and vowed to severely punish those responsible.

"A radical solution has to be found to address this distressing event. We need to improve the quality of life in Kosheh," said Nabil Osman, head of the state information service. Coptic families said they could identify many of their attackers as neighbours they had known for years.

Some clerics complained that the police failed to protect the town's Copts, who make up about three-quarters of Kosheh's residents. In 1998 Kosheh came to prominence during a murder inquiry in which the police rounded up more than 1,000 Christians in the town and tortured them to try to get confessions. Human rights activists said police wanted to charge a Christian suspect because they were worried sectarian violence would erupt if a Muslim were found to have been behind the murders. Police eventually charged a Christian.

Muslims and Christians in Egypt have lived together in peace but the 10m Christians sometimes complain of discrimination.

fields.headline: Beware robberbarons.com
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The internet has crowned the consumer king. Unrestricted by time or space, the wily shopper can search globally for goods and services, thereby eroding the pricing power of producers. The result? A brave new world of low inflation and unlimited consumer choice. Or so the techno-prophets would it.
fields.body:
The internet has crowned the consumer king. Unrestricted by time or space, the wily shopper can search globally for goods and services, thereby eroding the pricing power of producers. The result? A brave new world of low inflation and unlimited consumer choice. Or so the techno-prophets would it.

The reality may be somewhat different. For while the internet is undoubtedly exerting downward pressure on prices in the short term, it may ultimately stunt consumer choice and confer immense monopoly power on a handful of global corporations.

In other words, far from being a liberating force for consumers, it may become a tool of economic oppression.

The case for the internet being the consumer's friend has been persuasively put by DeAnne Julius, who sits on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.

She says that, not only does it allow shoppers to compare the prices of standard goods and services online and bypass the middleman to buy them directly or use that information to extract extra discounts from the local supplier, it has enormous potential to increase the efficiency with which capital and labour are combined in production.

"For many products ICT (information and communications technology) has reduced design times, increased quality control and shrunk the need for precautionary stocks in the production chain," she says.

"Improved information flows enable firms to respond more efficiently to shifts in consumer preferences, and to customise their products and services to their needs. The speed and low cost of information transfer has led to greater outsourcing by producers to the cheapest global supplier, spurring and speeding the globalisation process."

The upshot of all this is a dramatic shift in market power from sellers of goods and services to their customers.

With the hi-tech American economy growing rapidly without - so far - creating strong inflationary pressures, there is certainly plenty of evidence to support Ms Julius' thesis about the positive impact of new technology.

The UK economy is not immune to these influences. Why else would Ford, which once told its customers they could have any colour Model T they wanted as long as it was black, now be grovelling to them by offering to refund the difference if competitive pressures force it to reduce the prices of its new V-registration cars?

However, it may be that consumer power is no more than a passing phase and that producers will eventually regain the upper hand.

In a new research paper, City economist Peter Warburton, of Robert Fleming & Co, argues that in a truly global market place, swarming with products and services, the only ones that will survive will be those which stand out among crowd.

Producers have always known the value of branding, but in the wired world of the 21st century it will become even more important.

Hence the vast expenditure on electronic advertising. "The logic behind the promotion of power brands is that of universal recognition," says Mr Warburton. "If there is only room for a tiny number of global brands, then the race to establish them is one of strategic importance. The potential rewards are so vast to justify colossal advertising expenditure for the brief interval during which the pecking order is decided."

Amid all the turmoil which will accompany the introduction of e-commerce, the likelihood is that many old businesses will be replaced by dynamic new ones.

But once the dust settles the businesses that triumph could be in a powerful position to reassert themselves against the consumer, who may well face higher prices and less choice.

Mr Warburton says that corporations such as Unilever are anticipating these developments. He points out that in September the company announced a strategic cull of its 1,600 brands in order to concentrate on 400 power brands.

Mr Warburton says: "The shortening of the list of brands is a profoundly important development. Whenever a new means of product or service delivery is developed (eg telephone banking and telephone car insurance), the pioneers of the new medium target the most attractive segments of the consumer market and screen out the bad risk and low margin segments.

"A successful online retailer will concentrate on the product lines that are most popular. It has no incentive to offer 40 choices of marmalade."

Surveys suggest the traditional high street had a good Christmas, with sales volumes the strongest for years. But retailers were not able to take advantage of strong demand by widening profit margins.

This shows that consumers remain in the ascendant, but the question is for how long. Unless they refuse to give in to the likely attempts to nudge retail margins upwards once the initial phase of the e-revolution is over, the new economy could end up looking like the old one, with producers dictating the rules of the game.

fields.headline: 'Cyberforce' to fight online crime
fields.trailText: A national "cyberforce" of computer specialists is to be established by the home office to police the internet and combat a rising tide of online crime.
fields.body:
A national "cyberforce" of computer specialists is to be established by the home office to police the internet and combat a rising tide of online crime.

It was confirmed last night that the home secretary, Jack Straw, has assigned £337,000 to the UK National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS) to draw up plans for establishing a squad to counter criminal activity on the web.

The move, which will target those using computers for fraud, money laundering, distributing pornography and information about paedophilia, and hacking, follows a three-year NCIS study of internet crime which concluded that illegal activity on the web, from email viruses to cyber-stalking, is increasing as the wired population grows.

Operation Trawler highlighted the inadequacies of anti-computer crime units, leading to calls for a dedicated organisation.

The new unit is expected to include experts in the private sector, the Inland Revenue and police. It will also draw on resources available through links with MI5 and GCHQ - the government agency that eavesdrops on Britain and the world's communications networks.

Roger Gaspar, the director of intelligence at NCIS, and David Phillips, the chief constable of Kent and head of the crime committee at the Association of Chief Police Officers are drawing up plans for the unit, which will also make use of links with American intelligence organisations and the FBI. Barry McIntyre

fields.headline: The human genome
fields.standfirst:
US company Myriad Genetics' announcement that it has patented two human genes for breast cancer screening and intends to move into the European market with its own genetic test has raised the question of whether private companies should be given exclusive rights to exploit the codes printed by nature in the cells of every human beings. The move also threatens the work of 15 publicly funded British laboratories that perform the test at half the cost. Ros Taylor explains the implications
Special report: patenting genes
fields.trailText: What is the human genome?
fields.body:
What is the human genome?

The genetic information needed to build a human being. In other words, the DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid), which is carried within the 46 chromosomes in each cell. The DNA takes the form of a double-stranded "ladder" of chemical bases which make up the "recipe" for a human being.

Why do scientists want to map it?

Although genes only account for 2%-4% of human DNA, identifying their sequence is a revolutionary project. Researchers have mapped the genome sequence of worms, yeasts and fruit flies. But mapping that of a human has vast potential.

Genetic (inherited) characteristics are often responsible for diseases, such as cancer. Analysing the genome (known as "functional genomics") makes it possible to spot these tendencies and conceivably prevent them. Once scientists understand how these genes contribute to disease, it should be possible to prevent diseases from developing rather than simply treat them.

Of course, that would be of enormous benefit to someone with a family history of cystic fibrosis or breast cancer.

Who's going to win the race?

US corporation Celera say they have already completed 90% of the human genome sequence, and will have finished it by the end of 2001. The collaborative Human Genome Project, which includes the Wellcome Trust, Sanger and US public funding, has a target date of 2003.

Why aren't they collaborating on such an important project?

Good question. The rewards for the winner are potentially enormous. They might decide to sell the information to other researchers (as Celera intend to do), or use it themselves. They might even - as Myriad and other companies have done - patent the genes they have discovered. But the Human Genome Project makes all its data publicly available, and you can see how far they've progressed here.

Patent it?! Since no one can patent an arm or a toenail, how can a company patent a human gene?

At its most mercenary, because without their investment in "bioinformatics" - the massive task of processing the genetic information - we would never have known about it. But an EU directive on the subject hasn't helped. According to the intellectual property commission, "the discovery of [an element of the human body], including the sequence or partial sequence of a gene, cannot constitute a patentable invention." However, "an element isolated from the human body or otherwise produced by means of a technical process, including the sequence or partial sequence of a gene" can.

Going beyond the question of ownership, the ethical implications of gene patenting are very serious. Most bioinformatics forms already fund research into the ethics of genome mapping, but patenting is another matter.

Will it go to court?

Probably. But for the time being, Myriad has already successfully patented two human genes in the US. BRCA1 and BRCA2 are the two genes which, if present in women, give them an 80% chance of developing breast cancer. (The Institute of Cancer Research claims to have got there first, but Myriad grabbed the patent.) This gives them a monopoly on screening human DNA for BRCA in the US, which they would like to extend to Europe.

What's wrong with that?

Nothing, say Myriad, who argue that their screening process is more thorough than that currently used in Britain. But British labs describe the British process as more intelligent, looking at "hot spots" where mutations are likely to occur first. It's also half the price of the Myriad test.

Will Myriad succeed?

The Wellcome Trust intends to challenge any attempt to patent genes in court. A number of European countries have also rejected it, but the department of health has been in talks with Myriad.

Both Celera and a Wellcome Trust researcher were recently interviewed on TV; read the transcript here.

But British labs describe the British process as more intelligent, looking at "hot spots" where mutations are likely to occur first. It's also half the price of the Myriad test. Will Myriad succeed? The Wellcome Trust intends to challenge any attempt to patent genes in court. A number of European countries have also rejected it, but the department of health has been in talks with Myriad. Both Celera and a Wellcome Trust researcher were recently interviewed on TV; read the transcript here. fields.headline: Calling Nasser's bluff
fields.standfirst: Each week we ask a county cricketer what he's been up to in the close season. Mark Ilott, of Essex and England, is the latest to spill the beans
fields.trailText: Mark Ilott, 29, a left-arm medium-fast bowler, made his debut for Essex in 1988. He has won five England caps, taking 12 wickets at 45.16.
fields.body:
Mark Ilott, 29, a left-arm medium-fast bowler, made his debut for Essex in 1988. He has won five England caps, taking 12 wickets at 45.16.

Well, what haven't I been doing this winter? I've been working twice a week in the City for GNI, the futures- and share-brokers. It all sounds very highfalutin, but my work is mostly on the PR side, entertaining clients who like cricket, taking them to nets and hitting them on the head - that sort of thing.

I've also set up my own business Sportsmarkuklimited with my wife, Sandra. It is a hospitality management operation, and I am hoping that it will overlap a bit with my work with GNI, though they mostly use Peter Parfitt [who runs a similar business].

I'm doing some work for the ECCBA committee at Essex, which helps raise money in the years in which there is no named beneficiary, like this one. Sixty percent of the money we raise will go to players who don't get their own benefit, and 40% goes to help players improve their education. I am the Secretary and it is quite a good sounding board for my benefit year, which I hope is coming up. I really enjoy doing it.

And lastly, I am the father of two kids, James and Madeline, and the husband of one old woman. Madeline is only ten months old and a very early riser. She has her milk with me in the morning - she's a typical little madam.

We've been back training at Essex since November; we will all be at the height of fitness by the beginning of the season. If our devotion to fitness was any reflection on our cricket we would be in the first division. I've actually only been back training from January, as a safety precaution against re-injuring my knee, which I hurt last July. In fact, I'm flying out to see Doctor Hans Muller-Wohlfahrt in Munich on Monday. I'm not quite sure what he's going to do but basically he makes you feel better. Michael Owen, Jurgen Klinsmann, and Boris Becker have all been to see him.

I've spoken to Nasser briefly. I got a garbled message from his wife saying that Nasser, who'd offered the ECCBA his blue World Cup pads as a raffle prize, wanted them back. I told him I'd sold them for £500, but that I'd get them back for him if he wrote me an article for the ECCBA brochure. Then I got them out of the boot of the car where I'd stored them along with the pram and a medicine ball. They were a bit ripped but I've sent them out to South Africa. And I'm told on very good authority (Paul Newman of the Telegraph) that his ghosted article will be with me next week. Otherwise Nasser will be getting another phonecall.

Next season I hope Essex get back in the first division and that I take 60 wickets or so and get back in the reckoning for England. I know that my chances of a recall are slim, but I'm only 29 and I think that I'm still a good bowler. I had a very good start to the season last year, and I'd done well in South Africa last time, so I like to think that if I'd stayed fit I'd have had a chance of being picked for the tour. I think I would have complemented the other bowlers, and I'm certainly a better batsman than some of them.

Mark Ilott was talking to Tanya Aldred

webTitle: My life on the net: Graham Norton

fields.headline: My life on the net: Graham Norton
fields.standfirst: The comedian talks us through his favourite websites.
fields.trailText: The comedian talks us through his favourite websites.
fields.body:
The only purposeful site I go to is Ask Jeeves. It searches all the search engines, so you get the most comprehensive search. It's just very easy to use, very uncomplicated. In a normal engine you don't get what you want or you have to change the words you've typed in. What's great about jeeves is that it comes up with everything you've asked for. It's faster and less frustrating than some of the web can be.

I have a lot of favourite websites, but www.findadeath.com bears revisiting many times. It's about celebrity deaths, and in the last few pages mentions their last meals before they died. The pictures are fantastic and the stories are funnily written. I didn't know Judy Garland died in London somewhere in a small mews. It's the sort of thing that's perfect for the web; I would never buy a book on it. It's linked to www.findagrave.com , of course, which has photographs of every celebrity's grave you could ever, ever, ever think of.

Airport Sleeping Tips is the budget traveller's guide to sleeping in airports. I have no idea who Donna McSherry is, but I guess she lives in California. People send in their descriptions of airports. The good thing about Gatwick is that it's silent - they don't make announcements. But the air conditioning is turned up very high so it's cold. Again, what I like about this is that it's very much the web. I'll read it because it's vaguely amusing.

www.losers.org - well, basically, this is an index of sad home pages, people's own web pages. It's really funny for people who spend a lot of time on the web. It's broken up into categories: wannabes, freaks, dorks, goths, punks, rednecks, girls. Lots of hideous pics. It's so odd. These people have chosen these pics as how they want to be seen by the world. I don't mind the internet not being useful, and I do like the fact that anyone can be on the web.
