webTitle: Aitken offers £1m from his ex-wife to clear libel debts

fields.headline: Aitken offers £1m from his ex-wife to clear libel debts
fields.trailText: Details of an offer of around £1m by the ex-wife of Jonathan Aitken in part settlement of his debts were made public last night. Lolicia Aitken is offering the payment to the bankruptcy trustees who are attempting to realise the disgraced ex-cabinet minister's assets.
fields.body:
Details of an offer of around £1m by the ex-wife of Jonathan Aitken in part settlement of his debts were made public last night. Lolicia Aitken is offering the payment to the bankruptcy trustees who are attempting to realise the disgraced ex-cabinet minister's assets.

Aitken has not paid a penny towards the estimated £2.4m he owes Granada TV and the Guardian for legal fees incurred in defending the libel action that resulted in his serving seven months in prison - from which he has just emerged - for perjury and perverting the course of justice. He continues to live in the house in Lord North Street, Westminster, worth more than £1.8m.

An article in today's Times details what it terms a "secret meeting" that the former Tory MP held on Friday with lawyers representing his creditors. Aitken presented written proposals to try to secure a "voluntary arrangement" to come to terms over his debts.

He offered a payment from his ex-wife Lolicia, who currently lives at various properties in Switzerland, Monaco and Paris.

The Times adds that Aitken is also planning to offer payments from the serialisation of his book of memoirs, which have been bought by a Sunday newspaper and are also being published by the Murdoch-owned HarperCollins. The serialisation is expected to fetch £60,000.

Aitken went through a divorce with Lolicia in Switzerland after he lost the libel ac tion, but it appears that she is now in a position to offer money in return for retaining possession of Lord North Street.

If the debts are not settled, the trustee in bankruptcy will be legally allowed to start possession and sale proceedings for the house in Lord North Street. Aitken, who was a millionaire, is now insolvent.

A spokesperson for the Guardian said last night: "The Guardian is examining the proposal Mr Aitken put to his creditors on Friday. The Guardian wants to help bring about a resolution to the situation but the money owing is substantial.

"We have not lost sight of the great financial cost the paper would have had to bear had Mr Aitken's high-profile and dishonest libel action succeeded."

webTitle: Left's victory sours triumph of right at Pinochet's release

fields.headline: Left's victory sours triumph of right at Pinochet's release
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Victory for Ricardo Lagos, is likely to sour the triumph claimed by supporters of General Augusto Pinochet following home secretary Jack Straw's announcement that he was "minded" to send him home because he was unfit to stand trial.
fields.body:
Victory for Ricardo Lagos, is likely to sour the triumph claimed by supporters of General Augusto Pinochet following home secretary Jack Straw's announcement that he was "minded" to send him home because he was unfit to stand trial.

Instead, Gen Pinochet now faces the prospect of spending his final days under a government whose leader has repeatedly criticised his past

Victor Falcedo, 38, a real estate salesman, was jubilantly celebrating outside Mr Lagos's campaign headquarters last night. He was firm in his belief that the Lagos victory would be a catalyst for important human rights advances.

"The people who had their relatives 'disappeared' will now be able to continue in their search," he said. "We want our country to get ahead and Pinochet has to go to his home, take care of his health and nothing else."

Despite massive media interest in the return of Gen Pinochet to Chile, both Mr Lagos and his rightwing opponent, Joaquin Lavin, attempted to ignore the issue during the election campaign, reinforcing the feeling that the former dictator has finally been removed from the centre stage.

"Pinochet has already ended his life, both politically and physically. He has been condemned by humanity, abandoned by his party and is flat on his back," said Camilo Escalona, 44, secretary general of the Socialist party.

Flabio Rojas, a sociology professor at the university of Chile, who was celebrating at Mr Lagos's headquarters doubted that Gen Pinochet would face trial in Chile. "Everything here is setup to keep these men away from justice," he said.

But Andres Morano, 29, the head of Mr Lagos's internet media operations said: "We now have a great opportunity to demonstrate that in this country we too can serve justice."

fields.headline: Socialist wins Chile's presidential election
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Socialist candidate Ricardo Lagos narrowly beat the upstart Joaquin Lavin in the Chilean presidential election yesterday.
fields.body:
Socialist candidate Ricardo Lagos narrowly beat the upstart Joaquin Lavin in the Chilean presidential election yesterday.

With 87.45% of the ballot counted last night, Mr Lagos had 51.3% to 48.6% for Mr Lavin, the populist candidate of the country's two rightwing parties. Mr Lavin went to his rival's campaign headquarters to shake his hand.

Mr Lagos's victory will allow the governing centre-left coalition, known as the Concertacion, to retain a third consecutive term in power. The Concertacion has governed Chile continuously since the end of General Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship in 1990.

Mr Lagos is the first representative of the left wing of the coalition to be elected president and is expected to push hard to rebuild social and cultural institutions destroyed by the military dictatorship. The last Socialist president of Chile was Salvador Allende, who was elected in 1970 but overthrown by the 1973 military coup supported by the CIA.

At Mr Lagos's campaign headquarters, tears of joy mixed with dancing and a collective sigh of relief last night as members recognised that they had nearly lost the race. Just four months ago, Mr Lagos was expected to coast to victory. The surprise strength of Mr Lavin will force the government to acknowledge the call of Mr Lavin's supporters to create jobs and deal with the growing discontent in many rural provinces.

"There is still a lot to do to perfect this democracy," said senator Andres Zaldivar of the Concertacion . Acknowledging the strength of Mr Lavin's well-oiled campaign machine, be said: "Sometimes a fright is healthy, as long as that fright doesn't kill you."

Margarita Cea, a member of the Lagos team that worked in rural regions said: "Despite the tight voting, this election shows that the majority of Chileans want to go forward with the Concertacion. We will learn from our mistakes." Asked whether she feared that violence might break out between the two camps, Ms Cea was optimistic.

"The first few days there will be conflicts, but [they will be] verbal not physical," she said. "Both candidates have maintained that they want the country to remain in peace."

At Mr Lavin's campaign headquarters, the tears of shock were mixed with frantic mobile phone calls as the Chilean elite sought to understand how they could have come so close to taking power, then lose. The right wing has not been elected to power since the 1958 victory of Jorge Alessandri. Mr Alessandri's family expressed fear that another era of socialist chaos had commenced.

Pia Guzman, a congresswoman for the centre-right wing party, Renovation National, was more willing to see the Lagos victory as a sign that Chile would now be ruled by two large blocs which would need to cooperate to solve the country's pressing problems.

"We have to be a firm opposition, but always a constructive opposition," she said. "What Chile needs is to arrive at grand agreements and support for our democracy."

webTitle: Doctors and nurses given inflation-busting pay hike

fields.headline: Doctors and nurses given inflation-busting pay hike
fields.standfirst:
But health authorities won't get extra cash to cover pay rises
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: Nurses are to receive an inflation-busting basic pay rise of 3.4%, the government announced today, hoping to deflect growing criticism of its running of the NHS.
fields.body:
Nurses are to receive an inflation-busting basic pay rise of 3.4%, the government announced today, hoping to deflect growing criticism of its running of the NHS.

Senior nurses at the top of the Grade E scale will get a 7.8% increase this year. Doctors are to receive a 3.3% boost, while professions allied to medicine, such as physiotherapists, will get 3.4%. Other NHS staff, including ambulance workers and porters, will receive a 3.25% rise or £300, whichever is the greater.

Health secretary Alan Milburn said: "After years in which pay rises were staged, it is right that they should be paid in full.

"For the second year in succession, staff at the forefront of delivering patients care will receive pay rises well ahead of inflation."

He added: "This is a fair pay rise for doctors, dentists, nurses, midwives, health visitors, therapists and other health professionals.

"In particular, it will help recruit more nurses into the NHS. Experienced staff nurses will also get extra pay to make it more worth their while to continue nursing in the NHS."

Dave Prentis, deputy general secretary of Unison, which represents 250,000 nursing staff said: "Unison is pleased that the pay review body has recognised the need to stop experienced nurses leaving the health service by giving them an additional pay boost.

"However, this spoonful of sugar will not help the medicine go down for the lowest paid nurses... For the rest of the health team who are not covered by the pay review body, there remains a long way to go to bring pay up to a decent level."

Health minister John Denham acknowledged that health authorities and trusts would not receive extra cash to cover the wage rises, but would have to pay for them out of their existing budgets.

"We make an allocation - a good one, well ahead of inflation - for the health service at a local level, from which they have to cover all their expenses," he told BBC Radio 4.

Nick Harvey, the Liberal Democrat spokesman on health, said: "It will take a lot more than an above-inflation increase to even begin to address this problem of how to make nursing something people want to do and keep doing.

"There is a major crisis in terms of nursing recruitment and nursing retention," he told BBC radio. "We have lost getting on for a third of the nursing positions nationwide since 1987. We can't lose that many people and not suffer the kind of capacity problems that we have seen during this recent crisis."

A Labour-supporting neurosurgeon from Oxford added his voice to the clamour of criticism recently directed at the government's management and funding of the NHS, which has been struggling to treat outbreaks of flu across Britain.

Tipu Aziz, a neurosurgeon at the Radcliffe Infirmary in Oxford, declared in a letter to the Daily Telegraph that the government had "destroyed the NHS in 18 months".

Teachers are also expected to get an inflation-busting pay rise of between 3% and 3.5% later this month, in a deal to back up the introduction of performance-related pay.

Headline inflation currently stands at 1.4% with underlying inflation running at 2.2%.

webTitle: Blair vows to double specialist schools

fields.headline: Blair vows to double specialist schools
fields.trailText: Hundreds of comprehensive schools will be turned into specialist colleges over the next three years as the government switches its focus from primary to secondary education, Tony Blair said yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of comprehensive schools will be turned into specialist colleges over the next three years as the government switches its focus from primary to secondary education, Tony Blair said yesterday.

By 2003 one in four state secondaries will have a specialism in technology, languages, sport or the creative arts. This would almost double the number of specialist colleges to about 800, the prime minister said.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, will announce the first stage of the expansion this week when she names 36 colleges, 22 specialising in technology and 14 in languages.

"Unlike the last government, we are resourcing specialist colleges to work with neighbouring schools, both secondary and primary. So by the next election almost every secondary with either have specialist status or be linked to one that has. That way we'll get a diverse comprehensive system that offers parental choice," she said.

The 36 specialist colleges to be announced this week will include schools in Plymouth, Newcastle, Cumbria, Essex, Halton, St Helens, and the London borough of Islington.

The department for education and employment said 86% of English education authorities would now have at least one specialist college. By the last election, there were 222 and 500 are due to be operational by September.

webTitle: Enter Tyson, adored by fans, exit George Michael, ignored

fields.headline: Enter Tyson, adored by fans, exit George Michael, ignored
fields.standfirst: Roy Hattersley - I don't think we're boxing clever
fields.trailText: At 5.40pm yesterday Mike Tyson emerged into the arrivals area of Heathrow's terminal 4 building and the British immigration service breathed a huge sigh of relief.
fields.body:
At 5.40pm yesterday Mike Tyson emerged into the arrivals area of Heathrow's terminal 4 building and the British immigration service breathed a huge sigh of relief.

In the end, no one had to tell the fearsome Tyson that he was not welcome in the country - not that there were many volunteers for the task in the first place.

Tyson, accompanied by two police officers, gave a gentle smile and a brief flash of his gold teeth to hundreds of waiting fans who greeted his emergence - from underneath a "no entry" sign - with frenzied adoration.

All eyes at Heathrow were eagerly anticipating the arrival of one man. Not even the presence of George Michael, who was travelling on the same New York Concorde flight as the boxer, drew the crowd's attention as he slipped out of the airport like any other traveller, appearing somewhat bemused at why he was being ignored.

After days of controversy surrounding Tyson's arrival, flight BA002 touched down at 5.22pm. Fellow passengers said he slept most of the way, waking now and again to drink water and eat salmon.

According to airport officals, Tyson was quickly off the plane and presented his passport to an immigration offical. The boxer spent two seconds at an immigration counter before being handed his passport back and being told to "have a nice stay". Tyson simply smiled and took his first offical steps on to British soil.

As he emerged from the baggage reclaim area and made his way towards a Mercedes limousine, scores of fans rushed through the terminal building trying to get close to the former world champion.

A scrum of security guards formed a protective ring around the boxer as they fought back the crowd, swerved through doors and carefully dodged a couple of baggage trolleys on their way to the waiting car.

Submerged in the middle of it all, Tyson gave a brief smile and a clenched-fist salute as he was bundled into the back of the Mercedes and whisked off to a central London hotel to begin training for his first fight in Britain, on January 29 against Julius Francis.

A reporter was taken to hospital apparently suffering from shock after she was knocked down in the melee.

Perhaps it was not the reception that Tyson expected after spending most of last week up against the ropes as one British politican after another assaulted him verbally.

The future of the bout in Manchester was thrown into doubt after it was discovered that the boxer was on a list of people who should be denied automatic entry to Britain.

Immigration rules prevent anyone who has been sentenced to 12 months or more for a crime that would carry a similar sentence in this country from entering the UK.

Tyson was convicted of rape in 1992 and sentenced to six years' imprisonment, leading to demands that he should be prevented from entering the country. The only way he was able to get in was with the permission of the home secretary, Jack Straw, who used his executive powers.

Now that Tyson is here, the next 10 days will be spent in the luxury of the Grosvenor House hotel in Park Lane. His entourage have taken a whole floor and a gym has been constructed where he will train for the fight.

Women's groups pledged to fight the home secretary's decision. Pat Wilkins, solicitor for Justice for Women, said the group intended to make an application to the high court today. A full hearing could take place by the end of the week if the judge decides there is a case to answer.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here
fields.trailText: Steve Outing www.mediainfo.com
fields.body:
Steve Outing www.mediainfo.com

"The newspaper digital kiosk may finally kill the traditional news-stand. Imagine not only being able to get a copy of any newspaper at the airport news-stand print-station kiosk, but also being able to get any printed newspaper from print stations in libraries, on demand.

A long-term question about these services is whether news consumers - especially travellers - will still want to read the printed page. Won't we all be downloading our local newspaper and reading on screens rather than dead trees?

James Cutie, CEO of PressPoint [which will deliver papers - transmitted by the internet and locally printed - anywhere in the world] believes that in certain markets, digital reading will largely supplant paper.

News media futurist David Carlson, director of the Interactive Media Lab at the University of Florida-Gainesville's school of journalism, agrees that eventually paper will lose out to digital reading devices. Just spend a day watching an eight-year-old, he says, and you'll get an appreciation of how future adult generations will be perfectly comfortable meeting all their news and information needs sans paper."

Jim Rutenberg www.observer.com

"After a run of roughly 50 years, the age of network television came to an end on Sunday, January 9 2000, with the merger of America Online Inc and Time Warner [owner of HBO and CNN]. The $183bn merger means an era in which the TV set and the computer will merge.

'This means you may watch HBO on your Palm Pilot,' said Christopher Dixon, media analyst for Paine Webber.

With this broadband alliance, it is conceivable that one day soon, AOL-Time Warner subscribers will be able to log on and pull up archived episodes of the Sopranos, Roswell or ER at will, thus creating their own TV schedules.

Bressler said he believes many shows will be re-created for the internet with shorter running times for shorter attention spans. What about the commercials? Since online viewers would be inclined to skip through the commercials, careful product placement may tell you that Buffy the Vampire Slayer's pants are made by the Gap. If you're interested, you could click onscreen and buy a pair online."

Howard Kurtz http://www.washingtonpost.com

"At a more fundamental level, several analysts say, the creation of the world's largest media and cyberspace company seems to muddy the original dream of the internet as a democratising force that would enable thousands of individual voices to compete with major media organs. But the rapid expansion of newspaper, magazine and network sites on the web has given it a decidedly corporate cast."

fields.headline: It's content, stupid
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Many believe that last week's AOL-Time Warner mega-merger proves the importance of content in the new media age (hence AOL's desire to link with a "traditional" media company with leading consumer brands). Others point out that AOL, a leading internet portal, wanted to extend its broadband distribution, and will get privileged access to the cable franchises owned by Time Warner, America's second largest cable operator. Yet others saw the merger as proof that internet companies are more valuable than traditional ones, and that Time Warner needed to maximise distribution through an internet portal.
fields.body:
Many believe that last week's AOL-Time Warner mega-merger proves the importance of content in the new media age (hence AOL's desire to link with a "traditional" media company with leading consumer brands). Others point out that AOL, a leading internet portal, wanted to extend its broadband distribution, and will get privileged access to the cable franchises owned by Time Warner, America's second largest cable operator. Yet others saw the merger as proof that internet companies are more valuable than traditional ones, and that Time Warner needed to maximise distribution through an internet portal.

But what does it mean for the UK? In the immediate aftermath of the announcement, media shares in London soared, led by Pearson and BSkyB. Some shares have settled back, but the expectation is that investors will continue to favour content-rich companies.

This is proof, I believe, of a new orthodoxy in the public markets. A year ago, many big traditional media companies were thought to be threatened by the internet. Now, they are seen as major beneficiaries, owing to the value they can generate online with their expensively developed "offline" brands.

A mini AOL-Time Warner had, in effect, already been created in the UK, in the form of the intended merger of Telewest and Flextech. That deal, set to be completed in the next six months, creates an integrated company offering distribution (through Telewest's franchised cable homes) and content (including Flextech's four wholly-owned channels, its joint-venture BBC channels and existing and planned interactive services).

The combination is potent and timely, given the restructuring under way in the UK media sector, sparked by the intended merger of the two large ITV broadcasters United and Carlton, and the possibility that Granada will go for one or other of the merger partners. Media companies are seeking to leverage their existing brands and distribution windows, thereby tapping new revenue streams. Access to TV homes can fuel migration of consumers to new platforms such as the internet and interactive TV. Flextech's content and its pay-TV channels, supported by Telewest's broadband strategy, could be an opportunity to derive significant profits from singular, branded content in the digital environment.

The next wave of media expansion is likely to come from interactive TV and the internet, where Flextech has been focusing attention in the past 18 months. With Telewest's telephony offering, and its extensive cable TV franchises, the Flextech product is likely to have guaranteed long-term UK distribution. Moreover, the link with Telewest could provide a boost to distribution on other cable networks as well, where content is at a premium. Add to this the potential of new platforms, such as ADSL (digital lines offered by BT) and third-generation mobile telephony (offering internet access and short message services), and the combined group looks well-placed to distribute content to consumers.

So, which other companies might follow, combining internet, content and networking strengths? In the UK, all eyes are on Pearson, owner of the Financial Times, Longman's, Addison Wesley and Penguin, and an obvious potential partner for a big internet company. Equally potent would be the combination of a big ITV player (Granada?) with the UK's leading internet service provider, Freeserve, 80% owned by Dixon's. That would allow Granada to distribute its extensive entertainment content through at least 1.6m Freeserve homes (more in the future) And Freeserve, which has been searching for new content to help retain and grow its user base, would derive immediate benefit.

I magine, too, if Granada-Freeserve were joined by Carlton and Granada, once a single ITV company was a regulatory possibility. Still not AOL-Time Warner, but ITV-Freeserve looks a tantalising combination. There is a difference, however. Granada is worth £10bn; Freeserve is trading at £4.3bn. So, the relative sizes are reversed compared to AOL and Time Warner. But that shouldn't stop the logic of common ground.

In truth, however, it is unclear how many real mergers will result from the model of AOL-Time Warner. Content deals (long-term and exclusive) might be as good as an equity relationship when it comes to uniting the internet and traditional, linear content. The key is to bring together bespoke content and guaranteed distribution. The very big money will be made by re-purposing content owned outright for distribution on as many platforms as possible: traditional TV, pay-TV, the internet, mobile phones, etc. But it isn't essential to own the platform, too. Content providers should be able to do distribution deals, provided the material on offer wins consumer favour.

Final lesson, then, of the AOL-Time Warner merger. It really is all about content, content, content, after all.

Mathew Horsman is a media analyst at the City firm of Investec Henderson Crosthwaite

webTitle: Lib-Lab project in jeopardy as Blair cools on PR referendum pledge

fields.headline: Lib-Lab project in jeopardy as Blair cools on PR referendum pledge
fields.standfirst: Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's historic Lib-Lab cabinet committee could be on the verge of collapse after he refused to give an undertaking that Labour would hold a referendum on electoral reform after the next election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's historic Lib-Lab cabinet committee could be on the verge of collapse after he refused to give an undertaking that Labour would hold a referendum on electoral reform after the next election.

In a move that will provoke the Liberal Democrats, who are demanding a referendum as the price of continued links with Labour, the prime minister sounded a distinctly cool note about electoral reform.

Asked on BBC1's Breakfast With Frost whether Labour's next election manifesto would include a commitment to hold a referendum, the prime minister said: "As to what happens next parliament, well, there'll be a debate or discussion in the Labour party. We'll make up our minds later on that."

His remarks infuriated the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy, who last night warned of trouble ahead over Lib-Lab links if Mr Blair failed to live up to his manifesto commitment to hold a referendum on electoral reform.

"We are looking for a consistent commitment to [Labour's] existing manifesto commitment into the future," Mr Kennedy told Radio 4's Westminster Hour. "Obviously if, for whatever reasons, that position changes, then all bets are off."

The Lib Dems have accepted that a referendum will not be held this side of the general election - a decision they have privately welcomed as they know that they would lose the vote at the moment.

However, Mr Kennedy is insistent that he will pull the plug on Mr Blair's project to realign the centre left if Labour reneges on its manifesto commitment.

His warning, which was first made last weekend, appears to have fallen on deaf ears, judging by Mr Blair's non-committal response to questions on electoral reform yesterday.

"Well, let us see what the manifesto ends up saying," the prime minister told David Frost. "There are all sorts of discussions that are going on and don't take what I've said as meaning either way."

Mr Blair held out one crumb of comfort for the Lib Dems when he said that he still remained committed to growing cooperation between Labour and the Lib Dems.

"I certainly do want to see a relationship between the Liberal Democrats and the Labour party that grows closer over time," he said. "If people are basically modern social democrats who agree with each other then they should work closer with each other."

The prime minister's apparent indifference to electoral reform underlines the cooling in relations between Labour and the Lib Dems since Mr Kennedy's election last August.

Downing Street regards Mr Kennedy as something of a lightweight who has yet to prove himself as a party leader because of mixed signals he has sent out over his commitment to Lib-Lab cooperation.

The former Lib Dem leader Paddy Ashdown was highly rated by Downing Street because of his clear commitment to the "project" to realign the centre left. He was also seen as a heavyweight who could be a formidable opponent.

The prime minister's coolness over electoral reform came as he sounded a moderately Eurosceptic note about the European single currency. In the same interview he said that he sympathised with people who were opposed to joining the euro.

"If we had suddenly to join we would have a very difficult economic situation because our economy is not in the same cycle as that of France or Germany at the moment," Mr Blair said.

However, the prime minister said that he was still committed to holding a referendum on the euro after the next election if a series of economic tests had been met.

"It is in my view in Britain's interest to be part of the successful single currency but only provided economic conditions are met."

Mr Blair insisted that all ministers were rallying behind his position.

"If we had suddenly to join we would have a very difficult economic situation because our economy is not in the same cycle as that of France or Germany at the moment," Mr Blair said. However, the prime minister said that he was still committed to holding a referendum on the euro after the next election if a series of economic tests had been met. "It is in my view in Britain's interest to be part of the successful single currency but only provided economic conditions are met." Mr Blair insisted that all ministers were rallying behind his position.

fields.headline: Pink pound
fields.standfirst:
Will financial newspapers be able to succeed in a digital future, where real-time market news is available on the web? Chris Barrie meets a man charged with showing the FT how.
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It has to be said that Larry Kramer does not look like a media mogul. He is not huge. He is not smoking a cigar. His eyes do not look predatory. And he takes an endearingly self-deprecatory line on his own appearance.
fields.body:
It has to be said that Larry Kramer does not look like a media mogul. He is not huge. He is not smoking a cigar. His eyes do not look predatory. And he takes an endearingly self-deprecatory line on his own appearance.

But then Kramer is about tomorrow's media rather than today's. And his enthusiasm and energy for what the internet offers both journalists and readers is everything that a sceptical European expects from a west coast American.

Seated in an office in the elegant Financial Times building overlooking the Thames, Kramer is in London to explain his latest venture, a free internet service designed to bring financial news to Europe's fast-growing army of private investors.

The service, www.FTMarketWatch.com, is a joint venture between the Financial Times, owned by the media group Pearson, and MarketWatch.com, operator of one of America's leading financial websites. In a deal typical of the intricate webbing that laces new media companies together, Market Watch is part-owned by the American broadcasting giant, CBS.

The venture represents far more than just another online news service. It is an indication of just how seriously the big players in traditional media now take the new digital world. Faced with the arrival of rival internet services starting from scratch, the big media groups are coming together in an attempt to crush the upstarts.

FTMarketWatch.com already exists in US form as CBSMarketWatch.com, America's biggest financial news site. Kramer, chairman, chief executive and co-founder of MarketWatch.com, hopes to replicate in Europe the success of the US service, where demand for financial news has surged on the back of investor enthusiasm for fast-rising share values in technology companies. "There are only two things that motivate people to go to a financial site: fear and greed," Kramer says. "They have been there throughout history. Greed is about people who want to get rich and make a lot of money, and they believe there are ways to do it now that weren't available to them before."

Fear, on the other hand, has a broader impact. Individuals are having to take more responsibility for their own finances, a trend established in the US and becoming prevalent in Europe. The result is that people are fearful of being left behind: they see huge sums being made in the stock markets, and feel they must join the game.

If Kramer is right, this powerful combination of fear and greed will drive people to internet sites rather than traditional media such as the Wall Street Journal or the FT. This necessitates a fundamental change in the way such newspapers do business.

US experience with CBSMarketWatch.com has taught Kramer that the service has three key advantages over traditional media: it is free because it is funded by advertising; it is available on the internet and via partnerships with powerful new media players such as AOL and Yahoo; and it can offer very close to real-time news. When an investor has savings tied up in a volatile share, he or she clearly wants the most up-to-date information possible.

Kramer says that as a result far more people now turn to CBSMarketWatch.com than read the Wall Street Journal. Traffic growth across CBSMarketWatch.com has been astronomical. One year ago what would have been a good day now covers about four hours of activity. Capacity has had to increase by 40% a month for the past four months. "It is just exploding," he said.

This pedigree, coupled with the power of the FT brand, will make FTMarketWatch.com a formidable competitor for the fledgling services being started in Britain by companies such as TheStreet and BreakingViews, being set up by former FT journalists Hugo Dixon and Jonathan Ford. Already up and running in the US, TheStreet will be launching a British version of its service imminently at TheStreet.co.uk.

Kramer says pointedly that CBSMarketwatch.com is four times the size of TheStreet.com in the US. But the reality of the internet is that a competitor can close the gap quickly on a rival if better content is provided: users have little brand loyalty to keep them faithful to one site. So the one sure outcome is that financial journalists are suddenly in big demand.

FTMarketWatch.com will be edited by Thom Calandra, editor of the US site and a journalist with experience on the San Francisco Examiner and at the Bloomberg wire service. He will hire 35 journalists within six months, by which time the service will be up and running.

Using the FT's affiliation to other European papers such as Les Echos in France, the service will offer national services to each major European market over the next year to 18 months.

Kramer argues that the coverage FTMarketWatch.com will offer - market-driven news for the general public - has not existed before in Europe.

News editing is crucial: in the US the service has five editors remaking the "front" page endlessly, giving users a fast glance at the most important stories of the minute and the day.

"A lot of other news organisations, especially TV and newspapers, that went to the web automated that process. We erred on the side of more news editors. We felt people wanted our assessment of what is important.

"This should be music to the ears of journalists. Ours is a site built by journalists and it understands the value journalists bring to coverage, that you can't automate some things." Kramer argues that the news judgements are crucial given that investors will be making rapid decisions on the basis of what they read.

Originally a reporter on the San Francisco Examiner, Kramer became a financial reporter on the Washington Post, then assistant to executive editor Ben Bradley, before returning as executive editor of the Examiner. He also has an MBA from Havard.

Despite his enthusiasm for the internet, Kramer believes newspapers will survive. "A paper like the Financial Times has a long future because it is thought-provoking. It lets you take a deep breath and think about events and go at them. Newspapers have their own portability, and the written word still carries weight. Maybe they will be the second, not the first, draft of history. You will not see newspapers breaking news.

"Look at the newspaper business in the US. The newspapers that survived and flourished are the Washington Post and New York Times and LA Times which put things in context. The ones that died are the ones that survived on breaking news, afternoon papers and tabloids. The role just changes."

Kramer argues that financial news occupies a special place in the news market. Sports fans, for example, will use the net for information but their first stop is the game itself, to see the action. Similarly on entertainment, where users will use the web to supplement the experience of reading a book or seeing a film by visiting related websites.

But, he says, "In the financial world, we are the game. We are the entertainment as well as the coverage. You watch the game in real-time on our site. On top of that, every element of financial services is on the internet and they need a medium to advertise on in that world."

Kramer says the potential for advertising revenue is huge as a result. Magazines in the US like Business Week and Fortune, he says, make $300m-$400m a year in revenue from advertisers who reach 1m people. CBSMarketWatch had 4.6m monthly visitors in the third quarter last year. Given that an internet service has fewer costs than a conventional publication, the prospects for huge profits are clear.

Kramer finishes with a final piece of evangelical prophecy: "The internet is the medium of choice for financial news. It is better than television, it is better than radio, it is better than newspapers because financial news has a shelf life. This is the fastest way you can get information to people and if you can do it for free that is how they are going to get it."

webTitle: Dying to see in the millennium

fields.headline: Dying to see in the millennium
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: It is no secret that many people were dying to see in the millennium but only now is it possible to quantify the extent of the phenomenon.
fields.body:
It is no secret that many people were dying to see in the millennium but only now is it possible to quantify the extent of the phenomenon.

Far more people than expected died in the first week of this year and researchers believe the ability to postpone one's demise until just after significant events is behind it.

The Office of National Statistics in the United Kingdom said that 20,772 people died in the week to January 7, an increase of 65% on the 12,629 in the previous week. Even taking the flu epidemic into account, this is way ahead of the average of 15,900 who have died in the first week of each of the previous five years.

In New York City, 1,791 died in the first week of 2000, a 50.8% rise on the 1,187 in the same period in 1999 and 46% above the 1,226 in the final seven days of last year. This year's figures were not affected by flu, which was running at normal levels in the city.

"It does look significant," said Robert Butler, founder and president of the International Longevity Centre. "The will to live can be pretty powerful."

Richard Suzman, associate director of the National Institute on Aging, in Bethesda, Maryland, said: "It's pretty well established that people who are seriously ill will hang on to reach significant events, whether they be birthdays, anniversaries or religious holidays.

"In this case, making it into the next century or millennium certainly counts as that. The mechanisms are something of a mystery but the phenomenon is very real."

One specific example was offered by Joel Potash, medical director of the Hospice of Central New York, Syracuse.

"We had one person who was on intravenous fluids and said, 'I want to make it to the new millenium and then you can stop the IV.' " Dr Potash did not reveal whether the fireworks in Sydney, the crystal ball in Times Square, or the sight of Tony Blair holding hands with the Queen were enough to make the patient soldier on a little longer.

fields.headline: Chechen war enters guerilla phase
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russia increased its onslaught on the battered Chechen capital, Grozny, at the weekend, with the Chechen leader, President Aslan Maskhadov responding by declaring a renewed guerrilla war against the Russian forces.
fields.body:
Russia increased its onslaught on the battered Chechen capital, Grozny, at the weekend, with the Chechen leader, President Aslan Maskhadov responding by declaring a renewed guerrilla war against the Russian forces.

Russian aircraft and artillery subjected Grozny to one of the severest poundings of the four-month war and Russian commanders said the Russian ground campaign to capture Grozny, after three weeks of failure, had entered a "new stage". Operations to wipe out rebel strongholds in the southern mountains, the Russians claimed, would last another two or three weeks.

"We will finally take Grozny. We will finish the operation in the mountains, no matter who is hiding there in the caves. We will do that," Russia's prime minister and acting president, Vladimir Putin, stated in a TV appearance designed to boost further his chances of winning the country's presidential elections on March 26. "We'll be tough, but not cruel," he said.

In a further attempt to seal off the Chechen rebels, the Russian border service announced it had reached agreement with Georgia to co-ordinate patrols along and information on Chechnya's southern border - the republic's only international frontier. Moscow claims it is crossed by conduits for guerrilla arms and supplies.

The Russian agreement with Georgia, said the Itar-Tass news agency, foresaw "co-operative action to repel possible bids of Chechen rebels to break through the border".

The agreement came in the wake of Turkish President Suleyman Demirel's visit to Georgia at the weekend. Turkey is Russia's traditional and current rival for power and influence in the Caucasus, and Mr Demirel called for the erection of a "Caucasus stability pact", inviting Russia to join in a common effort to stem unrest in the region.

The call was certain to trigger suspicion and scepticism in Moscow, which views the Caucasus as its business and Turkey as a dangerous and ambitious usurper, backed by Nato and America. "What we see now is a Russian non-policy in the Caucasus," said a Turkish official in Georgia. "They're simply reacting to something they cannot cope with."

Meanwhile, the Chechen fighters have opted to try to build on their gains of the past 10 days by formally declaring a strategic shift from defence to guerrilla counter-attacking.

"The period of fighting for strategic positions is ending," said the Chechen defence minister, Magomed Khambiyev, following a meeting of rebel commanders. "From now on, we will focus on partisan war tactics. We do not aim to enter populated areas and hold them; our aim is to smash separate [Russian] units and to retreat to repeat the operation elsewhere."

A decision to suspend Russia's membership to the Council of Europe could hinge on a week-long fact-finding mission from the council that starts today. Leader of the delegation, Lord Russel-Johnston, told Interfax he "cannot rule out" the possibilty of a suspension.

fields.headline: A tale of three cities
fields.trailText: You report (World city rankings, January 13) that Zürich, Vienna, Berne and Geneva share top place in the city league table for quality of life, while London is in 34th place. I would be interested to know if the scoring covered racial diversity and tolerance as a plus factor.
fields.body:
You report (World city rankings, January 13) that Zürich, Vienna, Berne and Geneva share top place in the city league table for quality of life, while London is in 34th place. Obviously, London's poor transport provision is a major negative factor. But I would be interested to know if the scoring covered racial diversity and tolerance as a plus factor. Given the electoral success of racist parties in Austria and Switzerland, I would mark their cities down, since racism poisons the social environment for all residents. London is hardly perfect in embracing racial diversity, but we are getting there. I know that that enhances my quality of life and enjoyment, besides being an economic asset in an integrated European global economy.
Sarah Ludford, MEP
sludford@europarl.eu.int

 I am at a loss to understand why Ougadougou features in the bottom 10 cities (Real lives, January 14), alongside war-torn and violent capitals like Luanda and Lagos. Burkina Faso is one of the world's poorest countries but its citizens are rightly proud of their capital city. I am always struck by its clean streets, relaxed and safe atmosphere and the vibrant nightlife which is enjoyed equally by men and women. The city also hosts Africa's largest film festival, from which a retrospective of prizewinning films will shortly be showcased at London's ICA.
Rona Alexander
Oxford
ontheline@ontheline.org.uk

 It is absurd for Darcus Howe (Look on the white side, Media, January 10) to suggest Oldham "is a white space". The area of Oldham in question includes people from a mix of racial backgrounds, living with each other in a spirit, largely, of harmony and respect for each other. There is no finer example of Oldham's multicultural endeavour than in our sixth form college. Attainment figures show that both white and non-white students excel at similar levels.
Cllr John Battye
Mayor of Oldham

fields.headline: Worm's eye
fields.trailText: Baffled by the new economy? Lost in the 21st century's manic stock market and kaleidoscopic industrial scene? Worry no more. Here, seasonally adjusted for the Y2K bug and the Julian calendar, is your year 2000 decoder...
fields.body:
Baffled by the new economy? Lost in the 21st century's manic stock market and kaleidoscopic industrial scene? Worry no more. Here, seasonally adjusted for the Y2K bug and the Julian calendar, is your year 2000 decoder...

In terms of economic behaviour, a fundamental change of step: straight off Beachy Head.

A new paradigm that re-models everything we ever thought we knew about markets, labour and consumer goods: purple haze/going through my brain...

We are now living in a world without borders: modish concept dreamed up on television gardening programme.

Britain, after decades of under-achievement, is now poised to lead Europe in terms of economic growth: as in 1959, 1964, 1973 and 1987.

Key to the new economy is a relentless downward pressure on costs - the cost of labour, that is.

However, there will, of course, remain high-cost "hot spots": profits, rents, prices...

Let there be no doubt, nothing could be more obsolete than the old ways of measuring corporate success: such as profitability, turnover and the approval of a respectable accountant.

Investors need to learn quickly the new yardsticks: such as chronic losses, a trendy logo and the approval of a public-relations consultant.

We need to give maximum encouragement to "smart regions" in the new economy: we need to concrete over all the countryside in the south-east.

We need to call time on outdated ideas of regional policy - see above.

There is no place for sentiment in regional assistance: cut off aid to former mining villages.

Transport is pivotal to success in this new, unfamiliar economic environment: no more talk of congestion charges, and let's have extra carriageways for everybody.

America is setting the pace as this new decade dawns. It is the model for us all: as were Sweden, Germany, Japan, Singapore, Cuba, the Soviet Union...

Make no mistake, globalisation is here to stay: except for asylum seekers, immigrants, refugees, etc...

The World Trade Organisation is a monument to international cooperation: in the fields of teargas, rubber bullets, riot control.

Only the most backward-looking would seek to reverse the enormous changes seen during the past 20 years: You're the madman. Not me. You are.

To oppose free trade is little short of lunacy: Nurse! Quickly!

The internet is going to change everything: anyone remember Prestel?

We are moving towards a knowledge economy: everyone will work as London taxi drivers.

Books, wine, CDs: the only commodities ever mentioned in connection with internet commerce, doubtless to give the impression that the online shopper is a discerning sort of chap rather than an unhygienic sad-cake.

Britain can win in the new economy: anything's possible.

But it will need discipline and restraint: wage restraint, that is.

There is no room at all for uncompetitive working practices: you're fired.

However, success and talent must be properly rewarded: share options all round!

We are moving into exciting and wonderful new times: just another shot, just a small one...

And we can see clearly a bright road ahead: leave the bottle here, it'll save time.

There is no gain without pain in the new economic order: cue stock market crash.

But tomorrow is another day: the party's over.

Key to the new economy is a relentless downward pressure on costs - the cost of labour, that is. However, there will, of course, remain high-cost "hot spots": profits, rents, prices... Let there be no doubt, nothing could be more obsolete than the old ways of measuring corporate success: such as profitability, turnover and the approval of a respectable accountant. Investors need to learn quickly the new yardsticks: such as chronic losses, a trendy logo and the approval of a public-relations consultant. We need to give maximum encouragement to "smart regions" in the new economy: we need to concrete over all the countryside in the south-east. We need to call time on outdated ideas of regional policy - see above. There is no place for sentiment in regional assistance: cut off aid to former mining villages. Transport is pivotal to success in this new, unfamiliar economic environment: no more talk of congestion charges, and let's have extra carriageways for everybody. America is setting the pace as this new decade dawns. It is the model for us all: as were Sweden, Germany, Japan, Singapore, Cuba, the Soviet Union... Make no mistake, globalisation is here to stay: except for asylum seekers, immigrants, refugees, etc... The World Trade Organisation is a monument to international cooperation: in the fields of teargas, rubber bullets, riot control. Only the most backward-looking would seek to reverse the enormous changes seen during the past 20 years: You're the madman. Not me. You are. To oppose free trade is little short of lunacy: Nurse! Quickly! The internet is going to change everything: anyone remember Prestel? We are moving towards a knowledge economy: everyone will work as London taxi drivers. Books, wine, CDs: the only commodities ever mentioned in connection with internet commerce, doubtless to give the impression that the online shopper is a discerning sort of chap rather than an unhygienic sad-cake. Britain can win in the new economy: anything's possible. But it will need discipline and restraint: wage restraint, that is. There is no room at all for uncompetitive working practices: you're fired. However, success and talent must be properly rewarded: share options all round! We are moving into exciting and wonderful new times: just another shot, just a small one... And we can see clearly a bright road ahead: leave the bottle here, it'll save time. There is no gain without pain in the new economic order: cue stock market crash. But tomorrow is another day: the party's over.

webTitle: Precedents for releasing Pinochet's medical reports

fields.headline: Precedents for releasing Pinochet's medical reports
fields.trailText: In the debate on General Pinochet's health (Warning of legal action on Pinochet ruling, January 14), repeated reference has been made to the home secretary's decision not to extradite Roisin McAliskey.
fields.body:
In the debate on General Pinochet's health (Warning of legal action on Pinochet ruling, January 14), repeated reference has been made to the home secretary's decision not to extradite Roisin McAliskey. It is said that Ms McAliskey, also, enjoyed a private consideration by the home secretary of her medical condition and that there was no public disquiet when, after 18 months, the extradition process was halted by Mr Straw.

However, public knowledge of Ms McAliskey's health, and the ability of the requesting government (in her case, Germany) to be fully aware of every aspect of her health and any investigation into it, was very different. From her first appearance at Bow Street magistrate's court, and thereafter almost weekly during repeated bail applications, every aspect of her vulnerable health was set out in open court before successive stipendiary magistrates. Every word of medical reports which were frequently read out in full in Court, could be heard by the many members of the press who attended on every occasion.

Four full days before three different high court judges were spent on bail applications, all of which rested heavily upon medical evidence. The prosecution, as the adversary in those applications, was entitled to and did conduct its own medical evidence.

Following the birth of Ms McAliskey's baby, after she had been granted bail, her obstetrician held a press conference with Ms McAliskey's mother detailing the circumstances of the birth, including the near fatal condition of the baby who was described as "lucky to survive". The German government, through the crown prosecution service, was party to all medical decisions that led a second high court judge to order the transfer of Ms McAliskey to a specialist psychiatric mother and baby unit where she remained for the following nine months. Those in charge of her care provided detailed reports to the court and to the prosecution about her continuing condition. It was on the joint application of both the CPS and Ms McAliskey's lawyers, in agreement on her precarious health, that the divisional court, in a hearing presided over by the lord chief justice, ruled that Ms McAliskey was unfit to attend her committal for extradition.
Gareth Peirce
Birnberg Peirce & Partners

 Here in France, during the trial of Nazi collaborator Maurice Papon, his defence on more than one occasion demanded medical examination to support their claim that he was too old and infirm to stand trial. Each and every report was made public thus removing any doubt as to collusion of authority with the accused. Is it too much to hope that even at this late hour the British authorities will have the courage to follow this example?
Bill Reid
Paris, France

 Now the Home Secretary has released Pinochet on grounds of ill health will he now extend his compassion to Myra Hindley? At least she has served her judicial sentence.
Dr Andrew Wilson
London

fields.headline: Crusade for children
fields.trailText: The detention of Chechen youths (10-year-old Chechens to be held as Russia toughens stance, January 12) is another clear example of why all children and young people must not be used in armed forces.
fields.body:
The detention of Chechen youths (10-year-old Chechens to be held as Russia toughens stance, January 12) is another clear example of why all children and young people must not be used in armed forces. When young people are recruited and put into combat, their civilian peers also become targets.

Negotiations at the UN in Geneva on an optional protocol to the UN convention on the rights of the child could stop the recruitment and deployment of young people in government and non-governmental armed forces. However, those few governments that wish to continue using under-18s (primarily the US, with the UK government in the background) are seeking to weaken the protocol. For the sake of the 300,000-plus children and young people in armed forces across the world, and all other civilian children in war zones, the UK and others must now actively enable a ban on the use of under-18s.
Tim Montgomery
UK Coalition to Stop the Use of Child Soldiers
qpsirs@quaker.org.uk

 The US begins the new millennium by executing juvenile offender Douglas Christopher Thomas (Last Supper for boy killer on death row, January 10) and the executions of four more juvenile offenders are scheduled to take place. The only other nations known to have executed juveniles in the last decade are Iran, Nigeria, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and Yemen. Several international treaties to which the US is a signatory prohibit the use of the death penalty against juvenile offenders. It is a violation of the most fundamental human right: the right to life.
Don Ayers
Deborah Walsh
High Peak, Derbs

fields.headline: The new nationalism
fields.standfirst:
Russia's heir apparent is on the offensive

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The apparent intention of Yevgeny Primakov to pull out of Russia's presidential election in March is a blow to those who had hoped to see a genuinely democratic contest. Only a few months ago, Mr Primakov, a former prime minister backed by the Fatherland-All Russia alliance, looked like a good bet. Then came setbacks in last month's parliamentary elections and Boris Yeltsin's sudden decision to resign.
fields.body:
The apparent intention of Yevgeny Primakov to pull out of Russia's presidential election in March is a blow to those who had hoped to see a genuinely democratic contest. Only a few months ago, Mr Primakov, a former prime minister backed by the Fatherland-All Russia alliance, looked like a good bet. Then came setbacks in last month's parliamentary elections and Boris Yeltsin's sudden decision to resign. In doing so, he brought forward the election, which had been expected to take place in June, and designated Mr Primakov's main rival, the 46-year-old prime minister, Vladimir Putin, as acting president. Mr Primakov, while not formally quitting the race, has indicated that he will now seek election as speaker of the Duma. A campaign by pro-Kremlin media portraying him as too old, at 70, to take on the top job may have influenced his decision. But with opinion polls showing Mr Putin likely to win 55% of the vote (and beating Mr Primakov by 71% to 15%), and with powerful national and regional politicians defecting to Mr Putin's Unity alliance almost by the day, his cause looks hopeless. Mr Putin's drive for power appears unstoppable at present. His other opponents - the marginalised communist leader, Gennady Zyuganov, Grigory Yavlinsky of the small, liberal Yabloko party, and the absurdly rightwing extremist, Vladimir Zhirinovsky - are not seen as challengers who, realistically, can deny him the victory he covets.

Despite the appearance for the first time in Russian newspapers of criticism of the conduct of the war in Chechnya, Mr Putin continues to enjoy overwhelming public support for his ruthless line there. There are signs that Russians are also warming to his central campaign theme. This is the need to recreate a strong, centralised state which looks after its people at home and stands up for national interests against the west; which will crack down ruthlessly on terrorism, crime and corruption; and which will bring back Russia's sense of pride and self-worth after a post-communist decade of economic dislocation and political drift. In this, Mr Putin draws adroitly on Russia's centuries-old belief in the necessity of a powerful leader, an idea rooted not only in the years of Lenin and Stalin but in the tsarist era. His recently announced plans to enhance the security apparatus, to which he once belonged as a KGB spy chief, to increase defence spending by 57%, and to raise state sector pay and pensions all underpin his unashamedly nationalist message. In a country where approximately one-third of the population lives below the poverty line, Mr Putin is also portraying himself as the candidate of economic as well as political renewal. That Russia remains financially beholden to the west, that he has given no clear idea how he will fund his policies, and that he claims to remain committed to market reforms are issues which are likely to be fudged, at least until after the election.

Perhaps more worrying even than the prospective absence of a genuine electoral contest is Mr Putin's revamped "national security concept", unveiled last week. This appears to broaden the circumstances in which Russia might resort to nuclear weapons; it rejects the idea of a strategic partnership with the US; and it takes a geopolitical world view which postulates growing tension between a hegemonistic America and its European allies and Russia, China, India and other emerging nations. This paranoid document detects a conspiracy to weaken Russia. We hope this, too, is merely electioneering. For if it reflects Mr Putin's true opinions, there is trouble ahead.

fields.headline: Death of a warlord
fields.standfirst:
Was Milosevic behind Arkan's murder?

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Who killed Zeljko Raznatovic, otherwise known as Arkan, the Serbian gangster-warlord who, with President Slobodan Milosevic, introduced the world to the hideous concept of ethnic cleansing? Few will miss this monster, charged in 1997 with crimes against humanity for his leading role in massacres in Croatia in 1991 and in the 1992-95 Bosnian war, after his bloody demise at the wrong end of a Heckler & Koch submachine gun in a Belgrade hotel on Saturday. But many will wonder who among his numerous enemies ordered the hit.
fields.body:
Who killed Zeljko Raznatovic, otherwise known as Arkan, the Serbian gangster-warlord who, with President Slobodan Milosevic, introduced the world to the hideous concept of ethnic cleansing? Few will miss this monster, charged in 1997 with crimes against humanity for his leading role in massacres in Croatia in 1991 and in the 1992-95 Bosnian war, after his bloody demise at the wrong end of a Heckler & Koch submachine gun in a Belgrade hotel on Saturday. But many will wonder who among his numerous enemies ordered the hit.

Mr Milosevic has perhaps the most to gain from his death. Arkan had links to the most senior people in Serbia's security apparatus, from whom his Tiger paramilitary killers took their orders. He probably knew enough to put Mr Milosevic and his cronies away for life, several times over, should they ever be brought before The Hague tribunal. His distancing of himself from the Serbian leader over Kosovo and Montenegro, his contacts with a leading critic of the regime, Zoran Djindjic, and rumours that he was negotiating a deal with UN prosecutors, may have persuaded Mr Milosevic that he had outlived his usefulness. Other paramilitary bosses have met similar fates in the recent past. Vuk Draskovic, the opposition leader who dodged assassination last October, is convinced the government killed Arkan.

Alternatively, rival gangsters, relatives of his many victims, or even regional powers could be behind Arkan's killing. We may never know. What is clear, however, is that his murder has denied The Hague much evidence potentially of use in nailing not only Mr Milosevic but also the two principal Bosnian Serb indictees, Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, and others like them who remain at large. Not nearly enough is being done to catch these men. Violent death, even Arkan's, does not help the quest for justice in former Yugoslavia. But that quest must not falter.

fields.headline: That singing feeling
fields.standfirst: Michele Hanson
fields.trailText: What depressing news! Andrew Lloyd Weber has bought 10 more London theatres. Hopefully he won't stuff them all with his own oeuvres and wimbly-wambly tunes. I speak from bitter experience. A couple of Christmases ago, Rosemary and I sat through Jesus Christ Superstar, just to see what the fuss was about. After all, ALW is a life peer, his shows are packed out and London is clogged with his productions.
fields.body:
What depressing news! Andrew Lloyd Weber has bought 10 more London theatres. Hopefully he won't stuff them all with his own oeuvres and wimbly-wambly tunes. I speak from bitter experience. A couple of Christmases ago, Rosemary and I sat through Jesus Christ Superstar, just to see what the fuss was about. After all, ALW is a life peer, his shows are packed out and London is clogged with his productions.

What luck I am not religious. Had I seen the Son of God forced to sing such tunes, I might have issued a fatwah. And Rosemary was horrified. Coming from a Christian family and acquainted with the original text, this singalong adaptation gave her the shudders.

"Where's my mother?" whined Jesus on the cross. "God, why have you forgotten me?" And Mary was optimistic even in the grimmer moments. As Jesus crawled, bruised and battered, towards the cross, she was still hopeful. "Could we start again?" she sang cheerily. The lepers were surprisingly robust and the Last Supper rather wild. No one sat politely at a table and poor Jesus was shoved about by seemingly drunken disciples.

Rosemary and I were desperate for a drink at half-time and as we sat on the red swirling carpet (there were no seats), drinking heavily, we heard others chatting excitedly about the 40 lashes and looking forward to them. So we decided to stick it out. There was Jesus, tied by the hands, arms stretched out, as 40 people lashed him one by one and blood poured from the wounds. Magic. The audience was enraptured by the torture. Just right for a family outing.

But beware. Rosemary's colleague unwisely took her seven-year-old son to see it. He screamed with terror, was severely traumatised and had nightmares for days.

As we staggered, horrified, from our seats, an usherette overheard the criticisms. "I've never heard anyone complain before," said she, wide-eyed. "Well, you have now," said Rosemary in a fury. "How long do you expect this thing to run?" "Till the year 2004," the usherette said dreamily. We should be so lucky. Now the New Lord owns much of London's theatreland, we may be in for a life sentence. His works shall run for ever and ev-ev-er.

fields.headline: Brutal cog in Serb machine
fields.standfirst:
The life and death of a psychopath: how Arkan the warlord lived by the sword
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Zeljko Raznatovic was a showman. He loved playing the role of Arkan the warlord, dressing up in special forces fatigues one day, Armani's finest the next. He spoke fluent English and loved to engage the foreign press, defending his own role while freely criticising President Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Zeljko Raznatovic was a showman. He loved playing the role of Arkan the warlord, dressing up in special forces fatigues one day, Armani's finest the next. He spoke fluent English and loved to engage the foreign press, defending his own role while freely criticising President Slobodan Milosevic.

But all his clowning obscured the most important fact about Arkan. Through all their murderous sprees in Croatia and Bosnia, he and his militia were never just a marauding band of privateers. From the beginning they were an essential cog in the brutal machine run by President Milosevic, aimed at carving an ethnically pure Serb state out of the carcass of Yugoslavia.

The machine was called the vojna linija - the military line - a chain of command which ran parallel to the old Yugoslav army, through the state security department and the interior ministry. When Arkan and his men arrived at their first major "operation", the cleansing of Croats out of Vukovar in 1991, they were in jeeps with interior ministry number plates.

Arkan's direct superior in the vojna linija was Radovan Stojcic, an interior ministry thug known as Badza, who was made a general after the war. According to former members of the security apparatus, he was part of the direct line of command running from President Milosevic and Arkan. He was shot dead in similar circumstances in Belgrade three years ago.

There are other members of this inner circle still alive: Jovica Stanisic, the former head of the state security service thought still to be living in Belgrade, and his underling, Franko Simatovic, known as Frenki, who runs a paramilitary corps which was active in the brutal ethnic cleansing of Kosovo last year.

Perhaps the murders of Badza and Arkan were just the inevitable price of their lifestyle, on the very blurred edge between the security services and the Belgrade mafia. But both Frenki and Mr Stanisic must now be thinking very hard about their future. They are two of the very few people on the planet who can provide chapter and verse about Mr Milosevic's precise role in the mass murders of Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo.

Career criminal

Arkan was chosen young. He was the wayward son of a senior officer in the Yugoslav air force, who turned to petty theft and football hooliganism in the late 1960s. It is said his father first put him in touch with his future employers, the state security police, the Udba, in the hope they could find a use for his skills and energies.

It is not known what links were forged then, but the juvenile delinquent graduated to international bank robbery. He knocked off banks all across northern Europe and escaped from Dutch and Belgian jails. It was later reported that those escapes were abetted by the Udba, and that in return he carried out assassinations of Marshal Tito's enemies abroad. His nom de guerre, Arkan, was taken from one of the false passports the Udba provided.

He returned to Yugoslavia a rich man in the 1980s, opened a patisserie, took a stake in a hotel and started up a string of other businesses. But his Udba affiliation did not come to an end. Instead it entered a new phase which paved the way for his future life as a warlord.

It was arranged for him to take over Red Star Belgrade supporters' club. By that time, Tito was dead and Yugoslavia was showing the early signs of disintegration. Control of Red Star's youth brigades would be helpful if it came to a struggle for Belgrade.

In the end that was not necessary. Mr Milosevic emerged from the party ranks and, by exchanging communist red for the bright colours of a vicious brand of Serb nationalism, seized the vacant Yugoslav throne. The struggle for Belgrade was postponed and instead, Arkan's Red Star boys became the core of the Serbian Volunteer Guard - the Tigers.

They were equipped with the best uniforms and the best weapons, including Uzis and the kind of Heckler & Koch automatic which put a bullet through Arkan's eye on Saturday. They were turned into professional killers at a training camp in Erdut, near the heart of the Croatian battlefield. Badza was photographed visiting them there in 1991.

A former member of the Milosevic ruling circle, a nationalist who became disgruntled with the president's failure to hold on to either Croatia or Bosnia, asked me in 1997: "Where do you think the guns and Jeeps came from? How do you think Arkan got to all those places? Wherever there was Arkan, there was Badza."

Arkan's role in Yugoslavia's bloodletting has been well documented. He was there at Vukovar in 1991 and he was there in the first days of the Bosnian war in Bijeljina in March 1992. It was a ruthless massacre of civilians, not by wild-eyed ruffians but by clean-shaven crisply uniformed Tigers. They even allowed an American photographer, Ron Haviv, to come along, producing some of the most harrowing pictures of cold-blooded murder to emerge from the darkness of the war.

The aim was clear - to spread terror among Bosnia's Muslims; to act with such brutality and openness that word would spread like wildfire, sparking a panicked flight. It was easier and quicker than fighting from village to village. The technique also brought an added bonus: people fleeing in terror leave most of their valued possessions behind.

Ruthless killers

The Tigers were called on whenever the Belgrade regime required extreme brutality coupled with deniability. Mr Milosevic told the US envoy, Richard Holbrooke, that he had "no influence" over Arkan. Mr Holbrooke, now US ambassador to the UN, concluded that Arkan was a "freelance murderer".

As a military force, the Tigers were pathetic. In the face of the Croatian-Bosnian offensive of 1995, they were thrown into the fray in the eastern Bosnian town of Sanski Most. Arkan arrived in town with a supply of expensive food and drink from Belgrade, took over a floor of a hotel as his headquarters, and then left after a few days without fighting when it was clear the situation was hopeless.

The next time he came to Bosnia, it was in his reincarnation as a besuited candidate in the country's first post-war elections. Pictures of smiling cherubic face appeared on posters all around Bijeljina, the site of the bloodbath five years earlier.

He brought his Serb rock star wife, Ceca. He kissed babies, and claimed to be bewildered by the fact that there were no Muslims left in town.

"I have a lot of friends who are Muslims," he told me. "I used to visit them. They visited me. In Bijelinja, I personally had Muslim friends."

When I asked about their fate, he shrugged. "I came and then left after three days. Other people came to power... My guys did not commit one crime."

In one of the more obscene absurdities of post-war Bosnia, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe gave him £150,000 towards his election expenses, in the interests of promoting free speech. When an article appeared in the Guardian pointing out this strange turn of events, he wrote a wounded letter to the newspaper protesting his innocence.

The lies were as absurd as they were blatant in view of Ron Haviv's chilling photographs, but he was as convincing and charming as a true psychopath can be. He enjoyed chatting in English to the foreign press, and would remember names and faces. The journalists in turn were flattered to be courted by such a notorious figure, and he appeared to seek some sort of redemption in the eyes of the world by striving to pass off his version of history.

Months after the war, I went to explore a casino run by Arkan in Belgrade. I was at the roulette wheel soaking up the atmosphere when I sensed a presence behind my shoulder.

He was in high spirits. He asked about my health, and continued an exchange from the previous year about Serbia's future. He announced his heart was with the anti-Milosevic street protests in Belgrade, but he believed the time was not right to make a stand. The president's days were numbered, he said. But in fact it was Arkan who was running out of time.

A mass murderer defends himself

Arkan wrote to the Guardian on September 14 1996 after two articles in which he was branded a warlord. Here are extracts from that letter:

"I am not a war criminal or 'warlord'... principally because of the American hostility to [my] activities in defence of Serbs in Croatia and Bosnia, I have been investigated by the prosecutor's office of the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague. The result is that I have not been indicted for any war crime"

"During the second world war, hundreds of thousands of Serbs were killed by the Croatian nationalist regime... In my view, the Serbs were entitled to defend themselves against 'ethnic cleansing' by Croatia."

"Regarding Bosnia, there was widespread feeling among Serbs when the declaration of independence took place that they were being forced into an Islamic-run state"

"Contrary to common perception in the west, however, there are still non-Serb minorities living in Republika Srpska - Muslims, Croats, Hungarians, Albanians, Jews, Gypsies. I do not suggest that their numbers are large proportionally to Serbs but I welcome their continuing presence. A great many of these people support and are members of my party"

"It has always seemed to me naive of the Americans if they thought that by hammering out the Dayton agreement, and dividing Bosnia 49% to 51% between Republika Srpska and the Muslim-Croat federation, they were not reinforcing partition."

"I do not believe that, in reality, Serbs can live in a state governed by Muslim and Croat nationalists or even work in a government alongside such people."
