fields.headline: Who'd be a Sheila?
fields.standfirst: According to a survey out last week, Australia beats Britain hands down in the great-places-to-be stakes.  Margaret Simons  reports from Canberra on what life is really like for the women of Oz
fields.trailText: According to a survey out last week, Australia beats Britain hands down in the great-places-to-be stakes.  Margaret Simons  reports from Canberra on what life is really like for the women of Oz
fields.body:
For two Sydney models, 1999 was the year in which their mothers' prayers were answered when their daughters wed the heirs of Australia's richest families," declared the Sydney tabloid The Sun-Herald on Boxing Day. The article was on the weddings of Lachlan Murdoch, heir apparent to the Murdoch media empire, and Jamie Packer, son of Australia's richest man, to Sarah O'Hare and Jodie Meares. Both women were launched into their husbands' orbits because of the professional use they made of their bodies. Sarah O'Hare is a millionaire in her own right, thanks to her contracts with Wonderbra and Revlon; Jodie Meares, or Jodie Packer as she is now known, modelled swimwear.

The Packer wedding was the social event of the year. On the guest list were prime minister John Howard and his wife Janette, a woman thought to be a strong influence on her husband but who has proudly defended her role as a domestic support. Last year she said her way of dealing with the stress of political life was to get stuck into the housework.

The Packers and Murdochs have been referred to, not without irony, as Australia's royals, but in this country class has always depended on wealth rather than breeding. The message behind O'Hare and Meares' progress is an old one: be beautiful, marry well.

Damned Whores And God's Police was the title of leading Australian feminist Anne Summers' ground-breaking book, first published in the 70s, which looked at the way male-dominated colonial and pioneering society condemned women to being seen as at one or other moral extreme. But how much has changed?

In the run-up to the Sydney Olympics, Australia's highly successful women's national soccer team, the Matildas, has put out a calendar in which 12 team members pose naked. Why? One former member, Moya Dodd, puts it simply: money and fame. Sure, it is oppressive to become a pin-up, but "so are stilettos and there is still the occasional good reason for putting them on. At least these days the camera has taken the hard work out of the world's oldest profession."

In December, Australian news magazine The Eye ran the headline "The Loser Sex" over a story arguing that Australian women lag behind those in other countries when it comes to achieving equality. Average female earnings are just 81 cents to the male dollar; there are 17 female judges in the most senior court, compared with 93 men, no women in senior positions in the major banks and only one female editor of a city daily newspaper. Women make up 43% of the workforce, but hold just 3% of top management positions. In the US, the figure is 11% but there companies face being locked out of government contracts if they fail to implement affirmative action. In Australia, the worst that happens is the company has its name read out in parliament. At present there is no real campaign for change. The energy among women that led to Australia passing Equal Opportunity legislation 13 years ago has faded away.

In 1902, Australia became the first country in the world to allow women to enter parliament and the second in the world (after New Zealand) to give women the vote. (This excluded Aboriginal women who were not recognised as citizens until the 60s.) But nearly a hundred years later, no woman has ever been voted in as a political leader at state or federal level. Late last century, both sides of politics tried to promote high-profile women as prospective prime ministers. All ended in disaster.

Most recently, the former leader of the minority Australian Democrats Party, Cheryl Kernot, defected to Labor with clear hopes of eventually getting the party leadership. She at once faced a barrage of negative publicity, including the publishing of details of an affair she had over 20 years before with a man who had once been her student. The story was published by leading broadsheet The Sydney Morning Herald under the headline "The Other Side of Saint Cheryl". Saint or Sinner. Damned Whores and God's Police.

So why do Australian women seem to be lagging behind? It feels too simplistic, too out of step with the modern nation, the Olympic nation, the nation with the good millennial fireworks, to say that there are still hangovers of the pioneering colonial days when men were men and women were nervous. Perhaps the similarities between Australia and other countries are more important than the differences. Any western country could present broadly similar statistics of inequality and Australian feminism is haunted by the same issues: the "I'm not a feminist but" syndrome among young women; the question of whether to focus on the differences between men and women or the similarities; whether the aim should be equality at work or the privileging of domesticity, or both; the link between biology and destiny.

The greatest spur to debate on Australian feminism in recent times was a book by leading writer Helen Garner who investigated a sexual harassment complaint at Melbourne University's prestigious Ormond College. She questioned the young woman's use of the police and courts, and criticised what she described as modern feminism's "obsession" with sex and power in relations between the sexes. She said public debate about women and men had been commandeered by a "bullying orthodoxy" that focused only on institutional power, cast women always as victims and left no room for "eros", the free-moving creative, emotional and intellectual spirit that enlivens relations between people. Garner depicted this as a generational thing, a hard-line political orthodoxy from younger feminists, as against the libertarian approach of her own generation.

Debate about the book dominated Australian public life for months. Books were published in reply and arguments advanced in favour of young women. Melbourne journalist Virginia Trioli spoke of a generation of ambitious and politically sophisticated young women, working in the professions and the private sector, applying the principles of "many feminisms" and putting into practice the gains of their mothers' and grandmothers' generations.

Trioli's critics have suggested there might be more to feminism than making one's way in a man's world. And anyway, figures suggest women aren't doing so well in that respect.

In The Whole Woman, the latest book by Australia's most famous feminist, Germaine Greer claims the best feminism is not about equality with men but about liberation. "The aim of women's liberation was to do as much for female people as has been done for colonised nations. The visionary feminists of the late 60s and early 70s knew that women could never find freedom by agreeing to live the lives of unfree men."

And so back to colonies. One of the other defining images of womanhood in the Australian media over the past few months has been that of the Queen. In the wake of the defeat of the Republic Referendum in November, the cartoonists drew prime minister John Howard as a small boy sitting on her knee.

Howard came to power five years ago with an election credo that said he wanted Australians to be "relaxed and comfortable" about themselves. At the same time, academic Graeme Turner proposed a form of Australian identity that, rather than trying to resolve difference, should be grounded in its celebration, a proudly "mongrel republic".

The republic, mongrel or otherwise, is for the moment defeated. But perhaps it isn't foolish to hope that Australia may eventually be a good place to find some strong and different ways of being womanish.

At the same time, academic Graeme Turner proposed a form of Australian identity that, rather than trying to resolve difference, should be grounded in its celebration, a proudly "mongrel republic". The republic, mongrel or otherwise, is for the moment defeated. But perhaps it isn't foolish to hope that Australia may eventually be a good place to find some strong and different ways of being womanish.

webTitle: Serbia in fear after Arkan death

fields.headline: Serbia in fear after Arkan death
fields.standfirst:
Opposition leaders accuse the ruling elite of killing the indicted war criminal and mobster
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The assassination of the notorious warlord and mobster, Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, threw Serbia into political uproar yesterday, amid mounting allegations that the murder was sanctioned by President Slobodan Milosevic's ruling elite, who were alarmed at his growing power.
fields.body:
The assassination of the notorious warlord and mobster, Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, threw Serbia into political uproar yesterday, amid mounting allegations that the murder was sanctioned by President Slobodan Milosevic's ruling elite, who were alarmed at his growing power.

The gunning down of the indicted war criminal and two bodyguards in Belgrade's Intercontinental hotel on Saturday evening provided "confirmation that we are living in a country of state terrorism", said the controversial opposition politician Vuk Draskovic.

"These liquidations have the aim of spreading fear and insecurity among people," said Mr Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement.

Arkan seemed unassailable, the commander of his own private army of several thousand experienced fighters. "I am not afraid of anything, remember this," he said only last year. But yesterday the only sign of him that remained was his distinctive jeep, stranded in the hotel driveway, too heavy to be lifted by the tow vehicle.

The head of the United Nations mission to Bosnia described him yesterday as a psychopath and coward. "Crying for Arkan is like crying for [Nazi war criminal Adolf] Eichmann," said Jacques Klein, a US diplomat. "I don't think tears can be shed for a psychopathic mass murderer."

Mr Klein said his only regret was that Arkan had not been brought to justice at the war crimes tribunal in the Hague, which had indicted him for crimes against humanity, including alleged atrocities in Croatia in 1991 and in the 1992-95 Bosnia war.

Arkan led the feared Serb "Tigers" paramilitary unit which took part in the brutal three-month siege of the city of Vukovar in eastern Croatia in 1991. A year later, he helped the Bosnian Serbs to overrun northern and eastern Bosnia, where he was considered one of the pioneers of "ethnic cleansing", his fighters spreading terror among Muslims.

He had become an independent force in Serbia through his control of most criminal and black market activities. But he had also gained many enemies. Even his ownership of the top Serbian football club, Obilic, was marked by gangland violence. The Serbian football federation concluded recently that the results of last season's championship should be declared void, following threats made to referees and opposition teams.

But Arkan's most dangerous enemies were those in the ruling elite. Once reputed to be close to President Milosevic, he had of late moved further away from governing circles.

Analysts in Belgrade say Arkan was disenchanted with the growing influence of the small Yugoslav United Left (JUL) party, led by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic. Key government positions have increasingly been filled by JUL officials, prompting thoughts of defection by some old-guard members of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party.

Local journalists say Arkan may have come into conflict with Mr Milosevic's son, Marko, over fuel smuggling into Serbia in violation of international sanctions. They say Arkan had been making inroads into this highly profitable business which, they claim, was hitherto dominated by Marko.

Opposition leaders said the killing added weight to their demands for a change in government. The leader of the Democratic party, Zoran Djindjic, said the authorities were not capable of guaranteeing security and should therefore be replaced.

Mr Draskovic meanwhile is demanding a full investigation into the many unsolved assassinations in Serbia in recent years. Last October he was injured in a suspicious car crash in which four of his associates died. He maintains that this was an officially sponsored attempt on his life.

Many in Serbia predict that Arkan's murder could herald a new spate of political assassinations. With the exception of Mr Draskovic, most opposition leaders were yesterday extremely cautious about the wording of their comments on Arkan's death, apparently fearing for their own lives if they were too outspoken.

fields.headline: Only you
fields.standfirst:
Monogamy is back. 
  Caroline Sullivan  considers its place in the modern world
fields.trailText: What was going through Jane Goldman's mind when she jokingly gave her husband, Jonathan Ross, permission to sleep with an unnamed "world-famous star" who once propositioned him at an awards ceremony? Ross says both were simply amazed at the surreal situations in which one can find oneself when famous.
fields.body:
What was going through Jane Goldman's mind when she jokingly gave her husband, Jonathan Ross, permission to sleep with an unnamed "world-famous star" who once propositioned him at an awards ceremony? Ross says both were simply amazed at the surreal situations in which one can find oneself when famous.

It is fair to assume his wife's munificence came from a position of strength and security rather than a desire to bend over backwards for her man. Their 10-year marriage is said to be one of the most stable celebrity unions and Ross says he is violently opposed to people who take advantage of such scenarios.

But the anecdote revealed last week begs an interesting question. Every relationship has its own rules about monogamy and we all invest sex with varying degrees of emotional value. Maybe Goldman was simply curious about the anonymous star, much as I was when an ex-boyfriend had a crush on Princess Diana. Had Di demanded a royal command performance, I would have insisted he comply, just so I could hear about it afterwards.

If anything, we are becoming less liberal about social morality. Last month, an opinion poll found that the under-25s - the ones you'd expect to be taking advantage of the easy availability of Hooch - are more conservative than their parents. Despite the sexually assertive example set by cultural totems from Madonna to Sex And The City, only 58% of young adults believe women should have "some sexual experience" before settling down. More surprisingly still, it is women who are most against experimentation, suggesting the freedoms gained in the girl power 90s are not being exercised.

In fact, it is older women who are more likely to have ample experience and also to have been unfaithful - in another survey, in this month's Woman's Journal, 64% reported having cheated on a partner. (Tory voters are more promiscuous than Labour, by the way.) Furthermore, 38% believe that what 70s rock stars used to call "open relationships" can enhance a long-term partnership.

As David Bowie's ex, Angie, relates in her unintentionally hilarious 1981 autobiography, Free Spirit, there were no lengths to which she would not go to keep her ladyboy happy. This even extended to inviting another woman along on their wedding night: "Tumbling into bed seemed the right thing to do. Why break up what had been a perfect dinner party? David had promised our marriage wasn't going to be conventional. I guess he was right."

Either Angie was extraordinarily evolved or the balance of power lay with her husband and she had no choice. Though 30 years have passed since Angie's crowded wedding night (and a fat lot of good it did since the marriage crumbled anyway), not much has changed in this respect. Throughout the 90s, we were fed the idea that the parameters of gender relations had changed, that the oft-foretold day when women would have sex as transiently and guiltlessly as men had arrived. Company magazine ran a charming headline that said it all: "Come like a train (whenever you want)."

It ain't so. Monogamy is making a comeback as younger women discover the way to empowerment isn't coming like a train or affecting a tolerance they don't feel but retaining control over relationships through exclusivity. Not what you may have expected, but there it is. Opinion varies on what constitutes monogamy - a fifth of the Woman's Journal respondents claim kissing amounts to infidelity - but it seems that setting boundaries is important.

So the new rules of sex and dating seem very like the old rules. Some young women even talk of keeping more control of a relationship by not having penetrative sex - which even now is the rubicon that determines who holds the power. Perhaps we will return to a time when snogging in cars was as hot as it got and sex wasn't on the menu until you at least knew each other's surnames. A chaste little grapple in a Metro might do wonders for your love life.

webTitle: Granny D hits the road to save democracy

fields.headline: Granny D hits the road to save democracy
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Doris Haddock was driving with her son on a holiday in Florida a couple of years ago when she saw an old man walking along the road alone miles from anywhere. How wonderful, she thought, to live out Jack Kerouac's dream and hit the road.
fields.body:
Doris Haddock was driving with her son on a holiday in Florida a couple of years ago when she saw an old man walking along the road alone miles from anywhere. How wonderful, she thought, to live out Jack Kerouac's dream and hit the road.

Last year, Doris Haddock did just that, setting off from California to walk across the United States to Washington, where she is due to arrive on February 29. Her mission is to use her 3,000-mile journey to call for the reform of political financing: at present only candidates backed by big money can seriously challenge for high office, a situation which she feels endangers democracy. Next week, she will pause for a birthday celebration: on January 24, she will be 90.

A political activist all her life, Mrs Haddock decided to make her epic journey after hearing about Mildred Norman, who was known as the Peace Pilgrim and who criss-crossed America on foot from the 50s onwards. Mrs Haddock had long been concerned about the way that corporations funded political candidates and was angry that George W Bush seemed to be promoted as the best Republican candidate merely because he had raised $50m (£31m) before anyone else.

Having convinced her son and daughter and grandchildren of her serious intent she went into training. To save her family from too much attention she chose to walk under the name of Granny D. Her grandchildren speculated how many days Mrs Haddock, five foot tall and a smoker for 50 years, would last.

She now has a back-up van and a growing number of supporters who walk stretches of the road with her. "People ask if I'm afraid," she said . "But I figure I'm 89 and it doesn't really matter. How else better to spend my remaining days?"

Her aim is to make incumbent and would-be politicians say yes or no to the the following: "I pledge my vote and full procedural support to ban soft money, the $100,000 (£61,000) donations to state and federal political races, that undermines our democracy." She believes that too many politicians are in debt to the big-money interests, whether in guns, gambling or tobacco, that fund their campaigns and that candidates without such backing, such as Elizabeth Dole who dropped out of the race last year citing lack of money, cannot be heard.

"We don't know what George Bush stands for," she said. "Apparently he stands for being able to raise a lot of money. I don't want my grandchildren to have to vote for someone who has to sell his soul to get elected. I feel our democracy is slowly slipping away from us." Mrs Haddock has been surprised by the lack of knowledge of the political funding system shown by journalists. "Part of my mission is to wise up a whole group of young reporters coast to coast so they would be sensitive to the issue and ask harder questions of politicians," she said. Jack Kerouac would have been proud of her.

fields.headline: Stalkers face electronic tags
fields.trailText: Stalkers and violent partners may be electronically tagged to prevent them from approaching their victims again, Tony Blair announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Stalkers and violent partners may be electronically tagged to prevent them from approaching their victims again, Tony Blair announced yesterday.

Under the plan, police would be alerted if offenders came within 500 metres of an area from which they had been banned by the courts.

At the moment electronic tagging systems are only used to detect whether offenders, such as the former Tory minister, Jonathan Aitken, are observing a curfew at an agreed address.

The new scheme will involve updating the equipment to detect whether stalkers or violent partners are straying into prohibited areas.

"We are now considering electronic tagging for domestic violence and stalking cases," the prime minister told BBC1's Breakfast With Frost.

A Downing Street spokeswoman said that the success of existing electronic tagging systems had encouraged the government to extend their use.

Of the 15,000 offenders who have been electronically tagged since the launch of the scheme, 95% have complied with curfews.

"This is an area that we are looking at because we want to ensure that victims are better protected," the Downing Street spokeswoman said.

The government is acting after a series of high-profile cases in which victims of stalkers have spoken of their fear of their attackers returning once they have been freed from jail.

Tracey Morgan, who suffered a six-year campaign of intimidation, spoke last year of how the legal system was failing her after her attacker was convicted for the fifth time.

"When he is released, my sentence starts," she said of Anthony Burstow when he was jailed in January last year.

In March 1996, Burstow, a former Royal Navy petty officer, was jailed for three years for inflicting psychological grievous bodily harm on Ms Morgan.

The a case triggered the introduction of anti-stalking laws in 1997.

He resumed stalking again in January, 1998, six months after being released on licence.

The television presenter Zoe Ball, who has been stalked for the past year, has been forced to take out an injunction banning Colin Scholey from coming near her.

The present electronic tagging system, in which prisoners are released early subject to a nightly curfew, was launched last year.

Inmates face a curfew which places them under house arrest for a set proportion of the day or night.

Their compliance with the curfew is monitored through an electronic tag worn on the ankle which is linked to a central control unit.

Offenders who repeatedly breach their curfew faced being returned to prison.

webTitle: Worst fall ever in quality of UK's air

fields.headline: Worst fall ever in quality of UK's air
fields.trailText: Air quality in the UK during 1999 showed the worst deterioration since modern records began, figures today reveal.
fields.body:
Air quality in the UK during 1999 showed the worst deterioration since modern records began, figures today reveal.

The fall, revealed by Friends of the Earth, will come as an embarrassment to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who six months ago announced that 1998 had seen the biggest ever improvement in air quality.

Mr Prescott had by inference claimed that government policy was having a beneficial effect on pollution levels.

Experts said the figures showed the British weather, rather than anything the government had been doing, had a very large effect on the environment.

It emerged that in 1998 there were fewer spells of high pressure with little or no wind, a requirement for pollution levels to build up. Easterly winds off the continent, which carry French and German fumes to Britain, were also few and far between.

However, 1999 proved different and pollution rose dramatically.

FoE said the number of days last year on which air pollution exceeded official health standards rose by 20% in urban areas and by 53% in rural areas over 1998.

In 1999, pollution levels were above health standards on average one day in every eight at rural monitoring sites and one day in every 13 at urban sites.

"This is the biggest deterioration in air quality since records began in 1993," said Roger Higman, an FoE transport campaigner.

The figures come two days before the government publishes its air quality strategy.

Official figures from a government report will bring some cheer, showing that London is the world's least polluted mega-city - coming ahead of cities such as New York, Tokyo and Los Angeles as the least affected by transport pollution.

The report, prepared by Stephen Glaister for the department of health, is likely to be used by the government for not imposing national road congestion targets.

It says that if congestion charging is imposed in London by the new mayor, it is likely to have a more noticeable impact on local traffic volumes than fuel prices.

Professor Glaister, an independent adviser on pollution from the Imperial College, London, says the level of toxic vehicle emissions is falling nationally as well as in London. But in the capital, it is falling rapidly after the introduction of catalytic exhaust gas converters in 1992 and improved engine technology and fuels.

The report says there is a presumption in London that air pollutants damage health. "Some are, but several of the officially recorded pollutants are of little consequence in London," says Prof Glaister.

FoE's point, apart from embarrassing Mr Prescott for claiming credit for the weather, is to draw attention to the government's failure to set a traffic reduction target.

The government has refused to set a target, despite the fact that 430 MPs have called for him to do so, including 92 of those in Labour's 100 most marginal seats.

Mr Prescott has also said he will weaken the government's target to cut levels of deadly particles, mostly from diesel engines, which kill up to 8,100 people every year.

Ministers say this because the technology does not exist to do so and it would be wrong to set a target it cannot reach. The department of health estimates that up to 24,000 people a year may die prematurely because of air pollution.

Tony Bosworth, FoE's air pollution campaigner, said: "Air pollution showed a record deterioration in 1999 yet the government is failing to tackle the problem.

The government is refusing to set a target for traffic reduction, despite demands from no less than 430 MPs.

"Instead Mr Prescott says he will weaken a key air quality target.

"Parents, pensioners and asthma sufferers will be furious that the government is pandering to the roads lobby while they choke."

fields.headline: £6m Granada shares windfall for Dyke
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, is poised for a £6m windfall when he sells shares in one of the corporation's rivals - the independent television group, Granada.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, is poised for a £6m windfall when he sells shares in one of the corporation's rivals - the independent television group, Granada.

Mr Dyke has agreed to sell any shareholdings which conflict with his £500,000 a year BBC role by the end of April.

A sale of his shares in Pearson, the group which owns Penguin books and the Financial Times and whose TV production arm he ran since 1995, has already netted £800,000.

The planned Granada share disposals will add to the already substantial wealth amassed by Mr Dyke, who was also forced to sever his ties with the Labour party as the price of taking the top job at the BBC.

A statement from the corporation said Mr Dyke had listed all his personal shareholdings in a letter to the BBC governors about three weeks before he was officially appointed as director general.

The matter had also been discussed at a meeting of governors and Mr Dyke had been given nine months in which to dispose of his shares.

BBC sources said his financial position was well known to all the governors, who had agreed to follow custom at the corporation and allow Mr Dyke time to dispose of his investments. Tight sale deadlines can force investors to incur losses if market conditions turn against them.

Mr Dyke came to own shares in Granada after the Manchester-based firm mounted a successful takeover bid for London Weekend Television, where he was chief executive. Sir Christopher Bland, now the chairman of the BBC, was chairman of LWT at the same time, but has sold his shares.

Mr Dyke received a multi-million pound bonanza from selling shares after losing the takeover battle but held on to some of the equity.

He now faces having to sell his Granada shares while they are fashionable with investors and their stock market value is rising.

The shares are some way off their peak price over the past year but at the end of last week they rose by 38.5p to 617.5p.

webTitle: Blair will write to crash victim

fields.headline: Blair will write to crash victim
fields.trailText: A woman tourist injured when a car hit the security gates at the entrance to Downing Street  can expect to receive a letter of sympathy from Tony Blair.
fields.body:
A woman tourist injured when a car hit the security gates at the entrance to Downing Street was yesterday flying home with her family to the United States - where she can expect to receive a letter of sympathy from Tony Blair.

Ursula Webster, a mother of three, was taken to St Thomas' hospital with a broken leg after Saturday's incident.

It happened as she was emerging through the gates with her family after being allowed to walk up to the door of No 10.

Her three sons, aged three, six and eight, escaped virtually unscathed as their mother, who was accompanied by her husband, sacrificed her own safety to usher them away.

Downing Street confirmed that the prime minister and his family were not in their home at No 11 at the time of the incident.

A spokeswoman said Mr Blair would be writing personally to Mrs Webster.

She was discharged from hospital yesterday morning after a consultant said she could travel and boarded a flight back to the US with her children.

An off-duty NHS nurse was travelling with the family to Newark, New Jersey, via Frankfurt, to help with pain relief during the journey.

German airline Lufthansa paid for the flights because the Websters did not have travel insurance.

Scotland Yard confirmed yesterday that Stephen Bonnett, a 26-year-old engineer, has been charged following the incident.

Bonnett, of Writtle, near Chelmsford, Essex, will appear before Bow Street magistrates in central London today, said a spokeswoman.

He is charged with causing grievous bodily harm to Mrs Webster and with dangerous driving.

The incident happened at 12.31pm.

The ornate black and gold gates outside Downing Street were erected in 1989 on the orders of then prime minister Margaret Thatcher, amid strong opposition at the time from Labour.

Former prime minister John Major and his cabinet narrowly escaped injury two years later when an IRA gang fired three mortar bombs from a Ford Transit van in a nearby street.

One of the weapons landed in the garden behind No 10, blowing out windows in nearby buildings.

webTitle: No mercy for Briton, says Burma

fields.headline: No mercy for Briton, says Burma
fields.trailText: Burma's military government yesterday said a jailed British pro-democracy activist was being held according to "internationally accepted standards" and his 17-year sentence was unlikely to be reduced.
fields.body:
Burma's military government yesterday said a jailed British pro-democracy activist was being held according to "internationally accepted standards" and his 17-year sentence was unlikely to be reduced.

James Mawdsley, 26, a citizen of Britain and Australia, was arrested for distributing anti-government literature last year in Tachilek.

A government spokesman, Lt Col Hla Min, said Mawdsley, a former Bristol university student, had "probably been exploited" by pro-democracy groups opposed to the military regime.

Mawdsley had been arrested on two previous occasions in Burma but was released after promising never to return.

Lt Col Hla Min said Mawdsley was "not an actual threat to national security" but could not be trusted not to return and flout the country's laws.

He said Mawdsley had been visited by his parents and the International Red Cross. Mawdsley received a visit on Wednesday from his father, David.

He left Keng Tung on Friday, a day before journalists were flown in by the government to report on drug eradication programmes in the region. He arrived back in Britain early yesterday.

David's mother, Diana, speaking from her home in County Durham, said she was "stunned" by the government's hardening stance.

She added: "This has come completely out of the blue."

Mawdsley has said he was tortured during his second arrest, when he was released after 99 days in solitary confinement. He was inspired by Nobel peace prize winner Aung San Suu Kyi to work non-violently for democracy in Burma.

After he was sentenced in September, he decided not to appeal.

webTitle: Attack on Straw over extension of secrecy

fields.headline: Attack on Straw over extension of secrecy
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has been severely criticised for using the new freedom of information legislation to extend secrecy to cover up some of the worst scandals which hit the monarchy this century.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has been severely criticised by Lord Woolf, chairman of the lord chancellor's advisory council on public records, for using the new freedom of information legislation to extend secrecy to cover up some of the worst scandals which hit the monarchy this century.

Lord Woolf - who has attacked the home secretary with the full knowledge of Lord Irvine - has accused Mr Straw of turning the clock back by introducing new restrictions to prevent historians getting access to documents covering communications with the monarch and the awarding of honours for 75 years.

This would prevent documents on Edward VIII's abdication crisis in 1936 appearing for another 12 years until 2011. It will also put back the disclosures surrounding the former Labour prime minister, Harold Wilson's "lavender list" of dubious political honours until 2051 instead of 2006.

Details of Lord Woolf's protest have become public after Mr Straw put nine volumes of consultation papers on his new freedom of information bill in the House of Commons library.

In it Lord Woolf accuses Mr Straw of being more secretive than the last Tory government over hiding documents that could embarrass the monarchy.

"The previous administration decided that records of this sort should be open to the public after 30 years in the same way as other public records, unless closure was justified under the published criteria. The class exemption of this material for 75 years is thus a considerable regression."

He is also critical over a new provision banning the disclosure of papers surrounding the award of honours for 75 years.

"Under the existing criteria, the closure of records relating to honours is determined on the basis of personal sensitivity or, occasionally, on the basis of damage to international relations.

"The council can see no justification for introducing a class exemption for all such material for 75 years, regardless of the harm, or lack of it, that might be caused by release."

Lord Woolf also calls for a more radical approach for the release of documents before they are 30 years old - including a proper review under the FOI bill of all existing documents that should become public under the new law.

He points out that every year two kilometres of documents are released - and under the bill people will be able to apply for copies of them.

Such a process will "generate high costs, long delays, and a sharply reduced quality of service for members of the public if it were applied to every one of the two kilometres or so of historical records transferred to the public record office each year."

He calls for a new code of practice to be issued by the lord chancellor for the release of historical records when the bill becomes law, and for expert advice on which documents should be released to be given to the advisory council on public records.

The proposals are bound to be raised by MPs on the council since they are already critical about Whitehall seeking to limit the release of information in these two areas - even when it should be published.

MPs on the council are also becoming increasingly puzzled by pressure from the foreign office to limit the release of 30-year-old diplomatic cables on the grounds that overseas governments would object.

This objection is looking increasingly bizarre after the US government released sensitive cables only two years old on Princess Diana's funeral and her landmines campaign under its freedom of information laws. Both these would be banned for 75 years under Mr Straw's new bill.

webTitle: Learning disability woman takes commission role

fields.headline: Learning disability woman takes commission role
fields.trailText: A woman with a learning disability will today be appointed to the government's new disability rights commission.
fields.body:
A woman with a learning disability will today be appointed to the government's new disability rights commission.

This will be seen as an historic breakthrough for people who were formerly marginalised as "mentally handicapped".

Evelyn Rank-Petruzzietto, who is involved in several disability groups including People First, will be made a full member of the commission alongside charity leaders and business representatives.

Although she will have a facilitator to help her at commission meetings, she has convinced Whitehall officials that she will be able to play a full part in the work of the new body, which starts in April.

Mencap, the learning disability charity which has been among those lobbying for such an appointment, said it was delighted at the decision.

Sarah Talbot-Williams, Mencap's head of communications, said: "This is excellent news for the rights and future of people with a learning disability. They are often an unheard voice."

There are an estimated 500,000 people with a learning disability, of whom more than 200,000 are considered severely disabled. Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, is believed to have been strongly in favour of appointing a rights commissioner with a learning disability. The commission, which will give disabled people a body of equal status to the equal opportunities commission and the commission for racial equality, will be chaired by Bert Massie, a wheelchair user and former director of the disability charity Radar.

The vice-chairman, to be announced today, will be John Hougham, who is now chairman of the industrial relations body Acas, although he will be taking up the post at a later date.

Other members of the commission will include James Strachan, chief executive of the Royal National Institute for Deaf People, who is himself deaf; Shagiar Alam, assistant solicitor at Rotherham council, who has progressive arthritis; and Colin Low, vice-chair of the Royal National Institute for the Blind, who has sight impairment.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Complaints over Hindley
fields.body:
Complaints over Hindley

Managers at Addenbrooke's hospital, Cambridge, where Moors murderer Myra Hindley, 57, is being treated for a potentially fatal brain condition, have received complaints from people who object to her being there.

Keith Day, the administrative director, said yesterday there had been a "number of representations" from people who objected to her receiving treatment for a cerebral aneurysm.

Man held by police dies

An investigation has been launched after a 26-year-old man died early yesterday while being detained by Essex police.

Officers went to Broomfield, Chelmsford, shortly after 12.30am following an emergency call. The man, who has not been named, collapsed after being detained. He was certified dead in hospital. A post-mortem is due today.

Air crash bodies home today

The bodies of five British oil workers killed in an air crash off Libya on Thursday are expected to be returned home today, according to Sirte Oil.

Storms dogged the search yesterday for the five people still missing, as British accident experts arrived to try to establish why the Belfast-built plane crashed.

Tourists back ethical holidays

More than half (59%) of British tourists would be willing to pay more for their holidays abroad if the extra money went towards staff wages and the local environment, according to a survey out yesterday from Christian development agency Tearfund.

£7.6m jackpot

Four tickets shared Saturday's £7.6m National Lottery jackpot, scooping £1,917,412 each. The winning numbers were 10, 12, 16, 17, 31 and 47, and the bonus was 21.

The winning Thunderball numbers were 3, 15, 16, 18 and 27. Thunderball was 5.

webTitle: Anxious fathers may be bad for birth

fields.headline: Anxious fathers may be bad for birth
fields.standfirst: 'Keep them away from the delivery room' advises childbirth guru
fields.trailText: One of the world's leading childbirth gurus and the pioneer of water births, Michel Odent, is about to turn orthodoxy on its head again by suggesting that women in labour are better off if the expectant father sticks to pacing the corridor
fields.body:
One of the world's leading childbirth gurus and the pioneer of water births, Michel Odent, is about to turn orthodoxy on its head again by suggesting that women in labour are better off if the expectant father sticks to pacing the corridor and leaves it to someone else to wipe her brow.

Up to 90% of fathers-to-be now attend the birth of their child, but Dr Odent will say in a lecture on Friday that in their anxiety to spare their partner pain, men impede women from getting on with the primal business of giving birth.

He will even suggest that the new trend for men to be in at the birth is responsible for the soaring rate of caesarean sections.

Dr Odent believes that giving birth is a primeval act during which women must be able to respond to their bodies. But anxious men, distressed at seeing their partners in pain, tend to try to talk to them and ask them rational questions about what is going on, forcing them, in the process, to respond with the intellectual side of the brain.

As a result, Dr Odent argues, women are distracted from their focus on the physical and primitive business of coping with contractions and they feel more fearful in response to their partner's own anxieties.

They end up having more painkilling drugs and more interventions, such as the use of forceps or caesarean sections, than they would otherwise, he believes.

The National Childbirth Trust is often held responsible for encouraging men to attend the birth of their child, but its head of policy research, Mary Newburn, said yesterday that "there may be something in what he is saying".

The father of the child being born might not always be the best person to help the woman in labour, she agreed. "It is most helpful if people have an open mind about who will give a woman support when she is in labour. It is unhelpful if there is an assumption that a man will always be there," she said.

"The woman needs to be able to choose who is right for her, and to do that without offending her partner.

Reeling

"I think that attending the birth has become a kind of symbol of new fatherhood. A lot of men don't do much else, but they are there at the birth. It doesn't generally take all that long and employers are usually very sympathetic."

Ms Newburn understands Dr Odent's view that men can distract from the business of giving birth. "I believe he feels that women may feel inhibited by a partner being there and that can interfere with the process of labour.

"The important thing is that the woman feels relaxed. It is very easy for people to do the wrong thing if they are not used to a woman in labour. Most of us haven't seen it until our children are born.

"Men are supposed to be giving support and they really are reeling because they don't know whether what is happening is usual, fine or what, and they really don't know what to do."

In some cultures, women are traditionally supported by other women who have given birth.

In Japan, most women leave their partners and return to their mother's home before the birth. Japan has a very low rate of epidural use - where a spinal anaesthetic is given which removes pain but leads to greater likelihood of a forceps delivery - at just 1%.

Many women depend heavily on their highly experienced midwife to get them through labour, but some find their midwife is constantly disappearing to look after someone else.

Studies have shown that women in labour do best and have less interventions if they have one midwife with them throughout their labour.

But because of a shortage of midwives, it is quite likely each midwife will have more than one woman in labour to look after, and will be sharing herself out between one room and another. The English National Board for nursing, midwifery and health visiting published a report showing that in a third of units, women did not have one to one care.

Dr Odent is no stranger to controversy. The 70-year-old Frenchman, who lives in England with his partner and their three-year-old son - he stayed outside during the birth - recently proposed that women should fast before they try to conceive, to attempt to rid their bodies of chemical impurities.

He founded the Primal Health Research Centre, in London, which investigates the impact of babies' birth experiences on the rest of their lives.

For: 'I wanted him to be part of the experience'

Catherine Elms, 23, from Liverpool, expected her husband Jonathan, a 24-year-old contract cleaner, to be present when she gave birth to Joel last February.

"He was my only birthing partner, and I felt it was important he was just as much a part of the birth as I was. I wanted him to be part of this once-in-a-lifetime experience. And I also wanted him to be there for me: to give me support when I really needed him.

"When it came to the birth, it all happened at once. I'd been having contractions for three days, so when we were finally admitted to the hospital, they gave me some pethidine so I was able to sleep. Then my waters broke and Jonathan went to get a midwife.

"The rest happened within 10 or 15 minutes and as the midwives got on with their job he sat there holding my hand. He watched me giving birth to my son and the only words he offered were those of comfort.

"I disagree about men distracting their partners with their anxieties or questions, because when it comes down to giving birth, you've just got that one thing you're concentrating on."

Against: 'I just want it to be me, a midwife and my baby'

Alex Rose, 30, a London barrister, is refusing to let her fiance Ted, a 31-year-old record producer, be present when she gives birth to their baby in August.

She says: "Dr Odent's comments are intuitive: that's totally how I feel.

"It sounds completely selfish but I don't want Ted to be present. I just feel he'd be so over-emotional, that I just want to get on with it and then present him with a baby.

"I also think giving birth should be a private thing. I just want it to be me, my midwife and my baby - with as little fuss and as few people as possible.

"I'm not prudish, but there is an element of feeling physically exposed.

"And if I'm going to be screaming and shouting, I want to do it on my own. I don't want to be comforted. I don't think it's a thing you can be comforted about.

"I don't want to exclude him - after all, it is his baby. But his first reaction was: 'Arghh! I don't want to be there.' He'll probably faint - he is quite squeamish. But I think I'd feel the same if he was calmer.

"When you have a baby, you need to be with your best friend and other women. It sounds terribly feminist, but you want to surround yourself with other women - not men."

Interviews by Sarah Hall

"I believe he feels that women may feel inhibited by a partner being there and that can interfere with the process of labour. "The important thing is that the woman feels relaxed. It is very easy for people to do the wrong thing if they are not used to a woman in labour. Most of us haven't seen it until our children are born. "Men are supposed to be giving support and they really are reeling because they don't know whether what is happening is usual, fine or what, and they really don't know what to do." Many women depend heavily on their highly experienced midwife to get them through labour, but some find their midwife is constantly disappearing to look after someone else. Studies have shown that women in labour do best and have less interventions if they have one midwife with them throughout their labour. But because of a shortage of midwives, it is quite likely each midwife will have more than one woman in labour to look after, and will be sharing herself out between one room and another. The English National Board for nursing, midwifery and health visiting published a report showing that in a third of units, women did not have one to one care. Dr Odent is no stranger to controversy. The 70-year-old Frenchman, who lives in England with his partner and their three-year-old son - he stayed outside during the birth - recently proposed that women should fast before they try to conceive, to attempt to rid their bodies of chemical impurities. He founded the Primal Health Research Centre, in London, which investigates the impact of babies' birth experiences on the rest of their lives. "He was my only birthing partner, and I felt it was important he was just as much a part of the birth as I was. I wanted him to be part of this once-in-a-lifetime experience. And I also wanted him to be there for me: to give me support when I really needed him. "When it came to the birth, it all happened at once. I'd been having contractions for three days, so when we were finally admitted to the hospital, they gave me some pethidine so I was able to sleep. Then my waters broke and Jonathan went to get a midwife. "The rest happened within 10 or 15 minutes and as the midwives got on with their job he sat there holding my hand. He watched me giving birth to my son and the only words he offered were those of comfort. "I disagree about men distracting their partners with their anxieties or questions, because when it comes down to giving birth, you've just got that one thing you're concentrating on." Against: 'I just want it to be me, a midwife and my baby' Alex Rose, 30, a London barrister, is refusing to let her fiance Ted, a 31-year-old record producer, be present when she gives birth to their baby in August. She says: "Dr Odent's comments are intuitive: that's totally how I feel. "It sounds completely selfish but I don't want Ted to be present. I just feel he'd be so over-emotional, that I just want to get on with it and then present him with a baby. "I also think giving birth should be a private thing. I just want it to be me, my midwife and my baby - with as little fuss and as few people as possible. "I'm not prudish, but there is an element of feeling physically exposed. "And if I'm going to be screaming and shouting, I want to do it on my own. I don't want to be comforted. I don't think it's a thing you can be comforted about. "I don't want to exclude him - after all, it is his baby. But his first reaction was: 'Arghh! I don't want to be there.' He'll probably faint - he is quite squeamish. But I think I'd feel the same if he was calmer. "When you have a baby, you need to be with your best friend and other women. It sounds terribly feminist, but you want to surround yourself with other women - not men." Interviews by Sarah Hall

fields.headline: Mowlam reignites drugs debate
fields.standfirst: Minister admits smoking cannabis in her 'wild' student days but insists she will continue to spearhead government fight against drug useDrugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the cabinet office minister, who heads the government's anti-drugs campaign, yesterday reignited the debate on the legalisation of cannabis when she admitted inhaling marijuana as a student.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the cabinet office minister, who heads the government's anti-drugs campaign, yesterday reignited the debate on the legalisation of cannabis when she admitted inhaling marijuana as a student.

Showing characteristic honesty, Ms Mowlam immediately came clean about her "wild" days as a student when she was questioned about Sunday newspaper claims that she had smoked cannabis.

"I tried marijuana, didn't like it particularly and unlike President Clinton I did inhale," Ms Mowlam, 50, told Sky television, recalling her days as a postgraduate student at Iowa State university. "But it wasn't part of my life then and that's what happened."

Ms Mowlam, who studied in America in the early 1970s after an undergraduate degree at Durham university, said she did not believe her admission made her unfit to head the government's hardline anti-drugs strategy.

"I will continue to fight hard against the drugs that can kill people, like heroin and cocaine," Ms Mowlam said. "I will continue to say to young people, as I have done for the last two months in the job, that taking drugs is not within the law and is not a credible thing to do in your life."

Ms Mowlam, who described herself as a "child of the 60s", was forced to speak about her experimentation with drugs after a former student at Iowa recalled seeing her handling drugs at a party.

Claudia Beyer, a fellow postgraduate political student, said she saw Ms Mowlam holding a cannabis cigarette, though she could not remember whether she had smoked it. "I didn't see it touch her lips," Mrs Beyer told the Sunday Telegraph. "There was always time for partying at that time but Mo was very hard-working. She always had the work done first."

Ms Mowlam, one of the most candid members of the cabinet, who peppers conversations in private with colourful language, has made no secret of her wild days as a student at Durham in the late 1960s. She told one interviewer: "I suppose I was pretty wild. I was a child of the 60s and did everything that went with that."

Ms Mowlam, who is still angry at the way in which she was removed as Northern Ireland secretary last year, is unlikely to suffer any political damage from her admission.

Jack Straw, the home secretary who takes pride in his squeaky clean behaviour as a student at Leeds in the early 1960s, praised his cabinet colleague for being honest. "Good for Mo in making this clear," he told Jonathan Dimbleby on ITV. "One of her very great strengths is her integrity and if people have smoked cannabis in the past, far better to say they have."

The government's drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell, also supported Ms Mowlam. He told GMTV: "I think we've got to stop this idea of witch-hunts and pointing the finger. The debate needs to be at a much higher level than that. If there continues to be a label on people - you know, 'you are a bad person if you ever took drugs' - then we'll never move forward. There needs to be more of the openness."

The anti-drugs campaigner Janet Betts, whose teenage daughter Leah died after taking an ecstasy tablet, said: "All this shows is that Mo Mowlam was a student and, like thou sands of others in the 60s and 70s, she experimented with cannabis and in her case did not enjoy it."

Even the Tories made little attempt to capitalise on Ms Mowlam's admission. Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet office minister, said: "I appreciate that it is important for Mo Mowlam to answer questions about her past. But it remains true that the important thing is not her past experience but that she now continues - with us - to stress to young people in particular the dangers of experimentation with and use of drugs."

The government, however, is unlikely to welcome the reopening of the debate on the legalisation of soft drugs. Ministers, who stamped on Clare Short when she called for a debate on the issue, have come under fire from civil rights groups and the Liberal Democrats for refusing to consider relaxing the law.

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, seized on Ms Mowlam's remarks to reiterate his demand for a royal commission to look at drugs policy. "Having written personally to both Mr Hague and Mr Blair at the end of last week calling on them to enter into a debate on this very issue, I hope that Mo Mowlam's department and the revelations of this weekend will encourage a more open and mature debate into this crucial area of British society," Mr Kennedy said.

Opponents of the government will receive a boost later this month when the Police Foundation, whose president is the Prince of Wales, publishes a report saying that the possession of cannabis should no longer be punishable by jail. The report is also expected to call for a relaxation of the ban on the use of cannabis for medical purposes.

fields.headline: £25m gallery rising after 100 year wait
fields.standfirst: Manchester's Turners, Picassos and Hockneys set to see the light
fields.trailText: Better late than never: an extension which will double the size of Manchester's city art gallery is rising on land bought for the purpose 100 years ago.
fields.body:
Better late than never: an extension which will double the size of Manchester's city art gallery is rising on land bought for the purpose 100 years ago.

"It's been a long time coming but it will have been worth the wait," said a gallery spokeswoman as a huge crane - last seen in cultural action on the new Royal Opera House, in Covent Garden - swung over a forest of scaffolding.

The £25m development, funded with £15m from the lottery, £9m from Manchester city council and £1.1m from Europe, will be complete by the end of 2001.

The city owns 50,000 works of art but only 5,000 have been on display at any one time because of a shortage of space. Masterpieces by such artists as Turner, Picasso and Hockney have spent more time in store than on public view.

"This will dramatically improve visitor facilities and massively increase access to the city art collections," added the spokeswoman. "Items from the rich 20th century collection and rarely seen works on paper will be on permanent display for the first time."

The original gallery, designed in neo-classical style by Sir Charles Barry, opened 150 years ago as the Manchester Institution for the Promotion of Literature, Science and Art.

It was taken over by the city council, which contributed £2,000 a year for art works, including one of the country's finest collections of pre-Raphaelite pictures.

The council bought land for an extension in 1898 and 40 years later purchased the adjacent high-Victorian Athenaeum club, since used for temporary exhibitions.

The two existing buildings will be refurbished and cleared of grime. Both will be linked by a stone and glass extension designed by Michael Hopkins and Partners, architects of new parliament buildings at Westminster and the new Glyndebourne opera house.

The extension, on the edge of the Chinese quarter of the city, will also give the gallery a huge new space for blockbuster exhibitions.

In order to make a seamless join between old and new, heritage architects Peter Inskip and Peter Jenkins have tracked down the Lancashire quarry from which sandstone blocks for Barry's original gallery were quarried in the 1840s. Stone quarried there last summer will be used in the new extension.

More northern stone will be used to refurbish the original gallery's huge Ironic columns. Inside, work continues to spruce up the small but impressive entrance hall, with its reproductions of the Elgin marbles.

In the Athenaeum - which bears the proud inscription "For the advancement and diffusion of knowledge" - the magnificent original lecture hall, with wild plaster flourishes, is being converted into what is called "a theatre of decorative arts and design" - a gallery to show off a rarely seen collection of silver, ceramics, glass and furniture.

The finished scheme will also include a new children's gallery and an education space - the whole of the ground floor given over to facilities for lifelong learning. There will be a new shop and two cafes.

Disabled people will have access to the whole gallery.

The designers promise "to ensure the visitor experience is a pleasant one, whatever the weather".

The complex will open more than 18 months after the Lowry, the cultural centre with auditoriums and galleries which is now rising three miles away on the banks of the Manchester ship canal.

"Manchester will not have to wait much longer for a magnificently enlarged gallery which will enhance the cultural life of a great city in the 21st century," said the spokeswoman, unfazed by a potential rival.

fields.headline: Harrison recovering in Ireland
fields.trailText: The former Beatle George Harrison was holidaying in Ireland with his wife Olivia yesterday after being stabbed by an intruder in his Oxfordshire home.
fields.body:
The former Beatle George Harrison was holidaying in Ireland with his wife Olivia yesterday after being stabbed by an intruder in his Oxfordshire home.

The couple were spotted at an undisclosed location, almost three weeks after the attack at their 120-room mansion in Henley-on-Thames.

Olivia stood with her arms around her husband and carried a small flower.

In his first statement since the attack, the star said: "Olivia and I are overwhelmed by the concern expressed by so many people. We thank everyone for their prayers and kindness."

Harrison, 56, who spent new year in hospital after being stabbed in the chest, looked relaxed in the rural surroundings. He fended off the cold with a woolly hat.

The intruder beat Harrison's security system of razorwire, sensors and cameras to enter his home.

Michael Abram, 33, has been charged with attempted murder. He was bailed by magistrates in Oxford and is due to appear in court on February 11.

webTitle: They remember the 60s, but it was someone else smoking

fields.headline: They remember the 60s, but it was someone else smoking
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam's fellow 60s children were last night relaxed about her revelation that she had used cannabis during her student days.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam's fellow 60s children were last night relaxed about her revelation that she had used cannabis during her student days.

But the former wild ones were not exactly rushing to join the queue behind the cabinet minister to confess the same thing. Just because you remember the 1960s, they contended, it doesn't mean you weren't there.

Asked whether she had ever taken drugs, Edwina Currie, the former Tory health minister (17 in 1963), said flatly: "No I didn't. I've never even smoked a cigarette. If that's the best they can cook up on Mo Mowlam then she must be doing something right."

As a pupil at the Liverpool Institute for Girls, she spent a bit of time flirting with Steve Norris who, along with Paul McCartney and George Harrison, attended the boys' school.

But as the Beatles went off to cannabis and LSD-raddled fame and fortune, Mr Norris plunged into the drug-free drudgery of Worcester College, Oxford.

"I am very lucky - I am just too old to have been in school or university when drugs were about, so I can honestly say no I didn't," said Mr Norris, 18 in 1963.

Attempts to pose the question to the BBC's two director-generals, Sir John Birt and Greg Dyke, were met with a flat "I am unable to offer any comment on that at all" from a corporation spokesman.

John Humphrys, presenter of Radio 4's Today pro gramme and a 20-year-old in 1963, said: "None of your business, in short."

But he added: "I can't quite see why we should be excited as to whether somebody puffed on a spliff at the age of 20 or not. I'd be slightly surprised if most students hadn't. In fact I'd probably treat with a certain scepticism any 40- or 50-year-old who'd been to university and said they'd never so much as had a puff on a spliff."

Tony Blair, a mere 10 in 1963, dabbled in rock music at Fettes and St John's College, Oxford, but - as he said before becoming Labour leader - "didn't get into drugs". William Hague was a child of the 1960s only to the extent that he was born in them (1961). Home secretary Jack Straw (17 in 1963) not only did not take cannabis at Leeds university but actively campaigned against it.

The former Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown, asked if he had ever taken drugs, once testily told a student interviewer: "I do not accept the validity of the question."

But an increasingly tolerant attitude to cannabis among prominent people was illustrated by a survey which revealed that, of 81 MPs from the 1997 intake who replied to a survey, 22 had taken illegal drugs. One, David Prior - now Tory deputy chairman - said then: "I associate my experience with drugs - soft ones - not with Mick Jagger or Aldous Huxley, but with passing my law degree and working in a bank. You can wear a pinstripe suit and be utterly conventional and still roll a joint."

Mr Ashdown's successor, Charles Kennedy, has called for a royal commission on drugs. Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman (12 in 1963) repeated last night that he had taken drugs when a lawyer in London, the last time in about 1980. "It was some time ago and it happily came and went fairly quickly. Like Mo I found it not of any great interest and certainly with no addictive affects."

Mr Hughes said Ms Mowlam's revelation would actually help the debate. "I hope that by Mo making the statement she did the government are not so absolutist about not wanting to talk about changing anything. The fact it happens to be the person in the cabinet office in charge of drugs policy gives more credibility, particularly with users, than the blank 'nothing to do with us, we musn't touch it' approach."

The publicist Max Clifford said it did not matter if people such as Mo Mowlam had once used cannabis - and even that it would hardly matter if people in her position did so nowadays.

"I know people that take it. I know politicians that use it - so what? To a lot of people it's a form of relaxation and if you are under tremendous pressure, if you find something that doesn't harm you or anybody else then good luck to you."

Mr Clifford, 20 in 1963, said he had plenty of access to drugs in those days but had never taken them. "I suppose I never thought I needed it. Most of the people I represented took cannabis and other drugs - everyone I have ever dealt with, from Joe Cocker to Jimi Hendrix. Some of the time there was almost like a cloud in the office."

fields.standfirst: Weekend TV

The idea is that the emancipated and forward-looking Mrs Adela Bradley (played with a permanently raised eyebrow by Diana Rigg) applies new-fangled theories of psychology to 1920s detection. Unfortunately, the programme's fixation with authentic costumes, period cars and country houses conjures the illusion that the production has been lashed together from a warehouse full of spare props from Poirot and Miss Marple.
fields.body:
The Mrs Bradley Mysteries (BBC1, Sunday) offers disturbing proof that not even a platinum-plated cast is safe from rigor-mortis plotting and dialogue which resembles the minutes from a taxidermists' conference. The idea is that the emancipated and forward-looking Mrs Adela Bradley (played with a permanently raised eyebrow by Diana Rigg) applies new-fangled theories of psychology to 1920s detection. Unfortunately, the programme's fixation with authentic costumes, period cars and country houses conjures the illusion that the production has been lashed together from a warehouse full of spare props from Poirot and Miss Marple.

Certainly Dame Diana is eye-catching in a dizzying parade of bonnets, boots, brooches and leopardskin wraps, but how one could wish she wouldn't keep turning to the camera with a confiding aside or a knowing wink. It was annoying enough when Ian Richardson used to do it in his Francis Urquhart role. Here, it gave the impression that Rigg was acting inside her own self-contained bubble, and wanted the viewer to understand that she found the woefully static "action" around her something of a bore.

Not that you could blame her. Once you'd peeled away the trappings of lesbianism, kleptomania and theories of hypnosis, you were left with a routine rural whodunnit featuring only two mundane murders. So much energy was lavished on explaining the subplot featuring Mrs Simms and her love child, and on preparing viewers for the shock of finding a Sapphic love affair at the centre of the story, that characterisation and plot were aban doned altogether. It became increasingly hard to comprehend why Mrs Bradley looked so astonishingly pleased with herself.

It was a relief to turn instead to the rugged documentarism of Tracing The French Connection (BBC2, Saturday), in which Mark Kermode looked at the making of William Friedkin's 1971 movie and examined how the film was built on the real-life escapades of New York detectives Eddie "Popeye" Egan and Sonny "Cloudy" Grosso. This was a mine of information for movie buffs, illuminating one of the key movies from the so-called "New Hollywood" movement of the 70s while offering fascinating glimpses into the way the creation of a successful movie is invariably shrouded in ambiguity and thinly veiled jealousies.

For instance, both Friedkin and Gene Hackman told the story of how they met for lunch before Hackman was cast in the role which would win him a Best Actor Oscar. Hackman remembered the meeting as being hugely enjoyable, with Friedkin regaling him with jokes and anecdotes. Friedkin, on the other hand, claimed the lunch was so boring that he almost dozed off. It was scarcely surprising to learn that their relationship during shooting turned out to be one of bitter antagonism. Again, some members of the production crew recalled how Ernest Tidyman's script lay at the heart of the picture's success, while Friedkin claimed there was barely a word of Tidyman's work in the finished film.

You couldn't help admiring Friedkin's achievement, nonetheless. The relentlessly squalid and downbeat look of The French Connection set a benchmark in nouveau- vérité, while the celebrated car chase underneath the elevated railway still looks authentically hair-raising because it was. Friedkin shot it live with no tricks, no set- ups and no permission, and all the skids and collisions were real.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: It seems a little eccentric to choose Ottorino Respighi as Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3) this early in the millennium. There's no anniversary (he lived from 1879 to 1936), his talents were mediocre, and he passed much of his professional life looking firmly backwards. His flamboyant orchestrations won an audience, but about his only gesture to his own period was to insert a recording of a nightingale's song into The Pines Of Rome.
fields.body:
It seems a little eccentric to choose Ottorino Respighi as Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3) this early in the millennium. There's no anniversary (he lived from 1879 to 1936), his talents were mediocre, and he passed much of his professional life looking firmly backwards. His flamboyant orchestrations won an audience, but about his only gesture to his own period was to insert a recording of a nightingale's song into The Pines Of Rome.

"The 2 windowes of yowr privy chamber shall be the poles of my sphere" wrote young Robert Devereux to a woman well over twice his 23 years. But laying it on with a trowel came naturally to the ambitious Earl of Essex in his 11-year correspondence with Elizabeth I. Last summer the British Library acquired 43 of his often stormy letters, which have now been dramatised by Lisa Osborne as the new Woman's Hour serial (10.45am and 7.45pm, Radio 4).

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.standfirst: Charlie Sheen in The Wraith
fields.trailText: Charlie Sheen in The Wraith
fields.body:
Charlie Sheen in The Wraith

(Mike Marvin, 1986)

Who? Charlie (real name Carlos Irwin Estevez), son of Martin, brother of Emilio, and far more famous for his fondness for drugs, porn stars and firearms than his acting ability. And yet it all started so well for him - Platoon, Wall Street, Young Guns: the phrase Big in the 80s could have been invented for him. Sadly, the 90s started with Men At Work (a comedy about binmen) and went downhill from there. The new century will witness a career-boosting cameo in Spike Jonze's much acclaimed Being John Malkovich. It's about time.

The role: Well, he's motorbike-riding bad boy Jake by day, spooky black-clad drag racer The Wraith by night, where he seeks revenge on the gang who killed him back when he was someone else entirely. Got that? Good. Because it's about as much plot as you're going to get from this nonsensical affront to filmmaking.

Best Line: The Wraith is a supernatural figure in biking leathers and therefore a man of few words.

Cringe factor: For anyone else it would be sky-high, but Sheen's had so much humiliation in real life that no mere movie role could shame him.

Other wannabes: Fellow sons of famous fathers, Nick Cassavetes and Griffin O'Neal (as gang leader and gang member respectively), and Sherilyn Fenn as Cassavetes' girlfriend.

Critical judgement: "The Wraith", remarked The Washington Post's Paul Attanasio, "is essentially a wall-to-wall car chase that writer/director Marvin attempts to enliven with TV commercial visuals, tough-guy dialogue (on the order of 'Awright, you craterheads') and modestly inventive casting."

Also not starring in: 1985 TV movie Out Of The Darkness as "Man Having A Shave".

The Wraith, Sci-Fi Channel, Wednesday January 19, 10.0pm
