fields.headline: Ella Goldberg Wolfe
fields.standfirst: Immigrant who was hounded by the US authorities for her communism and met Stalin in Moscow, but ended up supporting Reagan
fields.trailText: Ella Goldberg Wolfe, who has died aged 103, lived to witness the entire trajectory of communism in the US. Born at Kherson, in the Ukraine, in a time of pogroms, she became a prominent American communist but later moved to the right politically, ending her life in the strongly anti-communist atmosphere of the Hoover Institution on the Stanford university campus in Palo Alto, California; her circle included Robert Conquest, the historian of Stalin's terror, and Edward Teller, "father of the H-bomb".
fields.body:
Ella Goldberg Wolfe, who has died aged 103, lived to witness the entire trajectory of communism in the US. Born at Kherson, in the Ukraine, in a time of pogroms, she became a prominent American communist but later moved to the right politically, ending her life in the strongly anti-communist atmosphere of the Hoover Institution on the Stanford university campus in Palo Alto, California; her circle included Robert Conquest, the historian of Stalin's terror, and Edward Teller, "father of the H-bomb".

Wolfe was brought to the US as a child. In 1910, at the age of 14, she met Bertram D Wolfe at a park tennis court in Brooklyn. He took an instant liking to her, and they were married in 1917, just in time for the October Revolution. They were married for 60 years, until his death in 1977.

Barely 5ft tall, Wolfe was striking rather than beautiful, with bright blue eyes that people remembered. She was also steely in her determination, and sharp in repartee.

Before the Russian revolution, the Wolfes and their friend John Reed were part of the cultural left in Greenwich Village. In 1919, together with Reed, Bert Wolfe wrote the Left Wing Manifesto, which created the American Communist Party. After the passage of the 1918 sedition act, the 1920s saw the "Palmer raids" in which many foreign-born radicals were deported to the Soviet Union. The Wolfes were forced to live clandestinely; they assumed false names and, on several occasions, were almost caught. They hid in New York, San Francisco and Washington, as well as in Mexico City, where they were friends of the great communist mural artist, Diego Rivera, and of Frida Kahlo, the painter, who had been Trotsky's mistress. In the US, they helped the great exiled Russian poet Vladimir Mayakovski and lent him money. He repaid them by putting it about that Ella was his mistress, which she rejected with amusement rather than anger.

Wolfe worked as her husband's unpaid secretary and editor. They decided not to have children, so as to free her for work as a revolutionary, something she later said she regretted. In 1929, Bert became a member of the Comintern, and the couple moved to Moscow, where they met Stalin. Years later, Ella described him as "smaller than I expected, with a pockmarked face, a brutal mouth and the yellow eyes of a mountain lion". Bert Wolfe angered Stalin by arguing for "American exceptionalism". This was the case (made by the section of the American communist movement known as the "Lovestonites", after their leader Jay Lovestone) that Marxist-Leninist ideas should not be automatically applied to conditions in the US but should be adapted.

This put them at odds not only with the Stalinists but with the Trotskyists. Although both factions in the US together had fewer than 1,000 members, they continued to argue through their journals, the Lovestonites' Workers Age and the Trotskyists' New International.

Stalin decided against Bert Wolfe and his "American exceptionalism". The Wolfes were probably lucky to survive; if they had fallen out so publicly with Stalin a few years later, during the great purges, they could well have been eliminated. Bert was expelled from the Communist Party and Ella left two years later after refusing to denounce her husband. By the 1940s, after the Nazi-Soviet pact and Hitler's attack on Russia, which turned the Soviet Union into a "gallant ally" to America, the Wolfes had left the Lovestone group.

Back in America, Wolfe went to college and earned a master's degree in Spanish at Columbia university in New York. This enabled her to teach, which she did in schools and at Hunter college. Her husband worked on his great book about the failure of communism, Three Who Made a Revolution. In the 1960s, he accepted a job at the Hoover Institution at Stanford, where they became known for their dinner parties attended by many of the great figures of the history of the left in the US and Europe.

Ella continued to work for many years, and was still driving at 96. By the 1970s, she and her husband had become conservatives, like so many of those around them at Stanford, and even supporters of Ronald Reagan.

Ella Wolfe lived to see her third century, and long survived the cause of revolutionary socialism to which she and her husband had given most of their life, but which they had rejected long before the Soviet Union collapsed.

Ella Goldberg Wolfe, activist, born May 10 1896; died January 8 2000

fields.headline: Wendy Trewin
fields.standfirst: Critic in her husband's footsteps
fields.trailText: What gave Wendy Trewin's career as drama critic its special quality was that it did not begin until she was 74, when she joined the Critics' Circle; she remained our oldest working critic until her death at 84.
fields.body:
What gave Wendy Trewin's career as drama critic its special quality was that it did not begin until she was 74, when she joined the Critics' Circle; she remained our oldest working critic until her death at 84.

As the widow of JC Trewin, who had been reviewing plays for longer than anyone could remember, she took over from him on The Lady when he died 10 years ago. She had been a journalist since she was 18 and a playgoer all her life. Both Trewins loved the theatre, but what characterised Wendy's writing was a refreshingly guarded critical faculty, one which could not be easily swayed by theatrical novelty.

Trewin was not as widely known as her husband, but she also wrote histories, including All on Stage (1980), the story of the Albery family of West End theatre owners; The Arts Theatre, London, 1927-1981 (1986) for the Society for Theatre Research; and The Royal General Theatrical Fund (1989), a history of the charity, of which she was a vice-president. She also wrote book reviews for the Birmingham Post and the Ham and High.

She valued her husband's role more than her own journalism. When she took over on The Lady she dreaded anyone finding out how old she was, sure that they would judge her to be past it.

The elder daughter of a piano and sheet-music retailer in the west country, she was born in Plymouth. She loved music, reading and reciting verse. Joining the staff of a local Sunday paper, the Western Independent, as a reporter, she met John Trewin, a Cornishman. He was about to move to London to join the Morning Post; he later became literary editor of the Observer. They married in 1938. They had chosen Bavaria for their honeymoon, but instead went to Scotland before settling in Hampstead.

An active member of the parish church, she became convener of an ecumenical study group. Among other books were John Gill of Penryn (1981), a life of her great-grandfather, a Cornish Quaker, pacifist and vegetarian, and in 1972 she edited a new edition of the journals of Caroline Fox, another Cornish Quaker and biographer of Carlyle and John Stuart Mill. In 1987 Trewin collaborated with a fellow Hampstead parishioner, Barbara Tomson, on Embroidered Church Kneelers.

She is survived by her two sons.

Wendy Trewin, critic, born July 19 1915; died January 4 2000

fields.headline: Leonard Marchant
fields.standfirst: Brilliant artist and teacher who revived the neglected craft of mezzotinting, reinventing the infuriatingly slow method in a modern idiom
fields.trailText: While a student at the Central School for Arts and Crafts in London, a young Leonard Marchant found an engraving rocker in a cupboard and proceeded to turn himself into a master of the painstaking art of mezzotinting.
fields.body:
While a student at the Central School for Arts and Crafts in London, a young Leonard Marchant found an engraving rocker in a cupboard and proceeded to turn himself into a master of the painstaking art of mezzotinting.

Marchant, who has died in Shrewsbury aged 70, grew up in Simonstown, the Royal Navy's enclave in South Africa. Though his first job was as a parliamentary messenger, he taught himself to paint and, aged 19, was given a one-man show in Cape Town. Fired by this success, he left for England to study painting and, he claimed, to escape the stifling home atmosphere created by his Catholic mother and aunts - his father was killed in the second world war. Without contacts in London, he phoned Jacob Epstein, whose recommendation resulted in a grant to study briefly at the Central school. It was later, when studying full-time at the Central, that he saw the mezzotints of the Japanese master, Yozo Hamaguchi, in a London gallery. He was hooked.

Creating a mezzotint is tedious in the extreme. The copper plate must first be prepared with a "rocker" which roughens the surface. A plate may be "rocked" 30 or 40 times. The rough texture is then reduced with a burnisher and a scraper, allowing the print a range of tones from velvety black through the greys to white. Marchant's plates could be months in the making. But the technical demands were the least of his worries. In its 18th- and 19th-century heyday, mezzotint was solely a reproductive medium, for copying masters such as Reynolds and Turner. The development of photography rendered it unfashionable, and by the 1960s the technique, known as la manière anglaise, was a bygone medium.

Marchant, by now a teacher in printmaking at the Central, began to create original mezzotints with a colleague, Radavan Kraguly. A perfectionist, he seemed to revel in the straitjacket procedure. Perhaps it was the metaphor of bringing darkness out of light that appealed to this straight-talking, sometimes sombre, man, who would suddenly relax and light up like a gleaming hue on one of his prints. His work was of squares and triangles with the occasional cat, black and ominous, and carefully arranged still lifes, featuring plants, a seed pod, a pot he might have bought at auction to celebrate the sale of a print.

There were one-man shows, notably at the Bankside gallery. He sold well at the Royal Academy summer exhibition, was a Florence Biennale prizewinner, spent a fellowship year at the British School in Rome, and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Painter-Printmakers.

But making mezzotints was not a paying job. Marchant and his South African wife, Tess, lived grandly in houses they could barely afford. Quercus, their shop in Primrose Hill, London, sold oak furniture in the 60s, before it was fashionable. When Marchant needed to renew stocks, he found he had priced himself out of the market.

Professor David Carpanini of the Royal Society of Printmakers says a mezzotinter has to be very sure of what he wants to do. "Marchant's work was very sensitive in being able to see the model in areas of tone, which is the fundamental ability of the skilled mezzotinter. He had extraordinary poetic insight."

Despite its revival, mezzotinting has a long way to go. It is not a favoured offering in art schools and dealers may also consider it "gloomy", though Marchant later printed in strong reds and brighter colours. A heavy smoker, Marchant contracted emphysema, but carried on rocking the plates till it became too much for him. He was an accomplished painter and, in his final year, was able to snatch a few hours a day to finish several large canvasses, including a much-cherished portrait of myself and my children.

He is survived by Tess.

Leonard Marchant, mezzotinter and painter, born October 23 1929; died January 9 2000

But the technical demands were the least of his worries. In its 18th- and 19th-century heyday, mezzotint was solely a reproductive medium, for copying masters such as Reynolds and Turner. The development of photography rendered it unfashionable, and by the 1960s the technique, known as la manière anglaise, was a bygone medium. Marchant, by now a teacher in printmaking at the Central, began to create original mezzotints with a colleague, Radavan Kraguly. A perfectionist, he seemed to revel in the straitjacket procedure. Perhaps it was the metaphor of bringing darkness out of light that appealed to this straight-talking, sometimes sombre, man, who would suddenly relax and light up like a gleaming hue on one of his prints. His work was of squares and triangles with the occasional cat, black and ominous, and carefully arranged still lifes, featuring plants, a seed pod, a pot he might have bought at auction to celebrate the sale of a print. There were one-man shows, notably at the Bankside gallery. He sold well at the Royal Academy summer exhibition, was a Florence Biennale prizewinner, spent a fellowship year at the British School in Rome, and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Painter-Printmakers. But making mezzotints was not a paying job. Marchant and his South African wife, Tess, lived grandly in houses they could barely afford. Quercus, their shop in Primrose Hill, London, sold oak furniture in the 60s, before it was fashionable. When Marchant needed to renew stocks, he found he had priced himself out of the market. Professor David Carpanini of the Royal Society of Printmakers says a mezzotinter has to be very sure of what he wants to do. "Marchant's work was very sensitive in being able to see the model in areas of tone, which is the fundamental ability of the skilled mezzotinter. He had extraordinary poetic insight." Despite its revival, mezzotinting has a long way to go. It is not a favoured offering in art schools and dealers may also consider it "gloomy", though Marchant later printed in strong reds and brighter colours. A heavy smoker, Marchant contracted emphysema, but carried on rocking the plates till it became too much for him. He was an accomplished painter and, in his final year, was able to snatch a few hours a day to finish several large canvasses, including a much-cherished portrait of myself and my children. He is survived by Tess. Leonard Marchant, mezzotinter and painter, born October 23 1929; died January 9 2000

fields.headline: John Reed
fields.trailText: The music of Franz Schubert has been well served by British scholars, for whom its study has been a labour of love rather than a profession. In the 19th century, Sir George Grove, civil engineer and chairman of the Crystal Palace Company, masterminded first performances of several Schubert symphonies, tracked down Schubert manuscripts in Vienna and wrote on the composer for his own Dictionary of Music. More recently, the grammar school science teacher Maurice Brown wrote extensively and authoritatively on Schubert's works. John Reed, who has died aged 90, was the latest in this distinguished line, enjoying a second career as a Schubert scholar after his retirement from salaried work.
fields.body:
The music of Franz Schubert has been well served by British scholars, for whom its study has been a labour of love rather than a profession. In the 19th century, Sir George Grove, civil engineer and chairman of the Crystal Palace Company, masterminded first performances of several Schubert symphonies, tracked down Schubert manuscripts in Vienna and wrote on the composer for his own Dictionary of Music. More recently, the grammar school science teacher Maurice Brown wrote extensively and authoritatively on Schubert's works. John Reed, who has died aged 90, was the latest in this distinguished line, enjoying a second career as a Schubert scholar after his retirement from salaried work.

Born in Aldershot, Reed studied English at London university, and began his professional life as an English teacher. After volunteering for second world war service in the RAF, he joined the BBC in 1946. There he worked in the education department as producer and administrator until he retired in 1968.

In 1959 he had published an article on the so-called "Gastein" symphony, and his reputation was firmly established with the appearance in 1972 of his first book, Schubert: The Final Years. It analysed Schubert's life and music, and cut through the myths surrounding the "Gmunden-Gastein" symphony, demonstrating that it is identical to the "Great" C major symphony, which dates from 1825, and not 1828.

Reed's Schubert Song Companion (1985) was, remarkably, the first book to discuss each of Schubert's solo songs. This remarkable compendium brought Reed the Vincent Duckles Award, and was an invaluable aid to concert organisers planning song series for the 1997 Schubert bicentenary. Reed's Schubert biography in the Master Musicians series (1987, revised 1996) is a highly readable and authoritative account.

Reed shared the results of his research not only through his publications, but through his generous assistance to other scholars. He was instrumental in founding the Schubert Institute (UK) in 1991 and became its first chairman, steering it to become a leading forum for the discussion and performance of Schubert's works. In 1997 he achieved a long-held ambition with the official inauguration of the Schubert Institute Research Centre within the University of Leeds.

Reed was a familiar figure in the musical world of his adopted home, Manchester, and became honorary director of the Manchester Camerata orchestra. His contribution to Schubert scholarship was recognised in 1989 through the award of honorary membership of Vienna's International Franz Schubert Institute.

John was happily married for over 60 years to his wife Marion, who died in 1998, and is survived by two sons and two daughters.

John Reed, musicologist, born May 30 1909; died December 27 1999

webTitle: Mandela hits out at Burundi's warring leaders warmongers

fields.headline: Mandela hits out at Burundi's warring leaders warmongers
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela used his first speech as facilitator of the Burundi peace talks yesterday to criticise the warring parties of the six-year conflict, likening them to barbarians, lacking in either "vision or talent."
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela used his first speech as facilitator of the Burundi peace talks yesterday to criticise the warring parties of the six-year conflict, likening them to barbarians, lacking in either "vision or talent."

Speaking in Arusha, northern Tanzania, where the negotiations are being held, he blasted delegates for their failure to compromise and urged them to rise above their differences and put the country's interests above their own.

"The fact that women, children and the aged are being slaughtered every day is an indictment against all of you. Why do you allow yourselves to be regarded as leaders without talent, leaders without vision?" he asked.

A bitter civil war has been raging in Burundi since October 1993 when Tutsi paratroopers assassinated the democratically elected Hutu President, Melchior Ndadaye.

Hutu rebels took up arms against the Tutsi-led government that replaced Ndadaye and the country has been embroiled in the inter-ethnic cycle of rebel attack and military reprisal ever since. More than 200,000 people have been killed.

Mr Mandela told the Burundian government and the rebel groups fighting to overthrow them that the outside world shuddered at news of the conflict and recoiled at the number of casualties.

"When they hear this they say, 'Africans are still barbarians. No human being could do what they are doing'," he said. The mood among delegates as they filed out of the conference hall was subdued. "There were things he said which did not please everyone," said a spokesman for one of the rebel factions, "but they were things that had to be said."

International observers involved in the process left the meeting pleased with Mr Mandela's speech but warning that the complexity of Burundi's civil war means his work will be cut out for him.

There are already 18 political parties involved in the talks and since the peace process began, ceasefires have been ignored and the humanitarian situation in Burundi has deteriorated to its worst levels.

In the past month more than 30,000 refugees have fled the country increasing the number of Burundian refugees sheltering in neighbouring Tanzania to 320,000.

webTitle: Cult plans a timely change of image

fields.headline: Cult plans a timely change of image
fields.standfirst: Japanese sect responsible for poison gas attack in Tokyo attempts to avoid government crackdown
fields.trailText: The Aum Shinrikyo cult is to dissolve itself and renounce its leader, Shoko Asahara, in an attempt to evade a crackdown by Japanese authorities.
fields.body:
The Aum Shinrikyo cult is to dissolve itself and renounce its leader, Shoko Asahara, in an attempt to evade a crackdown by Japanese authorities.

In a press conference scheduled for today, the apocalyptic cult, which killed 12 people in a poison gas attack on the Tokyo subway system in 1995, will attempt to break with its past by re-establishing itself under a new name.

According to Japanese media reports, senior members of the cult will claim that only a skeleton organisation dedicated to compensating the victims of Aum's crimes will remain. Followers are also expected to say that they are no longer under the influence of Mr Asahara, who is being tried for murder, gun-running and drug-trafficking.

But the apparent change of heart has already been dismissed as a stunt. The public security investigation agency, which monitors the cult, said the move is the latest ruse aimed at placating an increasingly hostile public.

Late last year, Aum made its first public apology for its misdeeds and gave 5 million yen (£29,000) to the bankruptcy lawyer representing the victims. The sudden display of penitence came just days before parliament enacted new legislation to restrict the cult.

Timing also explains the latest rebranding. On Thursday, the cult will have its last opportunity to argue against a new law which will allow the security agency to enter Aum premises without a warrant and to demand finance and membership reports.

The new law applies to any organisation or individual involved in indiscriminate mass murder over the past decade, and cult experts say it threatens the existence of Aum, which faces eviction and other penalties if it does not comply.

By changing its identity, Aum hopes to circumvent the law, but the odds are stacked against a repeat of its victory in 1997, when it avoided a ban by arguing that it was no longer a danger to society. Although Aum has not been charged with any crimes since then, the public security officials said it has re-emerged as a threat.

They said the growing revenues generated by the sect's two computer firms are fund ing recruitment campaigns and the purchase of properties, and that Aum shrines remain dedicated to Mr Asahara. It also says his 2,000 followers are still taught that killing is justified, a claim Aum denies.

Public opinion has swung sharply in favour of tougher action against Aum. There have been noisy protests outside the cult's buildings, which have forced followers to move from town to town. Local authorities have turned down members' residency applications by and politicians have joined in the denunciations.

These protests have increased since last month, when Aum's second-in-command, Fumihiro Joyu, was released from prison amid speculation that he will revive the cult. Instead, Joyu, who had been jailed for perjury and forgery in connection with Aum's activities, is said to be behind the decision to, at least superficially, break up the cult to ensure its survival.

Outside the Aum building in Yokohama where Joyu is staying, rightwing groups hold banners and shout slogans demanding that Aum leave the area. A new name is unlikely to make them disappear.

fields.headline: Finnish women battle for presidency
fields.trailText: One candidate has written about making love on a waterbed, another refuses to marry her live-in boyfriend, and a third is a former hard-drinking union boss.
fields.body:
One candidate has written about making love on a waterbed, another refuses to marry her live-in boyfriend, and a third is a former hard-drinking union boss.

Going to the polls yesterday to elect a new head of state, Finns had no shortage of colourful characters to choose from. But Finland's 4.2m voters seemed to be basing their decisions more on gender than on politics.

Four of the seven presidential hopefuls were female, and surveys have shown the country's women are determined to finally elect a female president after the former defence minister Elisabeth Rehn narrowly lost in 1994.

"It's really turned into a battle of the sexes," said Leena Krohn, president of the federation of women's organisations.

Finland was the first country in Europe where women got the vote (in 1906), is ahead of much of the rest of the continent in equal opportunities and pay for women, and boasts 74 women MPs in its 200-seat parliament. But Ms Krohn said the country still suffered from "rampant, old-fashioned male chauvinism".

With no real issues to discuss, campaigns have been decidedly lacklustre. Voters have been mainly drawn to rallies by the candidates' personalities.

webTitle: Pro-reform Iranian press in court over interview

fields.headline: Pro-reform Iranian press in court over interview
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Three of Iran's largest national newspapers were summoned to the press court yesterday for publishing on Saturday remarks by the country's leading dissident, Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, from an interview he gave to the Guardian last week.
fields.body:
Three of Iran's largest national newspapers were summoned to the press court yesterday for publishing on Saturday remarks by the country's leading dissident, Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, from an interview he gave to the Guardian last week.

Publishers from the dailies Fath, Asr-e Azadegan and Sobh-e Emrouz were interrogated behind closed doors, while a fourth newspaper, Azad, was named but no representative appeared before the court, which is a division of the judicial system with special reponsibility for the media. The publishers refused to comment in detail on the proceedings.

Lawyers in the case said they expected the papers to be indicted officially at a later date because there was confusion about the precise charges and the crime committed.

In Iranian law, there is no specific crime of publishing remarks given by dissidents. However, the newspaper Khordad was closed recently on similar grounds after its publisher, Abdollah Nouri, a protege of Ayatollah Montazeri, defended the cleric in court and demanded that his house arrest be lifted. Mr Nouri was tried for political and religious dissent and sentenced to five years in prison.

In the lengthy interview, conducted by fax, Ayatollah Montazeri, who has been under house arrest since November 1997, broke many taboos.

He accused the conservative establishment of distorting the spirit of the Islamic Revolution by giving too much power to Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and said the supreme leader should be elected by the people instead of being appointed by a handful of clerics.

Ayatollah Montazeri, who is considered one of the most learned theologians in Iran, also charged hardliners with holding a "monopoly" on political power by limiting the authority of the president, who is elected.

The interview, published on Thursday, has prompted a national scandal over Ayatollah Montazeri's call for civil liberties and freedom of expression. It was, therefore, ironic that the press court yesterday took the very action that Ayatollah Montazeri claimed was unconstitutional.

His comments that the supreme leader should be elected and not held above the law particularly struck a raw nerve with conservatives.

"We should ask Mr Montazeri if millions of people who are willing to pour into the streets in support of the supreme leader aren't a majority of this nation?" said the conservative newspaper Kayhan in an editorial.

Conservatives have tried to use the interview as an argument against the warming of relations between Iran and Great Britain. The interview was jointly conducted with Reuters news agency and, because both organisations are British, conservatives claimed it was timed to cast a black cloud over the visit of the Iranian foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, to Britain last week.

The visit was part of the full restoration of relations between the two countries, a process which began in September 1998. At that time, the Iranian government pledged not to carry out the fatwa against the British author, Salman Rushdie, for his novel The Satanic Verses. However, Iran's clergy says the fatwa is immutable.

"Should we disregard such provocations, which could go as far as overthrowing the system by a foreign government or collection of foreign 'mouthpieces'?" asked another conservative newspaper, Resalat, referring to Ayatollah Montazeri's interview.

In parliament yesterday, the conservative MP Hamid Reza Taraqi criticised Ayatollah Montazeri for giving the interview to a "colonialist" publication. Sources said the dissident was likely to be punished for granting the interview. There had been speculation that his house arrest could be lifted, but now that seems a remote possibility.

The Ayatollah's son, Ahmad, said by telephone from the family home in the holy Shi'ite city of Qom that his father had no regrets. "He feels that nothing worse can happen to him," Ahmad said.

webTitle: Doctor claims French prison inmates live in squalor

fields.headline: Doctor claims French prison inmates live in squalor
fields.trailText: The doors of Paris's infamous prison, La Santé, were opened to journalists this weekend after the jail's chief doctor said inmates lived in squalor.
fields.body:
The doors of Paris's infamous prison, La Santé, were opened to journalists this weekend after the jail's chief doctor said inmates lived in squalor.

In a book to be published this month and quoted at length in the media, Dr Veronique Vasseur claimed rats and cockroaches were commonplace, hygiene was non-existent, and brutal rapes and fist fights were daily occurrences.

La Santé, built in 1867, has 1,200 prisoners and includes a "VIP wing" that recently housed the former minister Bernard Tapie. Past inmates include the poets Paul Verlaine and Guillaume Apollinaire.

But despite many demands, only two visits by journalists have been permitted in recent years, according to Le Monde.

La Santé's director, Alain Jego, said the prison was "changing", but television cameras showed tiny cells, mouldy showers, and anti-suicide netting across corridors.

"The place remains an inhuman nightmare," Dr Vasseur said, "an eternal shame to France."

webTitle: EU to push for biological weapon inspections

fields.headline: EU to push for biological weapon inspections
fields.trailText: International efforts to outlaw biological weapons will enter a crucial stage today amid mounting pressure on the US to drop objections to effective verification measures.
fields.body:
International efforts to outlaw biological weapons will enter a crucial stage today amid mounting pressure on the US to drop objections to effective verification measures.

The EU and non-aligned countries are pushing for a tough treaty that would allow random inspections at a time when the rapid growth in biotechnology poses an increasing threat.

Biological weapons are cheap to manufacture (they are sometimes known as the poor man's nuclear bombs) and the quantities needed are much smaller than those needed in chemical warfare already covered by an international convention with an intrusive verification regime.

Though they are the easiest weapon of mass destruction to develop, treaties designed to prohibit the use of biological weapons are the weakest. The biological and toxin weapons convention, which came into force in 1975, includes no provision for verification.

The EU says it is essential for a new protocol to the convention - the subject of negotiations which start in Geneva today - to force states and companies to declare their production of biological and toxin agents and allow random inspections. EU governments agreed last November that the new protocol "must include provisions for rapid and effective investigations".

The US has paid little attention to the proposals, mainly, say European sources, because of objections by American biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries to on-site inspections. They claim they need protection for reasons of commercial confidentiality.

A US congress report noted that "some biological products are genetically manipulated to develop new commercial products, optimising production and ensuring the integrity of the product, making it difficult to distinguish between legitimate commercial activities and offensive military activities".

It added: "One bacterium strain can represent a large proportion of a company's investment in a pharmaceutical product and thus its potential loss during an arms control monitoring activity could be worth billions of dollars".

Independent US experts familiar with the negotiations say that privately the industry would be prepared to cooperate if forced to do so but is hiding behind the Clinton administration's apparent indifference.

Some European observers believe that Washington's lack of interest - despite its public concern about biological weapons in the hands of "rogue" states - reflects hostility to international treaties.

They point to the US senate's refusal last year to ratify the comprehensive test ban treaty, and its attempt to amend the anti-ballistic missile treaty signed by Washington and Moscow in 1972.

Stephen Pullinger, director of the British defence think tank Isis, said yesterday that the Geneva talks would be " a test of US commitment to an effective treaty-based non-proliferation regime".

Most of the 60,000 scientists previously involved in biological work in the former USSR, which armed some of its ballistic missiles with anthrax for use against western cities, are now unemployed.

Iraq, it says, had developed an extensive biological warfare programme, with 160 aircraft bombs and 25 missile warheads with biological agents discovered after the 1991 Gulf war. It was designing and developing missiles with ranges of up to 3,000km.

"There is an increasing reluctance to rule out nuclear retaliation to the use of biological weapons," says Isis. "An appreciation of the interconnectedness of all weapons of mass destruction means that unless we strengthen the prohibition of biological weapons we are unlikely to prevent further nuclear proliferation".

Biological weapons are cheap to manufacture (they are sometimes known as the poor man's nuclear bombs) and the quantities needed are much smaller than those needed in chemical warfare already covered by an international convention with an intrusive verification regime. The biological and toxin weapons convention, which came into force in 1975, includes no provision for verification. It added: "One bacterium strain can represent a large proportion of a company's investment in a pharmaceutical product and thus its potential loss during an arms control monitoring activity could be worth billions of dollars". webTitle: Gaultier looks to India for inspiration

fields.headline: Gaultier looks to India for inspiration
fields.trailText: Jean Paul Gaultier kicked off the second day of the Paris spring/summer 2000 couture shows yesterday with a collection that celebrated the Indian subcontinent.
fields.byline: Laura Craik, Fashion Editor, in Paris
fields.body:
Jean Paul Gaultier kicked off the second day of the Paris spring/summer 2000 couture shows yesterday with a collection that celebrated the Indian subcontinent.

On a catwalk strewn with flowers, the designer displayed a confident use of colour, texture and form with clothes that catered for every taste.

For the smart young miss about town, belted trenchcoats in beige and black had been restyled to include plunging backs and exaggerated epaulettes. For the belle of the ball, a full-skirted froth of gathered tulle in camouflage colours and matching bodices and gloves. And for anyone who could afford it, a sweeping snakeskin tabard dress worn with embroidered gold trousers.

Each outfit had a witty name. Thus, Goa Connection was a pair of faded jeans stitched through with crystals - in homage, perhaps, to the scruffy western travellers who make a beeline for that part of India. This was couture at its most relevant: it fused craftsmanship with modern aesthetics to create the perfect wardrobe for those with £10,000 to spare.

Alexander McQueen sent out one of his strongest collections to date for Givenchy. Largely mono in colour, it featured grey dogtooth check trouser suits, silver cashmere pencil suits and embroidered black lace sheath dresses.

There were plenty of McQueen-isms to give the collection a strong identity - cowl necks, low-slung hipster trousers and parchment bodices moulded like second skins - but they were tempered with sober cutting and tailoring and the effect was rarely gimmicky. Moth, rose and fern prints were in abundance, on blouses with trailing ties and on long chiffon evening wear.

Feathers were another feature. For those who criticised his last couture show for lacking movement (it was shown on perspex dummies), there was more than enough to compensate here, with swan, ostrich and emu feathers quivering gracefully in orbit around models.

Haute couture means strict rules and phenomenal prices

The five-day Paris couture schedule is less packed than the equivalent ready-to-wear, shown in Paris in March, because far fewer designers are invited to show.

Strict rules were implemented in 1945 to protect standards.

Today haute couture includes Chanel, Givenchy and Jean Paul Gaultier. There are six "membres invitees" and three "membres correspondants", including Valentino, Versace, and, for the first time this season, British milliner Philip Treacy. To be considered for inclusion, established houses must employ at least 20 people in their workshops, and newly created houses 10, and create at least 50 designs per show.

These are viewed by members of the press and by a select clientele of wealthy women, and their husbands, who can afford the prohibitive price of an item of couture. Because of the skill and labour-intensiveness involved, a garment can cost anything from £5,000 upwards.

webTitle: US 'kill vehicle' put to the test

fields.headline: US 'kill vehicle' put to the test
fields.standfirst: A reassessment of external threats has made Washington keen to develop new missiles and reluctant to give teeth to arms control treaties
fields.trailText: The United States military hopes to demonstrate this week that its anti-ballistic interceptor system is adept at downing missiles carrying nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, rather than at destroying decoy balloons.
fields.body:
The United States military hopes to demonstrate this week that its anti-ballistic interceptor system is adept at downing missiles carrying nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, rather than at destroying decoy balloons.

The latest tests are being conducted during a time of shifting perceptions about external threats to the US. The acting president of Russia, Vladimir Putin, last week lowered the threshold for using nuclear weapons; George W Bush, the leading Republican candidate for the presidency has warned of threats posed by China; and the US fears that North Korea might be able to reach its shores with a ballistic missile within 15 years, to say nothing of a "rogue attack" from a country such as Iraq.

But confidence in US interceptors designed to destroy ballistic warheads has been undermined by the disclosure that their previous performance was not the complete success it appeared to be three months ago.

While an interceptor did hit a mock warhead as planned, proving to the satisfaction of its supporters that the system worked, it turned out that this had happened only after the interceptor had drifted off course and homed in on a decoy balloon.

"What this says to me is, if that balloon hadn't been there, then they wouldn't have hit the target," said Tom Collina, director of the Arms Control and International Security Programme at the Union of Concerned Scientists. "They got lucky."

In a real attack, the number of decoys in space would be unlimited and the warheads would probably be more difficult to see.

"The only thing they demonstrated in this test is that if they can see the warhead, then they can home in with enough precision to hit it," said Theodore Postol, a professor of science, technology and national security policy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It had been a useful demonstration that "has very little to do with a real world defence", he said.

The interceptor is a 55kg "kill vehicle" launched on a rocket and steered with thrusters towards enemy missiles. It took off from Kwajalein Atoll in the Marshall Islands for the last test at the beginning of October, while the mock warhead and decoy were launched from Vandenburg Air Force Base in California.

The interception - reported as a UFO sighting - happened 140 miles above the Pacific and all was said to have gone well. But, in fact, an incorrect map had been loaded into the interceptor's computer so that it was unable to navigate by the stars and started to drift. However, it was still able to find the bright metallic decoy balloon and use that as a reference point to seek out and destroy the mock warhead.

Rick Lehner, a spokesman for the Ballistic Missile Defence Organisation, said: "I didn't know about it all, so obviously it wasn't of much concern at the programme office. It wasn't like they said: 'Oh my God, we had a malfunction'."

The Strategic Defence Initiative, under which the interceptor was created, was the brainchild of the Reagan administration. A year ago the defence department committed $6.6bn (£4bn) to developing the system during the next five years.

The Pentagon has until the summer to ascertain whether the system is ready to use and to present its findings to President Clinton. He is thought likely to leave a decision to the man who succeeds him in a year's time.

Mr Bush, favourite to be in that position, said recently: "At the earliest possible date, my administration will deploy anti-ballistic missile systems to guard America and our allies against attack and blackmail.

"I will work to persuade Russia that it is in both our nations' best interests to amend the anti-ballistic missile treaty to allow these defence systems to protect our people from rogue attack. If Russia refuses, we will withdraw from the treaty."

fields.headline: Cat's whiskers
fields.standfirst: The E-Type was everything a sports car should be: speedy, sleek and sexy. But since then, says  Jonathan Glancey, Jaguar hasn't come close. Until now perhaps . . .
fields.trailText: The E-Type was everything a sports car should be: speedy, sleek and sexy. But since then, says  Jonathan Glancey, Jaguar hasn't come close. Until now perhaps . . .
fields.body:
If you must have an E-Type Jaguar, there are several firms that re-manufacture these lithe, feline 60s sports cars. Most are a joy to drive as well as to look at. You get the catwalk looks - the sexiest car ever to take to the road - and an everyday driving machine that offers greater pleasure than 99% of current production sports cars. For the most part, these are too wide, too bulky and too complex to be as much fun as a lither, skittish E-Type. And very few contemporary sports cars have such a compelling see-me, touch-me, feel-me dashboard as an early E-Type, and only Ferraris, Alfas, Porsches and one or two others have such an inspiring engine and addictive exhaust note. Trouble is that, although you can get a decent original E-Type for less than £20,000, a specialist rebuild that will give a modern Jag a race for its money could set you back as much as £80,000. And this, for a Jag - a car traditionally built down to a cost - is pretty silly money.

Enter the F-Type, a prototype of a long-awaited successor to the E-Type. The shapely roadster you see here is very likely to make it into production and, if it does, to cost around £35,000. For that, Jaguar offers a car that promises to be eye-catching, rapid and closer in spirit to the great Coventry cats of the Le Mans winning days of the legendary C- and D-Types of the 50s than any since the original E-Type which went on sale, crudely under-developed, in 1961.

It does look good. It has most of the key elements that have made a Jag a Jag since William Lyons, founder of the company now owned by Ford, and his aerodynamicist, Malcolm Sayers, stamped their mark on saloon and sports cars alike: a high waistline, tall wheels tucked well up into swooping, voluptuous bodywork, pert, boat-like tails, aggressively curved front wings that appear to be pawing their way through the air with the grace, pace and muscularity of a big cat. The design of the cars has long meant to match the name of the marque. A Jaguar, if it's to be the real thing, must evoke the spirit of the great American predator that once sprung - until safety legislation culled it - from their bonnets. Jaguar has never needed to ape the forms of the past, but has used them instead as a kind of design resource or archive. The E-Type looked shockingly new 30 years ago, yet, if you looked closely, it was clearly spawned from Sayer's magnificent track-bound Spitfire, the 180mph D-Type.

Even more happily, Keith Helflet, the F-Type's designer, has suggested an interior - more of a cockpit really - free of the opulent, mirror-finish wood veneer and lumpen, funereal plastics that have spoiled so many Jaguars under Ford's ownership. Whilst Jag's trademark wood and leather interiors are part-and-parcel of its saloon cars (overblown in the competent yet grossly overstyled S-series saloon), they were never a feature of its sports cars - as they were never in such rivals as the fastest Aston-Martins and Ferraris.

The dashes of sporting Jags were elegant, aircraft-functional designs with big, clear white-on-black Smith's dials, elongated rows of black, plastic-coated toggle switches, black paint, leather-cloth and textured aluminium. Heflet's F-Type dash is not quite right - it looks a little fey and fiddly - yet it's imbued with the right feel. Hopefully, if (and most probably when) the car goes on sale, it will boast a more subtle and purposeful set of instruments and switchgear. The dashes of the big XJ8 coupe and roadster (wrongly hyped as E-Type replacements a few years back) are precisely what spoils these otherwise capable grand tourers. They have been designed to appeal to the US market, a sucker for acres of shiny wood and massive central consoles loaded with air-conditioning equipment, cup- holders capable of sustaining the ignominy of family-size beakers of Coke and stereo systems that would do for the QE2. In stripping this gross, radiogram-style furniture from the cockpit of the F-Type, Heflet is saying that this Jag is a real sports car.

The F-Type is just 5ft 8in wide, which means that in an age when some sports cars have been billowing to a size that makes them difficult to thread through city traffic or to skate along serpentine English B-roads any faster than a well-driven GTi-style hatchback, this car is designed for real speed. Yes, of course this is wilful talk in an country of flashing Gatso cameras and even Bigger Brothers to come - but a good sports car really can make a given journey, especially across country, fast and fun whilst sticking to legal limits.

Heflet says the car has been designed very much with women in mind. This makes sense. The E-Type was always popular with women and not because far too many people who should have known better said it resembled a giant phallus but because it was exceptionally good-looking and didn't require brawn to drive at a time when it was a real effort to heave most sports cars away from the curb. An E-Type never feels heavy.

Best of all, the car is all of a piece, a lovely bit of automotive jewellery that promises to threaten sales of the superb Porsche Boxster and the svelte Mercedes-Benz SLK. To Ford's credit the build-quality of Jaguars, a bad joke in the 70s and for far too much of the 80s, is now generally excellent. Scratch even a hallowed E-Type of the 60s and 70s and you'd find all sorts of bodged-together bits and dodgy parts; the F-Type will be a very different kettle of rivets. It is, of course, a toy - a glo rious toy - yet in an age when even Jaguar itself, designer and maker of some of the most charismatic and beautiful cars of all time (D-Type, E-Type, Mk2, XJ6 Series III) has managed to design some dogs (XK8, new S-series), it's high time that the Coventry cat was given back its claws. Those of the F-Type look very sharp.

fields.headline: Auto parts
fields.trailText: Quote of the week
fields.body:
Quote of the week

"Ford has built a hologram car for Tony's Dome but this won't give an accurate picture at all; in fact, it is the most useless invention I've ever heard of. What is the point of a car that doesn't exist? Sure, you could make it go into town but why, if you can't go with it?"
Jeremy Clarkson, Top Gear

Small is beautiful

A total of 48,723 new scooters joined Britain's roads in 1999, according to a survey by Peugeot - an increase of 76% over the previous year. They've become so trendy that they have now started to outsell superbikes.

Bubble in store

It has three wheels, one seat, does 70mph and is powered by 13 batteries - so environmentalists will like it. It's the American-made Sparrow (below), and 50 of them are due to land on our roads next month. The importer, Ecovec UK of Bakewell, Derbyshire, has arranged for green transport enthusiast Tony Benn to try one out. But you might need a little more persuasion - they cost £8,750 (but that does include a CD player).

fields.headline: Road test
fields.standfirst: BMW 3 Series Touring
fields.trailText: BMW 3 Series Touring
fields.body:
If you're one of the maladjusted few who have made it on to the waiting list for an Aibo, Sony's £1,600 robotic dog, you might be interested in something suitably New Century in which to take it for out-of-town walkies. In which case, you'll probably think BMW. Ever since they were awarded the 007 sales crest, the makers of the Bayerische Motoren-Werke have reinforced their authority as the führers of chic technology. You can now buy a BM mountain bike that looks like a brushed-aluminium preying mantis and, soon, a hard-topped moped that thinks it's a jet ski. The natural home of the battery-powered pooch, it appears, must be the back of a Beamer.

Or maybe not. Check the sales graphs for small estates and you'll note that while Audi has the perkiest pulse and Mercedes-Benz blips away contentedly, BMW has just slipped into a persistent vegetative state. Despite the fact that the Three Series saloon sells in such huge numbers that its closest rivals limp behind like milk floats, the Three Series Touring (a posh word for estate, meaning nothing more) has become a non-starter. The reason for this apparent blunder is, the maker says, that "the small estate market cannot be cracked without a credible diesel engine". A bit more tailgate room in which to swing a dog might also help. BMW's rethinking of the car purports to take both failings into consideration and the new model, currently in a showroom near you, is expected to sell 70% better than before.

Nice is a nice place to launch anything with wheels - kind winter temperatures and lots of jaunty, curved tarmac to test the tyres. What BMW didn't, however, anticipate for this event was snow. The snow ploughs got through just in time, but there was plenty of verglas on the higher slopes. The first tester, a 2.8 litre petrol, breezed through unruffled. This one sends more than enough power to the rear wheels but is, thankfully, never brash. It makes sporty, gruff noises, but, when required, is all poise and finesse. Very precise, very BMW. By comparison, the baby 1.9-litre option (badged the 318) works far harder to keep pace. It feels more zingy, which is hardly surprising because it has to puff more deeply to get over the hills. Nevertheless, it can manage more than 45mpg, is fairly civilised and falls comfortably on the right side of okay. All of which leaves the crunch car, the diesel. If this one is a duff, BMW knows it will severely hamper the new range's potential.

The engine is a four-cylinder turbo. It's not the new generation common-rail strain used by Rover in the 75 (interestingly, BMW's Touring developers thought the Rover-destined unit lacked power) but an older bit of kit. Mated to the Touring, the performance is more than adequate - the car will go to 60mph in under 10 seconds and can flex its torque band convincingly at high speed. Up in the Alps, the diesel felt as sporty as its petrol brothers, but the extra nose weight was evident on tight bends, where if felt more ponderous than the 328.

Later in the year, the 330d Touring SE, with a mighty three-litre diesel engine, will join the 3 Series ranks. This one is billed as a "serious, no-compromise performance car" and will be BMW's killer badge in the diesel estate league. If you want a discreet monster, this is the one to wait for.

Prices start at £22,095 for the 318 Touring; the 328 SE option is £28,995.

webTitle: Do I really need a lawyer to...

fields.headline: Do I really need a lawyer to...
fields.standfirst: ...start a small business?
fields.trailText: When you become your own boss, there are lots of difficult decisions to be taken. Should you be a sole trader, a partnership or a limited company? How do you raise finances? If you're renting premises, are the terms of the lease favourable? What terms should you spell out in contracts with people you do business with?
fields.body:
When you become your own boss, there are lots of difficult decisions to be taken. Should you be a sole trader, a partnership or a limited company? How do you raise finances? If you're renting premises, are the terms of the lease favourable? What terms should you spell out in contracts with people you do business with?

It's reassuring to have legal help when you're negotiating such daunting and unfamiliar territory. Unfortunately, it doesn't often come cheap.

The best plan is to do as much as you can yourself but consult a lawyer where it's necessary. Read as much as you can find on the subject. There are several good guides, including Patricia Clayton's Law for the Small Business (Kogan Page, £12.99); Jim Green's Starting Your Own Business (How To Books, £9.99); and the Which? Guide to Starting Your Own Small Business (Consumers' Association, £10.99).

The Desktop Lawyer website (www.desktoplawyer.com) has a useful section on business law, covering partnership, contracts, property and other areas. You can download your own documents for a charge and access lawyers' advice over the telephone. A similar website is at www.lawrights.co.uk.

There are also schemes which provide lawyers' help pro bono - free of charge - to young businesses in deprived areas, or to people who escape unemployment by setting up on their own. The Prince's Trust, for instance, has an arrangement with the national business law firm Dibb Lupton Alsop, to give help to start-up businesses in London and Manchester. The firm is about to start a mentoring scheme whereby lawyers specialising in the field the business operates in will as act as mentor to the would-be entrepreneur.

Business Links (Business Connect in Wales, Business Shop in Scotland) are partnerships between chambers of commerce, training and enterprise councils, local authorities, enterprise agencies and other bodies. They support new and existing small businesses by providing counselling, information, advice and business skills training.

Counsellors will advise on a range of problems from drawing up a business plan to finding premises. Check out www.businesslink.co.uk. A DTI publication, A Guide to Help for Small Firms, lists sources of help and advice on finance, exporting and starting a business.

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: Neil Ruddock
fields.trailText: Neil Ruddock
fields.body:
What are you driving?
A brand new blue Jaguar S type.

What does that say about you?
That I'm a family-orientated man - with a bit of power under the hood in case I don't want to be.

What do you like about it/ not like about it?
It's big, comfy and relaxing but it broke down after I'd had it for just a week. It was very embarrassing - it happened while I was having it cleaned in the middle of a photo shoot with the fans watching.

Why did you buy it?
I was drunk in Langan's with the lads and decided to pop into the car showroom over the road. I decided on the Jag because no one else in the club had one.

What kind of driver are you?
Relaxed. It doesn't bother me when people cut me up.

Any bad habits?
I'm on the phone a lot and always being told off by police.

What was your first car?
A white Fiesta XR2.

Have you ever got any speeding tickets or points?
No crashes - although a friend once borrowed my Porsche to impress a girl and wrote it off. He still owes me 63 grand.

What do you use your car for?
Taking the kids to school, going to work.

Have you ever experienced road rage?
My wife has. An off-duty policeman attacked her car, punching the windows while she had the kids in the back. We took it further and he was reprimanded. Luckily I wasn't there.

What sort of state is your car in?
I go through phases of keeping it clean although it's hard with the kids as they spill milk shakes and chips in the back.

What's in the boot/ glove compartment?
Golf clubs, CDs.

What music do you listen to on the road?
My favourite CDs for the car are Cliff Richard's Some People, Martine McCutcheon, Chas and Dave, Neil Diamond and George Michael.

Have you ever had sex in a car?
Of course I have. Before we had kids it was the only place we could do it.

What would be your dream car?
The Bentley Continental - the ultimate car for the ultimate sex.

Who would be your dream passenger?
The man from Camelot.

Neil Ruddock's autobiography, Hell Razor, is published by HarperCollins.

fields.headline: Full farce of the law
fields.standfirst: It was supposed to herald the end of the Law Society's fusty, white, male-dominated image. Instead, the arrival of Kamlesh Bahl has brought trouble of soap opera proportions.  Sally Weale reports
fields.trailText: Like all the best soap operas, the Law Society this week finds itself facing something of a cliff hanger. Ten years ago, this ancient and once august institution was as interesting as a sedate bridge night in Frinton. Today, submerged in a labyrinthine series of allegations and counter allegations of bullying and intimidation, the society has become the best show in town. And not for the first time.
fields.body:
Like all the best soap operas, the Law Society this week finds itself facing something of a cliff hanger. Ten years ago, this ancient and once august institution was as interesting as a sedate bridge night in Frinton. Today, submerged in a labyrinthine series of allegations and counter allegations of bullying and intimidation, the society has become the best show in town. And not for the first time.

The professional body that regulates and represents 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales might seem unpromising cabaret material, but in the space of a few turbulent years the Law Society has seen one of its official presidential candidates forced to stand down after being revealed as a groper, a massive surge in complaints about solicitors and the near-collapse of its procedures for handling the grievances, and an almost ceaseless tide of bitter in-fighting first unleashed in the time of one Martin Mears, a maverick who exploded on to the scene as president in 1995, and has never really gone away.

For the latest instalment of the saga at Chancery Lane we must look back to the summer of 1998. It was a heady time. Behind the neo-classical Ionic columns that guard the splendid headquarters of the Law Society there was a spirit of great optimism abroad. At last, it was about to banish its dusty, fusty, white, middle-aged-male image.

A woman was elected for the first time as one of the leaders of the massively male-dominated society - and not only that, she was an Asian. Kamlesh Bahl was, as one council member put it, "manna from heaven". She was a public relations dream come true. What's more, if all went according to plan, in July 2000 she would become the first woman, and the first from an ethnic minority, to become president of the society. Shortly before Christmas, the dream went sour. Two formal complaints were lodged against Bahl, alleging she had bullied one senior member of staff - head of policy Russell Wallman - and one ex-employee. The allegations, which are unprecedented at the Chancery Lane headquarters, were brought under the society's dignity at work policy introduced two years ago to provide redress for staff who feel they have suffered "harassment, bullying or victimisation" at work.

The full detail of the allegations has not been made public, but a retired law lord, Lord Griffiths, has been appointed to head an investigation into the affair which is due to start hearing evidence next month.

But it doesn't stop there. Following the two initial complaints, a number of further allegations of bullying or harassment were made to MSF - the trade union representing staff at the Law Society. And among those said to be have been unhappy at Bahl's behaviour is the Law Society's most senior bureaucrat, secretary general Jane Betts.

About 10 people provided further evidence to a committee set up within the Law Society to consider any other additional grievances from staff who were given until last Friday to come forward. It is due to report developments - behind closed doors, though it will inevitably leak - during the private session of the next full council meeting on Thursday.

Things would be bad enough if they stopped there - but true to the Law Society's spiralling soap-style storylines, it gets worse.

It emerged last week that Bahl, 43, has lodged her own formal complaint against - wait for it - the president, Robert Sayer. In a four-page letter from her lawyers, she accused him of "unfitting and inappropriate" conduct, alleging that he tried to make her leave the premises. Sayer, 47, had, the letter claimed, "threatened and intimidated" Bahl, who apparently brought her sister and her mother into the office to provide physical or moral support.

Bahl has stood her ground since, continuing to turn up to work in what must be extraordinarily strained circumstances and attracting the support of organisations including the Society of Black Lawyers, which argues she may be the victim of a campaign aimed at blocking her from becoming the first Asian woman president.

Bahl's enemies at the Law Society should not underestimate her. She is convinced she can persuade an independent arbiter she has behaved perfectly properly. After all, she was brought in as a new broom to change the way in which the Law Society operates - it was inevitable she would put a few noses out of joint. And she has proved she can weather tough times. As chairwoman of the Equal Opportunities Commission, she has already been at the centre of allegations of bullying, which she strenuously denies.

More than a dozen members of staff were unhappy about her management style - some, it was claimed, took time off sick with depression or stress-related illness.

The complaints were never proved. Employees requested redeployment rather than pursue their complaints - some left altogether, one took a secondment.

Her past may come back to haunt her. The Law Society's solicitors, Bindman and Partners, are understood to be seeking evidence on events at the EOC ready for Lord Griffiths' inquiry. Last week a former press officer at the EOC, who did not want to be named, recalled: "Kamlesh would come in - she never really had a grasp of etiquette or politeness, and she would single out members of staff and just start berating them, picking on aspects of their work, shouting at them in front of other members of staff".

Opinion among the membership of the 75-strong Law Society council is divided. "I've been in partnership in business, and an employer, and it's quite likely you could upset somebody and get one complaint. But two, three, four, five, six? From different places? It makes you think, doesn't it?" is one view.

One council member claimed to have seen Bahl treating staff inappropriately."I've seen her humiliating very senior staff members at the Law Society in public and in front of their junior colleagues. The woman has not got a clue about how to manage people. What I would like to see happening - whatever the outcome of the allegations - is that she stands down."

Another, former president Martin Mears, is more sceptical about the allegations: "I've known Kamlesh Bahl for the past five years. I've never seen her treat anyone offensively or rudely.

"My main complaint is all along, from beginning to end, decisions have been made which are prejudicial to her when she has not been given any opportunity to comment."

Mears, who was not exactly popular with staff during his own presidency and later fell out with his former vice-president, Sayer, is sending out a memo to all council members complaining about the procedures that have been adopted.

"To involve a retired law lord in domestic staff problems is absurd. It's terribly damaging to the Law Society and to Kamlesh Bahl."

"The whole thing is a pitiful spectacle," he elaborates in the latest New Law Journal. "A vice-president who, if she has behaved badly, could only have done so through the torpor or acquiescence of those around her; a secretary general, who, in relation to the Law Society's staff and its grievances, should have been in charge, but who instead has been swept along by the tide of events; a president who, in his general handling of the fiasco has made himself and the Law Society look ridiculous."

In contrast to his contempt for the society's role in the affair, Mears is full of admiration for Bahl. "She does not lose her self-possession, does not get upset. She's a woman of some calibre. Natural selection will ensure that she comes out on top," he says.

Entertaining as the slanging match is for those of us on the outside, it's a depressing spectacle for hard-pressed high street solicitors looking for proper support from their professional body. They don't want an organisation torn apart by political infighting, says council member Anthony Bogan.

"Most of the high-profile scraps that have taken place in Chancery Lane over the past 10 years are symptomatic of the wider problem of the Law Society which doesn't know what role it has in modern society. Is it a public regulatory body, protecting the public, or is it a professional trade union representing solicitors?"

The Lord Chancellor, Lord Irvine, might make the decision for them. Following last year's fiasco involving the society's complaints body, the Office for the Supervision of Solicitors, he took reserve powers to remove regulation of the profession from the society if it failed to improve its record.

But that's the stuff of future episodes. For now, EastEnders, Coronation Street, eat your hearts out. It's not over yet.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: It was eccentric to suggest (a note on page 24 of our Space supplement published in some areas, January 13) that Tsar Nicholas II visited Sir Arthur Sullivan's home in Walton on Thames "in 1918 before being assassinated". Nicholas and his family lived under arrest at Tsarkoye Selo from March to August 1917 when they were exiled to Tobolsk in western Siberia. They were later transferred to Yekaterinburg in the Urals where they were killed on July 16/17 1918.
fields.body:
It was eccentric to suggest (a note on page 24 of our Space supplement published in some areas, January 13) that Tsar Nicholas II visited Sir Arthur Sullivan's home in Walton on Thames "in 1918 before being assassinated". Nicholas and his family lived under arrest at Tsarkoye Selo from March to August 1917 when they were exiled to Tobolsk in western Siberia. They were later transferred to Yekaterinburg in the Urals where they were killed on July 16/17 1918.

We were wrong to say as we did on our front page, January 14, that Mike Tyson's fight against Julius Francis would be his "first outside America". On February 11 1990, Tyson fought James Buster Douglas in Tokyo and lost on a technical knockout.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Vote for Frank
fields.standfirst: A cabinet member begs Labour party supporters to shun Ken Livingstone, the prime minister's bette noireThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: I strongly support Frank Dobson for mayor. I have known Frank for years, politically and as a good friend. He is radical and egalitarian, with a big heart and a hard head. He would be a great mayor.
fields.body:
Labour party members in London will get their ballot papers for the candidate for mayor in two weeks. They then have a further two weeks to cast their vote.

I strongly support Frank Dobson for mayor. I have known Frank for years, politically and as a good friend. He is radical and egalitarian, with a big heart and a hard head. He would be a great mayor.

However, I fear that some party members, disgruntled by the imperfect process, the pressure and the spinning, will select Ken Livingstone as a protest vote. This would be a huge mistake for the party and for London. And it would play into the hands of the Tories, who would love Ken to be our candidate.

I urge all party members to focus on what really matters - the candidates' policies, their qualities and experience. It is not surprising that the media has focused on personalities and process. But it is disappointing that there has been so little discussion of what needs to be done in London to reduce poverty, solve transport problems and improve the quality of education and healthcare.

Frank has lived and worked in London all his life and brought up his family there. He knows the city, its strengths and its problems. He has been a tremendously hard-working, dedicated, popular London MP.

During our long years in opposition, Frank's energies were directed into helping make the Labour party electable so that we could offer Britain a government committed to social justice. We have to win elections to put our values into practice. Frank helped us win the 1997 election and to begin to restore the health service. He got rid of the internal market, won major financial support from the treasury and started to recruit new nurses and tempt back those who had left.

Party members should not forget that we won our landslide victory in London, as elsewhere, because Londoners wanted the policies Labour was promising - policies which we have since begun to put into practice. Policies which Frank drove forward as health secretary and as an active London MP. Londoners voted for a positive agenda of engagement with business, decent healthcare, better schools, reduced crime, better transport. Frank as mayor would work to deliver these for London to make it a better place to live and work.

Top of Frank's agenda is the fight against poverty. London is home to some of the richest people in Britain - and some of the poorest. Frank wants to reduce inequality and social exclusion.

Frank has five key pledges. He will appoint a medical officer of health for London, to reduce inequalities in health provision. He will give free bus passes to under-18s, to improve access to public transport. He will help tackle crime by introducing a named police officer for every Londoner. He will develop low-cost homes for nurses and teachers, to help recruit key workers. And he will work with the private sector to ensure that 80% of London homes have internet access, to improve leisure and education.

Some have accused Frank of being a stooge of No 10 in his bid to be mayor. That is completely false. Frank is no-one's stooge, as anyone who knows him knows very well. Frank alone made the decision to stand.

I rang him on the day he announced his candidacy. He told me how it had irritated him at first to keep reading in the press that he would be the candidate. But it made him and his family think about it. And at the Labour party conference he decided he would love to top his political career by becoming mayor and working to reduce poverty and inequality in our capital city.

I like Ken. He's a likable, cheeky chappy. Frank was right to insist that Ken be allowed to stand. Every party needs people who oppose and denounce and question what the government does. But that's not what we need in a mayor. We want a mayor who seriously wants to improve life for the people of London - not someone who will use the role to oppose government policy for the sake of it. Nor someone who will alienate business and promote their own foreign and national economic policies to try to show that they are better at economic policy than Gordon Brown.

Some people look back nostalgically on Ken's time at the GLC as halcyon days. This is a great exaggeration. The GLC was deeply unpopular until Margaret Thatcher set out to abolish it. Then, of course, when Thatcher wielded her axe, saving the GLC became a cause célèbre, with all Labour members and supporters rallying to its defence.

We should not forget how we let down our country in the days when too many in the party were focused on gesture politics. But now we should be looking to the future, not the past. A future where Londoners have a Labour mayor working for London of whom we can all be proud.

When ballot papers arrive on party members' doorsteps, I urge you all to choose the serious candidate. It will be a tragedy for London and the Labour party if members fail to support a man as kind and good and able as Frank.

Clare Short is secretary of state for international development

webTitle: Gent tears up Mannesmann trump card

fields.headline: Gent tears up Mannesmann trump card
fields.trailText: Vodafone's hostile £91bn bid for German telecoms group Mannesmann will this week turn into a battle royal between two sets of lawyers.
fields.body:
Vodafone's hostile £91bn bid for German telecoms group Mannesmann will this week turn into a battle royal between two sets of lawyers.

Mannesmann plans to publish the independent opinions of three leading German lawyers, "proving" its case that Vodafone will have to fork out up to 60bn euro (£37bn) in cash - money which it does not have - to compensate minority shareholders for the inevitable demerger of the mobile phone operator Orange if it wins.

But Chris Gent, Vodafone's combative chief executive, is already ridiculing Mannesmann's planned salvo as an attempt to to conceal its impending defeat.

"We would not have gone this far if we thought it was a problem," Mr Gent's advisers said last night.

The crux of Mannesmann's legal case is that Vodafone, in the event of victory, will be forced to sell Orange - acquired by its German prey for £19.5bn late last year.

But, its three German lawyers say, it will be almost impossible for Vodafone to put a real value, including likely synergies worth at least 1.2bn euros a year in profits and strategic losses, on Orange. It will be forced to enter a "domination agreement" instead.

This is triggered if Vodafone wins more than 50% of shareholders' votes - but less than 75% - for its bid. All minority shareholders, Mannesmann's lawyers argue, will then have to be offered cash to the same value as the paper offer - 54.7 shares for every one Mannesmann share - as compensation.

At Friday's closing prices, with both groups' shares 3% up after Mannesmann produced its official defence document in Düsseldorf, the Vodafone bid is worth 120bn euros - and the compensation could then be around 60bn euros.

With just three weeks to go to the closing date for Vodafone's offer, and Mr Gent and his rival, Klaus Esser, embarked on prolonged roadshows to woo investors in the US, UK and continental Europe, Mr Esser believes this legal backing will be his trump card.

He is even prepared to say that Mr Gent and his fellow directors could be sued by disgruntled Mannesmann shareholders if they refuse to enter into a domination agreement, putting the whole deal on ice if only one shareholder takes legal action.

But Vodafone insisted that the crux of Mannesmann's argument was invalid: its own top lawyers had given the company cast-iron advice that it had no need to enter into a domination agreement.

It said that, in the event of an Orange demerger, the minority shareholders in the new Vodafone Mannesmann group would be compensated with other assets. "A domination agreement is simply not going to happen," advisers said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Stress the big risk to business
Stress is likely to become the most dangerous emerging risk to business in the early part of the 21st century, a survey of the UK's leading risk managers has predicted.
fields.body:
Stress the big risk to business
Stress is likely to become the most dangerous emerging risk to business in the early part of the 21st century, a survey of the UK's leading risk managers has predicted.

Following the recent £210,000 pay out to the warden of a mobile-home site, the Association of Insurance and Risk Managers reckons that employee stress is the single main emerging risk for UK organisations and the third most important risk facing society as a whole after genetically modified organisms and e-commerce.

Airmic - whose prominence has increased following the recommendation that public company boards should issue annual statements of risks facing their business - said e-commerce was now the second most dangerous threat to business.

EMI sale talk
Germany's media group Bertelsmann is said to be considering the purchase of Sony Music or EMI, according to news magazine Der Spiegel - a putative move that the German group refused to confirm last night.
