fields.standfirst: Challenge the professionals
fields.trailText: Once again we invite amateurs to pit their wits against the professionals in our forecasting competition.
fields.body:
Once again we invite amateurs to pit their wits against the professionals in our forecasting competition.

Send in your estimates of the shape of the economy in 2000 and you could win £500 worth of book tokens from Macmillan, leading publisher of textbooks, academic and professional books, a magnum of champagne and the chance to have lunch with the Guardian's economics team.

We are looking for the most accurate forecast of key economic indicators: growth, interest rates, underlying inflation, unemployment, the current account and the exchange rate. Your forecast should contain six elements:

 Annual percentage growth in GDP in 2000;

 Bank base lending rate on December 31, 2000;

 Inflation, excluding mortgage repayments, December 2000;

 Total unemployed in December 2000 on the seasonally adjusted claimant count;

 The UK current account in 2000 (pounds, not % of GDP);

 Sterling's value against the euro on December 31, 2000. (how much one euro will buy).

You can score a maximum of 50 points for each question, giving 300 points for a perfectly correct entry.

 Answers, on the back of a postcard, to: Guardian Economics Competition, Economics Desk, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Don't forget to include your name and address and a daytime phone number. The usual Guardian competition rules apply and the deadline for entries is February 1.

Winners will be decided when the first estimate of 2000 GDP is available, in early 2001.

fields.headline: GTech is back with Camelot
fields.standfirst: Lottery operator says US firm's expertise counts for more than legacy of bribery case
fields.trailText: GTech, the controversial US gaming group, is back on board British operator Camelot's bid to renew its national lottery licence until 2008, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
GTech, the controversial US gaming group, is back on board British operator Camelot's bid to renew its national lottery licence until 2008, it was announced yesterday.

It is thought GTech's expertise as a software supplier outweighed any damage its presence might do to Camelot's application.

By re-engaging GTech, Camelot is underlining its determination to have its bid treated on its own merits as an operator of one of the world's biggest lotteries rather than on grounds of public relations or "image".

It is thought the consortium will demand judicial review of any adverse decision that ignores its achievements simply because of past embarrassments.

GTech, based in Rhode Island, was responsible for Camelot's darkest hour when, in 1998, a high court jury decided chairman Guy Snowden had tried to bribe entrepreneur Richard Branson not to make his Virgin group a bidder for the first lottery franchise in autumn 1994.

GTech sold its shares in Camelot and Mr Snowden resigned.

In the present bidding round GTech is not listed as a shareholder but it will be one of the main suppliers, alongside computer group Compaq and Scientific Games, the expert in "instant" lottery scratchcards.

Tim Holley, Camelot's chief executive, said: "We are extremely proud to be able to announce that GTech and Scientific Games have signed up to bid. They are both world leaders in their fields and their contribution will be crucial to continuing to run an efficient and successful lottery."

Camelot's shareholders are food and drinks group Cadbury-Schweppes, electronics group Racal and security printer De La Rue (with 26.7% each) and computer group ICL (with the balance). The Post Office will take a 20% stake should the bid be successful, and the existing shareholders will shrink their stakes to accommodate it.

That, however, might be unnecessary should the agreed £1.32bn bid for Racal from Thomson-CSF, France's electronics group, go ahead; under Camelot's charter a change in control of one shareholder permits the others first refusal on its stake.

GTech claims to have won 80% of all online lottery contracts worldwide since 1996.

The 1998 court case effectively asked jurors to arbitrate between Mr Snowden and the then Mr Branson, who claimed the former had tried to bribe him. Mr Branson had submitted his own bid to run the lottery on a non-profit basis, and Mr Snowden had apparently feared the Virgin chief's public popularity would win the day.

After Mr Branson's courtroom triumph, in which he won damages of £100,000, the Camelot consortium's remaining shareholders paid £51m for GTech's stake.

However, regulators ruled in April 1998 that GTech remained "fit and proper" to act as a supplier to the lottery operator, a ruling that will apply for the new licence, due to be awarded in June and to take effect from September 2001.

fields.headline: NatWest pioneers e-freight
fields.trailText: Trade in cargoes worth billions of dollars a year is moving on-line under a scheme announced yesterday by NatWest bank. Fraud and waste in shipping and air freight documentation will be reduced by the paperless system, the bank said.
fields.body:
Trade in cargoes worth billions of dollars a year is moving on-line under a scheme announced yesterday by NatWest bank. Fraud and waste in shipping and air freight documentation will be reduced by the paperless system, the bank said.

NatWest is a partner in the Bolero consortium, an international "club" set up in the autumn to put bills of lading, titles of ownership and other paperwork associated with the shipment of goods across international frontiers into "dematerialised" form.

Now it has become the first bank to offer trade in such documents to corporate customers who are not Bolero members.

With delays at foreign ports caused by faulty or missing paperwork capable of costing traders up to £60,000 a day, NatWest believes Bolero will catch on rapidly as the standard global online cargo data system.

Along with the insurance problems and other costs created by lost documents, international trade has been plagued in recent years by fraudulent cargo documentation that has fooled investors into buying "phantom" shipments of non-existent goods. Bolero, which is promoted as a secure data system, ought in time to eliminate many such frauds.

Bolero is jointly owned by the insurer TT, the Swift international money transmission system and a large number of other partners including banks, shipping lines, trading houses and shipbrokers.

Ultimately, NatWest and other banks hope to put on-line the whole range of cargo documentation including letters of credit and certificates of quality, eliminating delays and the potential for fraud.

NatWest's international trade director, Stephen Teal, said: "We understand the problems that businesses face when trading internationally - goods can arrive without key paperwork, resulting in time delays, additional costs and insurance problems."

Other banks are expected shortly to follow suit.

 Asda products will be on sale through interactive service television service Open from the summer - initially within the M25 area.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: The Observer
fields.body:
The Observer

German telecoms group Mannesmann is set to make up to £4bn through the flotation of 20% of its internet and e-commerce units. The money is likely to be used to buy into new internet services and for servicing debt, assuming that Britain's Vodafone fails in its hostile bid for the company. Vodafone's all-paper deal values Mannesmann at about £85bn.

The government is to step up pressure on privatised utility bosses to curb so-called "fat cat" pay deals. The utilities bill, to be published on Thursday, will require annual reports to spell out how remuneration packages are supposed to reflect specific consumer service standards and to make clear those cases where bosses have refused to make such a link.

Mail on Sunday

Granada is ready to wreck the agreed takeover of Chris Evans's Ginger Media Group by Scottish Media . The company might use its 18.5% stake in Scottish Media to block the £225m Evans deal. This in turn could trigger a hostile bid for Scottish Media.

Sainsbury is set to put its successful DIY offshoot, Homebase, up for sale as part of a plan to concentrate on its core grocery operations. The sale could raise £500m. Homebase has nearly a quarter of the £28bn home improvement market and its sale will be considered by incoming chief executive Sir Peter Davis.

Sunday Telegraph

Retail entrepreneur Philip Green has approached Asda chief Allan Leighton to join him in an £11bn bid for Marks & Spencer . Mr Green is assembling a high-powered team to mount the bid, including the finance director of a FTSE 100 company, the head of one of Britain's leading department store chains and a captain of industry who would become chairman.

St Gobain, the French building materials group, is poised to announce a cash bid for insulation and roofing company SIG in a deal that could value the company at more than £400m. St Gobain's top management has already held talks with SIG and a formal, agreed, bid is expected as early as this week.

Sunday Business

National Power is set for a boardroom shake-up with chief operating officer Graham Brown expected to leave later this year. Ross Sayers, chief executive of Hong Kong-based CLP Holdings, is expected to take over the UK side of the business, which is being demerged from the international operations in November.

Investment banking advisers to Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham are set to pick up fees of £200m if talks regarding a merger between the two parties are successful. The bulk of the fees will go to Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.

Sunday Times

BAE Systems - better known as British Aerospace - wants final assembly of Airbus's A3XX super-jumbo to take place in the US. The group is hoping to persuade its partners in the European consortium that American assembly will help overcome any resistance from US airlines.

Saatchi brothers Charles and Maurice are considering bringing an outside corporate partner into their advertising agency in a deal that could value the operation at up to £100m. They might sell up to 49% of M&C Saatchi to an international advertising group.

webTitle: She has a darkly erotic voice of strange beauty. But at the Opera House she's playing a bloke

fields.headline: She has a darkly erotic voice of strange beauty. But at the Opera House she's playing a bloke
fields.standfirst: Bulgarian mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova talks to Tim Ashley
fields.trailText: In a prismatic, white dressing- room in the backstage labyrinth of the Royal Opera House, the Bulgarian mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova - here to star in the forthcoming Clemenza di Tito - is talking about sex and singing.
fields.body:
In a prismatic, white dressing- room in the backstage labyrinth of the Royal Opera House, the Bulgarian mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova - here to star in the forthcoming Clemenza di Tito - is talking about sex and singing. I'd just asked her whether she'd ever sung Carmen. She shakes her head. Would she ever sing it? Well, maybe, perhaps, in time, if she found the right director. "The new generation of singers has to wait a while before the opera can be done differently," she adds. "Carmen is an emancipated woman. She's not a prostitute. She's an erotic woman who knows what she wants. Eroticism is something you must feel. It doesn't come from here," she went on, touching her abdomen, "or here" [she thrusts her breasts forward]. "It's got to be more -more - "

"Suggestive?" I essay.

"Yes," she says.

Suddenly she draws herself up and launches into the opening bars of the Habanera with the full-throttle, bosomy tone with which many singers of an earlier generation approached the role. "That's not right. It must be like this." Her eyes widening, she sings the same bit again, this time with the quintessential Kasarova sound - dark, restrained, sexual, somewhere between honey and molasses. The phrase slides down like some unearthly sonic caress.

Doing things differently, a flawless integration of technique and drama, and a tangible, though subtle, sexuality are very much part of Kasarova's style. I last heard her in Berlin, two years ago, as Charlotte in a semi-staged version of Massenet's Werther. Charlotte - who puts bourgeois values above passion and lives to regret it - is usually portrayed onstage as a prude. "That's not what's in the music," says Kasarova - and it wasn't in her performance, either. She swept on in a clingy, décolleté black number ("I was four months pregnant at the time,") and proceeded to chart, with unerring vocal and psychological accuracy, what she politely describes as "Charlotte's development from a girl into a woman."

It was one of those performances you just don't forget. Gone were all the usual insipid associations with burgeoning Romanticism (the opera, premiered in 1892, is based on Goethe's novel). In their place was something more contemporary, a being closer to a character from Ibsen or Zola - manipulative, teetering on the edge of neurosis, yet also vulnerable, tragic and intensely moving. As I watched Werther - played by the late Alfredo Kraus, whom Kasarova deeply admired - turn to jelly in front of this complex creature, the opera seemed suddenly to make perfect sense.

Kasarova's astounding allure has a Dietrich-like, androgynous quality, capable of transcending gender and orientation. She makes a credible bloke on stage. When she appeared as Rossini's Tancredi at Carnegie Hall, the critic of the New York Times swooningly compared her with Leonardo DiCaprio. Roles written initially for castrati, and "trouser roles", such as Mozart's Idamante and Bellini's Romeo, make up roughly half her repertoire. In New York, in October, she's going to add the lustily adolescent Octavian from Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier to the list. She likes playing chaps. "They get the best music, and it's harder to be a man than a woman," she remarked, giggling. "You can't be stereotypical, it can't be like this," and she flexes her arms in an attitude of Schwarzenegger-like masculinity.

She's back at Covent Garden after a seven-year absence to play her favourite man, Sesto, in Mozart's La Clemenza di Tito. The work's erotic and emotional dynamics are remarkable, and one wonders just what she will bring to them. Sesto is torn in two by his feelings for Tito, his friend and emperor, and the glamorously neurotic Vitellia, who wants Tito dead. In the opera's world, "love" is the word used to define relationships between men. What characterises the interaction between men and women is something altogether more driven and unnameable.

"Mozart understood people," says Kasarova. "He allows people to express feelings quietly. The surface is elegant, but underneath it's very dark. I like that." The production - "it's incredibly theatrical" - comes from Salzburg, which she regards as her musical home. In 1991 she caused a sensation there when she took over the role of Tancredi from Marilyn Horne at short notice. She brushes aside my remark that she became a star overnight. "I don't know whether it was a great success or not," she says. "I thought I was mad to do it."

Before that turning point, however, came years of hard graft. She was born in the central Bulgarian town of Stara Zagora, trained as a pianist before turning to singing, and left Bulgaria for the west in 1989. The rumours that shadow her, of a dramatic flight from an oppressive regime, seem unfounded. An invitation to Switzerland came from Zurich, where, for two years, she was part of the opera house ensemble. She admits that the communist sys tem encouraged her. "There are two worlds - there and here," she says, as if the old east were still very much a reality for her. "There, it was very intensive if you wanted to do sport or music. I had music lessons every day for five years. Here, it's different. There are singers who don't make it simply because they have no money." A look of sadness crosses her face.

As she talks, I realise that the rigorous discipline cultivated in those early years continues to drive her, and that this astonishing woman still, in some ways, regards herself as a student. "One should always learn," she said. "We singers [she uses those words a lot] can learn so much from other artists, learn from actors and cinema - but we must never copy. It's all a combination of acting, singing and your own personality. It's got to be part of you - and it's got to be natural. You must never pose. An audience will always notice if you pose. You need to build up a career carefully. It's always important to be part of an ensemble."

It was during her ensemble years in Zurich that Kasarova met her husband-to-be, Roger, who, along with their one-year-old son, Yves Lucien, is with her in London. Her face is radiant with pleasure and affection when I mention him. "Artists are always whingeing," she laughs. "Their partners have to put up with a lot. They need good nerves. I'm very lucky."

The candour and emotional frankness that characterise her singing spill into her words. Perhaps the most remarkable thing of all about Kasarova is the fact that, after years of being a star - and she's unquestionably that - she remains unaffected, unspoilt, modest and generous to her colleagues.

"Singers are all just different," she says. "You wouldn't want to hear the same singer all the time, would you?" Perhaps, if they were all like her, I would.

La Clemenza di Tito opens at the Royal Opera House on January 22. Box office: 0171-304 4000.

fields.headline: All stations lead to Rome
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey on the Italian architect who has given the Jubilee line extension a heroic sense of civic pride
fields.trailText: The stations of London's new Jubilee line extension are some of the most inspiring and imposing in the world. Practical, spacious and sometimes beautiful, these are public works to compare with those of the Romans at their best, with those of the medieval cathedral-builders, with the stupendously self-confident civil engineering of the Victorians.
fields.body:
The stations of London's new Jubilee line extension are some of the most inspiring and imposing in the world. Practical, spacious and sometimes beautiful, these are public works to compare with those of the Romans at their best, with those of the medieval cathedral-builders, with the stupendously self-confident civil engineering of the Victorians.

In these 11 heroic structures, constituted from hundreds of millions of tons of magnificently formed and crafted concrete, cast-iron, pressed-aluminium, brick, glass and stainless steel, you will find echoes of Trajan's market, of Piranesi, Brunel and Bazalgette - of the great structural engineers of the last century. We owe this civic magnificence and what appears to be a new-found faith in the public realm to a spirited team of engineers, contractors, builders and project managers, but mostly to Roland Romano Paoletti, the Italian architect who came to London from Hong Kong (where he had done much to shape the impressively efficient new metro) to lead the JLE design team - to be, in effect, both its chief architect and its client. This year, his decade-long project completed, Paoletti plans to return to Lucca, in Italy. His paternal family has lived there for at least 700 years; he is named Romano after a local church.

As a nation we have just honoured Paoletti with a CBE. But how can we realistically value the contribution of this cultured, deeply intelligent man who, despite near-overwhelming bureaucracy and all the dismal talk of privatisation and private finance initiatives, has steered through a public project of the very highest order? "It's an incredible achievement," says Richard Rogers. "You can get great things done in England, but the effort can be crippling. Roland is a very particular and special guy."

Born to an Italian father and Franco-Italian mother (with Hungarian blood in the mix somewhere) in the long-since demolished City of London hospital, Paoletti was evacuated to Scotland and then, in 1942, to Ireland. He recalls vividly his flight from Speke airport on board a smart Aer Lingus De Havilland Dragon bi-plane, watching the great ships he has always loved tied up in the city-side docks below.

In Ireland he was educated by Jesuits at Clonmel school, where the poet Gerard Manley Hopkins once taught. He trained as an architect in Manchester before coming to London to work for Basil Spence, architect of Coventry cathedral, on the design of the much-delayed British embassy in Rome. Two of the architects he was later to employ on the JLE, Michael Hopkins and Richard MacCormac, worked for Spence at that time. "We never met," says MacCormac. "I was a glorified tea-boy at the time, while Michael and Roland worked in separate buildings; Spence's was a large office with a big throughput of bright young things."

Paoletti left Spence's office, and England, in 1960, not to return in a professional capacity for 30 years. He went first to pursue post-graduate studies at the University of Venice. Here, he learned from such inspired and original architects as Carlo Scarpa, Ignacio Gardella, Giancarlo De Carlo and Ernesto Rogers, uncle of Lord Rogers of Riverside. At this time Le Corbusier was working on his final project, a city hospital for Venice. It was never built, yet its design came to haunt architects of Paoletti's generation.

"Le Corbusier came to the university to explain the scheme to us," Paoletti recalls. "What he showed us was not so much a building as a system of thought. The idea was for a hospital that was also a kind of sanitorium, like Thomas Mann's Magic Mountain. People might come to die here, but it would be in great dignity, with views of ships and with their bedrooms set above the purely mechanical working of the hospital."

Ever since, Paoletti has thought of architecture in terms of humane and civilising systems. What he wanted to learn was how to build, how to engineer as well as design, how to think through architecture and construction in the round. He was taken on by his hero, the engineer-architect Pierluigi Nervi. The sublime Canary Wharf JLE station, the result of much enjoyable discussion between Paoletti and David Nelson of Foster and Partners, is clearly a homage to Nervi, resembling his greatest work (airship hangars and sports stadia steeped in the spirit of Rome, yet making optimum use of new materials and technology) as seen through a lens that has been cut and polished in the 90s. Nervi sent Paoletti to Brazil, where he worked on the Italian embassy in Brasilia. This proved to be a long-delayed, frustrating project. In 1975, Hong Kong beckoned and, over 12 years, Paoletti designed no fewer than 37 brutally functional, faultless stations and three depots.

Here was "systems architecture" on a city-wide scale. It worked with peerless efficiency and was his passport to the JLE, via Wilfred Newton, chief accountant of the Hong Kong Mass Transit Authority, who was appointed chairman of the ailing London Transport in 1990. Putting together his own JLE team, Paoletti brought in some of the best British architects from outside London Transport, and was able to draw up 11 sets of working drawings and tenders within three years. He locked these into binding contracts, so that by the time John Major gave the project the go-ahead in October 1993, the heroic scale of the stations was inviolate. But he had to fight every inch of the way between Westminster and Stratford. "I had to go down on my knees and beg the architects to design a station for me," he says. "They were suspicious."

"In hindsight, it sounds like dreadful behaviour," says Richard MacCormac of MacCormac Jamie son Prichard, architects of the magical Southwark station, "but we were used to a London Underground run on the design side by pretty insensitive engineers who appeared to think architects were there to add some coloured tiles to their tunnels - what Norman Foster once called 'putting lipstick on the face of a gorilla'. Roland convinced us otherwise."

In fact, the architects came to produce some of their finest work, with Paoletti as client and collaborator. Michael Hopkins's ugly Portcullis House ("In my opinion, self-indulgent," says Paoletti) in Westminster is redeemed by the magnificence of the pure-engineering- style station he has threaded through its complex foundations ("A balance," suggests Paoletti, "as happy as that achieved at St Pancras by the architect Gilbert Scott and the engineer Barlow").

Paoletti's own Jubilee line stations, Waterloo and London Bridge (with Weston Williamson), are handsome arrangements of grand passageways and undercrofts. These are no skulk-ing, urine-reeking alleys, but the internal streets of nobly engineered Roman markets revisited in what is, below the surface and to Paoletti's constant delight, Roman London. "There can have been few occasions," says Andrew Saint, professor of architecture at Cambridge University, "when London has seen so many aspiring works of architecture on the same theme opening simultaneously. A parallel with the City churches built after the Great Fire is not out of place. History will judge, yet Paoletti's contribution, among others, is considerable. Perhaps the JLE achievement would have been impossible without such an inspired outsider working on t."

"Paoletti is an inspirational figure," says Richard Burdett, head of the London School of Economic's city- engineering programme. "The students here adored him when he came to teach. You can see there's nothing he likes better than engaging young people in complex ideas that bring together in a holistic way the arts and sciences of civil and structural engineering, architecture, design, history and the shaping of truly dignified public spaces."

Paoletti, a JLE passenger while he works at Canary Wharf, lives down the line in a house designed by Richard MacCormac overlooking the Thames. Until Lucca calls, his monument, at £1.50 a shot, is all around and underneath him.

Ever since, Paoletti has thought of architecture in terms of humane and civilising systems. What he wanted to learn was how to build, how to engineer as well as design, how to think through architecture and construction in the round. He was taken on by his hero, the engineer-architect Pierluigi Nervi. The sublime Canary Wharf JLE station, the result of much enjoyable discussion between Paoletti and David Nelson of Foster and Partners, is clearly a homage to Nervi, resembling his greatest work (airship hangars and sports stadia steeped in the spirit of Rome, yet making optimum use of new materials and technology) as seen through a lens that has been cut and polished in the 90s. Nervi sent Paoletti to Brazil, where he worked on the Italian embassy in Brasilia. This proved to be a long-delayed, frustrating project. In 1975, Hong Kong beckoned and, over 12 years, Paoletti designed no fewer than 37 brutally functional, faultless stations and three depots. Here was "systems architecture" on a city-wide scale. It worked with peerless efficiency and was his passport to the JLE, via Wilfred Newton, chief accountant of the Hong Kong Mass Transit Authority, who was appointed chairman of the ailing London Transport in 1990. Putting together his own JLE team, Paoletti brought in some of the best British architects from outside London Transport, and was able to draw up 11 sets of working drawings and tenders within three years. He locked these into binding contracts, so that by the time John Major gave the project the go-ahead in October 1993, the heroic scale of the stations was inviolate. But he had to fight every inch of the way between Westminster and Stratford. "I had to go down on my knees and beg the architects to design a station for me," he says. "They were suspicious." "In hindsight, it sounds like dreadful behaviour," says Richard MacCormac of MacCormac Jamie son Prichard, architects of the magical Southwark station, "but we were used to a London Underground run on the design side by pretty insensitive engineers who appeared to think architects were there to add some coloured tiles to their tunnels - what Norman Foster once called 'putting lipstick on the face of a gorilla'. Roland convinced us otherwise." In fact, the architects came to produce some of their finest work, with Paoletti as client and collaborator. Michael Hopkins's ugly Portcullis House ("In my opinion, self-indulgent," says Paoletti) in Westminster is redeemed by the magnificence of the pure-engineering- style station he has threaded through its complex foundations ("A balance," suggests Paoletti, "as happy as that achieved at St Pancras by the architect Gilbert Scott and the engineer Barlow"). Paoletti's own Jubilee line stations, Waterloo and London Bridge (with Weston Williamson), are handsome arrangements of grand passageways and undercrofts. These are no skulk-ing, urine-reeking alleys, but the internal streets of nobly engineered Roman markets revisited in what is, below the surface and to Paoletti's constant delight, Roman London. "There can have been few occasions," says Andrew Saint, professor of architecture at Cambridge University, "when London has seen so many aspiring works of architecture on the same theme opening simultaneously. A parallel with the City churches built after the Great Fire is not out of place. History will judge, yet Paoletti's contribution, among others, is considerable. Perhaps the JLE achievement would have been impossible without such an inspired outsider working on t." "Paoletti is an inspirational figure," says Richard Burdett, head of the London School of Economic's city- engineering programme. "The students here adored him when he came to teach. You can see there's nothing he likes better than engaging young people in complex ideas that bring together in a holistic way the arts and sciences of civil and structural engineering, architecture, design, history and the shaping of truly dignified public spaces." Paoletti, a JLE passenger while he works at Canary Wharf, lives down the line in a house designed by Richard MacCormac overlooking the Thames. Until Lucca calls, his monument, at £1.50 a shot, is all around and underneath him.

fields.headline: Lottery of life and death
fields.trailText: Last week a murderer was executed in the Bahamas. Two should have been hanged, but the other one had killed himself in his cell a couple of days before
fields.body:
Last week a murderer was executed in the Bahamas. Two should have been hanged, but the other one had killed himself in his cell a couple of days before. The executions were a speedy response to a decision of the Privy Council in London - by a majority of three judges to two - that there were no grounds to halt them. The majority judgment was given by Lord Hoffmann (who had also been in a 3-2 majority in another death penalty case a few months ago, with the same terminal result). I do not think I have ever read such dramatically opposed judgments. The minority judges - the former South African Lord Steyn and the New Zealander Lord Cooke - vividly expressed their opinions that the men had been subjected to years of inhuman and degrading treatment in prison, enough to justify not hanging them. Steyn and Cooke seemed scarcely able to believe that the three other judges could in effect sanction the executions. This polarisation of views demonstrates yet again my point that it is unjust and unacceptable that people's lives should depend on a 3-2 decision. One judge different and it could have been 3-2 the other way. It's a virtual lottery who happens to be picked for a particular case. Yes, I know that this is so for almost all appeals, but where people's lives are at stake, it should be different. At the very least, if the Privy Council continues to interpret the constitutions of countries who wish to kill people, decisions to give the go-ahead for executions should be unanimous.

The point about a catchphrase is that, if you want it to become popular, you've got to use it all the time. So it was disappointing that the Home Secretary announced his sensible decision to allow the pugilist Tyson into Britain without saying that he was "minded" to do so. He used the phrase so effectively in the case of Konrad Kalejs (minded to order his deportation) and, last week, when minded to send a former Chilean dictator home. It's an old legal format which, in theory, means: "That's what I think now, but, as a reasonable man, I am persuadable otherwise." In fact, it means: "I have absolutely made up my mind, and nothing can change it, but I have to go through the motions" (to avoid a judicial review). Strictly speaking, "minded" wouldn't have been appropriate in the Tyson case, but catchphrases don't always have to be accurate, merely repeated.

David Irving's case is not the first time Auschwitz has entered an English libel courtroom. In 1964, a jury listened to some of the most shocking evidence ever given in an English trial, much of it by concentration camp survivors. The claim was over one sentence in Leon Uris's novel Exodus: "Here in Block X, Dr Dehring performed 17,000 'experiments' in surgery without anaesthetic." Dering, who'd become a respectable London GP without the "h", sued Uris and the publishers, whose defence was that the allegations were largely true. Dering admitted that he had been a doctor at Auschwitz, but as a Polish prisoner; yes, he had conducted operations removing the testicles and ovaries of Jewish men and women - not 17,000 but around 130 - but he had been forced to do so. Also, because he performed them skilfully, he argued, he saved the victims from a worse fate, crude butcher-surgery. The jury decided that he'd been defamed, but awarded him "contemptuous" damages, the "smallest coin in the realm", a halfpenny.

fields.headline: In praise of men . . .
fields.standfirst: So much for the future of a more feminine management structure. Secretaries prefer to work for a man, discovers  Finola Lynch
fields.trailText: How do you like your boss? Sympathetic, empowering and not too busy, probably. They will be aware of the pressures of your job, but delegate responsibility where appropriate. They will be interested in your career development. Oh, and, preferably, they will be male.
fields.body:
How do you like your boss? Sympathetic, empowering and not too busy, probably. They will be aware of the pressures of your job, but delegate responsibility where appropriate. They will be interested in your career development. Oh, and, preferably, they will be male.

In a survey for Royal Mail special delivery, a quarter of secretaries polled expressed a preference for a male boss. Only 7% said they would prefer a woman. The future of management may be female, but Ms High-Flier, it seems, can expect little support from her secretary.

One should not, of course, assume that all secretaries are female, but women still make up the overwhelming majority. So it makes uncomfortable reading for those who like to believe that a soft and cuddly sisterhood exists in the previously macho office environment, where women look out for their own. The findings also raise questions about neat predictions of a feminised future for management, where "womanly" traits such as listening skills, flexibility and a more empathetic manner will become normal office currency.

Business psychologist John Nicholson is surprised by the survey's findings, asserting that "the qualities valued today in a successful boss are feminine, not masculine". He is emphatic that women make better bosses. "They listen more, are less status-conscious, conduct crisper meetings, are much more effective negotiators and display greater flexibility."

They are also considerably more common than they used to be. According to information group Experian, women are no longer scarce in the boardroom - they occupy a third of the seats round the conference table. Women directors are still relatively uncommon in older age groups, but among young directors the proportion is growing.

So why the unsisterly response from support staff? Are we really to come to the depressing conclusion that modern secretaries are closet Miss Moneypennys, pining for the "good old days" when a boss was male, charmingly dominant and ever so sexist?

Anecdotal evidence suggests that a reluctance to work for a woman may be more a question of management style than substance. "It's just women bosses' attitude," says Martha, a PA for 25 years who has worked predominantly for women, including a high-profile politician. "It's something women have that men don't. When they are snippy they are much more personal, whereas men sail through not taking a blind bit of notice."

Sonia Neill, a former secretary at Marks and Spencer, has experienced power struggles between women even where there was a significant disparity in status. "Women either find it awkward to give you work or they try to assert themselves by giving you really menial tasks. Men never do that."

Her particular bugbear is secretaries who have moved up the ladder. "You expect them to be more sympathetic because they know what it's like being at the bottom, but instead they seem desperate to prove a point."

The experience of Marilyn Davidson, professor of managerial psychology at the school of management at University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, is that women bosses are acutely aware of the affect they can have on female support staff. "A lot of female bosses feel they have to woo their secretaries. They are treading on eggshells and have to put an extra effort into getting their women secretaries on their side. Men don't have to do this because it is automatically clear what the roles are."

Davidson suggests traditional assumptions on gender and status are more tenacious than we might like to think. "I interview women in managerial positions who've advertised for secretaries and when the secretary realises their boss is female they have walked out."

Women managers and support staff have clearly come a long way over the past few decades. But perhaps the greatest problem is the assumption that women should, by virtue of their gender alone, be more empathetic managers. Maybe we just expect our female bosses to be better than their male colleagues - and when they are not, we bitch.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: •Easy peasy
fields.body:
Easy peasy

Repetitive strain injury is the fastest growing industrial health problem in the UK, and a particular risk for those who do a lot of typing. But splints to support damaged wrists have traditionally been uncomfortable, unattractive and hot. Wristeasy is a new product created by designer Sebastian Conran with occupational therapists from the Hammersmith hospital. Made in cotton and Lycra and fully machine washable, the manufacturers claim it can be worn comfortably for five times longer than conventional splints. For more info call 0870 120 7408 or visit www.wristeasy.com

Temps thrive on flu

The post-Christmas period normally sees a lull in recruitment activity, but this year it has been busier than ever, with temps in great demand to cover for staff off sick with flu. Agencies have been working hard to fill gaps in a UK workforce decimated by the bug and, according to recruitment agency Blue Arrow, many employers have been caught out by the severity of the outbreak. "Businesses had contingency arrangements for the millennium bug, but surprisingly few had planned for an occasion when up to 20% of their workforce fail to turn up because of illness," says communications director Charles Walker.

Coaching classes

If you supervise junior staff members, you not only need to motivate and instruct them, you also need to coach them. That's according to the author of a new book which aims to explain how this essential staff management tool works. Coaching People outlines the skills needed to coach others successfully, and highlights the benefits to both parties when all goes well. Author Dr Rob Yeung believes that coaching is all about empowering and inspiring people, and that it represents a tremendous way to get the best out of people. Copies are available from Plymbridge Distributors on 01752 202301.

 Glaring errors

Do your eyes feel tired after a day spent peering at your computer screen? One of the causes could be glare from overhead lighting and sunlight, reflecting off the surface of your monitor. This not only makes your documents more difficult to read, but it can lead to eyestrain and headaches. According to 3M, this eye fatigue can be eased by using an anti-glare filter, which also help to reduce static on your screen. Itsanti-glare filters have just been endorsed by the American Chiropractic Association as an important feature of an ergonomically correct work- station. For more details call 3M Customer Services on 01234 229470.

Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: Go-getting graduates
fields.standfirst: Graduate secretaries are more in demand than ever, and employers are finally recognising the extra skills they can bring to the job.  Hilary Whitney  reports
fields.trailText: Louise Moore was a fresh graduate from Cambridge when she began working as a secretary at publisher Michael Joseph. Now publisher for fiction, she is glad of the experience she gained as a secretary. "Today there are several graduate schemes in publishing, but when I began my career a secretarial post was one of the only ways to learn about the editorial side of publishing."
fields.body:
Louise Moore was a fresh graduate from Cambridge when she began working as a secretary at publisher Michael Joseph. Now publisher for fiction, she is glad of the experience she gained as a secretary. "Today there are several graduate schemes in publishing, but when I began my career a secretarial post was one of the only ways to learn about the editorial side of publishing."

Secretarial work has for many years been one way for talented graduates to enter attractive but highly competitive fields such as publishing or television. "It has always been a very effective way to start a career in the media," says Jacqueline Schaebbicke from Judy Fisher Associates.

But with the recent boom in higher education, more graduates than ever are appearing on the job market, and increasing numbers are finding careers within the traditional support sector. A new survey by employment agency Gordon Yates and the Guardian found that those secretaries with degrees spend a significantly higher proportion of their time in "managerial" duties and tasks requiring languages. While the industry average for time spent in traditional support duties is about 50%, graduates spend only a third of their day doing basic secretarial tasks such as typing and filing.

Victoria Wall of Victoria Wall Associates is acutely aware of the growing popularity of graduate secretaries. Almost three-quarters of the candidates her company places are graduates, 40% of whom will be in City-based jobs such as investment banks, sales, insurance, trad ing or financial PR companies. "These are intelligent, highly motivated people with excellent business acumen. As graduates they will have invaluable research and analytical skills. They will have a huge amount of client contact and will know their industry inside out."

Graduates are not only in demand in the more traditional industries, however. The fastest growing demand for graduate secretaries is in the new media sector, says Wall. "Internet and telecommunications businesses cannot afford to waste time and therefore are seeking young graduates with good secretarial skills who can think for themselves; who are proactive rather then reactive and who can cope with steep learning curves." She has found that graduates have a proven learning ability and so tend to take less time to learn the business and the job they are doing.

"A week in an internet business can be a year in another company and they therefore seek young, energetic graduates who want to work hard and are willing to put in the hours. They will progress quickly as they inevitably end up developing their roles within a very unbureaucratic environment."

Now making up a quarter of the admin and support sector, graduate secretaries have had a significant influence on the marketplace. And their presence has brought benefits to all talented support staff, not just those with degrees, says Richard Grace, managing director of Gordon Yates.

"The increasing provenance of graduates exemplifies the fact that the role is changing. There is more room for initiative and proactivity," he says. "You don't have to be a graduate, however. For people with that extra bit of talent and get-up-and-go, the door is wide open."

fields.headline: Come together
fields.standfirst: If you're struggling with a difficult boss and lack of recognition, try speaking with like-minded colleagues.  Helen Mulholland  reports on secretarial networks
fields.trailText: Networking was one of the buzzwords of the 1990s, as people increasingly realised that who you know can have an impact on your career. But there is more to networking than trying to meet important people at parties; other secretaries and support staff are useful contacts as well. They may not necessarily be able to get you a better job, but sharing expertise or discussing common frustrations can be extremely encouraging in realising you are not the only PA to struggle with a difficult boss and a lack of recognition. In an industry not known in general for mobilising on professional grounds, the signs are that workers within the secretarial sector are increasingly getting together.
fields.body:
Networking was one of the buzzwords of the 1990s, as people increasingly realised that who you know can have an impact on your career. But there is more to networking than trying to meet important people at parties; other secretaries and support staff are useful contacts as well. They may not necessarily be able to get you a better job, but sharing expertise or discussing common frustrations can be extremely encouraging in realising you are not the only PA to struggle with a difficult boss and a lack of recognition. In an industry not known in general for mobilising on professional grounds, the signs are that workers within the secretarial sector are increasingly getting together.

Marjory Mair is head of secretarial and administrative development at the Industrial Society. She actively encourages secretaries and PAs to share expertise, seeing it as a vital coping skill: "The job is getting tougher, there are higher expectations with more demanded of PAs then ever before. Keeping up with technology can be a challenge and the whole thing about knowledge sharing is something which is a must in order to stay ahead."

Secretarial networking has in the past been limited largely to a few pro fessional associations. Their membership base is usually defined by subject area or level of qualified expertise, and they can be extremely selective about who is admitted to their circle.

With a membership of 3,000 and 13 regional branches, the Institute of Qualified Private Secretaries (IQPS) is the largest professional body for secretaries, PAs and general administrators. Membership is through invitation, and based on a high level of qualification or lengthy senior experience.

Cynthia Desmond has been a member for nearly 20 years: "It gives you backup and the companionship of like-minded people. We are able to contact each other to find out about things; if it's something you don't know, somebody else in the organisation will." Other professional bodies, for workers in specialised sectors such as the medical, pharmaceutical and agricultural industries, fulfil the same role.

But other networking initiatives are on the increase. PA Exchange is the brainchild of Susan Bollond, PA to the chief executive of the Edinburgh international conference centre. "I set it up to be more informal and accessible," says Bollond. "We probably meet about three times a year, getting to know each other." With one eye still kept firmly on business, Bollond organises visits to top venues so that members can select the appropriate ones when organising their employers' corporate events.

Important as these large-scale initiatives are, getting together with colleagues within your company specifically to discuss shared work concerns can be enormously encouraging for support staff - and can get results. The internet company Nortel is a good example. When its annual survey registered strong dissatisfaction among secretarial and support staff, the managing director got the company's secretaries together. Their main gripe was lack of entitlement to private medical insurance which was available to the rest of the company, and a feeling that they were not being recognised as part of the team. Shortly after, they evolved into a network called the "Hub".

Kim Taylor is Hub's chair. "We have quarterly meetings for members to get together and we provide training that helps support staff to develop," she says. "It's especially good for new people in the company, who can find out what they need to know. I have developed myself, not only my career." fields.bodyText: Networking was one of the buzzwords of the 1990s, as people increasingly realised that who you know can have an impact on your career. But there is more to networking than trying to meet important people at parties; other secretaries and support staff are useful contacts as well. They may not necessarily be able to get you a better job, but sharing expertise or discussing common frustrations can be extremely encouraging in realising you are not the only PA to struggle with a difficult boss and a lack of recognition. In an industry not known in general for mobilising on professional grounds, the signs are that workers within the secretarial sector are increasingly getting together. Marjory Mair is head of secretarial and administrative development at the Industrial Society. She actively encourages secretaries and PAs to share expertise, seeing it as a vital coping skill: "The job is getting tougher, there are higher expectations with more demanded of PAs then ever before. Keeping up with technology can be a challenge and the whole thing about knowledge sharing is something which is a must in order to stay ahead." Secretarial networking has in the past been limited largely to a few pro fessional associations. Their membership base is usually defined by subject area or level of qualified expertise, and they can be extremely selective about who is admitted to their circle. webTitle: Call for Euroland heavyweight to square up to US

fields.headline: Call for Euroland heavyweight to square up to US
fields.standfirst:
Think-tank urges one voice

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: America will continue to dominate the global financial game by default unless European governments swallow national pride and appoint a single heavyweight representative to speak on behalf of the euro zone, says a pamphlet published today by a pro-European think-tank.
fields.body:
America will continue to dominate the global financial game by default unless European governments swallow national pride and appoint a single heavyweight representative to speak on behalf of the euro zone, says a pamphlet published today by a pro-European think-tank.

The pamphlet, by Steven Everts of the centre for European reform, argues that the creation of the euro has the potential to transform the existing dollar-centred global financial system, replacing it in the next decade with a bipolar dollar-euro world order.

But he says the Americans will only take European views seriously if European governments speak with one voice. He proposes the appointment of a financial supremo, a Mr Euroland, to lend greater strength and credibility to European positions in financial diplomacy.

He says that EMU members should also pool their seats at the IMF to make way for a single representative.

Mr Everts says Mr or Ms Euroland should be an authoritative spokesman for the euro zone, chosen unanimously by the finance ministers and based in the council of ministers secretariat in Brussels. He or she should be given a mandate to negotiate international financial and monetary agreements with, for instance, the US treasury secretary or the IMF managing director. The finance ministers of the euro zone would then quickly ratify (or reject) these agreements.

At the moment arrangements for European representation at international financial meetings, such as Group of Seven summits, are cumbersome and confused, with responsibility split between the finance ministers of Italy, Germany, France and the rotating European Union presidency and the European commissioner in charge of monetary affairs.

Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, and the central bank governors from euro zone governments also have a role.

"Clearly this unwieldy arrangement is unsustainable. There are still too many Europeans present to be a match for the nimble and effective US double act of Larry Summers (US treasury secretary) and the Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan," says Mr Everts.

 The impact of the euro on transatlantic relations. Steven Everts, Centre for European Reform, 29 Tufton Street, London SW1P 3QL

webTitle: In cyberspace, everyone can hear you scream

fields.headline: In cyberspace, everyone can hear you scream
fields.standfirst: From your state of mind to your shoe size, office gadgets in the 21st Century will have the capacity to reveal all manner of information about employeesbut will they have us all heading for early retirement?
fields.trailText: From your state of mind to your shoe size, office gadgets in the 21st Century will have the capacity to reveal all manner of information about employeesbut will they have us all heading for early retirement?
fields.body:
Hands up all those who were captivated by news this week that boffins in the US have invented the emotional mouse, which can detect your state of mind at work and get your PC to respond accordingly; slowing down when you're tired or playing games when you are bored.

It might seem churlish to slag off such gadgets before first sampling their delights, but surely only a screaming idiot would want an emotional health check every time they went online? Aren't your feelings the last thing you want your boss, colleagues and token office perv to know about?

Masking your emotions is a British business tradition which should be cherished. Do you really want your machine bursting into a chorus of Brahm's Lullaby when it senses you are stressed, or slapping smiley faces across the screen when you've just been made redundant? And how would it deal with your psychotic tendencies after a meeting with the manager? Can it be trained to spot a potential killing spree and put an emergency call straight through to the police?

"How will the workplace of the future look?" used to be a question that got the Tomorrow's World scientists all excited, the idea being that any new inventions would make the office look like a Utopian theme park. But the 'goodies' on offer for the next few decades are more likely to have us putting in for early retirement. Like breakfast bran, nicotine patches and pile cream, these gadgets may be what we need but they sure as hell aren't what we want.

Say a big 'no thank you' to:

Genetic business cards

These little fellows can be programmed to exchange all manner of information about you, from your shoe size to your sexual preference. But bog-standard cards already reveal sufficient info about the style, taste and status of their owners, which is why most business people with sense have reverted to the plain white variety. If you need to make further forays into the inner workings of a male colleague's psyche you need look no further than his tie - a more surefire guide to status and sexual predilections than any smart card could ever be.

Video phones

Rather stale in terms of new concepts but still yet to appear at a workstation near you. A lethal idea for numerous reasons I probably don't need to point out. Who needs to know you are busy dabbing face cream, cleaning your ear with a staple or sucking gravy off the front of your shirt while making that call to a client?

Virtual lunch breaks

You thought you were out to lunch but in reality you just browsed the virtual shelves of the virtual takeaway and then sat on the virtual bench feeding virtual crumbs to the virtual ducks. And did you really go out last night?

Corporate computer dating

Now you're talking. Having eschewed the temptations of your office colleagues, why not browse through the talent on offer in other companies - and all without changing your job or becoming a temp? With the longest working hours in Europe it's impossible to find a mate outside the office. And a business lonely hearts contact line - with checkable references - might put an end to all those wine bar whoppers about job prospects, finances and marital status, too.

webTitle: Together we can work it out

fields.headline: Together we can work it out
fields.standfirst: Joined a gym for new year? Your boss may also be keen that you get in shape.  Wendy Smith  on how companies have recognised the benefits of healthy employees
fields.trailText: Joined a gym for new year? Your boss may also be keen that you get in shape. Wendy Smith on how companies have recognised the benefits of healthy employees
fields.body:
There are people out there with designs on your body. You thought it was just you who wanted to be fit and heathy, rippling and raring to go (to work). But no - your boss also wants you to be fitter, less stressed and healthier. Recent years have seen a huge rise in awareness of occupational health, as UK managers cotton on to the idea that a healthier workforce on the office floor equals a wealthier outcome in the annual report.

Employers keen to keep their workforce happy in mind, body and spirit now provide anything from massage to ease away aches and pains to tai chi, football, hockey and aerobics classes. From onsite gyms and subsidised gym membership to informal encouragements to get active, there are endless opportunities for staff to run, jog and cycle away the stresses of corporate life.

We are even beginning to expect this type of facility at work. According to a report from the Institute of Management, more than one in five say their organisations provide sports and leisure facilities and another third want this type of facility. Mark Hastings, the institute's head of policy, is refreshingly direct in his assessment of the reasons for this people-centred focus: "Companies used to worry about getting bigger and better machines. Now they have been replaced as an issue by people. Deadlines are important and employers haven't got the extra staff anymore to take up the slack. When someone is off sick, it is not just a problem for them but the rest of the team as well."

Diane Sinclair, adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development, agrees. "The most important aspect of employee management is that employees are present and fit to work - they are not much use if they are not there." Apart from the cost of absenteeism, she says, companies with healthier workers can save on insurance costs and on litigation payouts from work-related illnesses.

How we work is also a factor. Being draped over a keyboard with a phone clutched to your shoulder hardly works up a sweat, and it doesn't do much for your posture either. The first six years of the 1990s saw a 122% rise in occupational illnesses, which added up to 2% of the nation's GDP lost to work-related illnesses.

But clearly the benefits of you getting fit are not just confined to your boss. "We drive more, sit more and take too many lifts," says Dr Kirstie Gibson, assistant medical director of BUPA wellbeing and corporate health division. "Activity helps your heart, your metabolism and reduces your cholesterol. Sitting around will mean that your flexibility will go as well as your stamina - you won't be able to run for that bus."

Putting its money where its professional mouth is, BUPA offers its staff an onsite gym, which opens from 8am to 8.30pm. Nellie Raymond, 38, PA to the director of corporate communications, uses the gym three times a week. Along with the 330 other staff in the company's central London headquarters, she can also choose from nine aerobic classes held each week. "I usually use the gym at the end of the day and I could be there anything from 45 minutes to an hour."

But there was no dramatic new year resolution or road to Damascas conversion for Raymond. She cheerfully admits to having always been a "gym person" - she is even a fitness instructor in her spare time. So she has become one of the increasing number of employees who consider gym facilities a vital workplace benefit. "Of course it is a motivating factor," she says. "If I had the option of a contract with a company with a gym or one without, I know which one I would chose."

What she really rates is the convenience. "It would be a real struggle for me to get to a local gym. I wouldn't go so often and gradually I know the pounds would creep back on. This way I can regulate my body weight and stay healthier."

Up to 200 members of Visa International's west London staff use the company's gym facilities every month to spin, step and tone their legs, tums and bums. Lunchtime is the busiest and among members of staff to be found pounding the flesh is 27-year-old Jane McInnes, PA to the vice-president of corporate communications. "I work out three times a week with either yoga classes or stretching sessions," she says. "It really suits me, helps me unwind and gets me away from my desk. I have had lapses when I haven't worked out quite so much, but my stamina level went down. I have now quite simply made this part of my lifestyle."

But if you are the sort of person who is exhausted just reading this, and doesn't relish the thought of greeting your boss on the rowing machine at lunch dressed in something tiny in Lycra, there are alternatives that companies may offer. BA's new headquarters near Heathrow offers a gym and classes, but as Judy Cook, head of nursing services for BA, explains, there is plenty for those who don't like the gym. In BA's case, this includes football, ballroom dancing and golf.

"The whole point of occupational health is about self-care for people and to stop people getting ill," says Cook. "Most large organisations don't as yet audit health, but we know from a gut reaction that occupational health has to be proactive."

Even if your company does not provide formal exercise facilities, there is nothing to stop you mobilising your colleagues into getting active. Posting a notice on the internal mail system is a good way to identify other slothful types who feel they should be getting fit but can't face it alone. Why not arrange to meet at lunchtime for a short jog around the office?

The rule of thumb as to how little you can do to stay healthy is 30 minutes' activity three to five times a week. You can walk to work instead of taking the car, use the stairs not the lift, walk an extra bus stop rather than getting on at the stop outside your house.

"Obesity leads to a greater risk of diabetes, and being overweight increases blood pressure," says Dr Gibson. "Activity at any age is good news, but later on in life it's almost like a personal health insurance."

webTitle: Drug duo ready to trade big brands for merger approval

fields.headline: Drug duo ready to trade big brands for merger approval
fields.trailText: Drug groups Glaxo and SmithKline Beecham are believed to be ready to sell off some of their top selling products as the price for winning regulatory approval for their £115bn merger, details of which will be unveiled today.
fields.body:
Drug groups Glaxo and SmithKline Beecham are believed to be ready to sell off some of their top selling products as the price for winning regulatory approval for their £115bn merger, details of which will be unveiled today.

SmithKline's nutritional products division - which includes Lucozade, Ribena and Horlicks - might be divested as part of the combined group's drive to cut £1.2bn a year out of the cost base. This is likely to involve the loss of more than 10,000 jobs from the 105,000 workforce as well as the closure of both companies' head offices.

The disposal of one of the best selling treatments might also be considered although insiders said there were no plans to volunteer products or divisions. But one analyst said yesterday: " If they have to offer up something to make sure they get this through the regulators they will. They won't want another failure."

He was referring to the collapse two years ago of merger talks which drew widespread criticism from shareholders and took some of the impetus away from British groups in the race for supremacy in a rapidly consolidating global pharmaceuticals market.

On the other side of the Atlantic, Pfizer is attempting to take over Warner-Lambert which had been holding merger talks with American Home Products while Pharmacia & Upjohn has just announced plans to combine with Monsanto.

Board meetings at both companies yesterday sanctioned a deal which will belatedly create the world's largest drugs company and the biggest corporation in Britain.

It will be led by SmithKline chief Jean-Pierre Garnier and chaired by Sir Peter Walters as Sir Richard Sykes, the chairman of Glaxo, will quit the boardroom for academia.

The merged company will be split roughly 60-40 in favour of Glaxo shareholders to reflect that company's market value of £66bn against the £48bn of SmithKline. But it is understood that SmithKline was arguing in last minute negotiations at the weekend that it should account for 2% to 3% more to reflect its more rapid growth prospects from drugs such as Avandia which is used to treat diabetes.

The deal is expected to see BP Amoco toppled as Britain's biggest company, although the £200m in fees to financial advisers may still be outstripped by the costs of Vodafone AirTouch's hostile offer for Mannesmann of Germany.

fields.headline: Carpetbaggers expelled
fields.standfirst: Portman ousts web-based conversion advocates
fields.trailText: Britain's fifth-largest building society, the Portman, yesterday confirmed it had expelled "several hundred" members who supported a resolution to convert to a bank.
fields.body:
Britain's fifth-largest building society, the Portman, yesterday confirmed it had expelled "several hundred" members who supported a resolution to convert to a bank.

But the society, which ruled that the November resolution was invalid under its rules, faces a challenge before the building societies ombudsman.

The challenge will be stiffened by the success - so far -of carpetbaggers in persuading the Skipton and Chelsea building societies to accept similar demutualisation resolutions. They are valid because they simply ask for the issue to be considered.

Up to 500 carpetbaggers, using a dedicated website to table their conversion resolution, have received letters from Portman saying their membership will be terminated from February 15.

A spokesman said the members could renew or reopen accounts if they agreed to give to charity any windfall paid out if the society converted to a bank over the next five years.

Its move provoked outrage among savers facing expulsion, with one calling it "completely undemocratic" and another saying it took away the members' right to make a choice on the society's future.

fields.headline: Charm and the maiden
fields.standfirst:
English National Ballet
Coliseum Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText: Franz, the romantic lead of Coppelia, is dumb enough to fall in love with a clockwork doll. But he also has to be a charmer, and Yosvani Ramos, ENB's promising new dancer, has a grin that could flirt the birds out of the trees. Earlier this season, Cuban-born Ramos was cast as the Nutcracker doll, with his head encased in a huge helmet. But even then his legs looked outstanding, holding long jaunty balances, executing squeakily clean jumps and turns. As Franz, in Ronald Hynd's cheery, long-serving production of Coppelia, Ramos obviously has greater opportunities to show off his technique.
fields.body:
Franz, the romantic lead of Coppelia, is dumb enough to fall in love with a clockwork doll. But he also has to be a charmer, and Yosvani Ramos, ENB's promising new dancer, has a grin that could flirt the birds out of the trees. Earlier this season, Cuban-born Ramos was cast as the Nutcracker doll, with his head encased in a huge helmet. But even then his legs looked outstanding, holding long jaunty balances, executing squeakily clean jumps and turns. As Franz, in Ronald Hynd's cheery, long-serving production of Coppelia, Ramos obviously has greater opportunities to show off his technique.

But unlike some, who harden their hearts to everything but their own prowess, Ramos not only looks as if he's dancing for the outrageous fun of it, he also seems to delight in everyone else on stage. He's never out of role for a second, whether he's playing Jack the lad with the village maidens, bumming a drink from his mates or veering between his fiance Swanilda and the mysterious Coppelia.

His excessive high spirits also make Ramos a good foil for Tamara Rojo's Swanilda. Rojo's bouyantly confident technique is ideal for the role but she also has a tendency to lapse into ballerina seriousness, and Ramos keeps the mischief alive between them. The pair are also well served by James Supervia as Dr Coppelius the batty old dollmaker. Supervia's large froggy features (he's played Toad for the RSC) mutate weirdly between the comic and the sinister, while his shambling body language evokes not only the musty tenderness of the old man's heart, but also musty smelliness of his person.

webTitle: Bid speculation puts M&S shares on rebound

fields.headline: Bid speculation puts M&S shares on rebound
fields.trailText: Shares in Marks & Spencer, the fallen star of the high street, are expected to soar this morning amid intense speculation that a bidding war for the group is about to erupt.
fields.body:
Shares in Marks & Spencer, the fallen star of the high street, are expected to soar this morning amid intense speculation that a bidding war for the group is about to erupt.

Philip Green, the retailing financier who recently spearheaded a break-up of Sears, is said to have finalised funding for an £11bn takeover bid which he wants to be fronted by Allan Leighton, the hugely successful head of the Asda supermarkets chain.

But Tesco, a rival group, is understood to be planning a "rescue" offer which it hopes the management of M&S will cling to rather than fall victim to Mr Green.

The intense takeover speculation follows a dismal Christmas trading performance from M&S, which has slipped steadily down the retail rankings from the position of pre-eminence which it held as recently as 18 months ago. The company is expected to announce the appointment of a new chairman - a post which has taken months to fill - some time in the next week.

It is understood that the takeover panel has sought clarification from both Mr Green and Tesco - neither of which is thought to have any significant shareholding in M&S.

Mr Green, who has appointed the US investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, has admitted he is weighing up a possible bid but Tesco appears to have convinced the panel that it does not plan an immediate move.

Neither Mr Green nor Tesco would comment on the speculation yesterday, Mr Leighton was unavailable and Marks & Spencer refused to discuss any plans it might be putting in place to ward off a hostile takeover bid.

The company's shares rose strongly towards the end of last week - they were up another 4%, by 14.5p to 331p on Friday - and are expected to rocket if a takeover bid is tabled.

Despite the frenzied speculation surrounding M&S - it is understood that beleaguered Sainsbury's also has cast the slide rule over the company - one potential bidder has been ruled out. Knutsford, the acquisition vehicle headed by former Asda chairman Archie Norman, which had been considered a potential predator of Sainsbury and M&S, now intends to bid for the industrial group Wassall, a much smaller fry.

Retail experts argue that M&S will not yield rapid takeover benefits because there are no large subsidiaries to sell off to finance a bid and many administrative, and staff reductions have been made by the management team headed by Peter Salsbury.

fields.headline: Sex god by a nose
fields.standfirst:
Barry Manilow
Wembley Arena, London
****
fields.trailText: To criticise Barry Manilow and his ladies, who sign letters "Lots of Manilove", is a gratuitous exercise. They've heard it all before. And after spending Friday night in what he calls "the Manilow Zone" - a parallel universe in which the Brooklyn love god is perennially number one in the charts (something he has never actually achieved here) - any desire to poke fun is extinguished. Why bother when he does it all himself? At the end of an athletic Could It Be Magic, which he co-croons with a thunderstruck Margaret from Halifax, he says, "Now the sex machine's gotta sit down" - and there are ripples of laughter rather than lust.
fields.body:
To criticise Barry Manilow and his ladies, who sign letters "Lots of Manilove", is a gratuitous exercise. They've heard it all before. And after spending Friday night in what he calls "the Manilow Zone" - a parallel universe in which the Brooklyn love god is perennially number one in the charts (something he has never actually achieved here) - any desire to poke fun is extinguished. Why bother when he does it all himself? At the end of an athletic Could It Be Magic, which he co-croons with a thunderstruck Margaret from Halifax, he says, "Now the sex machine's gotta sit down" - and there are ripples of laughter rather than lust.

While some of the overwhelmingly female house would probably love to see what's underneath that disco-era suit (what does one wear under a black shirt in this post-medallion age?), many more are here for the same reason Manilow's here - for an orgy of lush popular song.

He shows off his considerable arranging and interpreting skills, leading a large orchestra through a selection of hits, Broadway show-tunes and Sinatra standards, the latter from the Grammy-nominated Manilow Sings Sinatra. He extracts maximum cheese from the lighter-waving Mandy, but it's top-drawer parmesan; he flings himself, hips swivelling madly, into Copacabana, which was written before Ricky Martin was even born. He does the relaxed-crooner thing as satinly as Tony Bennett and if he really is nothing but a cynical manipulator of female hearts, he's a flawlessly entertaining one.
